Mecham, whose own comeback candidacy failed in the GOP primary, said he plans to vote for Symington. Goddard and Symington said they hadn't planned for the runoff possibility. The lead time to set up a runoff election is for planning it, determining who would be eligible to vote, printing ballots, hiring workers and scheduling polling places.

DOC.HEAD: A Fifth of California Vote Expected to Be Absentee
DOC.TEXT: About one-fifth of the Californians who will vote in Tuesday's election are expected to cast absentee ballots, a development that could delay announcement of the results, says the secretary of state's office. Most absentee ballots are counted as part of the election-night semi-official results. But a substantial percentage are received on election day and won't be part of the election-night count. ``If we have 500,000 absentee ballots outstanding, it could take a couple of weeks to count them,'' said Melissa Warren, a spokeswoman for the secretary of state's office. Between 7 million and 8 million people are expected to vote in California on Tuesday. A large number of absentee ballots could have a significant impact on the outcome of the race for governor and on when the winner is known. Two independent polls published Thursday found Republican Sen. Pete Wilson leading Democratic former San Francisco Mayor Dianne Feinstein by just one percentage point. ``We are expecting the absentee turnout to be substantial, which could complicate the vote-counting process'' and could put off announcing the results, Warren said. In June 1990, about 15 percent of voters used absentee ballots. In the last general election, November 1988, about 14 percent voted absentee, Warren said.
DOC.HEAD: There's No Poll Like Home
DOC.TEXT: It'll be easy for the mother of state Sen. J.D. Brackenrich to keep an eye on his election returns Tuesday. The polling place is on her porch. ``They have always voted on my mother's and father's back porch,'' said Democrat Brackenrich. ``My parents did it over the years just to help out. ``I never go close to the place on Election Day. No one is pressured to vote for me,'' he said. There aren't many other places to put the booth in tiny Kieffer, population 50, said Greenbrier County Clerk Eugene Spence. Brackenrich's Republican opponent, Fred Sampson, said he'd feel better if the booth wasn't in enemy territory. ``It looks kind of funny for a voting place to be in his mother's home. I guess I have to trust the county officials to make sure that nothing wrong takes place there,'' Sampson said. Brackenrich's mother, Helen Brackenrich, is an election worker and is scheduled to staff the booth, said Spence.
DOC.HEAD: Blanchard Campaign Asks for Equal Time for Endorsements
DOC.TEXT: Gov. James Blanchard is asking for free space to rebut three newspapers' editorial endorsements of his opponent. Blanchard's response should be published on the editorial page of the newspaper, ``using the same type size and layout as the editorial in question,'' said a letter to the newspapers from the Blanchard camp. The Oakland Press, The Detroit News and The Grand Rapids Press endorsed Republican John Engler. No self-respecting newspaper would grant such a request, said Tom Bray, editorial page editor for The Detroit News. Grand Rapids Press Editor Mike Lloyd called the Blanchard request ``laughable.'' Oakland Press Editor Neil Munro said the newspaper would print a response before the election as requested, but not in the same type size nor in the same position as the editorial.
DOC.HEAD: Hiler Defends Use of Tough Advertising
DOC.TEXT: Republican Rep. John Hiler said kind-spirited political advertising bores television viewers and nearly cost him re-election in 1986. ``If I have fuzzy milquetoast nonsense, boom, you're off to ESPN,'' he told high school students Wednesday. ``Politicians are sheep,'' he told a Rotary Club luncheon later. ``They use negative ads because they work.'' Hiler said he preferred to characterize his ads attacking Democratic challenger Tim Roemer as ``comparative'' instead of negative. ``I don't find anything particularly wrong with that,'' he told the Rotarians. ``You have three to five seconds to grab a viewer. I ran a campaign with fluffy ads (in 1986). They got me a 47-vote victory.''
DOC.HEAD: White Powder Mailed To Households
DOC.TEXT: Packets containing white powder have been mailed to 18,000 households by a state legislative candidate hoping to impress on voters the seriousness of the drug problem. ``This is not cocaine. But it could be,'' says a brochure sent with the plastic pouch of flour and powdered sugar. The brochures tell residents that drugs have become pervasive in schools, businesses and elsewhere. The mailing by Republican James M. Harkins, one of four candidates for the Harford County district's two seats in the House of Delegates, did not come cheaply. Harkins, a 17-year veteran of the county Sheriff's Department, spent roughly one-quarter of his war chest, or about $5,000, on the mailing.

DOC.HEAD: FBI Says Inmate Who Claimed KKK Murders Failed Polygraphs
DOC.TEXT: The FBI says it dropped an investigation into a convicted murderer's allegations that the bodies of black people killed by the Ku Klux Klan were buried in a mass grave in Fauquier County, Va. The case was closed after the Nevada inmate who made the allegations, Edward Allan See, 43, failed a polygraph test this week, authorities said Thursday. FBI officials began looking into the claims in February after See, who is serving two consecutive life sentences at Ely State Prison, told them 50 people were buried in the Warrenton area, 45 miles southwest of Washington. See, who failed part of a polygraph test administered by the FBI in March, also flunked the second test, which was administered Tuesday at Ely, authorities said. ``Based on that information we received today, we have discounted the information provided by Mr. See to date and no further investigation will be done,'' said Thomas F. Jones, FBI public affairs chief. ``A second polygraph was given and an evaluation and review of that led us to believe that no further reaction is required in this matter.'' William F. Dwyer, a Beverly Hills, Calif., attorney who represents See, said he was disappointed by the FBI's decision. He urged the bureau to verify or discredit See's claims by excavating the alleged grave site. He also said See wanted an independent polygraph test. ``If the FBI has chosen to close the investigation based on Eddie See's polygraph examination, then it appears sweat (affecting the polygraph) is considered more reliable than a backhoe in unearthing what may or may not be buried remains of Klan killings,'' Dwyer said. See claims he participated in the killings of several blacks abducted from the Washington area, tortured and killed. He says he was a member of the Klan from 1961 to 1964.

DOC.HEAD: Jury Levies No Punitive Damages Against Tyson in Fondling Case
DOC.TEXT: The woman who convinced a jury that boxer Mike Tyson grabbed her breasts and behind in a disco said she doesn't mind that she won only $100 in damages. ``It was the principle,'' Sandra Miller said Thursday after the jury declined to award her any punitive damages. ``He knows he did it. I know he did it. The jury proved that he did it.'' The jury on Wednesday ordered the former heavyweight champion to pay Miller $100 in compensatory damages after finding that he grabbed Miller's breasts and buttocks when she refused his advances at Bentley's disco in Manhattan on Dec. 10, 1988. Tyson testified during a four-day trial that he never touched Miller. Miller, 26, had sought $1 million in compensatory damages and $2.5 million in punitive damages. She said she believed Tyson would keep hassling women. ``He should have been punished,'' she said. ``He hasn't learned his lesson. There's no stopping Mike Tyson.'' Tyson supporters, including boxing promoter Don King, swarmed around him in the courtroom Thursday, congratulating him on the small damage award. Jurors left the courthouse without talking to reporters. The jury had heard testimony that Tyson's net worth was $15 million and listened to another woman claim the boxer had reached under her dress the same night. U.S. District Court Judge Michael B. Mukasey allowed Miller's attorney, Alan Clark, to present testimony about the other incident to show that his client's claims were not isolated. The second woman, Lori Davis, testified that she felt someone clutch under her dress as she was dancing at Bentley's. She turned and warned him not to try it again, she said. ``Then it dawned on me that it was Mike Tyson. ... He was grabbing my butt. I felt humiliated, violated, disgraced and petrified.'' Davis, 31, has a $7 million lawsuit against Tyson pending in state court. Under questioning by his attorney, Robert Hirth, Tyson said he felt no ill will toward women. He said: ``My mother's a woman and my sister's a woman.''

DOC.HEAD: Helms, Feinstein Lose In Mock Elections
DOC.TEXT: It was glum news for Republican Jesse Helms and Democrat Dianne Feinstein as millions of students and their parents cast ballots in nationwide mock balloting. Helms, the North Carolina senator, and California gubernatorial candidate Feinstein were among the losers Thursday in the National Student-Parent Mock Election. A surprise: Democrats barely maintained control of the U.S. House, organizers reported. Democrats captured 52.9 percent of the seats in the House while Republicans won 47.1 percent. In the real world, Democrats actually control more than 59 percent of the House seats, holding an edge of 258 to 176 over Republicans. Democrats are likely to increase their edge Tuesday. In the mock balloting, Helms was crushed in his bid for another term by Democratic challenger Harvey Gantt, 72 percent to 28 percent. In Oregon, Sen. Mark Hatfield won against challenger Harry Lonsdale, 61 percent to 31 percent. In governor's races: -Republican Pete Wilson defeated Feinstein in California, 59 percent to 37 percent. -In Arizona, Democrat Terry Goddard won against Republican Fife Symington, 55 percent to 45 percent. -In Texas, Republican Clayton Williams defeated Democrat Ann Richards, 56 percent to 44 percent. -And in Florida, Republican Gov. Bob Martinez lost a re-election bid to former Sen. Lawton Chiles, 52 percent to 48 percent. Junior and senior high school students in all 50 states and the Department of Defense dependents' schools called in tabulated results to the national election headquarters in the nation's capital. Questions developed by Congressional Quarterly Inc. and the Roper Poll asked participants to decide on strategies for dealing with the nation's drug crisis. The results: -Twelve percent favored harsher penalties for convicted drug dealers and users. -Nine percent wanted to require courses in public schools about the effects of drugs use. -Fifty-one percent wanted to increase efforts to prevent drugs from being brought into the United States from other countries. -Eleven percent wanted to legalize some drugs to make drug-dealing less profitable to organized crime. On the federal budget, 62 percent wanted to maintain current levels of defense even if it means the government has to borrow money. Thirty percent said the United States should borrow less money and reduce the deficit even if it means cuts in the defense budget. On the federal deficit, 59 percent said the United States should increase spending for social needs. Nineteen percent said the U.S. should borrow less money and reduce the budget deficit even if it means no improvements in social programs Twenty-six percent favored an increase in the federal gasoline tax. Forty-seven percent were against it. The mock election is ``the largest voter-education program ever,'' said Gloria Kirshner, president of the event. The purpose of the program, she said, is to obliterate civic illiteracy by involving students and their families in the electoral process.

DOC.HEAD: Family Pleads For Permission To Allow Woman To Die
DOC.TEXT: Testimony in Round 2 of a comatose woman's right-to-die case ended without any opposition to letting her die. Her doctor and her state-appointed guardian agreed with family members and friends of 33-year-old Nancy Cruzan, who has been in an irreversible coma since 1983. Dr. James C. Davis, who opposed removing a feeding tube when the family first sought court permission to let her die three years ago, changed his mind. He said during a Circuit Court hearing Thursday he favored the mercy death because he was convinced there was no hope for any improvement. He said living for years in a coma, without feeling or thought, was a terrifying prospect. ``I think it would be personally a living hell,'' Davis said. Asked if he would want someone to end his life if he were in her place, Davis replied: ``I think anyone would choose that if they had observed that condition.'' The U.S. Supreme Court, in its first right-to-die decision, last summer rejected a request by Ms. Cruzan's parents to end her life, ruling the state could bar such moves if victims had not made their desires known. Ms. Cruzan left no written instructions about what she would want done under such circumstances. The family went back to court, saying they had new witnesses who could support their claims that she would want to die. Judge Charles E. Teel, who ruled in the parents' favor before he was overruled, said he would rule on the new petition by Jan. 1. Joe Cruzan testified he knew his daughter would rather die than spend the rest of her life as a ``vegetable.'' ``My God, I wouldn't be here today if I thought there was any question,'' he said, his voice cracking. Two former co-workers and a former employer also said Ms. Cruzan told them she would not want to live if she ever suffered permanent brain damage. She went into a coma after a 1983 car crash. Doctors say she will never recover but could remain alive for 30 years or more in her currentcondition. Ms. Cruzan's state-appointed guardian said he agreed with the Cruzans and her personal physician that the feeding tube should be removed. ``I think it clearly is not in her best interest to go on this way,'' said the guardian, Thad McCanse. ``I'm convinced Nancy would not want to live like she is now.'' Debi Havner, who now lives in Enid, Okla., and Marianne Smith of Joplin, testified that while working with in 1978 at a school for severely handicapped children in Joplin, the three once agreed none of them would not want to be kept alive artificially. Tom Turner, the former owner of an Oklahoma office products store where Ms. Cruzan worked briefly in 1981, said in videotaped testimony that she also discussed her opposition to certain life-sustaining measures with him. ``She said such things as `Vegetables can't hug their nieces,''' Turner said. ``Her family was a major portion of her life, and if she couldn't have them, she didn't want to live.''

DOC.HEAD: Horror Film Master Roger Corman Directs First Film in Nearly Two Decades
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 2nd graf to drop redundant word `films'
DOC.TEXT: Academy Award voters aren't likely to give it a second look, but those who love horror Hollywood style are in for a rare treat. Roger Corman is back. For the first time in nearly 20 years, the director of such B movies as ``Attack of the Crab Monsters,'' ``Wasp Woman,'' ``Teen-age Caveman'' and ``She-Gods of Shark Reef'' returned to the movie-set hot seat. ``Frankenstein Unbound,'' Corman's fresh look at the classic Mary Shelley novel, opens today. Unlike Corman's earlier low-budget films, which featured little-known actors, ``Frankenstein Unbound'' boasts the marquee names of John Hurt, Raul Julia and Bridget Fonda. Corman, 64, last directed a film, the World War I drama ``Von Richthofen and Brown,'' in 1971. ``About halfway through filming it, I just realized I was getting tired,'' Corman said in an interview. ``I had directed more than 50 films in something like 15 or 16 years. ``I never intended to stop directing. What I wanted to do was take the traditional sabbatical.'' But it was not to be. Corman went on to produce scores of films, including ``Boxcar Bertha,'' ``Piranha'' and ``Humanoids From the Deep.'' Corman is credited with giving early breaks to aspiring Hollywood newcomers such as Jack Nicholson, Sylvester Stallone, Martin Scorsese, Charles Bronson and Ellen Burstyn. Among his better known films are ``The Masque of the Red Death,'' ``The Tomb of Ligeia'' and ``The Raven,'' all adapted from Edgar Allan Poe tales. He also made the original ``The Little Shop of Horrors,'' featuring Nicholson, in 1960. Corman, who co-wrote and co-produced ``Frankenstein Unbound,'' says the film budgeted at $9 million doesn't truly fit into the horror category, though it depicts disemboweled animals, decapitations, impalings and a gruesome monster. ``It's not really a horror film, not quite,'' Corman said. ``It's really a kind of science fiction-fantasy-horror with a little bit of a moral point.'' Corman said his two-decade absence from behind the camera worried him at first. ``As we're driving out to the set for the first day of filming, I thought, Am I really going to be able to pull this off?'' Corman said. Problems surfaced quickly. ``We get there, the cameras weren't ready. I immediately said, `All right, fellas. I told you I want the camera on the dolly over here. Let's lay the track, get the camera out, that wall over there is not dressed, let's bring in the props, let's get this thing moving,'' he said. ``I didn't even think about it until somebody brought me some coffee a few minutes later. And I realized, I'm just working again. It's as if I had stopped working last Friday.'' Corman says he'll direct again, but for now he's off to Europe, where ``Frankenstein Unbound'' will the opening night feature at the first Stockholm Film Festival. The onetime lord of low-budget movie fare still has an eye for a good deal. ``They sent me a ticket,'' he said. ``And I figured I might as well go.''

DOC.HEAD: Survey Finds Students Drinking Water Containing Lead
DOC.TEXT: Federal investigators believe hundreds of thousands of children continue to drink water containing lead at school despite laws aimed at reducing lead contamination. States have failed to enforce laws requiring schools to test drinking water for lead and the government has not provided adequate guidance on what water coolers pose a health risk, according to an Environmental Protection Agency report made available Thursday. Lead is a powerful poison. Even traces can be harmful to children because it can hurt development of the brain and nervous system. Children under 7 are considered particularly vulnerable. The EPA inspector general's office estimated that, based on a limited survey, fewer than half of the school districts in the country may be testing thoroughly. An examination of 13 school districts in the mid-Atlantic region revealed that three had not tested for lead while most of the others conducted inadequate tests. ``Our findings confirm that harmful amounts of lead exist in the drinking water provided by schools. Both the EPA and the states must be more aggressive in eliminating the health hazard imposed by lead in drinking water,'' said the report. Three of the school districts - Pittsburgh, Richmond, Va., and Charleston, W.Va. - had not tested for lead at the time of the survey. The investigation was finished in April and the report completed in September. The EPA considers lead concentrations above 20 parts per billion to be hazardous to school children. The report said that the agency believes every year more than 250,000 children are exposed to lead level in drinking water that are high enough to impair their intellectual and physical development.
DOC.HEAD: McGrath Released From Hospital
DOC.TEXT: Rep. Raymond J. McGrath, R-N.Y., has been discharged from a hospital where he was treated over the last week for a blood clot in the lung. ``He's under strict doctor's orders to get plenty of rest,'' press secretary Dan Zielinski said. He said McGrath plans to go to New York on Sunday and hopes to make some campaign appearances. ``He realizes he's missed quite a bit during the last week and he wants to do as much as he can,'' the press secretary said. McGrath is taking blood-thinning drugs and must have his blood checked daily for the next week. He was hospitalized after becoming ill in his Capitol Hill office Oct. 25. Doctors at Walter Reed Army Medical Center diagnosed a pulmonary embolism, or a blockage in a blood vessel in the lung. McGrath, 48, of Valley Stream, is running for a sixth term from a heavily Republican district in Nassau County. He is being challenged by Democrat Mark Epstein, an environmental lawyer.
DOC.HEAD: Fisher-Price Recalls Carriage Strollers
DOC.TEXT: The Consumer Product Safety Commission says Fisher-Price is recalling about 60,000 of its Carriage Strollers, Model No. 9121, because they have been known to collapse with children in them. Side tubes have failed to slide properly in some cases when the stroller unfolded. This can prevent the locking mechanism from engaging fully. Fisher-Price said it is aware of 23 injuries to children using the strollers, ranging from bumps and bruises to one broken arm. The strollers have been sold since June 1989, for about $120 to $140. Consumers who own this stroller should call Fisher-Price, toll-free, at 1-800-527-1034 between 8 a.m. and 5 p.m. daily, in most time zones. Fisher-Price will send consumers a prepaid mailing package with instructions to return a wheel from their stroller. Those who return a wheel will receive a new Carriage Stroller free of charge. The new stroller will be modified to assure the locking mechanism will engage fully. Consumers should not return strollers to the store where it was purchased. Fisher-Price, of East Aurora, N.Y., no longer manufactures or sells this product.

DOC.HEAD: LaRouche Says He And Cellmate Jim Bakker Were Victims Of Plot
DOC.TEXT: Imprisoned political extremist Lyndon LaRouche recently had fallen television evangelist Jim Bakker for a cellmate but says he's happy to be in a new cell with fewer visitors. Bakker and LaRouche spent a month together in a 10-by-16-foot cinder-block cell in the federal penitentiary in Rochester, Minn., where both are serving lengthy terms for fraud and conspiracy convictions in separate cases. LaRouche told The Herald of Rock Hill in a telephone interview published today that he and Bakker were compatible, but he's relieved to have a new cellmate now. He said Bakker, founder of the PTL television ministry, gets a lot of mail and has a ``big retinue of admirers (within the prison) who would constantly come around.'' LaRouche, a longtime proponent of intricate conspiracy theories, insisted that he and Bakker were innocent victims of secret plots by the Reagan and Bush administrations. ``There's been a targeting of anyone or any group which had independent financing, which had political clout, and Jim's group was getting political clout,'' LaRouche said. A four-time fringe presidential candidate currently running for the seat in Virginia's 10th Congressional District, LaRouche, 68, is serving a 15-year sentence on mail and tax fraud charges. He masterminded a plot to siphon millions of dollars from three corporations forced into bankruptcy. Bakker, 49, is serving a 45-year sentence on charges of conspiracy and mail fraud for overselling lifetime partnerships to the now-bankrupt PTL ministry at Heritage USA near Fort Mill, S.C.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar, Nikkei Decline
DOC.TEXT: After a three-day rally, the dollar slipped sharply against the yen in Tokyo today, while share prices fell again on the Tokyo Stock Exchange. The dollar closed at 129.10 yen, down 1.60 yen from Thursday's close of 130.70 yen. After opening at 129.65 yen, it ranged from 128.97 yen to 129.65 yen in active trading that totaled $13.87 billion in spot transactions. Dealers saw the dollar's fall as part of a series of adjustments to a long plunge that began in the summer. The dollar closed at a two-year low of 124.40 yen on Oct. 18. Then earlier this week it increased by 3.35 yen during a three-day rally, ending at 130.70 yen Thursday. ``There had been too much dollar buying,'' said Shigeto Yanase, a dealer at The Dai-ichi Kangyo Bank. Brokers said concerns over the faltering American economy were resurfacing, with many market players waiting for the release of U.S. government unemployment figures later today. The stronger yen did not help boost sentiments on the Tokyo stock market, traders said. The 225-share Nikkei Stock Average closed at 24,194.99 points, down 100.17 points or 0.41 percent from Thursday's close. The Nikkei average has now fallen 1,134.32 points in four days. Volume in the first section was estimated at a thin 320 million shares, below Thursday's 350 million. Investors were cautious before Sunday's parliamentary byelection, which has raised doubts about Japanese Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu's leadership, said a dealer at Daiwa Securities Co. In bond dealings, the price of the benchmark No. 119 10-year Japanese government bonds rose to 84.90 points as of 5 p.m. from 84.30 points at Thursday's close. Their yield fell to 7.725 percent from 7.860 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Alzheimer's Disease Rises Sharply; More Awareness May Explain Increase
DOC.TEXT: Federal health researchers tracking a dramatic rise in reported deaths from Alzheimer's disease say more awareness of the malady, rather than a sharp rise in its incidence, is the main reason. ``It's a little difficult to believe that the number of people with Alzheimer disease could increase 950 percent in eight years,'' said Dr. Richard Sun, an epidemiologist at the U.S. Centers for Disease Control in Atlanta. ``Our general feeling is heightened awareness was a little more important'' Sun said Thursday. The CDC said in its weekly report that 11,311 people, or 4.2 per 100,000 population, died from Alzheimer's disease in 1987. In 1979, the first year of a CDC study, 857 deaths, or 0.4 per 100,000, were attributed to the disease. For the entire 1979-87 period, Alzheimer's disease was listed as the underlying cause of death for 46,202 people in the United States. Alzheimer's disease tends to strike older people, and because the U.S. population is aging it is likely that incidence of the disease also is up - though not as much as the death rate increase, Sun said. He said there currently is no definitive study of how many people have Alzheimer's. The disease, characterized by progressive mental deterioration, first was recognized in the early 1900s. But public awareness of the disease was fairly limited until the 1970s. Doctors then, Sun said, ``realized that Alzheimer disease was a specific disease ... and not a normal process of aging. There was something different about people with Alzheimer disease.'' The disease has gotten much media attention in the last 10 years, with television devoting prime time programs to it and national magazines featuring Alzheimer's on cover stories. Federal funding for research on Alzheimer's and related disorders rose from $3.9 million in 1976 to $53.9 million in 1986, the Atlanta-based CDC reported. Sun said that in recent years, doctors in some cases may have changed a diagnosis from senility to Alzheimer's as they began paying more attention to the latter. Sun said the death rate patterns reported by the CDC are consistent with those documented in England, Norway, Australia and Canada. The increase in the death rates for Alzheimer's disease came at the same time that rates for other leading causes of death - such as heart ailments, stroke, liver diseases and hardening of the arteries - were going down, he said. In a separate report, the CDC said Thursday that seven chronic diseases accounted for 79.5 percent of all deaths among the elderly. Chief among them was heart disease, followed by malignant tumors, cerebrovascular disease, lung disease, diabetes, atherosclerosis and kidney disease. The study was based on 1987 Medicare data.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Convicted of Obstructing Justice Gets 6-Month Sentence
DOC.TEXT: U.S. District Judge Robert Aguilar, convicted of obstructing justice by leaking a wiretap and lying to the FBI, was sentenced to six months in prison. U.S. District Judge Louis Bechtle said Thursday that Aguilar's crimes warranted a term of up to 27 months, but he levied the lighter penalty because of Aguilar's likely impeachment. ``These proceedings will be long and humiliating and embarrassing and burdensome, a major and substantial punishment,'' said Bechtle, a Philadelphia judge assigned to the case by Chief Justice William Rehnquist. Aguilar, the third federal judge in U.S. history sentenced to prison for felonies committed while on the bench, faced a possible 10-year prison term and $500,000 in fines. Prosecutors sought a minimum three-year term. The sentence includes fines and assessments of $2,100, and 1,000 hours of community service during two years of supervised release after imprisonment. Aguilar remains free without bail during his appeal, which defense lawyer Paul Meltzer said would take two years. Unless impeached - the only way a federal judge can be removed involuntarily - he will keep his title and salary. He is not hearing cases but is available for settlement conferences. Aguilar, 59, of San Jose, was appointed to the court in 1980 by President Carter. He declined to comment during or after the hearing, but was smiling broadly when he walked up to Meltzer in a hallway and thanked him. It was ``a lighter sentence than we anticipated,'' said Jess Aguilar, one of the judge's brothers. Another defendant, former Teamster leader Rudy Tham, was sentenced to 18 months in prison and fined $20,000 Thursday for conspiring to seek illicit aid from Aguilar in overturning his embezzlement conviction. In a separate trial, Aguilar was acquitted of conspiracy in the Tham case. A jury convicted Aguilar in August of two felony charges for disclosing a wiretap in February 1988 to reputed mobster Abe Chapman and lying in April 1988 to FBI agents who questioned him about the wiretap and his involvement in Tham's case. A fellow judge had told Aguilar in August 1987 that he had been seen with Chapman, whose name had come up in a wiretap application. Aguilar's nephew testified that Aguilar told him to tell Chapman not to call him, and mentioned a wiretap. Aguilar testified that he was only trying to warn Chapman to stay away from him. When FBI agents questioned Aguilar two months later, he told them he knew nothing of a wiretap on Chapman and would not have told Chapman if he had known. Aguilar was never accused of seeking personal gain, unlike the two other federal judges imprisoned in the last decade: Harry Claiborne of Nevada, convicted of tax evasion in 1984, and Walter Nixon of Mississippi, convicted of perjury in 1986. Prosecutors instead portrayed Aguilar as a judge who wanted to impress his friends with his influence, and lost his sense of limits.

DOC.HEAD: Health Proposals Embraced, But Not Implemented, by State Agencies
DOC.TEXT: State health departments have embraced in principle a set of proposals issued two years ago for improving public medical care, but the agencies have been slow to adopt the recommendations. Federal health officials aren't sure why, but say it may be because of a shortage of funds. The Institute of Medicine, which advises the federal government on public health issues, made 66 recommendations in 1988. In 1989 the state officials were surveyed by the Association of State and Territorial Health Officials on 25 of the proposals. The U.S. Centers for Disease Control reported the results of the survey Thursday. Among the findings: - Forty-eight of 50 state health departments agreed they should ``link with mental health services to improve the integration of service delivery.'' Only 13 had done so. Eighteen more said they planned to. - All 50 state agencies agreed the public should be better educated on community health needs and policy issues. Only 34 had a program to achieve that goal. - Forty-five agreed state health departments should develop comprehensive strategies to influence health-related behavior. Just 21 had implemented a plan. - In some areas, there was consistency between agreement and implementation. For instance, 49 state departments agreed that food protection is a job for the agencies and 48 had such programs in place. The survey did not get into why the recommendations were not implemented, CDC epidemiologist Dr. Arthur Liang said. But he said it was clear from the level of agreement noted in the survey that it's not because of any lack of awareness or knowledge by state officials. ``I think for some of these new areas, new for public health perhaps, there hasn't been a consensus between the policy makers and the taxpayers,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Earthquake Jolts Remote Indonesian Area Of New Guinea
DOC.TEXT: A moderate earthquake today jolted a remote mountainous area on the island of New Guinea, but no casualties or damage were reported, the Meteorology and Geophysics agency said. The quake, measuring 5.2 on the Richter scale, hit Indonesia's western side of the island at 12:38 p.m. (10 p.m. EST Thursday), the agency said. It was centered in the Baliem valley, 35 miles east of Wamena. The eastern end of the island belongs to the nation of Papua New Guinea. Wamena, capital of the mountainous region of Jaya Wijaya, is about 2,200 miles east of the Indonesian capital Jakarta. The agency said the quake also was felt in the Irian Jaya provincial capital of Jayapura, about 170 miles northeast of Wamena. In August last year 106 were killed in Kurima mountainous district just east of the area by an earthquake measuring 6 on the Richter scale. The Richter scale is a gauge of the energy released by an earthquake, as measured by the ground motion recorded on a seismograph. Every increase of one number means that the ground motion is 10 times greater. A quake of magnitude 5 can cause considerable damage in populated areas.

DOC.HEAD: Experts on Nazi Era Dispute Bush's Claim that Saddam Worse Than Hitler
DOC.NOTE: EDS: SUBS grafs 3 and 19 to CORRECT spelling of `Wiesenthal.'
DOC.TEXT: President Bush says a look at history will back up his suggestion that Saddam Hussein is a barbarian surpassing Adolf Hitler, but experts on the Nazi era disagree with him. ``We don't see the kind of atrocities being committed in Kuwait and Iraq that would match those of Nazi Germany,'' said Richard Breitman, a professor of history at American University and a specialist in the Hitler era. ``No one yet, and I hope no one ever will, match up to the systematized brutalities and racist policies that Adolf Hitler committed,'' said Rabbi Abraham Cooper, associate director of the Simon Wiesenthal Center in Los Angeles. The center is devoted to the study of the Nazi Holocaust, in which an estimated 6 million Jews were killed, and its contemporary implications. Bush, speaking at a Republican rally in Mashpee, Mass., Thursday, said Saddam's Iraqi invaders ``have committed outrageous acts of barbarism. Brutality - I don't believe that Adolf Hitler ever participated in anything of that nature.'' Later, at a news conference in Orlando, Fla., Bush said, ``I don't think I am overstating it. I know I am not overstating the feelings I have about it. ... I think the American people are as outraged as I am about the treatment of the people in our embassy, for example, and I think it is important that they know my concerns on this subject.'' ``I was told that Hitler did not stake people out against military targets,'' the president said. ``He did respect the legitimacy of the embassies, so there are some differences.'' He added, ``I see many similarities between the Iraqi behavior in Kuwait and the way the Death's Head regiments behaved in Poland. Go back and take a look at the history and you can see why I'm as concerned as I am.'' '' The Death's Head units were notorious blackshirted SS troops that began as Hitler's personal bodyguard. They were blamed for many atrocities during the German invasion of Poland. Breitman said many of the specific points Bush made were correct and could make Saddam appear worse than Hitler in some respects, ``but I don't think the overall record would show that to be the case.'' He said that at the outbreak of World War II the Nazis interned foreign diplomats in conditions ``that were not comfortable, but were nothing like what we are seeing in Kuwait and Iraq.'' These diplomats were eventually exchanged for German diplomats in Allied custody, Breitman said. He said he was not aware that the Nazis ever took hostages to potential military targets to use them as human shields as Saddam has done. Cooper, however, said Bush was ``absolutely wrong'' on the point. ``Look at the millions of people of all nationalities who were forced into slave labor factories in Germany and many of them got blown away by the Allied bombing missions,'' he said. Breitman said Hitler is not known to have visited any of the Nazi death camps, but ``that does not mean he was not involved.'' He also said the activities of the Death's Head units were ``only the tip of the iceberg in terms of brutality in Poland'' by the German invaders. The historian said he was not defending Saddam. He said the Iraqi leader has committed crimes ``that give the idea of a Nuremberg-type trial a certain legitimacy to raise.'' Administration sources have said that such a trial, along the lines of the war crimes trials held in Nuremberg, Germany, after World War II, is a possibility. At the Wiesenthal Center, Rabbi Cooper said, ``Saddam Hussein has a list of crimes that I don't think has to be compared with anybody in order for the people of America to understand how serious a threat he represents.'' ``But let's also keep this thing in some sort of perspective,'' he said. ``And to say that he outstrips Adolf Hitler, I just think it's either a slip of the tongue or a speech writer got carried away.'' Other Jewish leaders generally agreed. David Harris, executive vice president of the American Jewish Committee, said, ``Both men, each in his own way, represents an incarnation of evil. But to try and suggest that Saddam Hussein is a man of even greater evil than Adolf Hitler to me doesn't add to the discussion.'' Abraham Foxman, national director of the Anti-Defamation League of B'nai B'rith, called Bush's remark ``an unfortunate exaggeration that could hurt the president's credibility at a time when it is very important that he remain credible.'' ``Saddam Hussein is writing his own chapter of barbarism,'' Foxman said. ``It's the Saddam Hussein chapter and one need not compare or exaggerate.''

DOC.HEAD: Bombs Explode In Police Dormitory, Killing One
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 11 grafs to UPDATE with three unexploded bombs found. CORRECTS that unexploded bombs found at two dormitories, interval between first blasts was about five minutes sted two hours. Pickup 12th graf `In central...'
DOC.TEXT: Two bombs blamed on leftist radicals blew up in a police dormitory, killing an officer and injuring six other people. The blasts and other incidents today cast doubt on security efforts for Emperor Akihito's coronation 10 days away. Three unexploded bombs were found and a firebomb was hurled at a police station today, after the blasts at the dormitory early this morning and late Thursday night. The violence occurred as 26,000 police officers were mounting a massive security operation for the Tuesday coronation. Representatives from more than 150 countries are to attend, including Vice President Dan Quayle and Britain's Prince Charles. Although scores of strategically located buildings or those related to the imperial household, city utilities and other likely targets have been singled out for special attention under the security operation, police dormitories were not included in the list. ``I feel a very strong anger at the violent outrage of the ultra-leftist groups,'' Tachio Ohori, head of the Metropolitan Police Department, told Japanese reporters in a hastily arranged, predawn news conference called after he inspected the blast site. ``With all the strength of the department we hope to successfully carry out security for the upcoming coronation,'' he was quoted as saying in several major newspapers. No group claimed responsibility as of this evening. Japanese radical groups generally take several days to issue such statements. Officer Hiroshi Aoki, 48, died almost immediately after the first blast at 11 p.m. Thursday at the dormitory in a Tokyo district known for its numerous nightspots. The second bomb went off about five minutes later. Officials said earlier that the bombs exploded two hours apart. A Metropolitan Police Department official, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said the injured included four other officers, the dorm's cook and another civilian. The official said the type of explosives and other details of the blasts, separated by about two hours, were under investigation. Both bombs had been placed near a garbage collection area inside the dormitory complex, officials said. Along with the dormitory blasts, police reported finding two more bombs near another police dormitory about an hour after the first blasts, and at a public restroom elsewhere in the capital early today. In central Japan, a Molotov cocktail was lobbed at a police station before dawn. No injuries were reported. Leftist radicals, including the 5,000-member Chukaku-ha, or Middle Core Faction, have repeatedly vowed to use violence to ``destroy'' the coronation and other related ceremonies. They consider the emperor a symbol of Japan's militarist past and oppose state funding of the enthronement. Last month police announced they would increase the security deployment to 32,000 by busing in reinforcements for the coronation day. On Wednesday it was revealed that they are considering a further increase of thousands more. ``We have not made a final decision, but an increase is being considered because of the increasing difficulty of the situation,'' a National Police Agency official said. Metropolitan Police Department officials today also refused to comment on whether the thousands will be added. Leftist radicals have been particularly active in anti-imperial activities since the funeral of Emperor Hirohito in February last year. Although police mobilized 32,000 officers in Tokyo to guard that ceremony, the Chukaku-ha set off a bomb along the funeral procession route. The bomb exploded before the procession arrived, and no one was injured. Over the past month, police have announced uncovering alleged plots by the Chukaku-ha to jam television broadcasts of the coronation and fire rockets at a tunnel along a train route the emperor is to travel later this month. The radical group is believed to have mortar-style weapons with a range of 4 miles.

DOC.HEAD: Voice of Mormon Tabernacle Choir Quits Over Relationship with Newswoman
DOC.TEXT: J. Spencer Kinard, for 18 years the announcer for a CBS radio program featuring the Mormon Tabernacle Choir, has resigned in a flap over his relationship with a local television newswoman. Kinard, 50, also quit his job as vice president for news and public affairs at KSL television, station vice president Bill Murdoch announced Thursday. The station, owned by the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints, also employs Jennifer Howe, 24, as a news anchorwoman. KSL staffers criticized Kinard and Howe after they were seen together on several occasions. Both maintained their relationship was professional, not romantic. Since 1972 Kinard has been announcer for the weekly ``Music and the Spoken Word'' radio program featuring the church's famous choir. The Sunday program, which debuted in 1929, is the CBS Radio Network's longest-running show. Kinard also has been an executive with KSL for 18 years. ``I am convinced that the events over the past few weeks have made it impossible for me to be effective in that position,'' he said in a written resignation Wednesday. He could not be reached for further comment. His son, David, said Thursday night Kinard was not taking phone calls. Kinard had been on medical leave from both jobs since Oct. 19. Howe, whom the station placed on two weeks' paid leave last week, said she hadn't heard about Kinard's resignation. Howe's husband filed for divorce the day after she and Kinard were seen on a Sept. 30 flight from Oakland, Calif., to Salt Lake City. Kinard and Howe said that was a chance meeting.

DOC.HEAD: Republic Begins Issuing Rationing Coupons, Confusion Reported
DOC.TEXT: The Ukrainian government today began issuing rationing cards in what was seen as an effort to prevent hoarding and to keep scarce products from being sold outside the republic. Some Ukrainian nationalists saw the move as a prelude to issuing a currency in the southwestern republic, whose parliament declared sovereignty in July. The immediate result, however, was confusion and long lines of angry shopers in Kiev, the Ukrainian capital, media reports said. Each worker, student and pensioner receives coupons equivalent to 70 percent of their monthly income along with the cash, under the system decreed by the Ukrainian Council of Ministers last Friday. The coupons, good for six months and marked with cash values similar to ruble notes, must be presented along with rubles to purchase basic goods, such as food, gasoline, cigarettes and liquor. ``Only slightly more than half of Kiev's residents have been given coupons,'' the newspaper Komsomolskaya Pravda said in a report from the Ukrainian capital. ``Others were not so lucky.'' The newspaper said that most people were caught unaware by the new measures, announced last Friday on radio and television. ``During the day, many streets of the capital were blocked by groups of angry people,'' it said. Chris Kedzie, an American economic researcher living in Kiev, said, ``it is a very confusing and difficult situation. People were caught by surprise.'' He said there were no specific instuctions issued on how to use the coupons and state stores were closed three times during the week as managers prepared for the new system. Kedzie said the primary goal of the coupons, according to economists he interviewed, was to keep Ukrainian goods inside the republic and feed their own people during the winter. ``This is a stopgap measure. There are not enough food and goods for the winter,'' he said. ``People are stocking up on everything.'' The independent Ukrainian Information Agency said, ``this resolution was adopted in hurry, without proposing it for the preliminary discussion by the population.'' It said the coupon system will not properly provide for the needs of families, lead to black marketeering and result in inflated prices. Petro Borsuk, an official of the nationalist Ukrainian Republic Party, said he was optimistic the coupon system would take root. ``I see it as a first step toward a (Ukrainian) national currency,'' he said in a telephone interview. Vladimir Pylutchuk, a member of the Supreme Soviet Economic Reform Committee, said the coupon system could be seen in the context of creating a Ukrainian currency, but not in the immediate future. For the time being, he told Kedzie in an interview, ``it's a way to keep goods in the republic.'' All but one of the 15 Soviet republics have declared some form of autonomy from Moscow. The only holdout is Kirgizia, a Central Asian republic, and its legislature is expected to declare sovereignty soon.

DOC.HEAD: McDonald's Eliminating Plastic Foam Containers
LaserPhoto CX1
DOC.TEXT: McDonald's Corp.'s decision to switch from polystyrene containers to paper for its food products is being hailed by some - but not all - environmentalists. ``It is a mistake to make plastic the great satan and paper the great saint,'' said Jan Beyea, a scientist at the National Audubon Society. ``Both processes generate pollution.'' A recycling company, meanwhile, lamented McDonald's announcement Thursday that it would start phasing out its clamshell-shaped containers - which had been blamed for filling landfills and depleting the ozone layer - within two months. The fast-food giant had been playing a key role in educating the public about the need to recycle, said E. James Schneiders, president of National Polystyrene Recycling Co. McDonald's just last week said it planned to expand an experimental plastic recycling program to all of its 8,500 U.S. restaurants. ``NPRC is disappointed to learn that McDonald's has decided to phase out its use of polystyrene foam packaging,'' Schneiders said. But the non-profit Environmental Defense Fund, which had worked with McDonald's since August on plans to phase out the plastic foam containers, was elated. ``McDonald's understands that the future is green,'' said Frederic D. Krupp, the fund's executive director. ``I think other companies will follow suit.'' Several U.S. cities have banned the use of polystyrene foam, saying it contributes to landfill problems by lingering for years before disintegrating. The polystyrene production process also is suspected of harming the Earth's ozone level. ``Although some scientific studies indicate that foam packaging is environmentally sound, our customers just don't feel good about it,'' McDonald's Corp. President Edward Rensi said by telephone Thursday from the company's suburban Oak Brook headquarters. ``So we're changing.'' Joseph Bow, president of the Foodservice & Packaging Institute in Washington, accused McDonald's of ``bowing to public pressure that is based on misconceptions and misinformation.'' ``You don't want to get rid of them (polystyrene products) all together,'' he said. ``They provide consumers with a sanitary and timesaving method of food delivery.'' A spokeswoman for the Environmental Protection Agency in Washington, Robin Woods, said her agency had no studies that indicated foam packaging is environmentally sound. But she also said, ``It may not be an environmental hazard because it's inert. It's not something that breaks down easily and leeches into landfills, for example.'' McDonald's said the foam containers will be replaced by paper products manufactured in a new process that will preserve the food's temperature and freshness. McDonald's Vice President Shelby Yastrow said the polystyrene containers are made for McDonald's by several companies, including Amoco Foam Products Co., Mobil Corp., Jen-Pak and Huntsman Chemical. Amoco Foam President John Giroux said 10 percent of his company's polystyrene sales were to McDonald's. Rensi said the sandwich containers represent about 75 percent of the company's polystyrene use. McDonald's still will use plastic utensils and coffee cups. Rensi and Krupp said McDonald's and the environmental group had formed a task force to look into phasing out polystyrene containers last August. When Krupp heard last week that the company was having a change of heart he quickly lobbied against it. ``When we learned they were planning to go to comprehensive recycling, we reacted strongly,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: U.N. Says Israel Fails to Protect Palestinians
DOC.TEXT: Palestinians in the occupied lands cannot count on Israel to protect them, and the United Nations may call for a meeting to ensure their safety under international law, the U.N. chief says. Israel's U.N. mission rejected Thursday's comments by Secretary-General Javier Perez de Cuellar as interference and said Israel has sole control of the territories. Perez de Cuellar's proposals came in an 11-page report ordered by the U.N. Security Council after the Oct. 8 killings of 20 Arabs by Israeli forces during rioting in Arab east Jerusalem. The council has already condemned Israel for the bloodshed. Perez de Cuellar did not make specific recommendations on deploying U.N. observers or peacekeepers to monitor the territories captured from Arab neighbors in the 1967 Mideast War. Arabs have sought U.N. intervention. Palestine Liberation Organization representative Riyad Mansour said the report was ``positive'' but fell short. ``We would have preferred stronger and clearer recommendations ... through recommendations by the secretary-general to the council to dispatch a U.N. force to provide protection,'' Mansour said. He said such a proposal would soon be made to the Security Council. Arab leaders have compared Israel's occupation to Iraq's control of Kuwait. They have chastized the United Nations for its more subdued response to Israel's occupation. Perez de Cuellar said the Palestinians' distrust of Israeli authorities ``had grown so deep that they felt that only an impartial presence, properly mandated by the United Nations, would be able to provide them with a credible sense of protection.'' He did not support or reject that suggestion, however. ``The tragic events of Oct. 8, 1990, are only the most recent of many grave incidents in the occupied territories that have resulted in the deaths and wounding of a large number of civilians,'' Perez de Cuellar said. Israeli forces intervened in riots in Jerusalem on that day after Arabs started throwing stones at praying Jews. Perez de Cuellar said that despite the need for protection of Palestinians, the essential, underlying problem ``is a political conflict that lies at the heart of the tragic events.'' ``For any measure or protection to be ensured, the cooperation of the Israeli authorities is, under present circumstances, absolutely essential,'' he said. The Security Council had proposed sending an investigating team to Israel, but Israeli authorities said they would bar any U.N. envoys from carrying out such a mission. The secretary-general said Thursday that the Security Council might wish to call for a meeting of the 164 nations that signed the 1949 Fourth Geneva Convention on protection of civilians in wartime. He indicated such a gathering could consider how protective measures should be imposed and whether a ``protecting power'' should be designated in the occupied territories. The convention, which Israel signed, prohibits mistreatment of civilians, deportations, collective punishment or destruction of property. Diplomats said they could not recall a prior meeting of the 164 signatories to reassess the convention and decide how it should be applied to new situations. Yuval Rotem, a spokesman for Israel's U.N. mission, said his country's ``responsibility (under the Geneva accord) is not subject to review or intervention by other authorities.'' He said the status of the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip ``is not clear under international law and the Geneva Convention regarding occupied territory does not legally apply.'' However, Rotem said Israel had decided to act in accordance with the convention's humanitarian provisions. ``Under established rules of international law,'' he said, ``Israel has the sole responsibility for the administration of these areas, including the duty to maintain law and order.'' At least 765 Palestinians have been killed by Israelis during the nearly 3-year-old Palestinian uprising against Israeli rule of the occupied lands. At least 290 Palestinians have been killed by fellow Arabs, most as suspected collaborators. More than 50 Israelis also have died.

DOC.HEAD: Fog In East and South; Clouds in Midwest
DOC.TEXT: Temperatures heated up in the East today after some early morning fog, while snow began to fall in South Dakota and Montana. Skies were partly cloudy in the Midwest. Sunshine and temperatures in the 70s were predicted for the East and highs in the 80s were seen for the South today. Showers were predicted for the central Plains. A storm system that brought record rainfall to Oregon this week was expected to combine with Arctic air and bring snow from northern Arizona to southern Minnesota. Up to a foot of snow was possible at higher elevations. Sunny skies prevailed over most of the West. Temperatures were expected to reach the 20s and 30s in the Rockies, the 40s and 50s in the Pacific Northwest and the Great Lakes region and the 60s and 70s in the Midwest and West. The high temperature for the nation Thursday was 89 degrees at Gage, Okla., and Childress, Texas. Other reports at 5 a.m. EST: -East: Albany, N.Y., 35 partly cloudy; Atlanta 50 fair; Boston 49 foggy; Buffalo 57 partly cloudy; Charleston, S.C., 55 fair; Chattanooga 40 foggy; Cincinnati 51 fair; Cleveland 55 fair; Detroit 51 cloudy; Hatteras 61 partly cloudy; Jacksonville 61 foggy; Key West 73 fair; Knoxville 41 fair; Macon 42 fair; Miami 75 cloudy; New York 51 foggy; Philadelphia 50 foggy; Pittsburgh 50 partly cloudy; Portland, Maine, 36 cloudy; Richmond 46 foggy; Tampa 69 partly cloudy; Washington, D.C., 51 fair. -Central: Birmingham 44 fair; Bismarck 42 cloudy; Chicago 62 fair; Denver 37 fair; Des Moines 63 cloudy; Fort Worth 62 partly cloudy; Indianapolis 51 fair; Kansas City 66 windy; Little Rock 53 fair; Louisville 51 fair; Memphis 56 fair; Nashville 51 fair; New Orleans 56 foggy; North Platte 43 fair; Oklahoma City 60 cloudy; Omaha 54 partly cloudy; Rapid City 34 snow; St. Louis 64 partly cloudy; Minneapolis-St. Paul 50 cloudy; Sault Ste. Marie 49 foggy; San Antonio 57 fair. -West: Albuquerque 51 showers; Anchorage 25 cloudy; Boise 32 fair; Casper 28 snow; Fairbanks 13 snow; Great Falls 30 snow; Honolulu 75 partly cloudy; Las Vegas 53 cloudy; Los Angeles 59 fair; Medford 31 fair; Pendleton 34 fair; Phoenix 59 showers; Portland, Ore., 39 cloudy; Reno 29 fair; Salt Lake City 37 cloudy; San Diego 58 partly cloudy; San Francisco 55 fair; Seattle 39 cloudy; Spokane 26 fair. -International: Calgary 25 partly cloudy; Toronto 50 cloudy; Winnipeg 34 cloudy; Mexico City 50 hazy; Acapulco 77 fair; San Juan 76 fair.

DOC.HEAD: Foreman Who Saved Co-Worker From Grinding Machinery Among Carnegie Heroes
DOC.TEXT: A Massachusetts gravel plant foreman who saved a co-worker from grinding machinery and two Canadian women who confronted a knife-wielding intruder after he slashed their elderly neighbor were among 18 people recognized by the Carnegie Hero Fund Commission. The annual awards honor people who risked their lives in efforts to save others. Three of those named Thursday died in their attempts. The commision founded by Pittsburgh industrialist Andrew Carnegie in 1904 has recognized 7,495 Americans and Canadians over the years. More than $18.8 million has been awarded. Winners, or their survivors, get $2,500. Twenty-four-year-old Michael Radwich of Hinsdale, Mass., said he had little time to think when co-worker Scott Pierce became entangled in a gravel sorter he was repairing on Oct. 18, 1989. ``He was leaning in to see how it was working,'' Radwich said. ``I could see him getting wrapped up in the shaft, getting dragged up.'' ``I grabbed for him and yanked him out. He fell back on the deck and I could see his arm was almost off,'' he said. Pierce's left arm and Radwich's left thumb were nearly severed and had to be reattached. Also honored were Grace Nolan, 50, of Whitby, Ontario, and Irene Beaton, 67, of Lindsay, Ontario, who challenged a man who broke into the home of a neighbor, Dorothy Blackhall, 72, and slashed her face. Mrs. Blackhall survived and the attacker was placed in a mental institution, Mrs. Nolan said. Kenneth L. Yant, Jr., 33, of Plainfield, Ind., was among those who died as a result of their heroics. Yant died Aug. 26, 1989 while trying to rescue an 11-year-old boy from drowning in Martinsville, Ind. Another award winner who died was John E. Dedon, 42, of Jackson, La., who died trying to save an 8-year-old boy from drowning Aug. 6, 1989. The third was David A. Guillen, 32, was fatally shot Dec. 1, 1989 when he intervened on behalf of a 13-year-old boy being robbed of his bike in Bell, Calif. Other winners were: -Daniel D. Sanders, 30, of Washington, Pa., who jumped into a creek and saved a fisherman from drowning Oct. 18, 1989, in Burt, N.Y. -Curtis C. Dennison, 35, of Irwin, Pa., who carried a woman from a car moments before leaking gas ignited, engulfing the car in flames on Oct. 28, 1989, in Lewisville, Ohio. -Gerald Heinen, 48, of Loves Park, Ill., who tried to save a 79-year-old woman from a burning car in Ridott, Ill., on Aug. 29, 1989. The off-duty firefighter crawled through the woman's car window and pulled her out. She later died. -John Joseph Theriault, 29, and Pierre O. Theriault, 35, who rescued a teen-age girl dangling from a tree near the top of a 130-foot cliff in Bathurst, New Brunswick, on March 30, 1989. -Don W. Rocap, 67, of Lubbock, Texas, who saved two men from a burning car after a crash in Lubbock on Oct. 10, 1989. -LeRoy Aden, 47, a gas station attendant from Fletcher, N.C., who rescued a state trooper struggling with a driver who pulled a gun in Skyland, N.C., on Feb. 11. Aden grabbed the driver's gun hand and pulled him off the officer. -Lawrence Ogletree, 38, of Evans, Ga., who saved a 2-year-old boy in a runaway car in Martinez, Ga., on Aug. 8, 1989. -Ricky D. Bailey, 31, of Zachary, La., who nearly drowned in the same rescue that left Dedon dead. Charles Saucier, 21, of Lake City, Fla., who also nearly drowned in that rescue. -Robert L. Mathews, 32, of Warren, Ohio, who entered a burning house in Warren three times to rescue a 3-year-old boy from his bedroom Nov. 17, 1989. -Michael J. Smith, 31, of St. Thomas, Ontario, who saved a 10-year-old boy from drowning in Lake Erie on Port Burwell, Ontario, on Aug. 4, 1989.

DOC.HEAD: Former East German Leader Erich Honecker Says He Was Right
DOC.TEXT: Erich Honecker, ousted Communist leader of former East Germany, says in a newspaper interview published today that in the long run ``I will be seen to have been right.'' The weekly newspaper The European quoted him as saying that his former countrymen and women, now in a united Germany since Oct. 3, are becoming aware of the rights and social services they have lost. He also predicted communism will return to Eastern Europe, reversing the revolution that swept East Germany and the rest of the region last year. Honecker, 78, was head of state in the former East Germany from 1976 until he was toppled Oct. 18 last year. He was arrested on charges of treason last January. The paper, printed by London-based publisher Robert Maxwell and circulated throughout Europe, said he was interviewed in a small apartment within a Soviet military hospital compound outside Berlin. It said the interview was conducted by Heinz Judge, a comrade of Honecker in the anti-Nazi resistance. The paper said Honecker expressed no fear in the interview of facing criminal charges. ``I am not afraid of a show trial. I consider all the charges so far brought by the prosecutor's office untenable,'' Honecker was quoted as saying. ``I also reject responsibility for the figure, cited by the prosecutor's office, of 200 killed on the GDR (German Democratic Republic - East Germany) borders. I have no personal guilt for that. And what, I ask myself, about those who killed GDR border guards while violating our frontiers?'' The paper quoted him as saying it had been ``a great disappointment for me that so many people have forgotten socialism and turned to the D-mark instead. ``But I am not afraid that former GDR citizens would threaten me or lynch me, despite the demonstration cries and banner slogans of the so-called `democrats.' Quite the contrary; in the end I will be seen to have been right,'' he said. ``It has already become quite obvious to all what rights and social services they have lost,'' Honecker said. He contended that the communist parties of the old East bloc had been brought down by intrigues but that they could bounce back. ``What is needed now,'' Honecker was quoted as saying, ``is a merciless investigation of the reasons for what has happened and the relevant conclusions to be drawn. The communist movement has certainly suffered a defeat but it will recover.'' He offered no apologies for his years in power. ``Everything I did, I did in the knowledge that I was doing something for the people and for peace. In the present situation they need scapegoats and I am being made the biggest one,'' he said. ``My wife and I are shocked by the allegations and calumnies against us. We are accused of corruption and self-enrichment at the expense of the people,'' Honecker said. ``But Margot and I have nothing to reproach ourselves with. We did not lead a life of luxury and we do not have a bank account in Switzerland.''

DOC.HEAD: Radio Station Offers ``Breeders Cup'' to Couple Who Conceive First
DOC.TEXT: A Florida radio station promotion will award a ``Gulf Coast Breeders Cup'' and $1,000 to the first of three couples to conceive a child in a novel contest designed to lure baby-boomers. ``We thought, `Why do another car giveaway?''' WTKX Program Director Mike Ondayko said Wednesday. ``This is the type of promotion that gets the audience excited about something.'' The three couples will be selected from contestants who submit 50-word essays explaining why they can beat other couples in a ``race to conception.'' The station will give the finalists what it calls ``love enhancers:'' a water bed, a night in a hotel, a seafood buffet, a gift certificate from a lingerie shop, champagne, candles and green M&Ms. Female contestants must submit to a pregnancy test at the onset of the competition to make sure they are not already pregnant. To determine the winner, the station will pay for a weekly pregnancy test. Contest rules prohibit artificial insemination and in-vitro fertilization. The contest is aimed at boosting the station's popularity among listeners in the 25-44 age group.

DOC.HEAD: FBI Reviewing Reports of Drug Link to Flight 103 Bombing
DOC.NOTE: EDS: SUBS 5th graf to CORRECT spelling of Frankfurt
DOC.TEXT: The FBI will review reports that terrorists exploited an undercover drug operation to bomb Pan Am Flight 103 but there is nothing thus far to support them, the Justice Department says. Deputy Attorney General William P. Barr said Thursday in a statement that ``at this time we know of no evidence giving credence to these allegations'' but it was important ``to determine their credibility as soon as possible.'' The department said the FBI will review reports by NBC-TV and ABC-TV that terrorists penetrated a Drug Enforcement Administration operation to put explosives aboard the 1988 flight that ended in a bomb explosion over Lockerbie, Scotland. In Germany, an official also said investigators would examine the reports but added that an earlier inquiry had failed to substantiate them. Frankfurt City Prosecutor Hubert Harth said investigators there had examined the charges a year ago. He said the information then pertained not to the DEA but to a drug-tracing operation of the Central Intelligence Agency. ``There was absolutely no confirmation in this direction,'' Harth said. ``Nonetheless, we will once more examine these new reports.'' The networks reported Tuesday that terrorists might have substituted baggage containing bombs for suitcases loaded with heroin that DEA had placed on U.S.-bound planes to track the routes of Lebanese drug traffickers. FBI Director William Sessions, speaking to reporters in Glasgow, Scotland, refused to comment on the network reports. Sessions expressed confidence that the bombers would be brought to justice but indicated that the investigation could take additional years. ``We will not let go. We are not only tenacious, but we are diligent about our responsibility,'' said Sessions. The FBI investigated similar reports a year ago and found no basis for them, said officials who spoke on condition of anonymity. DEA spokesman Bill Ruzzamenti said there was ``absolutely no evidence whatsoever in anything we have done preliminarily to substantiate any claims about any involvement by DEA in any way with Pan Am 103.'' NBC reported that terrorists may have discovered an arrangement between DEA and German security officials that allowed them to substitute explosives-filled suitcases for luggage that contained heroin. The bombing killed 259 people aboard the U.S.-bound flight and 11 more on the ground. The New York-bound flight originated in Frankfurt and stopped in London, where passengers and luggage were transferred to a larger airplane.

DOC.HEAD: Government Eases Return for Exiles; Five Dead In Factional Fighting
DOC.TEXT: Special travel documents allowing political exiles entrance to South Africa will be issued to speed their return, Home Affairs Minister Gene Louw announced today. Louw spoke a day after the government said it was ready to begin releasing political prisoners and allow the large-scale return of exiles in accordance with an earlier agreement with the African National Congress. The actions indicate the government wants constitutional negotiations with the ANC and other opposition groups to proceed as quickly as possible. Also today, the independent South African Press Association reported that parents at an elite Afrikaner school near Cape Town have voted to accept students of all races, making it thefirst of its kind to open its doors to blacks. The parents of Groote Schuur Laerskool voted overwhelmingly to remain a government-funded school with autonomy over admissions requirements, the news agency said. Elsewhere in South Africa, more black factional fighting Thursday night left at least five people dead, officials said. Release of political prisoners and the return of thousands of exiles have been key ANC demands in peace talks with the government designed to set up full-scale negotiations. In August, the government agreed in principle to the demands, but implementation was delayed by disputes in the talks with the ANC. Membership in the ANC and other anti-government organizations was a crime in South Africa until February, when President F.W. de Klerk legalized 60 opposition groups and movements. Thousands of people had fled the country to avoid arrest. Justice Minister Kobie Coetsee on Thursday released the first report of a government-ANC working group on the prisoner and exile issues. The report set guidelines for ANC exiles, prisoners and fugitives to apply for indemnity from prosecution for acts committed during the group's 30-year guerrilla war against the white-led government. The ANC suspended its largely dormant armed struggle in August to meet government demands. Coetsee said the government ``could now proceed in a phased manner'' with the agreement to release political prisoners and bring back exiles. He said the rate of implementation would depend on the ANC's adherence to its promise to end all violence. The ANC has said it has 20,000 exiles and estimates there are about 1,500 political prisoners. The government has not given figures for either category. Exiles seeking to return will fill out applications stating their past acts, but Coetsee said the information could not be used against them in a court of law. A special committee will be set up to review applications, and the Justice Ministry also will consider some applications. Coetsee would not say who will be on the committee. Fighting between mine workers of different tribes erupted at a coal mine in Natal Province, injuring 11 people, and five people died in other violence, officials said today. The mine clash between Zulus and Xhosas occurred Thursday night at the Kilbarchan coal mine near Newcastle, about 150 miles southeast of Johannesburg, said Genmin, which operates the mine. Also in Natal, two people were killed and seven wounded when a group of unidentified assailants opened fire with automatic weapons Thursday night on three houses in Stanger, police said. Two more people died in separate Natal shootings, and a body with stab wounds was found in the Tembisa black township near Johannesburg, police said. Factional fighting pitting Zulus loyal to the conservative Inkatha Freedom Party against Xhosas and other blacks linked to the ANC has killed about 800 people in townships near Johannesburg since August. The unrest spread from Natal Province, where five years of warfare has killed 5,000 people.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Down, Gold Steady
DOC.NOTE: Eds: DELETES dollar signs from foreign currency comparisons.
DOC.TEXT: The dollar continued to fall against the yen in European trading this morning and was broadly lower against other key currencies. Gold was steady. In Tokyo, the dollar's three-day rally against the yen ended abruptly. It closed at 129.10 yen, down 1.60 yen from Thursday's close. Later in London, it was quoted at 128.65 yen. Other dollar rates at midmorning compared with late Thursday: -1.5010 German marks, down from 1.5070 -1.2701 Swiss francs, down from 1.2745 -5.0380 French francs, down from 5.0525 -1.6950 Dutch guilders, down from 1.6980 -1,127.00 Italian lire, down from 1,129.75 -1.1650 Canadian dollars, unchanged In London, the British pound was quoted at $1.9525, unchanged from late Thursday. Dealers in Tokyo saw the dollar's fall as part of a series of adjustments to a long plunge that began in the summer. The dollar closed at a two-year low of 124.40 yen on Oct. 18. Then, earlier this week, it increased by 3.35 yen during a three-day rally, ending at 130.70 yen Thursday. ``There had been too much dollar buying,'' said Shigeto Yanase, a dealer at The Dai-ichi Kangyo Bank. London's major bullion dealers fixed a recommended gold price of $379.75 per ounce at midmorning, unchanged from late Thursday. In Zurich, the bid price was $379.75, down from $380.70 late Thursday. Gold in Hong Kong rose 81 cents an ounce on Friday, to close at $380.06. Silver traded in London at a bid price of $4.23 a troy ounce, up from $4.19 on Thursday.

DOC.HEAD: Arkansas Attorney General Convicted of Expense Account Theft, Spared Jail
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 6th graf, `Jurors convicted...' to add that attorney general has $26,500 salary.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto LR1
DOC.TEXT: Attorney General Steve Clark was spared jail time after his conviction for using his state credit card to boost his brief run for governor and sagging personal finances. Clark was fined $10,000 Thursday after the jury convicted him of felony theft by deception. ``I think it's important that Steve Clark as attorney general was treated like any other person in the system,'' Prosecutor Chris Piazza said after the verdict was announced. ``Obviously, I'm very disappointed,'' said Clark, 43. ``As I've said all along, it was never my intention to defraud or deceive.'' Defense attorney Bill Bristow said an appeal was likely. Jurors convicted Clark of a less severe crime than the one prosecutors filed against him, deciding the theft amounted to less than $2,500 but more than $200. Clark, who is paid $26,500 a year as attorney general, had been charged with stealing more than $2,500. Clark said he would make a decision whether to resign his office within 24 hours. Bristow scheduled an afternoon news conference to answer questions about Clark's future. Todd McCall, spokesman for the attorney general's office, said the state constitution requires Clark to resign because of his felony conviction. McCall would not comment on whether Clark could remain in office if he appeals the verdict. Jurors deliberated for just over four hours before arriving at the verdict. Circuit Judge Perry V. Whitmore followed the jury's sentencing recommendation by fining Clark and sparing him jail time. ``I didn't want to see the man go to prison,'' said juror Brenda Beall, 27, of North Little Rock. ``My God, he has suffered enough, but we didn't want him to get away with taking our money - your money, my money.'' Piazza argued successfully that Clark used a state Visa card to prop up his gubernatorial campaign and failing personal finances. Before discrepancies in his expense records were exposed in the Arkansas Gazette, Clark announced he would seek the Democratic gubernatorial nomination. He dropped out of the race a few weeks later, after dozens of people told reporters they didn't attend dinner parties where Clark reported them as guests, or said the meals were strictly social affairs. Piazza said Clark used the credit card to help raise campaign contributions that ended up in his personal checking account. Five women friends of Clark testified they shared meals with him that were charged to the state.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Soldiers Restricted Because of Talks in Philippines
DOC.TEXT: American authorities have imposed travel restrictions at U.S. military bases here as Manila and Washington prepare to resume talks on the future of the facilities, a spokesman said today. The Air Force spokesman, Maj. Wayne Crist, said the restrictions took effect Wednesday at Clark Air Base, 50 miles north of Manila. He said there will be a 9:00 p.m. to 5:30 a.m. curfew and base personnel will not be allowed to leave the facility except on official business. Liberty also will be curtailed for service members at the Subic Bay Naval Base and the San Miguel naval communications facility west of Manila starting tonight, a U.S. Navy spokesman said. The spokesman said only personnel living outside the facility will be allowed to leave the base, but their movement will be limited to travel directly between their homes and their offices. Clark is located in Pampanga province where Communist insurgents are active. Communist rebels killed two American servicemen near Clark on the eve of exploratory talks in May. U.S. officials said American and Philippine military reports have indicated that the threat against Department of Defense personnel and their families at the facilities ``has significantly increased.'' They did not elaborate. Travel restrictions were also imposed in September, during the first round of talks on a new bases treaty. There were no attacks against U.S. service members then. President Corazon Aquino said the negotiations will resume before she leaves Nov. 11 for Japan to attend coronation ceremonies for Emperor Akihito. The U.S. maintains Clark, Subic and four smaller facilities under an agreement that expires in September 1991. The Philippine Constitution requires a treaty approved by the Senate to keep the facilities beyond 1991. There are about 40,000 U.S. troops, Defense Department employees and dependents at the U.S. facilities in the Philippines.

DOC.HEAD: Police Shoot To Repel Attack On Mosque, 10 Hindus Killed
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 12 grafs to UPDATE with higher death, injury tolls, quote from injured Hindu. Pickup 10th graf, `Singh's government...'
DOC.TEXT: Police fatally shot at least 10 Hindu fundamentalists today, repulsing a renewed assault on a Moslem mosque in a religious dispute that has left more than 250 people dead nationwide. More than 60 people and three police officers were injured in the clash. The conflict has spilled into Moslem Bangladesh, where two more people died today from anti-Hindu rioting. Pakistan's caretaker prime minister said India is not doing enough to protect Moslem shrines. About 10,000 Hindus tried to storm the hilltop Babri Mosque, which they want to replace with a Hindu temple in Ayodhya, 300 miles southeast of New Delhi. The conflict in the northeastern town threatens to bring down the government of Prime Minister V.P. Singh. Police used tear gas and pushed back the crowds with blows from 6-foot-long bamboo staves. Reporters saw scores of people injured before the crowd retreated down dirt alleys and into buildings. Police opened fire after coming under a repeated barrage of stones from the roofs of buildings. Witnesses saw police chasing the militants onto the roofs and firing on the crowds in the narrow lanes below. Reporters counted 10 bodies in the streets and in a hospital.
