Witnesses claimed more people were killed, and Hindu militants refused to let them take away the corpses. Doctors at Faizabad Hospital said they treated 64 people for injuries, including 48 hit by gunfire. Six of those injured were in critical condition. Three injured policemen were also brought to the hospital. One of the injured Hindus, Bhupendra Singh Rawat, 24, accused the police of shooting needlessly. ``Two policemen dragged a man out of the house and shot him in the chest. Then they also shot two people who were crying over a dead body. They were shot in the back,'' he said, speaking from a hospital bed. Today was the last day of a four-day pilgrimage period declared by astrologers and Hindu holy men as the auspicious time for beginning construction of the temple. At least 257 people have been killed in an unrelenting wave of violence in six Indian states since the fighting began Oct. 24, according to a tally of official reports and news agency accounts. Singh's government vowed to defend the Moslem site until the courts decide its fate. His stand cost him his majority in Parliament when a Hindu party withdrew its support last week. He faces a no-confidence motion Nov. 7, which he appears likely to lose. Moves were afoot to replace him as leader of the Janata Dal Party, which might rescue the governing National Front coalition from defeat in Parliament. Jockeying in the Janata Dal centered on two rural-based politicians, Devi Lal and Chandra Shekhar, who command wide followings among lower-class Hindus. Singh was elected last year largely on the strength of the middle class, which grew disenchanted with the Congress Party headed by Rajiv Gandhi. The Ayodhya dispute ignited religious tensions in neighboring Bangladesh, an Islamic nation with a Hindu minority. Three people were reported killed and more than 350 were wounded in three days of rioting in Dhaka, the capital, and in 12 other cities. Doctors said two people died of bullet wounds in Dhaka early today. One Moslem businessman died Wednesday of wounds suffered in Dhaka. Hindus say the 460-year-old Babri Mosque was built on the foundation of an early Hindu temple marking the birthplace of Rama, the much-worshiped warrior god. Moslems dispute the history of the site and say that relinquishing the site would jeopardize hundreds of other Moslem sites.

DOC.HEAD: Belgian, U.S. Cancer Researchers Win Swiss Prize
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Embargoed until 11 a.m. EST; time set by source.
DOC.TEXT: A Belgian and an American scientist today won a Swiss foundation's prize for their cancer research. Thierry Boon of the Ludwig Institute for Cancer Research in Brussels and Ronald Levy of Stanford University in California will split the $315,000 Steiner Prize. Boon was honored for inquiries into immunology that could help lead to therapy and promote the study of organ transplants, the foundation said. Levy was cited for introducing a treatment for malignant tumors using so-called monoclonal antibodies. The prize, administered by the Bern-based Steiner Foundation, is drawn from the estate of Josef Steiner, a wealthy Swiss pharmacist who died in 1983. It has been awarded since 1986 and is considered one of the world's top cancer research prizes.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Remands Palestinian-American For 15 Days
DOC.TEXT: A judge today ordered a Palestinian-American held for questioning on suspicion he carried out a fatal bus attack. The suspect was the first to be extradited from the United States during the Palestinian uprising. Mahmoud Atta, allegedly a member of the Abu Nidal terrorist group, is accused of taking part in a 1986 machine gun attack on a bus carrying Jewish settlers in the West Bank. The driver was killed and a passenger wounded. His lawyer accused police of violating the extradition agreement barring mistreatment by denying Atta a change of clothes and a shower since his arrival in Israel on Wednesday. ``Police invited all the camera crews and then presented him dirty and unshaven,'' defense lawyer Leah Tzemel told reporters outside the courtroom. ``This is how you build an image of a terrorist.'' Atta, 37, also known as Mahmoud el-Abed Ahmed, flashed a victory sign to dozens of photographers with a shackled hand before being led into the courtroom of Jerusalem Magistrate Moshe Ravid. Ravid granted a police request that Atta be held 15 days for questioning. ``I guess the Americans wouldn't have extradited him if they didn't have some evidence against him,'' Ravid said. Atta, an American citizen, was arrested by U.S. authorities three years ago. On Aug. 31, the U.S. Supreme Court rejected his final appeal of extradition, and he was brought to Israel. He was the first suspect extradited from the United States during the nearly 35-month-old Palestinian uprising against Israeli occupation in the West Bank and Gaza Strip. The Abu Nidal group threatened to attack U.S. targets if Atta was extradited. Following the threats, the State Department issued an unusual warning that Abu Nidal's group was planning a revenge attack on a passenger ship in the eastern Mediterranean. Ms. Tzemel said today that unidentified security agents, including a Hebrew-speaker, originally captured Atta in Venezuela and interrogated him for nine days before delivering him to American authorities on June 6, 1987. Atta sat silently during the 90-minute hearing, listening to an Arabic translation of the Hebrew proceedings. His feet remained shackled. No indictment has been handed down against Atta, and he did not enter a plea. He has repeatedly said he was innocent. It is routine in Israel for suspects to be held for police interrogation before charges are brought.

DOC.HEAD: Cross Into Greece And Seek Political Asylum
With PM-Albania
DOC.TEXT: Nine Albanians, including two soldiers, crossed into Greece from Albania today and sought political asylum, the government said. The Albanians, all of Greek origin, were men between the ages of 19 and 27. They declared their opposition to Albania's hard-line Communist government. Five other Albanians of Greek extraction fled to Greece on Thursday. The announcement said the nine men made their way across the border and through unmarked, rugged terrain in northwestern Greece. They surrenderedto police in the village of Psarades. Their request for political asylum is being considered, the government announcement added. Hundreds of Albanians have sought asylum in Greece in the past two years. An undisclosed number of ethnic Greeks have been shot and killed by Albanian border guards as they attempted to flee. The Orthodox Church of Greece says 400,000 Albanians of Greek extraction live in Albania and face religious persecution. Albania denies that, and says the number of ethnic Greeks is less than 100,000.

DOC.HEAD: With PM-Unemployment
DOC.TEXT: Here are the unemployment rates for 11 major states released Friday by the Labor Department: -California, 6.0 percent, up from 5.9 percent in September. -Florida, 6.2 percent, up from 6.0 percent. -Illinois, 5.9 percent, down from 7.2 percent. -Massachusetts, 6.3 percent, up from 6.2 percent. -Michigan, 7.4 percent, up from 7.2 percent. -New Jersey, 5.5 percent, up from 5.2 percent. -New York, 5.6 percent, up from 5.5 percent. -North Carolina, 4.6 percent, up from 3.7 percent. -Ohio, 5.9 percent, up from 5.2 percent. -Pennsylvania, 6.1 percent, up from 5.5 percent. -Texas, 5.7 percent, down from 6.3 percent.

DOC.HEAD: New Yorkers Reflect on `Trick or Treat' Attack on Homeless
DOC.TEXT: A Halloween attack on a group of homeless men that left one dead and nine injured was an indication that New York residents don't see homeless people as human beings, the city's human rights commissioner said. A dozen young people, some dressed in Halloween costumes, yelled ``trick or treat'' before attacking the men with bats, pipes, knives and meat cleavers, said Capt. Steve Davis, a police spokesman. Carlos Melendez, 35, was killed when the gang slashed his throat. He was pronounced dead at the scene, Davis said. ``What we are witnessing here is a dehumanization process which is already under way,'' said Human Rights Commissioner Dennis DeLeon. ``As New Yorkers, we must all realize that the homeless are human beings with rights like all the rest of us which must be recognized and enforced.'' The attackers, aged 16 to 25, waited in a dark wooded area and attacked the homeless men as they walked over a narrow footbridge to the Keena Men's Shelter on Ward's Island. The footbridge links the island with Manhattan. Ward's Island, in the East River beneath the Triborough Bridge, also is home to the Fire Department training academy, several psychiatric hospitals and a sewage disposal plant. Davis said that two or three of the attack victims said they had been robbed of $15 or $20 each. But Melendez was found with $15 in his pocket. The robbery-and-assault spree lasted about 35 minutes Wednesday, ending just before a police officer arrived to close the footbridge at 10 p.m. ``Everyone knew you had to get off the bridge before 10 p.m. or you'd be stuck on the island,'' Davis said. Five of the injured men were treated at a hospital and released. Three others were treated by police at a precinct house, and another man was listed as stable at Harlem Hospital after he was beaten about the face with a baseball bat. ``The motive was robbing people and assaulting them,'' Davis said. ``I can't believe the fact it was Halloween escaped them.'' No arrests have been made in the attack.

DOC.HEAD: Prospect of Meeting on Palestinians Causes Worry in Israel
With PM-UN-Palestinians
DOC.TEXT: The prospect of a meeting called by the United Nations to ensure the safety of Palestinians raised fears here today about Israel's increasing isolation in the world community. United Nations Secretary-General Javier Perez de Cuellar on Thursday suggested the meeting, saying Palestinians in the occupied lands cannot count on Israel to protect them. His proposals came in an 11-page report ordered by the U.N. Security Council after the Oct. 8 killings of 20 Arabs by Israeli forces during rioting in Arab east Jerusalem. The council has already condemned Israel for the bloodshed. Israel's U.N. mission rejected the secretary-general's comments as interference and said Israel has sole control of the territories. The Foreign Ministry scheduled a briefing for reporters on the latest U.N. move, then canceled it. Ministry officials said they stood by the Israeli U.N. mission's response. Yossi Achimeir, an aide to Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir, told the daily newspaper Davar that Israel was ``doing everything'' to ensure the security of the 1.7 million Palestinians in the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip. ``If there is any lack of security it derives from the violent activities of the Arabs against Israelis and their own brethern,'' Achimeir was quoted as saying. Misha Harish of the opposition Labor Party said the center-left party rejected the call for an international meeting. But his statement criticized Shamir for refusing any U.N. investigation of the Temple Mount deaths. ``Shamir is creating unnecessary conficts with the president of the United States and the rest of the nations of the world,'' Harish said. Diplomats quoted in the Haaretz newspaper said they were concerned by Perez de Cuellar's suggestion. The meeting by the 164 nations that signed the 1949 Fourth Geneva Convention would be to consider how to protect Palestinians in the disputed lands. The diplomats expressed fears that an another Israeli rejection of a U.N. action would erode the Jewish state's international standing, Haaretz said. The fears by the unidentified diplomats were echoed by veteran statesman Abba Eban, who said the continued focus of U.N. attention on Israel was harmful not only to the Jewish state but to the Arab and Western alliance against Iraq. ``There are many in the country ... who believe there has been damage ... by all this activity around our problem at a time when the main interest of Israel now is to actually help strengthen the great coalition that was formed against Saddam Hussein,'' the former foreign minister told army radio.

DOC.HEAD: Bush To Visit Germany on Nov. 18
DOC.NOTE: Eds: ADDS 3 grafs with Bush to be in Paris. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: President Bush will meet with Chancellor Helmut Kohl on Nov. 18 in Germany, Kohl's spokesman said today. Spokesman Hans Klein said the visit would probably last a few hours and would likely occur somewhere in the vicinity of Kohl's hometown, Oggersheim. Klein said preparations were still under way, and that he did not know exactly where the two leaders will meet. No other details were immediately available. On Thursday, the White House said Bush will go to Paris Nov. 19-21 for a 34-nation arms control summit. The projected centerpiece of the summit will be the signing of the Conventional Forces in Europe treaty, the most sweeping arms control accord in history. It would set limits on tanks, anti-aircraft artillery and various other categories of non-nuclear weapons from the Atlantic Ocean to the Ural Mountains of the Soviet Union.

DOC.HEAD: Lawyer Alleges Torture in Treason Case
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Koigi wa Wamwere cq
DOC.TEXT: A lawyer for four Kenyans charged with treason tody told a magistrate that they had been tortured while in custody. The four, who include a former legislator and two lawyers, are charged with plotting the overthrow of President Daniel arap Moi's one-party government, a crime punishable by death. They were among suspected dissidents arrested following demonstrations urging democratic changes. Koigi wa Wamwere, a former legislator, lawyers Mirugi Kariuki and Rumba Kinuthia, and Geofrey Kuga Kariuki ``have been subjected to torture and degrading and inhuman conditions'' since their arrest last month, lawyer John Khaminwa told the court. He did not provide specifics. Magistrate Omondi Tunya ruled the torture claims could only be discussed in the High Court on Nov. 7 during the hearing of a previous plea by three defense lawyers. On Thursday, lawyers for three of the detainees asked the High Court to order prison authorities to permit them to see their clients. The lawyers said officials at Kamiti prison in a Nairobi suburb prevented them and a doctor from seeing Wamwere and Mirugi Kariuki on Oct. 26. Tunya agreed with the state attorney's argument that the lawyers should arrange their intended visits to their clients well in advance with prison authorities. The accused first appeared in court 10 days after their arrest Oct. 19. The government had earlier announced police seized machine guns and grenades Oct. 8 in arresting Wamwere. Wamwere, a critic of the Kenyan establishment, had lived in self-exile in Norway since 1986 and belonged to an opposition underground group calling itself the Kenya Patriotic Front. Kinuthia and Mirugi Kariuki practiced law. Geofrey Kariuki's background was unknown. On Oct. 22, Kenya broke diplomatic relations with Norway, accusing the Nordic nation of meddling in internal affairs by seeking to help Wamwere. Norway did not protest Wamwere's arrest, but it objected to Kenya's refusal to allow Norwegian diplomats to check on his welfare or offer legal assistance.

DOC.HEAD: Japan Starts to Resume Loan Program Frozen After Tiananmen Attack
DOC.TEXT: Japan announced today it was resuming a development loan program for China that has been frozen since the brutal suppression of pro-democracy protests in Beijing last year. Japan will make available up to $283 million to China for seven projects in an effort ``to contribute to economic stability and to promote the economic modernization efforts of the country,'' the Foreign Ministry said. It said in a statement that Japan's ambassador to China, Hiroshi Hashimoto, and Qi uaiyuan, a Chinese Foreign Ministry official, exchanged a memorandum of understanding on the plan. The funds are part of a five-year package of development loans to China totaling $6.28 billion. The money was frozen by Tokyo to condemn China's crack down on the pro-democracy protests in June 1989. But in July, Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu promised to gradually resume the loans, putting Japan ahead of Western industrialized nations in relaxing sanctions on Communist China. ``What we have decided is to release this frozen aid step by step in accordance with the pace of change in China,'' said Foreign Ministry spokesman Taizo Watanabe. He said Japan welcomed China's cooperation with the West in the Persian Gulf crisis. Other industrialized democracies also have been gradually easing sanctions on China in recent months. The European Community agreed last week to end its ban on high-level diplomatic contacts with China and to go ahead with soft loans. Spain's foreign minister is expected to visit China in several weeks. The United States also has allowed the resumption of some trade credits from the Export-Import Bank as well as World Bank loans, and is expected to gradually resume high-level visits. Bans on military sales to China are expected to continue, however. The terms of the Japanese loans to China include an annual interest rate of 2.5 percent and a 30-year repayment period. Japan will not require that Japanese companies be involved in the programs. The development projects to be financed by the loans include construction of a bridge, two dams and three chemical fertilizer plants, as well as urban water supply improvement.

DOC.HEAD: Gantt Promises To Take `High Road' As He Attack Helms Ads
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Recasts lead and adds 3 grafs to UPDATE with polls.
DOC.TEXT: Democrat Harvey Gantt pledged that he would stay on the ``high road'' in the final days of his campaign against Sen. Jesse Helms as polls showed the candidates locked in close contention. While both candidates made personal appearances Thursday, attention focused on Helms' televisi funeral of Emperor Hirohito in February last year. Although police mobilized 32,000 officers in Tokyo to guard that ceremony, the Chukaku-ha set off a bomb along the funeral procession route. The bomb exploded before the procession arrived, and no one was injured. Over the past month, police have announced uncovering alleged plots by the Chukaku-ha to jam television broadcasts of the coronation and fire rockets at a tunnel along a train route the emperor is to travel later this month. The radical group is believed to have mortar-style weapons with a range of 4 miles.

DOC.HEAD: Union Supporters Rally; Daily News Claims 1.06 Million Distributed
DOC.TEXT: The front of a store selling the strike-torn Daily News was hit by arsonists today and two delivery men were attacked but the newspaper says it distributed more than a million papers. The violence came after more than 13,000 union supporters rallied in front of the News building on Thursday, temporarily closing a block on 42nd Street. Dozens of labor leaders and politicians urged the strikers to continue their fight. Cardinal John O'Connor sent a letter saying, ``I do not believe that union members wanted to initiate the current strike.'' Police initially estimated the crowd at 5,000 but later changed their estimate to 13,000. They reported no arrests or injuries during the demonstration, but several scuffles erupted. The News says it printed and distributed 1.06 million copies despite a strike by nine of its 10 unions, but availability of the paper remained spotty. In the Rego Park section of Queens today, a stationery store was hit by arson a little after 4 a.m., said Sgt. Tina Mohrmann, a police spokeswoman. The store's owner said he was warned over the past few days not to sell the paper. He told police he has not stocked it for four days. The Fire Department found flammable liquid at the store, which was burned on the outside and slightly inside, Mohrmann said. Also early today, a replacement worker driving a News truck on the Long Island Expressway sustained a small cut on his hand when a large rock crashed through the windshield, Mohrmann said. No arrests were made. Later, two security guards escorting a Daily News truck were attacked by three bat wielding men who drove up to their car and broke the windshield, Mohrmann said. The two victims were taken to a nearby hospital with facial injuries, she said. Some Daily News employees continued to cross picket lines and return to work, including Betty Liu Ebron, whose byline reappeared Thursday on the Apple Sauce column. Labor lawyer Theodore Kheel, an unpaid adviser to the News' unions, offered to buy the nation's second-largest metropolitan daily. He told the Tribune Co., the Chicago-based owner of the News, that he had lined up American investors and would be able to negotiate contracts with the unions and work out a joint operating agreement with the New York Post. ``The paper is not for sale,'' said Lisa Robinson, a News spokeswoman. Eight of the News' 10 unions went on strike Oct. 25, joined a day later by the Newspaper Guild, over what they term unfair labor practices. Violence rocked the first nights of the strike when pickets damaged delivery trucks and buses carrying replacement workers.

DOC.HEAD: Researchers Discover Family's Genetic Defect for Aneurysms
DOC.TEXT: Former Air Force Capt. Michele Hegler said fear of developing the kind of aneurysm that killed five of her relatives led to her participation in research that has uncovered a genetic cause of the disease. ``I was scared, but I didn't hesitate because so many in our family had died,'' the Houston resident said Thursday. ``Now that I know, my family and I can take precautions.'' Thomas Jefferson University researchers announced a discovery Thursday that linked Mrs. Hegler's genetic defect to aortic aneurysms, a disorder that afflicts about 2 million Americans. The university researchers also said they developed a saliva test to detect the mutation, which can be used to identify which of Mrs. Hegler's relatives are at risk. ``Our study proves for the first time that there is a genetic cause for aortic aneurysms in people who do not have any other signs of a genetic disease,'' said Dr. Darwin Prockop, the lead researcher. For someone with the genetic defect, Prockop said their chances of developing an aneurysm is almost 100 percent. In 1988, physicians discovered while examining Mrs. Hegler that several family members had died from ruptured aortic aneurysms. An aortic aneurysm is a balloonlike swelling in the body's largest blood vessel. Of the 2 million Americans at risk of developing an aortic aneurysm during their lives, some 15,000 die each year die when the aneurysms burst, causing massive bleeding. The ruptures most often occur in the arteries of the heart and brain. The discovery is ``a major breakthrough that can now offer physicians a way of anticipating and preventing the dire consequences of aortic aneurysms,'' said Dr. Roger Ladda of the Penn State Medical Center. Ladda said scientists can build on the work to detect similar mutations in other families and possibly uncover a ``universal mutation.'' The study was reported in Thursday's Journal of Clinical Investigation, published by Rockefeller University in New York. The researchers discovered a single mutation among the 30,000 units in the gene responsible for a protein that is part of the building blocks that make up the blood vessels' walls. Mrs. Hegler's defective protein weakens the vessel walls, leading to the rupture. Prockop said they focused on the collagen, called type III procollagen, because it determines the strength of the aortic walls. Prockop and the scientists found the same defect in preserved tissue samples of Mrs. Hegler's mother, who died in 1960, and her aunt, who died in 1986. Both suffered ruptured aortic aneurysms. The researchers then developed a test to look for the same defect in other relatives. Mrs. Hegler said 10 relatives agreed to join the research, and four - including Mrs. Hegler's two children and her brother - carry the defective gene. Mrs. Hegler's 15-year-old son no longer plays football and her 17-year-old daughter has dropped gymnastics. The family goes together for checkups to detect any aneurysms. Physicians had attributed most aneurysms in people without any known genetic disease to atherosclerosis, which also weakens blood vessels while clogging them with cholesterol. If a physician discovers an aneurysm before it ruptures, surgeons can repair the blood vessel by patching it, much like a tire. But almost all patients whose aortic aneurysms rupture die despite emergency surgery, Prockop said. In a related development, detailed ``maps'' of the brain developed by University of Florida physicians are allowing doctors to treat 90 percent of the formerly untreatable brain aneurysms. Dr. Arthur Day, of the university's Department of Neurosurgery, reported an ``outstanding rate of safety and success'' in diagnosing and surgically treating 80 patients with aneurysms of the ophthalmic segment of the carotid artery over the past nine years. The carotid artery carries the major part of the brain's blood supply, while the ophthalmic segment is named for its location near the branch that supplies blood to the eye. Day credits much of his success in safely reaching and treating ophthalmic segment aneurysms to the detailed studies of the brain's anatomy undertaken by Dr. Albert Rhoton, chairman of the Department of Neurosurgery.

DOC.HEAD: Stabbed Former Cabinet Member Dies of Heart Failure
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 6 grafs to UPDATE with autopsy report showing blood transfusion mistake. Pickup 3rd graf pvs, `Niwa had...'
DOC.TEXT: Hyosuke Niwa, a 79-year-old former Japanese labor minister, died today of heart failure caused by excessive bleeding, officials said. His death came 12 days after he was stabbed by a mental patient. An autopsy report revealed Niwa was given the wrong blood type during emergency transfusions, which could have contributed to his death. Niwa had been in a coma in Aichi Medical University Hospital since he was stabbed, said a spokesman for the hospital in central Japan. Niwa, who had type O blood, was given type B blood during transfusions at two hospitals, according to the autopsy by medical staff at Nagoya University. Heart failure was listed as the official cause of death, but officials suspect the transfusion mistake may have hastened Niwa's death, Kyodo News Service reported. Mixing blood types can cause red blood cells to rupture and clump together. Niwa had been in a coma in Aichi Medical University Hospital since he was stabbed, said a spokesman for the hospital in central Japan. Niwa was attacked Oct. 21 while walking to a military ceremony at the Moriyama military base in Nagoya, 170 miles west of Tokyo. He was stabbed by a 47-year-old mental patient with a knife, police said. Niwa, a 12-term member of the governing Liberal Democratic Party in Parliament, was labor minister from December 1988 to June 1989 in the Cabinet of former Prime Minister Noboru Takeshita. Niwa was survived by his wife Yuriko, son Takamitsu, and daughters Atsuko, Setsuko and Yoshimi.

DOC.HEAD: State Supreme Court Settles Dispute Over Republican Gubernatorial Ticket
DOC.TEXT: The Minnesota Supreme Court has settled a dispute over the Republican gubernatorial ticket that arose when Jon Grunseth withdrew from the race amid allegations of sexual misconduct. The court voted 5-2 Thursday to reject Sharon Clark's claim that she should be the candidate for lieutenant governor on the ballot with primary runner-up Arne Carlson. Clark's attorney had argued that Clark was legally entitled to the lieutenant governor's candidacy because she won the Sept. 11 primary as Grunseth's running mate. Grunseth withdrew Sunday after reports that he swam nude with teen-age girls nine years ago and had a mistress during both of his marriages. But the court said Secretary of State Joan Growe did not err in deciding Joanell Dyrstad - Carlson's primary running mate - should join him on supplementary ballots for the Nov. 6 election. Chief Justice Peter Popovich, in a sharply worded two-page dissent, said the Republican Party had failed to fulfill ``the basic duty owed to its members'' by asking the court to settle the dispute. ``Avoiding its duty and requiring the court to settle the political differences within that party is disrespectful of the role of the judiciary and a misuse of the judicial process,'' Popovich wrote. The dispute began after the Minnesota Independent-Republican Party's executive committee on Tuesday decided the party had no committee empowered to fill the vacancy created by Grunseth's withdrawal. Given the party's conclusion, Growe said state law requires that the runner-up in the primary become the GOP nominee. Party officials said the committee decided to leave the running-mate decision to the court. Clark thanked the court for hearing the case and pledged ``100 percent'' support to Carlson and Dyrstad. ``I had to do what I felt was right, and what I owed the primary voters,'' she said in a statement. Growe said she would order supplementary, paper ballots for the governor's race to be printed by 5 p.m. Friday. A 1972 constitutional amendment mandated that candidates for governor and lieutenant governor run as teams to insure that the candidates would be ``substantially politically and personally compatible,'' Chief Deputy Attorney General Jack Tunheim said in a brief filed on Growe's behalf. Popovich rejected that argument in his dissent. ``The inevitable result of this reasoning is that an incumbent governor could not appear on the ballot if the lieutenant governor withdrew at th last minute,'' he wrote. ``Doubtless, the Legislature could not have intended such an unreasonable and absurd result.''

DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto DHA-1
Two Killed, 350 Injured In Anti-Hindu Violence
With PM-India
DOC.TEXT: Two people died today of injuries suffered during three days of anti-Hindu rioting caused by a Hindu-Moslem religious dispute in neighboring India, hospital officials said. The deaths raised to three the number of people killed in violent confrontations in Dhaka and 12 other Bangladeshi cities. News reports said 350 people have been injured. Curfews imposed on Wednesday in Dhaka and the southern port of Chittagong were due to be lifted briefly today to allow Moslems to attend sabbath prayers. The two cities were the worst hit by anti-Hindu rampages. Two of the dead were Moslems, and the third was not identified. All suffered gunshot wounds, but it was not clear who shot them. The trouble began in Chittagong on Tuesday night following reports that Hindu fundamentalists tried to seize a mosque and replace it with a Hindu temple in the Indian town of Ayodhya. More than 200 people have died in Hindu-Moslem violence in India. In Bangladesh, an Islamic country with a Hindu minority, newspapers reported hundreds of demonstrators were injured when anti-Hindu gangs clashed with police in Dhaka, Chittagong and Barisal. Dainik Bangla, a government-owned daily newspaper, said police used steel-tipped batons to disperse 400 Moslems who tried to break into a Hindu temple in Barisal, 75 miles south of Dhaka. At least 50 people were injured. In Dhaka,the capital, riot police armed with tear gas guns and truncheons wounded about 100 people who tried to ``vandalize and loot Hindu-owned shops and temples,'' said Ittefaq, an independent Bengali-language daily. It said nine people were hospitalized. In Chittagong, the country's second largest city, 500 Moslems attacked a Hindu village with knives and homemade bombs Thursday night, witnesses said. They said 50 people were injured in an attack at Patharganj, and another 50 were injured in anti-Hindu violence in Boalkhali, Anwara and Hathazari. Bangladesh, formerly East Pakistan, has a population of 110 million, 88 percent of whom are Moslems. Ten percent are Hindus. On Thursday, President Hussain Muhammad Ershad called out the army in Dhaka and ordered security forces to take ``tough action against the forces who are trying to disrupt peace and harmony.'' He visited a Hindu temple in Dhaka, which was earlier vandalized by Moslem gangs.

DOC.HEAD: Militias Banned In Aoun's Former Enclave
With PM-Lebanon-Fashion, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The government today ordered the army to seize weapons and close checkpoints operated by militias in the Christian enclave seized from rebel Gen. Michel Aoun. The announcement by Defense Minister Albert Mansour was the latest step in President Elias Hrawi's plan to remove all militias from Beirut and eventually disband and disarm them. But the government order was confined only to a 80-square-mile strip of territory north of Beirut and did not appear to signal a general crackdown on private armies in Beirut and its environs. The militias are responsible for most of the estimated 150,000 deaths during Lebanon's 15{-year-old civil war. Christian leaders Samir Geagea and George Saddeh had demanded the removal of Syrian-backed militias who have moved into Aoun's territory since the general's 11-month-old mutiny was crushed Oct. 13. More than 550 people were killed and 1,200 wounded in the Syrian-led attack. Mansour said in an order to the army commander, Gen. Emile Lahoud: ``All military manifestations should be removed. The possession and transport of illegal weapons should be banned.'' The directive allows the army to ``raid suspected weapons caches'' and prevent the militias in Aoun's former territory maintaining checkpoints there. It also said buildings seized by militias by force and used as centers for the private armies should be ``turned over to their legal owners.'' The directive said ``in the event of disobediance, force is to be used.'' There were no response by two Syrian-supported militias in the area, the Syrian Social Nationalist Party and Christian gunmen led by militia chieftain Elie Hobeika. Syria, the main power broker in Lebanon and a backer of Hrawi, is likely to tell them to comply with Mansour's directive. But Hrawi faces considerable difficulties in his ultimate aim of disbanding and disarming Lebanon's private armies under an Arab Leage-mediated peace plan to end the civil war. The four main Christian and Moslem militias have pledged to withdraw their fighters from a ``Greater Beirut'' in line with the government plan. The militias are the Lebanese Forces, the Druse Moslem Progressive Socialist Party; the pro-Iranian Shiite Moslem Hezbollah, or Party of God; and the more secular, Syrian-backed Shiite Amal movement. The peace pact, ratified by Parliament, calls for the equal distribution of power between the majority Moslems and the long dominant Christians. Aoun, like Hrawi a Christian, had opposed the pact because it had no guarantee for the removal of the 40,000 Syrian troops in Lebanon under a 1976 Arab League peacekeeping mandate.

DOC.HEAD: House Report Criticizes Congress as Well as Former HUD Chief
DOC.NOTE: EDS: SUBS 8th graf pvs, The report, with 2 grafs to UPDATE with Adams appearing before grand jury. Picks up 9th graf pvs, But it said.
DOC.TEXT: A congressional investigative report that accuses former Housing Secretary Samuel Pierce of being less than honest in the HUD scandals also points a finger at Congress itself. The report by the House Government Operations Committee, ending a 16-month investigation of the Department of Housing and Urban Development by its housing subcommittee, said Congress as well as the administration should end practices that bring political influence to federal housing decisions. ``There is a need to take politics and discretion out of housing programs,'' the report said. ``This applies equally to the executive and legislative branches.'' Congress allotted some $30 million for 40 housing projects favored by House and Senate members in the supplemental appropriations bill for fiscal 1990, which ended Sept. 30. Similar projects were funded in appropriations for the current fiscal year as well. ``Just as it was wrong for HUD under Secretary Pierce to dole out housing units and grants to former HUD officials and the politically well-connected, ... so too Congress should not earmark funding for housing projects,'' the report said. ``This practice by Congress, which circumvents objective criteria, competition and merit, should be ended,'' it said. The bulk of the report was approved unanimously by Democratic and Republican members of the panel. That section supported the position of current HUD Secretary Jack Kemp, who unsuccessfully opposed congressional earmarking of specific housing projects. The focus of the panel's final report was Pierce, HUD secretary for all eight years of the Reagan administration, who is under investigation by court-appointed special prosecutor Arlin Adams. Meanwhile, Adams and his staff appeared before the special grand jury empaneled earlier this year to consider evidence in the case. It was Adams' first appearance before the panel since it was convened. Investigators carried large charts into the grand jury room. The congressional report left unanswered whether Pierce broke any federal laws or committed perjury in his sworn testimony to the subcommittee last year, saying that was a question for Adams to pursue. But it said there was evidence that Pierce and other HUD officials misled Congress and concealed the full nature and extent of abuses at the department - as well as their own involvement. ``At best, Secretary Pierce was less than honest and misled the subcommittee about his involvement in abuses and favoritism in HUD funding decisions,'' the report said. ``At worst, Secretary Pierce knowingly lied and committed perjury during his testimony.' Pierce's attorney, Paul Perito, blasted the ``spurious allegations'' of the report. ``It sounds like the last gasp of a politically oriented and motivated investigation that failed to uncover one piece of evidence supporting their suggested conclusion that Secretary Pierce benefited directly or indirectly,'' Perito said. ``They may disagree with him on the way HUD was managed. That is not a violation of federal law.'' Pierce appeared before the investigative subcommittee in May 1989, but later invoked his Fifth Amendment right against self-incrimination in refusing to submit to further questioning. Subcommittee Chairman Tom Lantos, D-Calif., said Pierce tried to distance himself from abuses and political favoritism at HUD before the panel. ``He stated that he `never told these people to fund anything,''' Lantos said. ``However, sworn testimony from other witnesses and a paper trail of documents suggest that he was directly and intimately involved in the abuses and favoritism in HUD funding decisions.'' The report said the Section 8 Moderate Rehabilitation Program, which provided grants to private developers to renovate housing for the poor, ``became a cash cow which was milked by former HUD officials and the politically well-connected.'' Among the consultants who collected fees for helping obtain grants for developers was former Interior Secretary James Watt. Abuses in that program alone could cost the government $413 million in overpayments, the report said, while other HUD problems will cost taxpayers more than $1 billion. The report also cited a pattern of favoritism shown to Pierce's former New York law firm - Battle, Fowler, Jaffin and Kheel - including assistance to clients who were seeking Moderate Rehabilitation grants.

DOC.HEAD: Five Dead, 11 Injured in South Africa
With PM-South Africa
DOC.TEXT: Fighting between mine workers of different tribes erupted at a coal mine in Natal Province, injuring 11 people, and five people died in other violence, officials said today. The mine clash between Zulus and Xhosas occurred Thursday night at the Kilbarchan coal mine near Newcastle, 150 miles southeast of Johannesburg, said the Genmin company, which operates the mine. It said one of the injured was in serious condition. Four of the casualties were security personnel hurt while trying to stop the fighting. Also in Natal, two people were killed and seven wounded when a group of unidentified assailants opened fire with automatic weapons Thursday night on three houses in Stanger, police said. Two more people died in separate Natal shootings, and a body with stab wounds was found in the Tembisa black township near Johannesburg, police said. Factional fighting pitting Zulus loyal to the conservative Inkatha Freedom Party against Xhosas and other blacks linked to the African National Congress has killed about 800 people in townships near Johannesburg since August. The unrest spread from Natal Province, where five years of warfare has killed 5,000 people. The government this week lifted emergency restrictions on 11 Johannesburg-area townships but ordered curfews and roadblacks in three townships outside Cape Town wracked by recent unrest. Law and Order Minister Adriaan Vlok ordered the curfews to begin Thursday night in the townships of Khayelitsha, Crossroads and Lingulethu. ANC spokesman Trevor Manuel called it a ``high-handed, bully-boy action,'' likely to anger residents. Speaking from Cape Town, he said violence would not end until town councilors in the townships step down. Many anti-apartheid militants see the black councils as collaborators with the white-led national government. Police reinforcements from Pretoria were called in to enforce the 9 p.m.-to-4 a.m. curfew after Vlok declared the townships ``unrest areas.'' Officers set up barriers leading into the townships and searched cars as they entered.

DOC.HEAD: Iranian Flag Flies Again In London With Modest Hope For Hostages
DOC.TEXT: Iranian diplomats today raised their nation's flag over their embassy for the first time in 20 months, part of a diplomatic thaw that has stirred hopes of freedom for British hostages in Lebanon. The ceremony was attended by two friends of journalist John McCarthy, one of three Britons believed held by pro-Iranian Moslem extremists. They delivered a letter asking for a meeting with Charge d'Affaires Seyyed Shamsoddin Khareghani. ``Relations between Iran and Britain have a long history with its ups and downs,'' Khareghani noted in a brief speech at the embassy in Kensington, west London. ``There are many grounds for cooperation between the two countries ... particulary with regard to current issues in the Midle East and the Persian Gulf region,'' he said. Britain and Iran severed ties in March 1989 after Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini called on Moslems to kill British-born author Salman Rushdie for his book ``The Satanic Verses.'' Many Moslems consider the book blasphemous. Relations were restored last month. Since Khomeini's death in June 1989, Iran has sought better relations with the West. The London embassy will have five diplomats to match the number of British envoys who returned to Tehran last week. At the brief ceremony, the flag of Pakistan was lowered and replaced with the green, white and red flag of Iran. Pakistan looked after Iranian interests in Britain during the dispute. Foreign Office Secretary William Waldegrave said last week that Iran was trying to be helpful in efforts for the release of the hostages, many of whom are believed held by terrorist groups with ties to Iran. But he noted Britain does not have diplomatic ties with Syria, which has 40,000 troops in Lebanon. Thirteen Western hostages, including six Americans, are believed held in Lebanon. Terry Anderson, chief Middle East correspondent of The Associated Press, was kidnapped March 16, 1985, and is the longest-held hostage.

DOC.HEAD: Student Leaders Accept Administration Offer of Temporary Center
DOC.TEXT: A weeklong sit-in by Smith College students protesting for a multicultural center ended today with students voting on a compromise. ``We're thrilled that we've reached an agreement. It has been an exhausting process,'' school spokeswoman Debra Bradley said. Under the agreement proposed Thursday, the administration will convert Hampshire House, a center for commuter students, into a temporary home for cultural groups. As many as 60 protesters had occupied the halls of Smith's main administration building since Oct. 26, refusing to move until administrators came up with firm plans for a center that would serve the interests of minority and foreign students. About 17 percent of the exclusive women's school's 2,600 students are non-white. Students had asked that another building, Lilly Hall, be turned into the multicultural center and although they were happy with the compromise, they have not given up that goal, said Vivian Chiang, chairwoman of the Asian Students Association. ``Most of us all are just so happy it's over because we're so tired, but I can guarantee that there's still skepticism,'' she said. ``It's a stopgap for this year. I just want to make sure that the administration doesn't forget that it's a stopgap.'' Although ballots were not expected to be completely tallied until day's end, Chiang said the compromise had been accepted by leaders of all seven organizations. A meeting was scheduled today between the students and a group of architects conducting a study on space reallocation at Smith that school officials said could uncover a permanent home for the center. Currently, only the Black Student Alliance and Nosotras, a Hispanic group, have space in Lilly Hall. Both groups supported the protest. Administrators said turning all of Lilly Hall into a multicultural center was impossible because it would mean evicting the School of Social Work and the Graduate Office. But administrators have promised to find a permanent home for the multicultural center. The debate over a multicultural center has been raised periodically at Smith since 1983. Protesters said the college seems more concerned about recruiting minority students than helping them once they arrive.

DOC.HEAD: Thatcher in Crisis After Deputy Prime Minister Quits
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Inserts 2 grafs after 3rd, `Publicly, key...' to UPDATE with report of Howe's replacement. Pickup 4th, `Howe's resignation...'
DOC.TEXT: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's opponents had a field day today after her deputy, Sir Geoffrey Howe, quit in protest of her resistance to Britain's integration into the European Community. ``Instead of having a leader who holds the party together ... we have one who unfortunately allows the party to break up,'' said ex-prime minister Edward Heath, who himself was ousted by Mrs. Thatcher as party leader in 1975. Publicly, key aides in Mrs. Thatcher's 22-member Cabinet rallied round, although they take a more conciliatory policy than the prime minister in the drive toward European union. Government sources said today that Education Secretary John MacGregor had been chosen to replace Howe as leader of the House of Commons, according to Press Association, the domestic news agency. It was not known whether anyone would assume Howe's additional title of deputy prime minister. Mrs. Thatcher, her government in disarray and looking increasingly embattled, was closeted at her 10 Downing Street office ``working on a couple of speeches for next week,'' a spokeswoman said. Howe's resignation late Thursday prompted speculation that he or another senior lawmaker may try to oust her as leader of the Conservative Party - and thus the premiership - in a challenge this winter. But many observers believe a leadership challenge would be too risky for the party, now less than two years from the June 1992 deadline for the next general election. Howe, 63, a soft-spoken man who had come to irritate Mrs. Thatcher profoundly, according to political insiders, handed his resignation to her without notice in a 30-minute interview on Thursday evening. He cited ``a growing difference'' between them over Britain's role in Europe. ``We need to persuade friends as well as challenge opponents. ... We should be in the business, not of isolating ourselves unduly, but of offering positive alternatives,'' he said. Mrs. Thatcher responded that she did not believe their differences ``are nearly so great as you suggest,'' and said she was saddened by his departure. Howe had stayed on as deputy prime minister after Mrs. Thatcher removed him as foreign secretary against his will last year. The end came for him when she lashed out after a European Community summit in Rome last weekend. The leaders agreed 11-1 to set a timetable for monetary union and debated proposals for closer political ties. Mrs. Thatcher shouted ``No, No, No!'' during a rowdy debate in the Commons on Tuesday and ducked an invitation to back Howe. London's Financial Times reported today that Mrs. Thatcher had berated Howe at Thursday morning's regular Cabinet meeting over his organization of parliamentary business. Howe was the last survivor of the 21-member Cabinet named by Mrs. Thatcher when she first won power in 1979. His departure left her government in apparent disarray and the prime minister increasingly embattled. ``Mrs. Thatcher may tower over her party as she towers over all she surveys,'' commented the pro-Thatcher London newspaper The Times. ``But the tower is an ever-more lonely one.'' ``The truth is that the problem is not a Cabinet minister here or a Cabinet minister there,'' said Paddy Ashdown, leader of the small Liberal Democratic Party. ``The problem is the prime minister.'' Some commentators had predicted the Howe resignation because of a growing divide in the party over Europe. The liberal newspaper The Guardian today called his departure ``the final body blow to the Thatcher government.'' The split over Europe has blown up with the Thatcher government already in deep trouble. For 16 months it has lagged behind the Labor Party in poll ratings, and is now a daunting 16 points behind. The government's unpopularity is mainly over high interest rates, 10.9 percent inflation, a new local government tax that has backfired and criticism of Mrs. Thatcher's rigorous style. In 1986, two Cabinet ministers quit in a dispute over whether a European or U.S. consortium should rescue Britain's ailing Westland helicopter company. Last October, Chancellor of the Exchequer Nigel Lawson resigned over Mrs. Thatcher's stalling on linking the pound to other European currencies. In July, Trade Secretary Nicholas Ridley, whose views were believed close to those of Mrs. Thatcher, was forced to quit after calling moves toward monetary union a ``German racket.'' Howe now reverts to being a rank-and-file legislator, joining the ranks of senior dissidents. They include former Defense Secretary Michael Heseltine, the most popular choice, according to polls, to succeed Mrs. Thatcher. He has also been obliquely criticizing her policy on Europe.

DOC.HEAD: Boston Herald Endorses Silber
DOC.TEXT: The Boston Herald today endorsed Democratic candidate John Silber for governor, saying he can restore the public's lost faith in government. ``John Silber means change,'' the newspaper said. ``And change is what we need.'' The Herald said Republican William Weld's posts as a former U.S. attorney and Justice Department official ``have simply not prepared him for the compex job of running the Commonwealth of Massachusetts.'' ``Over the next four years, the governorship of Massachusetts is certainly no job for the faint of heart,'' the Herald's front-page editorial said. ``John Silber is the right man for the job.'' Weld won The Boston Globe's endorsement Thursday. The Globe also praised Silber - who is on leave as president of Boston University - for his intelligence and competence in his professional field, but faulted him for his ``tart-tongued behavior'' and his ``intimidating tactics.'' It said Weld's leadership style was more likely to get results. The Herald said Silber's rapid rise in popularity is ``a reflection of the public's anger. ``If John Silber has captured the sense of public outrage, he has also captured its sense that anything is possible if you work hard to make it happen.''

DOC.HEAD: Boy Loses Right Eye Following Attack
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Note contents.
DOC.TEXT: A 10-year-old was recovering today from surgery to remove his right eye after he was attacked on his way home from school, a hospital spokesman said. Doctors removed the fourth-grader's eye and wired his jaw on Thursday, in the second operation since the Oct. 22 attack, said spokesman Phil Van Stavern at Children's Hospital of Oklahoma in Oklahoma City. The boy was in fair condition and doing a little walking on his own, Van Stavern said. The boy told police he was walking home from school when a man approached him to ask for help finding a dog. The man chased and caught the boy, who was found later that night in brush near the school. The assailant also lacerated the boy's genitals andcut his other eye. Van Stavern said those injuries would not be permanent. No arrests have been made, police said. Norman is 25 miles south of Oklahoma City.

DOC.HEAD: City Softens Stance on Overweight Police Officers
DOC.TEXT: Three police sergeants who were demoted for being overweight have been reinstated but ordered into a weight-loss program, the police commissioner said. ``We looked into it and determined that it was better to have the people in a weight-loss program and not tie it into their promotions,'' Commissioner Willie L. Williams said. Officers Stephen Guckin, Joseph McGoldrick and John Harkins will still be required to lose weight, but will not have to meet a deadline. The three were promoted in April, but demoted last month when a physical revealed they had not lost weight. The action was taken because the three had signed agreements to lose the weight. Guckin was expected to lose 40 pounds, but lost only 20 to remain at 260. McGoldrick was supposed to lose 28 pounds, but his weight remained stable at 291. Harkins was expected to lose 100 pounds, but lost only two and weighs 313. Five other officers promoted under the same agreement either met their required goals or came close and were not disqualified. All officers will be required to take a physical every two years and any officer found overweight will be assigned to a weight-loss program, announced Williams and John Shaw, president of Fraternal Order of Police Lodge 5.

DOC.HEAD: U.N. Commissioner Resigns Early in Term
DOC.TEXT: The U.N. high commissioner for refugees, Thorvald Stoltenberg, said today he is resigning less than a year into his five-year term to become Norway's foreign minister. Stoltenberg, 59, who was foreign minister from 1987 to 1989, said he was taking the change because it comes at a ``critical moment for Norway.'' His resignation after 10 months in office came as a shock to the agency, which is facing its biggest refugee crisis ever and has been recovering from low staff morale under its previous leadership. U.N. Secretary-General Javier Perez de Cuellar will nominate Stoltenberg's successor. There was no immediate indication who that would be. The U.N. High Commission for Refugees supervises programs for 15 million refugees worldwide, including 5 million Afghans in Iran and Pakistan, about 2 million in southern Africa and the Horn of Africa, and many in southeast Asia. The agency, which won the Nobel Peace Prize in 1954 and 1981, has been in dire financial straits and last month approved an 11-percent cut in next year's budget, to $345.5 million. The U.N. General Assembly approved Stoltenberg, then Norway's U.N. ambassador in New York, as high commissioner on Nov. 20. He was the only candidate nominated by Perez de Cuellar for the post, which was vacated by Jean-Pierre Hocke of Switzerland under a cloud of suspicion and criticism. Hocke resigned over charges that he used a special education fund for refugees to upgrade his air travel to first class. He was also criticized for alleged financial mismanagement and favoritism, but he denied wrongdoing and nothing was proven. Stoltenberg is an attorney of international law and also served as Norwegian defense minister. He is a key adviser to Prime Minister-elect Gro Harlem Brundtland and a respected and popular politician in Norway. Refugee organizations in Norway immediately criticized his move. ``It is letting down the refugees, and I must protest it strongly,'' Annette Thommessen, head the Norwegian Association of Asylum Seekers, told the national news agency NTB.

DOC.HEAD: A Revival of Gershwin's `Oh, Kay!' Opens on Broadway
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Adds 5 grafs with what other critics said. No PMs planned.
DOC.TEXT: The title tells all. ``Oh, Kay!'' is OK, a modestly successful and often engaging adaptation of the 1926 George and Ira Gershwin musical, which opened Thursday at Broadway's Richard Rodgers Theater. That may not be enough for Broadway where only the powerhouse, not the pleasant, survive. Producer David Merrick most likely was hoping to repeat the success of his last show, ``42nd Street,'' the quintessential 1930s movie musical that director Gower Champion brought to life on stage. In fact, there are echoes of his production in this revival, directed and choreographed by Dan Siretta, who usually resides at the Goodspeed Opera House in Connecticut. The big dance finale in ``Oh, Kay!,'' done to two virtually unknown Gershwin songs, ``Show Me the Town'' and ``Sleepless Nights,'' harks back to Champion's show. A somewhat different version of ``Oh, Kay!'' was done at Goodspeed several years ago. Siretta's production was adapted by James Racheff from the original book by Guy Bolton and P.G. Wodehouse. What Siretta and Racheff have done is turn ``Oh, Kay!'' into an all-black musical, transplanting the story of bootleggers and chorus cuties from Long Island to Harlem. The change does work and serves as an excuse to bring on three sensational dancers - Gregg Burge, Kevin Ramsey and Stanley Wayne Mathis. These men can move. Burge, who does his signature high kick throughout the show, can earn applause just by hopping across the stage. Ramsey leads the chorus in the musical's one big show stopper - well, more like a show finisher, since it ends the first act - a rousing religious revival version of ``Clap Yo' Hands.'' And Mathis swivels his way through ``Fidgety Feet'' with style. Siretta's energetic choreography has a show biz savvy just right for the spirited music. He's never at a loss for a strut, jump, split, Charleston or a tap dance - particularly a tap. They pop up with regularity throughout the evening. Only when he is forced to deal with long stretches of dialogue does Siretta's perpetual motion machine slow down. The book shows its age, despite Racheff's tinkering. The jokes are more than old. These gags had whiskers the day they were written. But that doesn't stop Helmar Augustus Cooper, who barrels through the role of bootlegger turned butler with a comic finesse that would have made the show's original funny man, Victor Moore, break out in giggles. The fun falters when the action shifts to leading lady Angela Teek. Kay, the title character, needs to break your heart when she sings ``Someone to Watch Over Me,'' the evening's best known song. Teek belts the blues out of it, but the result is emotionally barren and unaffecting. As for Teek's acting, she mugs more than emotes. The musical's handsome curly-haired playboy hero is played by Brian Mitchell with a Johnny Mathis croon. Mitchell gets to sing one of the show's oddities, an unknown, unpublished Gershwin song called ``Ask Me Again.'' It shouldn't remain unknown for long. The rest of the Gershwin score remains as heavenly as ever, including ``Maybe,'' ``Do, Do, Do'' and ``Dear Little Girl.'' There's an honest emotion and sweet simplicity to Ira Gershwin's lyrics that the years have not reduced to cliches. And George Gershwin's melodies, ranging from sassy to sentimental, sound wonderful in Arnold Goland's orchestrations. The settings by Kenneth Foy underwhelm but then much of the action takes place in the playboy's Harlem living room. To compensate, the costumes by Theoni Aldredge are star-spangled opulent with a heavy dose of sequins. In the end, the production is buoyed by that glorious Gershwin music and those three fabulous dancers. When they fly high, so does the musical. When they are off-stage, ``Oh, Kay!'' shows its age. What other critics said: Frank Rich, The New York Times: ``This loose adaptation of the Gershwins' 1926 musical is a chintzy, innocuous slab of stock that is likely to leave more than a few theatergoers shrugging their shoulders and asking `Didn't I doze through that a couple of summers ago in a barn?''' Linda Winer, Newsday: ``For anyone who has been pining for the thrill of dancing feet, kicky old songs and plenty of bugle beads, there is news on Broadway for a change. Producer David Merrick, ailing and considered out of commission for much of the decade since `42nd Street,' has roared back with an adaptation of `Oh, Kay!' ... that is both taut and easygoing - and a lesson on how to make a fluff-ball old musical move.'' Howard Kissel, the Daily News: ``For the last 40 years, David Merrick has operated on a principle many producers (and even critics) either do not know, ignore or have forgotten: People go to the theater, especially the Broadway theater, to have a good time. They certainly will at `Oh, Kay!''' Clive Barnes, New York Post: ``Looking back, I am not at all sure that in my heart of hearts I expected to enjoy this all-new `Oh, Kay!' at all - and I am absolutely positive that I never expected to enjoy it this much. The evergreen Gershwins, the ever-hopeful Siretta, and yes, the large-named Mr. Merrick (welcome back, David), have given us an enchanted, delicious evening.''

DOC.HEAD: Church Opens Grave of Former Haitian Slave Up for Sainthood
DOC.TEXT: Anecdotes and facts about the life of a former Haitian slave who's being considered for sainthood so far have been easier to unearth than his bones. Before Cardinal John O'Connor turned the first shovelful of dirt Thursday on what's thought to be the grave of Pierre Toussaint, church and medical officials said they hoped to find a casket or a skeleton. But three hours of digging at a Manhattan cemetery produced only bits and pieces of bones that cannot yet be confirmed to belong to Toussaint, whose life drew the highest praise from O'Connor as he blessed the grave during a brief ceremony. ``It would be magnificent if it could eventually be determined that he deserves to be a saint,'' O'Connor told about 100 spectators who were kept from the grave by police barricades on All Saints Day. ``He was a very holy man. I wish I were as holy as he,'' the cardinal said at Old St. Patrick's Church Cemetery in the city's Little Italy section. Toussaint was buried there after his death in 1853 at age 87. By midafternoon, workmen had found part of a jaw with teeth that probably belonged to a man, said Dr. Victor Tchertkoff, acting chairman of the Department of Pathology at New York Medical College. He said it would be given to an anthropological pathologist for examination. He said other small bones appeared to be from human ribs. ``We were hoping for more of a person but we didn't get what we hoped for. Wait until tomorrow. Tomorrow is another day,'' said Tchertkoff. For decades, historians have been studying the life of Toussaint, whose last name means ``all saints.'' Court papers filed to get permission for exhumation called Toussaint a ``model of charity.'' He is considered the founder of Catholic Charities because he helped the needy for 66 years when no formal systems of assistance existed. Shortly after workers began digging Thursday, several children darted through the barricades to pocket fistfuls from the growing mound of earth as keepsakes. The bones must be positively identified so that the Vatican may distribute some of them or his personal items to Haiti or prominent places of worship. The examination of his remains is a preliminary step during the period of investigation and examination of his life. The examination occurs before he is considered for beatification, only an early step in the overall process, which could take years. Church officials said it was likely that the remains of Toussaint, his wife and stepdaughter were buried in the grave in wooden coffins that would have disintegrated. Each shovelful of dirt was carefully combed for bones. Tiny pieces of pottery, shells and animal bones also were found. ``It could take days yet,'' said Joseph Zwilling, a church spokesman, of the quest to find the remains. Toussaint was born a slave in Haiti in 1766 and moved to New York with his owner's family in 1787. He became one of the city's leading hairdressers and was allowed to keep some of his income. When Toussaint's owner died, leaving his wife and child impoverished, Toussaint secretly supported them for about 20 years. The widow freed Toussaint from slavery shortly before she died in 1807. The church is investigating two miracles attributed to Toussaint: the recovery of a young Haitian with cancer who refused medical care and relied solely on prayers to Toussaint and a Miami woman's claim he cured her breast cancer.

DOC.HEAD: Pilot Safe After Around-the-World Floatplane Trip
DOC.TEXT: A pilot who landed his floatplane in the North Pacific while completing the last leg of an around-the-world flight was safe aboard a fishing vessel today. The Coast Guard was trying to determine whether his aircraft is worth salvaging. Petty Officer Jeff Roberts said pilot Tom Casey was safely aboard the fishing vessel Judy B, about 22 miles west of Kiska Island in the western Aleutians. ``He's in good shape, excellent condition,'' Roberts said. ``The last report we have is that the aircraft has a punctured pontoon but is upright and floating. I guess he had some engine problems. . .. Any decision about salvage will be made when the cutter arrives.'' Lt. Susan Hargiss said Casey alerted Coast Guard crews in Juneau that he was in trouble shortly after 1:30 p.m. Thursday. A short time later, Casey was spotted by a Coast Guard C-130 transport plane responding to a distress signal from an emergency locator beacon. Casey, 53, was unharmed and remained with his craft, the Liberty II, while crews circled above late Thursday, Hargiss said. He is a Seattle-based pilot who was trying to complete a record around-the-world flight by landing only on water. He was the first person to make the flight from Japan to Attu in a single-engine floatplane since Charles Lindbergh logged the trip decades ago, the Coast Guard said. Casey had landed his plane on oceans, and the lakes and rivers of 20 nations. His around-the-world plan temporarily was stymied in Anchorage during the summer when he was unable to gain travel clearances from the Soviets.

DOC.HEAD: Military Takes Island Without Rebel Resistance
DOC.TEXT: Tamil rebels abandoned without a fight their stronghold on Mannar Island off Sri Lanka's northwest coast, military officials said Friay. Two thousand government troops in amphibious landing craft moved in Thursday, supported by gunboats and air cover, said the officials, speaking on condition of anonymity. But there was no sign of the rebels. ``We feel the Tamil terrorists bolted because the terrain of Mannar Island does not give any encouragement for guerrilla warfare,'' one official said. Soldiers sweeping the island recovered a large number of abandoned vehicles, including an ambulance, but saw no guerrillas, the officials said. There was no word on the government landing from the Liberation Tigers for Tamil Eelam, who maintain offices in Paris and London. The rebels have fought a seven-year war for a homeland for the Tamil minority in the north and east of Sri Lanka. The Tigers had established a stronghold on the island, blowing up a causeway and cutting off access from the Sri Lankan mainland. The island, 140 miles northwest of Colombo, is the closest point to India's south coast. About 60 percent of the island's 100,000 residents are Tamils, mostly Christians making a living from fishing. The rest are Moslems. Last week the Tigers posted warnings to Moslems, telling them to leave the island or be killed. Moslem refugees claimed the rebels stripped them of all their valuables before forcing them off the island at gunpoint. Deputy Defense Minister Ranjan Wijeratne said 50,000 Moslem refugees had fled Mannar and the northern Jaffna peninsula, the rebel stronghold. Moslems, who make up 7 percent of Sri Lanka's 16 million people, often have been victims of the ethnic war between the Tamil minority and the Sinhalese majority. Tamils make up 18 percent of the population. Sinhalese comprise 75 percent, and control the government and military. More than 14,000 people have died after Tamil militia launched the separatist war in 1983.

DOC.HEAD: Atwater Says He Has `Found Jesus'
DOC.TEXT: Lee Atwater, who was accused of negative campaigning as head of George Bush's presidential campaign, says he has turned to the Lord since being diagnosed with cancer. ``I have found Jesus Christ. It's that simple. He's made a difference, and I'm glad I've found him while there's still time,'' the Republican National Committee chairman said in an interview published Friday in The State newspaper. Atwater, who was diagnosed with an inoperable brain tumor in March, said he wants to world to know about his spiritual conversion. ``I don't hate anybody anymore. For the first time in my life, I don't hate somebody. I have nothing but good feelings toward people. It's just no point in fighting and feuding,'' he said. Atwater made rapist Willie Horton a household name and turned the Pledge of Allegiance into an attack on Democratic candidate Michael Dukakis during the 1988 presidential campaign. ``Since I have been ill, I have found more honest, decent people who have gotten in touch with me, that have held values that I never knew existed,'' said Atwater, a South Carolina native. Atwater said he has been making peace with former foes, Democrats and Republicans. He said he has written letters of repentance and asked people for forgiveness. In a letter this summer to Columbia attorney Tom Turnipseed, Atwater said one of the ``low points'' in his political career was the ``jumper cables'' comment he made regarding Turnipseed's shock treatment for depression. ``My hope is that you will grant a sick man a favor and try to forget it. ... There are a very few people I need to get square with, and you're one of them,'' Atwater wrote. ``Tom, this is very sincere,'' he said he added as a postscript.

DOC.HEAD: Man Fatally Stabs Four Children, Remains at Large
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 3 grafs after 2nd graf to UPDATE with sheriff identifying suspect, neighbors giving his age and name and location of mother. Picks up 3rd graf pvs, `Hankins said...'
DOC.TEXT: Police said today they were searching for a man who crashed through a bedroom door at his mother's home, stabbed four small children to death and injured three others. ``He went for the little ones, ages 1 to 5, in a back bedroom,'' said Leflore County Coroner James Hankins. ``I found them on the floor and all had been stabbed in the neck with a sharp instrument.'' Webster County Sheriff Bill Middleton said Henry Curtis Jackson of West Point was wanted on four counts of murder and three counts of attempted murder. ``He probably believes he killed all seven of them,'' Middleton said. Neighbors said the 26-year-old Jackson's mother, Martha, was at church when the attack occurred. Hankins said the injured included a woman slashed in the abdomen and two children wounded in the neck. The coroner said the man being sought in the slayings was believed to be the father and uncle of the children, while the wounded woman was the mother of at least two of the children. ``They all have the same last name and we're trying to sort them all out,'' Hankins said. ``I've been in this business for 28 years and this is as bad as I've seen.'' Two survivors of the attack said the man entered the home and argued with the occupants before pulling a knife and knocking down a door to get to the children, police said. Neighbors were alerted when one victim ran from the home and called for help, Hankins said. More than 100 friends and neighbors in the low-income, Rising Sun Community - about two miles south of Greenwood - quickly gathered, he said. The suspect left in a car belonging to one of the victims, ran a stop sign and wrecked the car in Eupora, about 65 miles east of Greenwood, about 10:30 p.m., police said. The suspect fled before officers arrived at the wreck. Officials then brought in officers from area law enforcement agencies, called off school today in Eupora and told residents to lock their doors. ``Right now, they're concentrating the search in an area just north of town,'' said Roger Miller, police chief in nearby Mathiston. He said tracking dogs and at least one helicopter were being used. ``They think he is on foot and still in the area,'' Miller said. ``We're getting assistance from just about everywhere.'' Regina Fay Jackson, 23, was listed in stable condition with multiple stab wounds in the Greeenwood Leflore County Hospital, said spokeswoman Tricia Chick. Sarah D. Jackson, 11, was listed in serious but stable condition with stab wounds, Chick said. Andrea Alice Jackson, 1, was transferred to the University Medical Center in Jackson where spokeswoman Barbara Austin said the child was in surgery at mid-morning. The names of the dead were not immediately available, Hankins said.

DOC.HEAD: Incumbent Republican Fighting for Survival
DOC.TEXT: Democrat Mike Kopetski was just 707 votes away from upsetting incumbent Rep. Denny Smith in 1988. This year, with an assist from the savings and loan crisis, he may succeed. Smith is considered the most vulnerable House member in Tuesday's elections, according to Roll Call, a Capitol Hill newspaper. ``We're the underdog, but we're bouncing back up,'' the Oregon Republican said. ``We're in a very tight race.'' A poll released Friday appears to support Smith's contention that Tuesday's vote will be close. Kopetski was favored by 50 percent of those interviewed in a poll commissioned by The Oregonian newspaper, while Smith was supported by 46 percent. The margin of error was 4 percentage points. That's a significant gain for Kopetski, who was chosen by 41 percent of those interviewed in August, while 47 percent favored Smith. The margin of error in that survey also was 4 percentage points. Kopetski is hammering away at Smith's connections with several savings and loans, contending there were improprieties with the lawmaker's role. Smith, a five-term incumbent, denies any wrongdoing, saying he only went to bat for S&L directors who were being hounded by federal regulators. ``I don't have anything to hide,'' Smith said. He was a director of the American Federal Savings and Loan Association in Salem from 1977 to 1987. The thrift, in danger of being seized by federal regulators, merged with Home Federal Savings and Loan and Smith was forced off the board. ``People are just plain mad over the fact that Congress and the Bush administration have failed to aggressively go after people who still have the bucks from this national scandal,'' Kopetski said. ``They know Denny Smith helped to create this scandal.'' The House Democratic Campaign Committee filed a complaint with the House ethics committee accusing Smith of violating ethics rules by using his office for personal gain in dealings involving S&Ls. Smith called the filing a ``dirty trick'' instigated by Kopetski and asked for quick handling of the complaint. But House leaders decided there wasn't enough time to discuss it before Congress adjourned Oct. 27. On another issue, Smith accuses Kopetski of ``cozying up'' to Saddam Hussein because the Democrat questioned the U.S. military deployment in the region after Iraq invaded Kuwait. Smith used radio ads, with the voice of Adolf Hitler in the background, to suggest that Kopetski wanted to appease aggressors. Kopetski, who served in the Oregon House from 1985 to 1987, calls that ridiculous and says Smith has been waging a name-calling, negative campaign in an attempt to divert attention from his own conduct involving S&Ls.

DOC.HEAD: Halloween Fires, Arson Arrests Up This Year in Detroit
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New throughout to UPDATE with mayor announcing arson and arrest figures, meeting with volunteers.
DOC.TEXT: More fires were set and more arson arrests made this year than last during the three-day Devil's Night period, Detroit's annual Halloween arson spree, Mayor Coleman Young said today. There were 281 fires during the period from Tuesday through Thursday compared with 223 a year ago, Young said in a midday news conference. On Devil's Night itself, there were 141 fires, up from 115 on Oct. 30, 1989. Thirteen families comprising 29 people were left homeless by the arson, the city said. ``That is still too many fires. But clearly, it was a long way from being the worst night since 1984, as one highly exaggerated report put it,'' Young said in a statement. ``Clearly, we have come a long way from 1984, when we experienced 810 fires during the last three days of October.'' Young said police arrested 22 people on arson charges between Monday and Thursday. Last year, police made eight arrests during that period. A 6 p.m. to 6 a.m. curfew from Monday through Thursday for juveniles led to 326 arrests compared with 378 last year. The mayor called together representatives of dozens of block clubs and community organizations that mobilized to fight the firebugs. He read the names of every group that took part in combatting the fires. On an average day, 60 fires are reported in the city.

DOC.HEAD: Lawmaker Detained, Expelled from Troubled Township
DOC.TEXT: Police on Friday briefly detained a member of Parliament after he refused orders to leave a township declared an unrest area, and officers used tear gas to disperse onlookers. The lawmaker, Jan van Eck of the liberal opposition Democratic Party, was released after a few hours. Police escorted him out of Khayelitsha, one of three black townships placed under strict security measures Thursday. There was a low-level police presence in the townships on Friday compared with the previous day, when officers set up roadblocks and checked vehicles entering for weapons. There were no police blocking the road when van Eck drove into Khayelitsha at midday with a delegation of the African National Congress. Khayelitsha and the neighboring townships of Crossroads and Lingulethu were placed under 9 p.m. to 4 a.m. curfews Thursday. Security tightened under special measures giving police wider powers to prevent demonstrations and other protests such as work boycotts. In the township, van Eck visited the home of an anti-apartheid leader. Police Maj. Gen. P.C. Fourie said he was told to leave when he began addressing a crowd. But he refused to do so and was taken away in a police van. Fourie said a crowd of about 100 people began rioting during van Eck's arrest, and police used tear gas to restore order. No injuries were reported. In other unrest-related incidents, police Friday said 11 people were injured when Zulu and Xhosa miners battled at a mine in Natal Province. Thousands of blacks have died in Natal in factional fighting involving supporters of the Zulu-based Inkatha Freedom Party and Xhosas and other blacks backing the African National Congress. Both groups oppose apartheid but differ on tactics for fighting it. Also in Natal, four people were shot to death in various incidents, and the body of a man who had been stabbed was found in a township outside Johannesburg, police said Friday. The mine clash and shootings occurred Thursday. In other developments: -Delegations from the Inkatha Freedom Party and the right-wing Conservative Party met for the first time since 1986.
