Both sides called the talks fruitful but did not elaborate. -Home Affairs Minister Gene Louw announced that special travel documents allowing political exiles entrance to South Africa will be issued to speed their return. Louw spoke a day after the government said it was ready to begin releasing political prisoners and allowing the large-scale return of exiles in accordance with an earlier agreement with the ANC.

DOC.HEAD: Four Movies Made by Will Rogers to be Released on Video
DOC.TEXT: Four of Will Rogers' classic comedies from the 1930s will be released on video early next year, officials said Friday. James Griffiths, senior vice president for 20th Century Fox, announced the plans in Oologah, where residents of the humorist's hometown were celebrating Will Rogers Days. Rogers, who was born 111 years ago Sunday, made 20 talking movies. He died in a 1935 plane crash in Alaska. The four movies are among 2,000 old classics stored away in a California movie library. Griffiths said the release, a joint project of 20th Century Fox and CBS-Fox Video, was prompted by Jimmy Rogers, the humorist's son. ``He is never remembered as an actor,'' Rogers said. ``I asked dad about his career once and he said he thought of himself as an actor. This is why we are happy to have these come out.'' The four movies - ``Ambassador Bill,'' ``A Connecticut Yankee,'' ``Mr. Skitch'' and ``Doubting Thomas'' - were picked as a representation of Rogers' works.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
ROCHESTER: Fitzwater said.
DOC.TEXT: Bush will leave Nov. 16 and return to Washington Nov. 23. He will spend Thanksgiving Day with the troops in the Gulf region. While in the region he will consult with King Fahd, Egypt's President Hosni Mubarak and the exiled emir of Kuwait, fitzwater said in a statement. Bush will stop first in Prague on Nov. 17 to help celebrate Czechoslovakia's turn to democracy, and will meet there with President Vaclav Havel. On Nov. 18, he will continue on to Ludwigshafen, Germany, to meet with Chancellor Helmut Kohl at his residence, before going to Paris for the Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe. Plans are to complete an agreement for conventional arms reduction at the conference of the 35-nation organization. Before the announcement of Bush's Persian Gulf trip, the president campaigned for Republican candidates in Ohio. In Cincinnati, he mixed themes of war, peace and politics, promising to drive Saddam Hussein from Kuwait while holding out the hope of bringing U.S. troops home ``without a shot being fired.'' Bush told: 2nd graf a0539

DOC.HEAD: Psychologist Says Iraqi President Achieving A Dream
DOC.TEXT: Three months after seizing Kuwait, Iraqi President Saddam Hussein has what he always has wanted - a place ``at the very center of power, commanding world events, with the entire world's attention focused on him,'' according to an expert on Saddam's behavior. Those who hope that Saddam will retreat meekly from Kuwait in the face of moralistic pronouncements from abroad won't find much comfort in the analysis of Dr. Jerrold M. Post, a George Washington University expert on political psychology. ``In pursuit of his Messianic dreams, there is no evidence he is constrained by conscience,'' says Post, who during a long prior career in the U.S. government founded the Center for the Analysis of Personality and Political Behavior. ``When there is an obstacle in his revolutionary path, Saddam eliminates it, whether it is a previously loyal subordinate or a previously supportive country. ``In pursuing his goals, Saddam uses aggression instrumentally. He uses whatever force is necessary and will, if he deems it expedient, go to the extremes of violence, including the use of weapons of mass destruction.'' That view of a penchant for heavy-handed rule is substantiated by David Korn, who has written about Saddam's human rights performance for a rights monitoring group, Middle East Watc. Political killings, Korn says, have become ``a hallmark of the Baath regime'' that Saddam heads. Both Korn and Post have said that in 1982, Saddam's health minister was arrested after suggesting that Saddam step down. They said that after the minister's wife pleaded with Saddam for permission to see him, his body arrived at her doorstep in a sack, chopped to pieces. Judging by the results, Post believes the politics of mass terror at home and abroad have served Saddam well. ``He clears his throat and the Dow Jones average drops 60 points, he smiles and it goes up 60 points,'' says Post. Post says the major influence on Saddam's life was a maternal uncle who imbued Saddam with a hatred of foreigners and notions of Arab nationalism. The uncle's world view was summed up in a pamphlet he wrote years ago: ``Three Whom God Should Not Have Created: Persians, Jews and Flies.'' Post praised President Bush's handling of the Persian Gulf crisis, and said he believes that Saddam is prudent enough to realize when retreat might be his wisest course. Post points out that Saddam showed flexibility last August when he returned 700 square miles of territory to Iran after vowing he would ``never'' take such a step. ``Never is a short time when revolutionary pragmatism dictates, important to remember in evaluating Saddam's vow never to relinquish Kuwait,'' Post says. At the same time, Post says any such retreat probably would only be temporary. ``If in response to the unified demonstration of strength and resolve he does reverse his course, it is a certainty he will return at a later date, unless strong measures are taken to contain him,'' he says.

DOC.HEAD: American Airlines Jetliner Makes Emergency Landing
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Updates with safe landing, 225 aboard.
DOC.TEXT: Mechanical problems on an American Airlines jumbo jet carrying 225 passengers forced an unscheduled stop on a flight from London to Dallas, but the plane landed safely at Kennedy International Airport. The plane had a wing flap that would not contract and may have blown a tire on takeoff from London's Gatwick Airport, said Tim Smith, an airline spokesman in Fort Worth, Texas. He said there were reports that the rubber, or something from the tire, dented a flap on the right wing. The extended flap caused drag that used up extra fuel, so the plane was diverted to Kennedy as a precaution, he said. After circling Kennedy to burn off fuel, the plane landed safely about 1:30 p.m. EST. The plane had been scheduled to reach Dallas at 3:50 p.m. EST. Federal Aviation Administration spokeswoman JoAnn Sloan identified the plane as Flight 51.

DOC.HEAD: More Americans to Be Freed; Bush to Visit Troops for Thanksgiving
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 11 grafs to UPDATE with interviews with hostages, Bush to visit American troops at Thanksgiving. Pickup 9th pvs, `Saddam refused...'
DOC.HEAD: With PM-Gulf-Embargo, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Diplomats said today that four more Americans in Iraq will probably be freed this weekend, and the White House announced that President Bush will visit America's troops in the Persian Gulf for Thanksgiving. Iraqi officials, meanwhile, today allowed foreign reporters to interview hostages from the United States, Britain and Japan. With the Iraqi officials standing nearby, the captives said they eagerly want to go home but denied reports they are being mistreated. ``I love freedom. When I get out of this and go home, I'll go to the beaches and have a nice swim,'' said a man who identified himself as Clem J. Hell, an educator from Takoma Park, Md. Baghdad has offered to allow hostage relatives to travel to Iraq for the holidays, and Iraqi officials reacted angrily today to U.S. and British efforts to discourage hostage families from accepting the offer. In another development, Saudi sources said Syria is to send more land troops to Saudi Arabia, bringing its contribution to 15,000 soldiers and 300 tanks. There had been fears that Syria might withdraw from the multinational force against Iraqover U.S. arms shipments to Israel. The White House announced that Bush will travel to Saudi Arabia to visit some of the tens of thousands of U.S. troops who were sent to the Middle East after Iraq invaded Kuwait and later annexed the oil-rich emirate. The White House said Bush will also stop in Egypt when he heads to the Persian Gulf region after a trip to Paris for the Nov. 19-21 Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe. During a campaign in Cincinnati earlier today President Bush promised to drive Saddam Hussein from Kuwait while at the same time holding out hope that the United States could bring its troops home ``without a shot being fired.'' Bush also told a GOP rally: ``Saddam Hussein must get out, and he must get out totally, and the legitimate rulers must be returned.'' Bush suggested Thursday that in some forms of brutality, the Iraqi president had surpassed even Hitler - raising some eyebrows by comparing Saddam to the man who ordered the extermination of millions of people in World War II. Today marked the beginning of the fourth month of the Persian Gulf crisis, which started when Iraq invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2. Saddam refused to let foreigners leave both nations when the United Nations retaliated by imposing a trade embargo on Iraq and the United States began sending more than 200,000 troops to the region. In announcing plans to free four sick and elderly Americans, Iraqi Information Minister Latif Jassim denied the captives were being treated badly. A U.S. official in Baghdad today identified the four to be freed as Randall Trinh, 49, of Hacienda Heights, Calif.; Dr. Abdul Kangi, 50, of Glencoe, a Chicago suburb; Raymond Gales, a diplomat stationed in Kuwait and now in Baghdad; and Michael Barnes. Trinh, a Vietnamese American, is suffering from an acute ulcer and Gales had unspecified medical problems, the official said on condition he not be further identified. No details were given on Barnes and it was not known whether Kangi was sick. Kangi, and Indian American, was on a holy piligrimage when the crisis started. The official Iraqi News Agency said the government was acting on a petition from the Arab-American Reconciliation Society. Diplomats, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said the men would not leave Baghad before Saturday, when government offices reopen and paperwork can be processed. Friday is the Moslem sabbath. Thousands of foreigners, including about 1,000 Americans, remain in Iraq and Kuwait. Iraq has selectively freed hundreds of them. The latest mass release was of about 300 French nationals this week. Iraq has said relatives of the hostages should come visit them over the holidays, but Western governments have responded skeptically and advised citizens not to travel to Iraq. The Iraqi Foreign Ministry today criticized that reaction, saying that the United States and Britain ``have no respect for human values.'' Jassim said these governments ``are totally inhumane.'' The British Foreign Office asked relatives not to go, but 10 wives of British hostages said they will fly to Iraq next week to seek their husbands' freedom. Other relatives welcomed Iraq's offer to let them visit at Christmas. ``We know our husbands are suffering, and we just want to go back and rescue them,'' said Dorothy Goodwin, leader of the group of wives. On Thursday, Jassim insisted that ``all the Americans at sites have complete freedom.'' ``They can watch TV, read books and read newspapers. They also enjoy the friendship of Iraqi forces,'' he said. Bush denounced the hostage-holding on Thursday and criticized Saddam with his harshest accusations yet. ``They have committed ourageous acts of barbarism,'' Bush said of Saddam's forces. ``Brutality - I don't believe that Adolf Hitler ever participated in anything of that nature.'' ``The brutality against innocent citizens will not be tolerated and will not stand,'' he told an audience in Burlington, Mass. The remark about Hitler surprised some people in the audience. Bush was asked later at his Florida news conference whether his comparison might be overdrawn. ``I don't think I'm overstating it,'' he replied. The president said he believed that ``Hitler did not stake people out against military targets and he did indeed respect the legitimacy of the embassies.''

DOC.HEAD: Woman On Trial For Using Men's Room at Concert
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 7 grafs to UPDATE with trial resuming; prosecution ending its case and judge considering motion; Picks up 9th graf, ``Quite frankly ...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto HT2 of Nov. 1
DOC.TEXT: The prosecution rested its case today against a woman accused of illegally using a men's restroom at a country-western concert because the line was too long for the women's room. Defense attorney Valorie Wells Davenport asked the judge to order an acquittal for her client and sister, Denise Wells. Municipal Judge Francelia Totty was considering the motion early this afternoon. Ms. Wells, a 33-year-old legal secretary, is on trial on misdemeanor charges of violating a city ordinance. The law bars members of one sex from using a public restroom designed for members of the opposite sex in a manner calculated to cause a disturbance. She faces a maximum $200 fine if convicted. Ms. Davenport said the case has generated national attention because the issue ``is something that's touched all our lives.'' ``It's not a gender-based thing. It's common fairness,'' she said Thursday, when attorneys seated a jury and began testimony. Ms. Davenport said Ms. Wells used the men's room out of desperation because the women's room line was too long. The attorney told her sister not to talk to the media, and she called the prosecution ``a silly waste of taxpayer money.'' ``Quite frankly, I always thought Texas was big enough to come to a lady in distress and dismiss charges like these,'' she said. ``We have four brothers. Denise grew up using the men's room.'' Police Officer Daniel B. Ramsey testified Thursday that he was working as a security guard July 7 at a concert at The Summit by country-western star George Strait when he saw Ms. Wells coming out of a men's room stall. ``She said in a voice that could be heard to the front of the restroom, `There - I left the lid up, just like y'all like it,''' Ramsey said. ``I think she was extremely embarrassed when she made that remark,'' Ms. Davenport said during a recess. Under cross-examination, Ramsey said there were 20 women in a line stretching into the hallway waiting to enter the women's room. The line of people waiting to use the men's room did not reach past the door, he said.

DOC.HEAD: People in the News
LaserPhoto NY44
DOC.TEXT: Bob Stern, the 5-foot-2 president of Short Sizes Inc., wanted to show that short men can dress for success, so four years ago he started developing the list of the ``10 Best-Dressed Shorter Men in America.'' At the top of the clothier's list this year: actors Tom Cruise and Michael J. Fox and White House Chief of Staff John Sununu. Cruise and Sununu are the tallest on the list. Both are 5-foot-9, the maximum height for the list. Stern said Cruise is a trendsetter who has turned black sunglasses and black silk shirts into a national passion, while Sununu ``never beats around the bush'' in both politics and dress. Fox, 5-foot-5, was named to the list for the third consecutive year for ``charmingly combining a tux jacket and shirt with washed jeans and tennis shoes,'' Stern said. Others listed, in ``descending'' order, are novelist Tom Wolfe and the former host of television's ``This Old House,'' Bob Vila, both 5-foot-8; singer Billy Joel, Broadway actor Robert Morse and Cleveland Mayor Michael R. White, 5-foot-7; gymnast and television sports analyst Bart Connor, 5-foot-6; and actor-director Danny DeVito, 5-foot-1. --- NASHVILLE, Tenn. (AP) - Humorist Minnie Pearl will celebrate her 50th anniversary Saturday night on the Grand Ole Opry, sharing the spotlight with country music pioneer Roy Acuff. Pearl, 78, has requested that Acuff be on stage with her when her golden anniversary on the country music show is observed. ``I want to start it with the curtain going up and Roy Acuff singing `The Wabash Cannonball','' she said. Pearl also asked to spend part of the show sitting center stage on a stool, reminiscing and joking with Acuff, 87, known as ``the king of country music.'' ``I love doing that, because it gives us more time with the audience,'' she said. Acuff is her longtime friend and the only regular Opry performer who started on the show before she did. He started in 1938. The anniversary performance will be broadcast live on cable TV's The Nashville Network from 8 p.m. to 9 p.m. EST. --- ROCHESTER, N.Y. (AP) - Kenny Rogers broke his rule against honoring requests at concerts because someone offered to donate $25,000 to a charity in the country singer's name. Rogers told the audience Wednesday he had received a letter from a man asking Rogers to sing ``Through the Years'' as a surprise for the man's wife on the couple's 11th anniversary. Rogers wrote the man - Jeff Burd, 31, of Edison, N.J. - that he doesn't honor requests. But Burd, a financial consultant, persisted. His second note included an offer to give a check for $25,000 to a charity in Rogers' name. Rogers said he was moved by the gesture. So he sang ``Through the Years,'' and performed a bonus number, ``You Decorated My Life.'' He said the donation would benefit a shelter for the homeless in Athens, Ga., where Rogers lives. So far, he has raised about $150,000 to build the shelter. Burd and his wife, Louvette, flew to Rochester for the concert. Backstage at the Rochester War Memorial, where Rogers was appearing with Dolly Parton, Burd gave his check to Rogers' road manager, Gene Roy. Was the serenade worth $25,000? ``Definitely,'' Burd said. ``Kenny did more than I could ask. I had requested the song from me to my wife, but he sang it for both of us. He did it better than I asked.'' --- NEW YORK (AP) - Maureen O'Boyle will succeed Maury Povich next season on the syndicated ``A Current Affair'' program that Povich has anchored since 1986, a spokesman said Friday. O'Boyle, a Charlotte, N.C., native who began her career at WECT-TV in Wilmington, N.C., currently serves as anchorwoman of the program's weekend edition. She has been anchoring the show's weekday version the last four weeks. Povich, whose contract with the series expires in June, is leaving to co-produce and star in his own talk show. The 51-year-old anchorman is married to CBS News star Connie Chung, who earlier this season decided to postpone her scheduled ``Face to Face With Connie Chung'' series because she wanted to try to have a baby. She is continuing to do ``Face to Face'' specials.

DOC.HEAD: Economy's Forecasting Gauge Plunges Again; Recession Widely Seen
DOC.TEXT: The government's gauge of future economic health dropped 0.8 percent in September, the second straight big decline and the third month without improvement, the Commerce Department said Friday. Many analysts said a national recession not only had arrived but was intensifying. ``The recession has begun,'' said Lawrence A. Hunter, an economist with the U.S. Chamber of Commerce. ``All indications are that the employment report will get worse before it gets better as more companies ... lay off workers and close production facilities.'' ``We're clearly in a recession and the data that we got today and the data we got this week all confirm that the recession is intensifying,'' said Elliott Platt, economic research director for Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette, a New York securities dealer. Though the Bush administration contends the economy is still growing and will continue to do so at least into the new year, the question for many private analysts now is rather how long and severe the contraction will be. In another report pointing toward a weak economy, the Labor Department said Friday that unemployment remained unchanged at 5.7 percent in October but that there were big job losses across the economy. In all, non-farm payrolls lost 70,000 jobs, due mainly to the slumping construction and manufacturing industries, that report said. The Commerce Department reported the 0.8 percent decline in its Index of Leading Economic Indicators following a 1.2 percent August drop for the package of forward-looking statistics. It blends such indicators as buyers' confidence and orders for consumer goods. Three consecutive declines in the index is generally viewed as a strong - although not infallible - sign of an approaching recession. ``You now have two months in a row of negative indicators with the likelihood that October also will be negative,'' Platt said. The index was unchanged in July, but August's decline was the steepest since a 1.4 percent fall a month after the October 1987 stock market crash. Although the index is designed to forecast economic activity six to nine months in advance, many economists agree with Platt that the economy already is in a recession. ``What we had was an economy that was gradually losing momentum, sliding toward a recession ... then got hit with a series of adverse shocks (including the Persian Gulf crisis) which pushed it over the edge very abruptly,'' said Larry Meyer, senior economist with Laurence H. Meyer & Associates, a St. Louis economic forecasting firm. ``That's one reason why we're not getting the advance warning that we otherwise might have gotten,'' he explained. Many analysts predicted the October index also will be down. Platt noted that declines already have been reported for three of the 11 indicators - average workweek, consumer confidence and business delivery times. Mark M. Zandi, an economist with Regional Financial Associates in West Chester, Pa., agreed the October index will be down ``fairly sizably'' and said the September report indicates the economy ``is in for a very severe contraction at least through 1991.'' Other economists, on the other hand, contend a recession will be mild and the economy will pick up by the middle of next year. Nine of the forward-looking indicators dragged the index under in September, while one was unchanged and one improved. Peter Radford of National Westminster Bancorp in New York said the report was discouraging because it was so widespread. ``It's as close as you're going to get to unanimity. It's right across all the sectors ... they are all pointing in the same direction,'' said Radford, who predicted the index would probably show ``more of the same'' in October. Contributing to the September decline were lower stock prices, a decrease in orders for consumer goods, an increase in weekly unemployment claims, a decline in building permits, a drop in an index measuring consumer confidence, a decrease in unfilled orders, a lower money supply, faster business delivery times and a decline in the price of raw materials. The only positive contributor was an increase in orders for new plants and equipment. The average workweek was unchanged. The various changes left the index at 143.3 percent of its 1982 base of 100 an down 1.1 percent from its level a year ago.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
At Least 6 Killed in Ethnic Violence in Soviet Moldavia
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Combines urgent series. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Ethnic tensions exploded into violence in Soviet Moldavia today when armed Moldavian nationalists and ethnic Russians clashed east of the capital, leaving at least six people dead and 30 wounded, Tass said. The casualties occurred in fighting near a village outside Dubossary, a town of at least 10,000 people to the northeast of the republic's capital, Kishniev, Tass said, quoting the Dubossary deputy mayor, Alexander Parajan. A police officer also was wounded in a shootout in Dubossary, and at least 2,000 workers have formed brigades to defend the town's residents, according to Tass, the official Soviet news agency. Dubossary is an area in eastern Moldavia whose predominantly Russian and Ukrainian residents are opposed to Moldavia's secession drive from the Soviet Union. They already have declared an autonomous republic in the heavily non-Moldavian areas along the Dniester River. Their separatist fight intensified last week after another separatist group, the Gagauz minority in the southern corner of the republic, declared autonomy and began holding elections for an independent government. Groups of ethnic Russians and Ukrainians reportedly helped defend the Gagauz against brigades of Moldavian nationalists trying to stop the secession drives. Both groups have accused Moldavians of discriminating against the minorities during Moldavia's own independence drive from the Soviet Union. The Kremlin sent 500 to 800 Interior Ministry troops to the Gagauz region to keep order last week. Today's violence came hours after the Moldavian Supreme Soviet legislature declared a state of emergency in Dubossary and the nearby towns of Tiraspol and Bendery. It had imposed similar rules on the Gagauz area last week. The legislature also voted to form a new Moldavian national guard, separate from the national Interior Ministry troops and its regiments based in Moldavia. Tass said the emergency rules were expanded following reports that ``armed units'' were approached the cities from Kishniev, Parajan said. He did not say who made up the units, Tass reported. Parajan told Tass Dubossary residents were preparing to protect their city. He said people were blocking bridges over the Dniester but gave no details. ``We demand the introduction of Soviet Interior Ministry troops, instead of Kishniev militia or volunteer units,'' Tass quoted Parajan as saying. Gagauz representatives have been negotiating with a joint Moldavian-Soviet committee trying to resolve the standoff in the Gagauz districts. Both sides agreed to pull back their defenders, mostly youths reportedly armed with sticks and metal rods, and to allow the security forces to establish a buffer. There had been no reports of violence since Wednesday, when Moldavians attacked the frontier with Romania, threatening to kill guards and their families unless Soviet forces withdraw. The militants gave up and no casualties were reported. Tass said today that the situation in the Gagauz areas has nearly returned to normal, with Interior Ministry troops remaining at the border but now letting people pass through. ``Industrial enterprises, offices and schools are working normally. Road blocks have been removed...,'' Tass reported.

DOC.HEAD: Only Herself To Blame For Stunning Defeat
DOC.TEXT: Ousted Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto suffered a stunning defeat at the ballot box because she didn't do her homework, not because of large-scale vote tampering, analysts say. Ms. Bhutto's left-leaning Pakistan People's Party was outmaneuvered in the Oct. 24 parliamentary election by the Islamic Democratic Alliance, a right-wing coalition backed by the people who count in Pakistan - the army and the bureaucracy. For the 37-year-old former prime minister, the defeat was humiliating. The People's Party and its three smaller allies won only 45 seats in the 217-member National Assembly, less than half the number they controlled in the last legislature. Most observers and opinion polls predicted a close race. They also were astounded by the magnitude of the victory. The energetic, charismatic former prime minister attracted huge crowds throughout her campaign. But that didn't translate into broad public support for her party or her former government, which was dismissed Aug. 6 on charges of corruption and mismanagement. Ms. Bhutto blamed her defeat on large-scale vote fraud, a charge dismissed by her opponents and three separate and independent teams of observers. While many Pakistanis believe some rigging occurred, they doubt it would have significantly altered the outcome. In the end, they say, she still would have lost. Despite her repeated charges of ``an electoral coup d'etat,'' Ms. Bhutto and her party have yet to produce solid evidence to back up their claims and haven't a clue how the balloting could have been rigged without notice. The People's Party, founded in the late 1960s by Ms. Bhutto's father, former Prime Minister Zulfikar li Bhutto, once represented the most progressive political force in Pakistan. But Ms. Bhutto largely ignored the party machinery once she took the oath in December 1988 as the first woman leader of a modern Moslem nation. She failed to see the modern, well-organized force moving into her path. Supporters say the party badly needs restructuring to challenge the alliance, which is more in tune with the lower and middle classes than the landowning families that have led Pakistan since its creation in 1947. ``Enough mileage has been made out of the pro-poor image that the party earned during the late 1960s,'' political analyst Khalid Mahmud said. ``There is a need to put some substance in the hollow rhetoric before the `have-nots' lose all patience and give the PPP even bigger surprises.'' Since her dismissal three months ago, Ms. Bhutto has proved she's a tenacious fighter, and most analysts believe it's premature to say the spell that she has held over Pakistan for more than a decade has been broken. But critics and supporters alike say she will have to make drastic changes in her outlook and style if she wants to salvage her demoralized party. ``She must descend from the pedestal and pursue alliances that could broaden her support base. She must set aside past arrogance in dealing with the smaller parties, especially those who fought along with the People's Party against dictatorship but were not deemed fit to share the spoils of victory,'' Mahmud said. Ms. Bhutto still faces the most serious challenge of her political career. Some of her opponents admit privately they are making a concerted effort to force her out of politics. Seven charges of mismanagement and abuse of power are pending against her before special one-judge tribunals, and conviction on any one could bar her from political life for seven years. But even some of her right-wing opponents say that would be bad for Pakistan. If country needs a stable government, they said, then it also needs a strong opposition.

DOC.HEAD: San Jose and North Carolina Papers Recognized for Public Service
DOC.TEXT: The Associated Press Managing Editors association presented its 1990 Public Service Awards on Friday to the San Jose (Calif.) Mercury News and the Washington (N.C.) Daily News. The San Jose Mercury News, in the 50,000-and-over circulation category, was selected for its coverage, including public service information, following the Oct. 17 earthquake that devastasted parts of Northern California. The Washington Daily News led those in the under-50,000 circulation class for uncovering the fact that city officials for eight years had known cancer-causing chemicals were in the local tap water. The disclosure resulted in a two-month water ban, an improved treatment system, and state and federal reviews of water regulations. Paul Janensch, editor and general manager of The Journal-News in Rockland County, N.Y., and chairman of the judging panel, presented the plaques at the APME convention here. The other judges, all former presidents of APME, were Larry Allison, senior vice president and editor of the Long Beach (Calif.) Press-Telegram; James F. Daubel, editor and publisher of The News-Messenger of Fremont, Ohio; Robert H. Giles, editor and publisher of The Detroit News; Robert J. Haiman, president of the Poynter Institute for Media Studies, St. Petersburg, Fla.; Ted M. Natt, editor and publisher of The Daily News of Longview, Wash., and Robert E. Rhodes, Atwood Professor of Journalism at the University of Alaska at Anchorage. The other finalists in the 50,000-and-over circulation category were: Albuquerque (N.M.) Journal; Chicago Tribune: The Des Moines (Iowa) Register; The Detroit News; Lexington (Ky.) Herald-Leader; The Courier-Journal of Louisville, Ky.; The Philadelphia Inquirer; Seattle Post-Intelligencer, and The Blade of Toledo, Ohio. Under 50,000-circulation finalists were: The Albuquerque (N.M.) Tribune; The Bismarck (N.D.) Tribune; Star-Tribune of Casper, Wyo.; Columbia (Mo.) Missourian; Livingston (Mont.) Enterprise; The Sun News of Myrtle Beach, S.C.; West County Times of Richmond, Calif.; The Salina (Kan.) Journal, and Valley News Dispatch of Tarentum, Pa.

DOC.HEAD: Rafsanjani Visits Quake Victims, Urges Speedy Re-Housing
DOC.TEXT: President Hashemi Rafsanjani on Friday visited refugees of the earthquake that struck Iran's northern provinces last June, killing 40,000 people and leaving half a million homeless. The Islamic Republic News Agency, monitored in Nicosia, said Rafsanjani called for ``more attention toward permanent settlement'' of the homeless. The quake struck the country's northern Gilan and Zanjan provinces, injuring 60,000 people. Authorities have said that freezing temperatures and heavy snows expected within weeks make providing shelter urgent. Tehran radio reported Thursday that so far only half the homeless refugees had been provided shelter. Rafsanjani urged provincial authorities to speed up water and power supplies, cut by the quake, and to rebuild roads as soon as possible. Roads are the only means of transportation for the more than 1,800 villages devastated by the quake. Gilan's governor-general, Ali Reza Tabesh, told Rafsanjani that ``roads and infra-structural installations had suffered enormous damage,'' IRNA said. It reported him as saying that $30 million had been given to the provinces to rebuild roads and bridges. He also said some 170,000 houses had been destroyed and that industrial damage in the areas totalled about $179 million, the agency said.

DOC.HEAD: The Longest Running Show on Broadway - Sardi's
DOC.TEXT: The curtain went up and the theater crowd came back for the reopening this week of Sardi's, the venerable Manhattan restaurant that has been host to Broadway's stars and stargazers since the days of Prohibition. If the new owner looks familiar, well, he was the old owner. Sardi's is owned by a Sardi again - 75-year-old Vincent Sardi, grandson of the man who founded the 44th Street eatery as a speakeasy in 1921. Vincent had sold the restaurant and retired to Vermont four years ago. The new owners ran into financial problems, and Sardi's closed in July. Vincent, who still had a stake in the restaurant, decided to come out of retirement and run it himself. ``It's basically the old Sardi's - you don't want to change it. It worked before,'' said Sardi. ``I've been to these new places - lavish, but very cold. They spend millions, and the places have no personality.'' Sardi's has multiple personalities - or at least caricatures of them. Sketches of Broadway stars past and present still line the walls at 234 W. 44th Street, where the restaurant sits opposite the Shubert Theater. Since July, passersby were greeted at the front door by a sign which promised, ``Very soon I will reopen Sardi's, The Longest Running Show on Broadway. Vincent Sardi.'' On Thursday night, he made good on that promise. It was like old times at Sardi's - the after-theater crowd filled the place in an opening night party for David Merrick's new show ``Oh, Kay!'' ``All my old customers were here. It was wonderful,'' said Sardi. ``But The Times didn't like the play.'' It's not the first time that's happened at Sardi's, which was once a place for the city's elite to see and be seen. John Barrymore, Helen Hayes and Rex Harrison were among those who frequented the restaurant in the days when the paparazzi monitored the front door nightly. ``If you don't see at least a dozen of the celebrities caricatured on Sardi's walls, it means there's been a strike at Actor's Equity,'' advised the book ``New York on $1,000 A Day.'' Food was not the attraction, as critic Mimi Sheraton made clear in this 1982 review: ``Those who go to the restaurant to observe celebrities will rarely be disappointed. Those that go for good food that is well served will rarely be satisfied. For reasons that remain a mystery, food, service and housekeeping at Sardi's leave almost everything to be desired.'' People still packed the place. While aiming to create the old ambiance, Sardi did spruce things up. He sunk $500,000 into improvements: new carpet, new paint, reupholstered banquettes. Things were allowed to run down by the previous owners, who ran into financial problems, Sardi said. The restaurant opened to the general public Friday, with a healthy lunch crowd and a good number of dinner reservations. Sardi is aware it's a rough market these days, but he's hoping to restore his restaurant to its past glories. ``It's going to be tough. But the name was not tarnished. We had a terrific following, and I hope they'll be back,'' said Sardi. ``We're happy to be back. It's going to be big time.''

DOC.HEAD: Palestinians Strike to Mark Balfour Declaration Anniversary
DOC.TEXT: Palestinians staged a general strike Friday to protest Zionism's first major victory 73 years ago, the Balfour Declaration which offered Britain's support for a Jewish homeland in Palestine. Israeli officials, meanwhile, defended Israel's treatment of Palestinians following criticism by U.N. Secretary-General Javier Perez de Cuellar. But some opposition figures also expressed fears Israel was becoming more isolated from the world community. The strike, called by the fundamentalist movement Hamas, or Zeal, closed shops and halted most public transport in Arab east Jerusalem and the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip. In Jerusalem, police blocked Palestinians from the territories for a fourth week from entering the walled Old City to attend the main Moslem weekly prayers at the Al Aqsa mosque. Officials maintain the step is needed to prevent a repetition of the Oct. 8 riots on the Temple Mount that led to the death of 20 Palestinians in Israeli gunfire and subsequent condemnation of Israel by the U.N. Security Council. At Al Aqsa, Moslem preacher Mohammed Hussein recalled the Balfour Declaration of Nov. 2, 1917, which conditioned Britain's support of a Jewish homeland on the idea that the civil and religious rights of non-Jews would not be harmed. ``We have been deprived of our national rights and now there is no freedom to worship in our own mosque,'' Hussein told several thousand worshipers. In the Gaza Strip, soldiers shot and wounded eight Palestinians, including four who were hit when troops opened fire on stone throwers after noon prayers in Gaza City, Arab reporters said. In reaction to the latest U.N. criticism of Israel, a spokesman for Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir maintained that Israel was ``doing everything'' to ensure the security of the 1.7 million Palestinians in the occupied lands. ``If there is any lack of security it derives from the violent activities of the Arabs against Israelis and their own brethren,'' spokesman Yossi Ahimeir told the daily Davar. Shamir, in an interview for his 75th birthday in the Yedioth Ahronoth, defended his rejection of a Security Council resolution urging a U.N. investigation of the Temple Mount deaths. ``Is is the intervention of the U.N. in Jerusalem. I don't care what they want to investigate. ... The wording of the Security Council resolution harms our security in Jerusalem,'' he said. Israel annexed Arab east Jerusalem after seizing the area in the 1967 Middle East war. Most Western nations, including the United States, do not recognize Israeli sovereignty there. Other officials seemed hesitant to react to Perez de Cuellar's suggestion for an international conference how to protect the Palestinians. The Foreign Ministry scheduled a briefing on the latest U.N. actions, then canceled it after reporters had been waiting for almost an hour. The daily Haaretz quoted unnamed diplomats as saying they feared further Israeli rejection of U.N. moves on Palestinians would erode Israel's support in the world community. Micha Harish, general secretary of the opposition Labor Party, issued a statement rejecting Perez de Cuellar's suggestion but criticizing Shamir for refusing a U.N. investigation of the Temple Mount deaths. ``Shamir is creating unnecessary conficts with the president of the United States and the rest of the nations of the world,'' he said. Perez de Cuellar made the suggestion of calling a meeting of signatory states to the 1949 Geneva Conventions in an 11-page report compiled by the Security Council after the Oct. 8 killings. He said the meeting should consider ways to protect Palestinians since U.N. pleas for Israel to abide by the Conventions on treatment of occupied people had been ``ineffective.'' Israel's U.N. mission rejected the comments as interference, saying Israel has sole control of the occupied territories. Israel maintains the Geneva Conventions do not apply in the West Bank and Gaza, but that it follows the conventions' humanitarian provisions. However, Israel regularly uses punishments forbidden by the conventions, such as deportations and demolition of Palestinian homes. The argument is that these actions have been deemed legal by the Israeli Supreme Court.

DOC.HEAD: Bush to Visit Persian Gulf
DOC.NOTE: EDs: Edits to delete some trip details to shorten; pick up 9th pvs bgng ``Bush told...
DOC.TEXT: President Bush said today he would strive to bring U.S. forces home from the Persian Gulf ``without a shot being fired in anger.'' The White House said the president would visit the troops on Thanksgiving. Bush will travel to Saudi Arabia, also stopping in Egypt, after a trip to Paris for the Nov. 19-21 Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe, White House Press Secretary Marlin Fitzwater said. Bush planned to share Thanksgiving dinner with a few of the 230,000 Americans deployed in the region. Before the announcement of Bush's Persian Gulf trip, the president campaigned for Republican candidates in Ohio. In Cincinnati, he mixed themes of war, peace and politics, promising to drive Saddam Hussein from Kuwait. Bush told a GOP rally: ``Saddam Hussein must get out, and he must get out totally, and the legitimate rulers must be returned.'' It was the fourth day in a row that Bush has sought to press his verbal barrage against the Iraqi leader. But Bush said he had no apologizes for raising the subject at one political rally after another as he seeks to provide last-minute help for GOP candidates in next Tuesday's midterm elections. ``I'll repeat it today, I'll repeat it tomorrow and I'll repeat it the next day,'' Bush declared. Earlier, Bush had urged American hostage families to ignore Saddam's invitation to visit loved ones in captivity, calling it a brutal ``ploy.'' ``I think those people should come home to visit with their families. I think they should be released from captivity,'' Bush said Thursday. He suggested the Iraqi leader had surpassed even Adolf Hitler in some forms of brutality. Today, Bush told his Ohio audience: ``Let me be very clear. There cannot be any compromise'' short of total Iraqi withdrawal from Kuwait. Praising the more than 220,000 U.S. troops now stationed in the Persian Gulf region, Bush said: ``I'll do my level best to bring every single one of them home without a shot being fired in anger. But we will not stop short of our stated objectives. ``We are the United States of America. We are standing for principle. And that principle must prevail.'' ``Brutality against innocent civilians will not be tolerated and will not stand,'' he said. ``It is inhumane, it is wrong and it must not be rewarded.'' ``Shift gears with me,'' Bush told his Ohio audience as he moved from traditional partisan attacks on Democrats to what has become his daily diatribe against the Iraqi leader. ``Our nation is together in our determination that Saddam Hussein's aggression will not stand,'' he said. The president appeared at a $50-a-person fund-raising breakfast and at a separate $2,000-a-couple private reception in an effort to help raise last-minute funds for Ohio Republicans in two close races. Republican George Voinovich, the former mayor of Cleveland, is in a hard-fought battle against Democratic state attorney general Anthony Celebrezze in the gubernatorial race. Black Republican J. Kenneth Blackwell is in a tight contest against Charles Luken, the son of retiring incumbent Rep. Tom Luken, for the senior Luken's House seat. Bush, in a nonstop campaign swing for Republican candidates that will end on Election Day, was to speak later today at GOP rallies in Rochester, Minn., and Sioux City, Iowa, before flying on to California to the night. Several hundred protesters gathered in a square outside the Cincinnati hotel where Bush was speaking, bearing signs protesting U.S. Gulf policy, including, ``Fund Education, Not War.'' ``I can share their concern,'' Bush said, noting the demonstrators in his remarks. But, he said ``We are talking about brutal, naked aggression. We are talking about one country bullying a neighbor.''

DOC.HEAD: Prosecutor Steps up Honecker Probe, Official Demands Trial
DOC.TEXT: Prosecutors said Friday they had stepped up their probe of Erich Honecker, while a top official in Bonn demanded a trial and conviction of the former East German Communist leader. Honecker is confined to a Soviet military hospital outside Berlin, while German officials wrestle with his fate. Prosecutors are trying to decide whether there is enough evidence to charge him with corruption and murder for the shoot-to-kill orders aimed at would-be escapees. About 200 people were killed trying to flee from East Germany's hard-line regime. In an interview published in the weekly newspaper The European, Honecker was quoted as boldly predicting he ``will be seen to have been right'' in his leadership of the country. ``I am not afraid of a show trial. I consider all the charges so far brought by the prosecutor's office untenable,'' the 78-year-old Honecker added. That caused immediate criticism in Bonn. Legislator Wolfgang Boetsch said the interview showed Honecker was demonstrating his ``mockery of the people and cynicism.'' ``Whoever is ready for interviews should also be ready to stand before justice to see whether he is guilty,'' the member of the conservative Christian Social Union told reporters. Honecker, deposed a little more than a year ago, reportedly had been in ill health. But pictures taken shortly before the Oct. 3 reunification of Germany showed him looking fit and energetically walking through the woods near the hospital. Berlin prosecutors said on Oct. 19 that a lack of manpower had prevented them from making progress in their investigation of him, sparking skepticism at a crowded news conference. However, prosecutors' spokesman Cornel Christoffel said things had changed in the last two weeks. ``They are concentrating the investigation on Mielke and Honecker,'' Christoffel said of the five-member team. Erich Mielke, the former secret police boss, is already in jail awaiting trial. Christoffel said the team will have to pore through 400 file folders in Honecker's case before deciding whether to arrest him or bring him to court. The spokesman said Honecker's case was of top importance ``because of his prominent position within the Communist Party.'' While the prosecutor's office maintains its staunch independence, there appeared to be growing pressure to bring Honecker to justice. The No. 2 official in the Inner-German Relations Ministry said Honecker must be ``convicted for reasons of political health, morality and atonement for the most serious human rights violations.'' In addition to the shoot-to-kill orders, State Secretary Ottfried Hennig also listed what he said was Honecker's responsibility for 300,000 politically motivated convictions. ``Whether he can be put in prison afterwards is a decision that is exclusively up to the doctors,'' Hennig told the Berlin newspaper Neue Zeit. Despite the pressure to bring Honecker to trial, there are some Germans who feel that it would be better to leave him alone rather than facing a heavily publicized courtroom drama.

DOC.HEAD: Police in Two States Seek Suspect in Homicide, Abduction
DOC.TEXT: Police in Michigan and Iowa were searching Friday for a man suspected of killing the mother of his ex-girlfriend and then abducting the young woman, their two children and the woman's sister. Terry Lee Janssen, 25, was at large Friday afternoon with 21-year-old Shannon Pallas, who officials believe is being held against her will, said Berrien County Prosecutor Dennis Wiley. Janssen is believed to be armed, he said. Relatives said Janssen drove a truck for a living. The children, ages 1 and 2, and Pallas' 14-year-old sister were dropped off unharmed early Friday at the home of Janssen's mother in Waterloo, Iowa, Wiley said. The body of Pallas' mother, Sharon Limas, 47, was found Thursday night in her Lake Township home in the southwestern tip of Michigan. Investigators said she apparently was killed by a shotgun blast. Pallas and the three other family members lived at the home and apparently were abducted after the slaying and driven to Waterloo by the suspect, police said.

DOC.HEAD: Giant Crane Being Dismanted for Shipment to China
DOC.TEXT: What's being called the world's largest crane, designed for a project that would have supplied major cities with electricity from floating nuclear power plants, has been sold to China. Workers from the China State Shipbuilding Corp. are dismantling the crane at Blount Island - along the St. John's River - for shipment by Christmas to a port on the Yellow Sea. The Chinese reportedly paid $3 million for the 38-story crane, which cost about $15 million when it was built for Offshore Power Systems, owned by Westinghouse Inc. and Tenneco Inc. The first plant was to have been launched in 1979, and nine more were to follow. The project was abandoned in the early 1980s, partly because of fears fueled by the accident at a nuclear plant on Three Mile Island in Pennsylvania.

DOC.HEAD: Germany Says 53 Soviet Soldiers Have Applied For Asylum
DOC.TEXT: Fifty-three Soviet soldiers have applied for asylum in Germany since the end of August, the Interior Ministry said Friday. It is widely believed that dozens of other Red Army soldiers have deserted and are hiding out in what was East Germany before unification of the Germanys on Oct. 3. Moscow has agreed to withdraw its 380,000 troops based in what was East Germany by 1994, but the returning Soviet soldiers will face bleak housing and economic conditions in their homeland. A spokesman for the Interior Ministry in Hesse state, Christian Jaletzke, said 32 of the latest asylum applications were being handled in Hesse. Jaletzke also said the wife and two children of a Soviet major who is seeking asylum had been given permission to remain in Germany. He said the major had returned to the Soviet Union to apply for a discharge, and was expected to join his family when he gained his release from the military. Jaletzke did not identify the family by name but said they were of Jewish descent. Soviet Jews have been leaving in large numbers because of freer emigration policies and fears of rising anti-Semitism in the Soviet Union.

DOC.HEAD: Bush to Visit Persian Gulf at Thanksgiving
DOC.TEXT: President Bush will visit U.S. troops in the Persian Gulf at Thanksgiving as part of a trip that will also take him to Europe, the White House said today. White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said Bush will have his Thanksgiving dinner with some of the 210,000 U.S. servicemen and women assembled in the gulf following Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait. Bush will travel to Saudi Arabia after a trip to Paris for the Nov. 19-21 Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe. Following the Paris summit, Bush will travel to the gulf, stopping in Egypt and Saudi Arabia for talks Saudi Arabian King Fahd, Egyptian President Hosni Mubarak and the exiled emir of Kuwait. Bush will leave Nov. 16 and return to Washington Nov. 23. Bush will stop first in Prague on Nov. 17 to help celebrate Czechoslovakia's turn to democracy, and will meet there with President Vaclav Havel. On Nov. 18, he will continue on to Ludwigshafen, Germany, to meet with Chancellor Helmut Kohl at his residence, before going to Paris for the Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe. Plans are to complete an agreement for conventional arms reduction at the conference of the 34-nation organization.

DOC.HEAD: US Team To Head For Israel To Complete Deal on Soviet Housing Funds
DOC.TEXT: Secretary of State James Baker III said Friday that a U.S. team would leave for Israel soon to finalize the transfer of $400 million in housing guarantees for Soviet Jews, officials said. The decision to send the team - conveyed by Baker to Israel's new ambassador, Zalman Shoval - ends a prolonged dispute which contributed to already strained relations between the two countries. The dispute concerned U.S. demands that Israel not use the guarantees to build homes in the predominantly Arab part of Jerusalem, which the Israelis captured from Jordan in the 1967 Mideast war. Shoval made clear that although Israel would not use U.S. money to build homes in the eastern part of Jerusalem, it would use its own money to build wherever it wanted. ``There are no two cities of Jerusalem, just as there are no two cities of Berlin,'' Shoval told reporters. Israel's Arab neighbors are incensed at the growing number of Jewish homes being built in what they regard as occupied territory. Israel annexed the land in 1967, but only a handful of countries recognize the move. The Bush administration has raised Israel's hackles several times in recent months by questioning Israel's right to the eastern part of the city - an explosive issue that the Reagan administration had refrained from raising. But the question arose this year partly as a result of the rising tide of Soviet Jews being allowed to leave for Israel under the newly liberalized emigration policies of President Mikhail Gorbachev. After months of negotiations, Israeli Foreign Minister David Levy wrote Baker on Oct. 2 agreeing that the U.S. housing guarantees would be used only to build homes for immigrants on lands Israel controlled before 1967. But several members of the Israeli government, including hardliners such as Housing Minister Ariel Sharon, then backed off Levy's promise, prompting fresh U.S. doubts. Israel was then asked to reassure the United States, which Shoval did in messages to the State Department earlier this week. This paved the way for Baker to instruct the team of experts from the Agency for International Development to leave for Israel. State Department spokeswoman Margaret Tutwiler said the group would leave soon, although the date was not yet fixed. Shoval said the $400 million will only guarantee 5,000-7,000 housing units, whereas Israel will need to build some 250,000 homes in the next four to six years for the Soviet immigrants. Israel will have to raise $20 billion to $30 billion dollars over the next few years to absorb as many as two million Soviet Jews expected over the next seven to eight years, he said. Relations between Israel and the United States have been severely strained since the start of the Persian Gulf crisis. The United States has twice voted against Israel at the United Nations in connection with the killing of 21 Palestinians on Jerusalem's Temple Mount during an Oct. 8 riot. President Bush has sent Israeli Prime Minister three letters in the past 10 days regarding Israel's refusal to accept a U.N. investigation of the killings, officials said. Shamir has rejected Bush's request that Israel accept the team. Nonetheless, Shoval described the tone of Bush's letters as ``cordial and warm.'' Bush even sent Shamir a third letter Friday, he said, congratulating him on his 75th birthday.

DOC.HEAD: Helms: Deal Struck To Build Oregon Inlet Jetties
With AM-Helms-Gantt, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Next week's election has nothing to do with the timing of the announcement that long-awaited jetties will be built in the treacherous Oregon Inlet, Sen. Jesse Helms said. The announcement came Thursday, almost a week after a storm tossed a dredge through the Herbert C. Bonner Bridge, knocking out a 370-foot section and isolating Hatteras Island. Helms and Gov. Jim Martin said it was that accident, not political motives, that led opponents to reach an agreement on the jetties. ``That got their attention,'' Helms said, speaking of several federal agencies involved in the issue. ``I think it brought them together and they agreed, for the first time, something needed to be done and should have een done earlier.'' On Thursday, U.S. Transportation Secretary Samuel Skinner presented a $2.5 million check to state Secretary of Transportation Tommy Harrelson to go toward rebuilding the bridge's missing segment. Skinner said the check represents the federal government's 80 percent share of the repair costs. The presentation was made during a campaign news conference called by Helms in Greensboro. Helms, a three-term Republican senator, is in a close re-election race in Tuesday's election against Democrat Harvey Gantt. A letter Helms carried to the news conference from U.S. Interior Secretary Manuel Lujan Jr. said permits for the construction of the jetties would be forthcoming in six to eight months. ``The jetties will save the fishing industry of North Carolina in that area,'' Helms said. Commercial fishing boats use Oregon Inlet to travel between the Atlantic Ocean and a seafood processing center in Wanchese. Twenty-six people have been killed in accidents in the inlet during the last 26 years, Martin said. The jetties are designed to prevent the inlet from becoming clogged with sand. Fishermen, environmentalists and politicians have fought for two decades over the jetties. Environmentalists fear the jetties would cause erosion of nearby Outer Banks beaches in the Cape Hatteras National Seashore and the Pea Island National Wildlife Refuge. The jetties agreement came after the Army Corps of Engineers said it would give the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service and the National Park Service, which control land access on both the north and south sides of Oregon Inlet, a voice in the project's design, Helms said. Earlier estimates were that the jetties would cost $115 million, Helms said. But changes that make the design more environmentally sound also bring down the cost to $84 million, he said. Preliminary plans call for one-mile stone jetties to be built on each side of the inlet between Bodie and Hatteras islands on Dare County's Outer Banks. Still, the jetties have some opponents. A Duke University marine geology professor, Orrin Pilkey, said the jetties will cause even more erosion on the Outer Banks. ``In the next few years, we should see severe erosion downstream, which is already happening,'' Pilkey said. ``Highway 12 is on the brink of being lost with every storm.''

DOC.HEAD: Benazir Bhutto, Party To Take Oath In Parliament
With AM-Bhutto
DOC.TEXT: Ousted Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto's supporters on Friday rejected appeals to boycott Parliament and grudgingly agreed to take their oaths. Ms. Bhutto's populist Pakistan People's Party suffered a stunning defeat in the Oct. 24 national elections that brought a right-wing coalition to power. She has accused her opponents of massive vote fraud, although the claims have yet to be substantiated. Her fellow party members' decision to take their seats Saturday on the opposition bench in the National Assembly gave Ms. Bhutto's husband, Asif Ali Zardari, a brief taste of freedom after 23 days in jail on kidnapping and extortion charges. Zardari was elected to the federal legislature from the Lyari slum in the southern port city of Karachi. He was to be flown to the capital under armed escort early Saturday to take his parliamentary oath. Zardari, 38, has been blamed for much of Ms. Bhutto's troubles since her government was ousted Aug. 6 on corruption charges. He came under regular fire during her 20 months in power for allegedly demanding commissions on lucrative government contracts. He has steadfastly denied any wrongdoing. The conservative Islamic Democratic Alliance, a loose-knit coalition of 18 parties united only in their contempt for Ms. Bhutto, will form Pakistan's fifth civilian government in 43 years. Nawaz Sharif, 41, will be the next prime minister. He was the alliance's unanimous choice for the post, which will be decided by secret ballot in the National Assembly, the policy-making lower house of Parliament. However, the vote is merely a formality. ``It's a distorted democracy, but it's better than nothing,'' said Iftikar Gilaini, a former law minister in Ms. Bhutto's Cabinet. Sharif's alliance swept the polls, winning 105 seats in the 217-seat Assembly. He also claims the loyalty of another 40 seats controlled by independents and smaller parties. Ms. Bhutto's People's Party and three allied groups won only 45 seats. ``We have to work to defeat them from within and from without,'' Gilaini said during a meeting of party members Friday. The 37-year-old former prime minister called the meeting to plot a strategy to protest election results, which included possibly boycotting the National Assembly. The more militant party workers favored either a boycott or street demonstrations to force new elections in at least 100 constituencies where they allege mass rigging occurred. ``It's too late now for street demonstrations,'' said one party worker, who refused to be identified. ``The momentum is lost.'' National elections were called three years early after President Ghulam Ishaq Khan used his constitutional powers to dismiss Ms. Bhutto's government. Ishaq Khan accused her government of widespread corruption, ineptitude and confrontational politics.

DOC.HEAD: Marlon Brando's Daughter in Coma
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout with lawyer's confirmation; ADDS reports that Cheyenne Brando once implicated father in shooting. No pickup. Adds byline.
DOC.TEXT: A drug overdose left Marlon Brando's daughter, Cheyenne, in a coma at a hospital in Tahiti, the actor's lawyer said today. ``There should be some news today on whether she's going to make it,'' said Robert L. Shapiro, who represents Miss Brando's brother, Christian, on murder charges in the shooting death of her 26-year-old Tahitian lover, Dag Drollet. Marlon Brando was leaving for Tahiti to be with his daughter, Shapiro said. Ms. Brando was charged by French authorities in Tahiti as an accessory to Drollet's murder, and was not allowed to leave the island. Shapiro said he expected Christian Brando's trial to begin with jury selection as scheduled on Monday. ``He's very depressed by this, exceedingly depressed. What else can happen?'' Shapiro said of the 32-year-old defendant. ``It just is a continuing chain of horrible events for both the Brandos and the Drollets.'' Ms. Brando overdosed on tranquilizers and antidepressant drugs, he said. After the May 16 shooting of Drollet at the Brando compound in Los Angeles, Ms. Brando fled to Tahiti, where she recently gave birth to Drollet's child. Prosecutors in Los Angeles want Ms. Brando to testify at her half-brother's trial. The state Supreme Court on Thursday referred to an appeals court a prosecution request to delay the trial pending the outcome of efforts to bring Ms. Brando to Los Angeles. Deputy District Attorneys Steven Barshop and William Clark said today they would have no comment on the new developments. Clark said he also expected jury selection to start Monday. Shapiro has stated in court that Ms. Brando had a drug problem. Before she left the United States, he said she ingested cleanser. A physician at Mamao Hospital today confirmed Ms. Brando, 20, was at the Tahitian facility. ``I can't say anything further without the authorization of the family,'' he said. ``She's hospitalized. That's all I can say.'' Meanwhile, Clark confirmed a report that Ms. Brando once gave a statement implicating her father in the slaying of her lover. Shapiro said it was one of five conflicting statements given by Ms. Brando and she eventually recanted it. ``I accused in front of his lawyers, my father of complicity in the murder of Dag, because I thought he was fixated with the `Godfather' and that he was crazy on the subject,'' Ms. Brando said, according to the syndicated television program ``Hard Copy,'' which said it obtained a copy of her deposition to a Tahitian court. ``He was jealous of my life and my happiness and he always wanted me to take care of him,'' the young woman said. ``However, I must tell you that I retracted my accusation of complicity that I made at the moment of Dag's death because I was traumatized.'' In the statement, Cheyenne Brando told the judge: ``Your honor, you must see this film (`Godfather'). You will understand everything.'' Clark confirmed other statements from Ms. Brando's deposition, including her account of moments after the shooting. ``He (Christian) told me, `It's done. I have killed him,'' Ms. Brando said. ``He told me that it was necessary that I lie by saying, that I must say that he was fighting with Dag and that the shot was the only shot.'' Shapiro said Ms. Brando ``clearly is suffering from serious mental and emotional problems.'' He said she gave authorities five different accounts of the shooting ``all varying in degrees and varying in people's involvement.'' At one point, he said Ms. Brando implicated ``a person who has not been mentioned at all as being the cause of the death of Dag.'' He declined to identify the person. Marlon Brando said his daughter has had emotional problems since Drollet died. The last time he accompanied his son to court he burst into tears when asked about his daughter's condition.

DOC.HEAD: San Francisco Giants Ready To Become Santa Clara Giants
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 15th graf, `Giants owner ... ' to CORRECT owner's first name Bob sted Ron. Version moved on sports wires.
DOC.TEXT: Baseball's Giants moved here 33 years ago because New York wouldn't build a ballpark, and the team will be on the road south to Santa Clara County if voters there agree Tuesday to pay for a new stadium. The team has been unhappy with cold, windblown Candlestick Park near downtown San Francisco, but the city's voters have rejected proposals to build a new stadium. Leaders in five cities in Santa Clara County 40 miles to the south stepped in with a plan to finance a stadium for the Giants by raising utility taxes. Voters in those communities are faced with a complex web of ballot questions, all of which must pass for the stadium to get the go-ahead. ``If they build it we will come, no question,'' said Corey Busch, vice president of the Giants, which would be renamed the Santa Clara Giants. ``We have never been happy with Candlestick. And neither have the fans.'' Baseball Commissioner Fay Vincent has lent his support to the plan. He has said the Santa Clara Giants ``has a nice ring to it,'' and the proposal would keep the team in the San Francisco Bay area. Voters in the five cities are being asked to approve a 1 percent utility tax to finance the proposed $153 million stadium. Measure G is the utility tax question on the ballots in Santa Clara, San Jose, Sunnyvale and Milpitas. If approved, the tax would raise about $16 million a year. Those cities have agreed to become members of a Joint Powers Authority that would operate the stadium. The city of Mountain View would become a member only if its voters approved a separate utility tax, Measure O. Even if those measures pass, voters in San Jose and Santa Clara also must approve two closely related measures. San Jose residents will decide whether to allow the city to participate in building a sports facility. If Measure H doesn't pass, nearly half the utility tax proceeds would be lost - essentially killing the deal. Santa Clara voters will decide whether to allow use of 98 acres of city-owned land for the stadium. ``It's a very complicated set of ballot issues, which will make it tough for some voters to follow,'' said Art Troyer, a Santa Clara County official who would become the interim director of the stadium authority. ``We think it's going to be a close vote for that reason and because people just don't want to pay more taxes for anything.'' The proposed utility tax would cost the average resident $16 to $18 a year for 12 to 14 years until stadium profits began to repay construction bonds. The Giants' lease at the 64,000-seat Candlestick Park expires in 1992, and the team hopes to occupy the proposed 45,000-seat Santa Clara stadium for the 1994 season. Giants owner Bob Lurie has said since the early 1980s that he wanted to leave Candlestick, which has narrow aisles, bad weather and parking and access problems. San Francisco leaders tried unsuccessfully to get voters to approve a new downtown stadium, most recently last year. ``We have no choice but to look for another home, especially with the rising costs and players salaries,'' Busch said. ``The franchise cannot survive in Candlestick Park. ... And if Santa Clara doesn't build us a stadium, we'll go somewhere else.''

DOC.HEAD: Police Disperse Protest of Religious Violence
LaserPhoto DHA-1
With AM-India, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Police used steel-tipped truncheons Friday to disperse about 2,000 Moslems protesting religious violence and deaths in Hindu-dominated India. Anti-Hindu riots earlier this week across predominately Islamic Bangladesh killed at least three people and injured more than 350, according to officials and news reports. Hospital officials said two of the victims died Friday of gunshot wounds. In India, more than 275 people have died since Oct. 24 when fundamentalist Hindus began efforts to raze a mosque and build a Hindu temple on the site. Hindus say the 460-year-old Babri Mosque was built on the foundation of an early Hindu temple marking the birthplace of the warrior god Rama. Moslems dispute the history. At least two of the victims in Bangladesh were Moslems and the religion of the third has not been identified. All suffered bullet wounds, but it was not clear who fired the shots. Anupam Sen, a Hindu leader, claimed 1,276 Hindu temples were damaged and 10,000 Hindus lost their shops or homes in the riots. The march Friday began outside the Baitul Mosque, the largest in Dhaka. Witnesses said police appealed to the crowd to disperse before moving in with truncheons. There were no immediate reports of injuries. Curfews in Dhaka and the southern port of Chittagong were briefly lifted for Moslem sabbath prayers. The unrest began in Chittagong on Tuesday night following reports that Hindus tried to seize the mosque in Ayodhya, India, 300 miles southeast of New Delhi. At least 10 people died Friday in a second attempt to storm the site. Police used steel-tipped batons to disperse 400 Moslems who tried to break into a Hindu temple in Barisal, 75 miles south of Dhaka, said Dainik Bangla, a government-owned daily newspaper. At least 50 people were injured. Dhaka riot police armed with tear-gas guns and truncheons wounded about 100 people who tried to ``vandalize and loot Hindu-owned shops and temples,'' said Ittefaq, an independent Bengali-language daily. In Chittagong, the country's second-largest city, 500 Moslems attacked a Hindu village with knives and homemade bombs Thursday night, witnesses said. Bangladesh's 110 million people are 88 percent Moslem, and 10 percent Hindus. On Thursday, President Hussain Muhammad Ershad called out the army in Dhaka and ordered security forces to take ``tough action against the forces who are trying to disrupt peace and harmony.'' He visited a Hindu temple in Dhaka, which was vandalized by Moslem gangs.

DOC.HEAD: Bidder Wins Pop Singer's Scarf
DOC.TEXT: What price fame? How about $714 for a blue silk scarf owned by Madonna? The price was right for Moses Findley, who placed the winning bid at an auction for the silk scarf that went with a $20,000 blue-sequined dress owned by Madonna, a Michigan native. It was worn by the singer during the filming of her video, ``True Blue.'' The ensemble was stolen two years ago from an MTV display at Twelve Oaks Mall in this hamlet about 15 miles northwest of Detroit. The dress was returned by attempts to send back the scarf were unsuccessful, police said. By Thursday, 10 bids came in to the Novi Police Department, mostly from metropolitan Detroit, but one came from Chicago and one from Los Angeles. ``I never dreamed that I would be the high bidder on this,'' said Findley, of Southfield. ``I'm just ecstatic about it.'' Findley, 39, said he will auction off the scarf this month and hopes it will bring bids of thousands of dollars that he will donate to the Pontiac Rescue Mission and several Detroit agencies that aid the homeless. The money from the police auction will go to the Novi Drug Abuse Resistance Education program.

DOC.HEAD: Man Who Killed Teen-Ager Reaches Plea Agreement With Prosecutor
DOC.TEXT: A man who fatally shot a teen-ager reached a plea agreement under which he can avoid jail, fines, and a criminal record. District Attorney David Moss appeared Thursday at a news conference with the defendant, Bobby Wayne Hale. Moss, who is seeking re-election Tuesday, said he had received petitions signed by thousands of people asking that he not prosecute Hale. ``Not for one minute have I been allowed to forget that I have an election next week,'' Moss said. Under the agreement, Hale pleaded no contest to second-degree manslaughter and received a six-month deferred sentence. Police said Hale fatally shot Jesse Elmer Jones as the 16-year-old was driving away from the home of Hale's daughter on Oct. 16. The woman's home had recently been burglarized. ``The situation escalated into something that I had no control over,'' Hale said. ``How something so unintentional can go so wrong, I don't have the answer for it.'' Moss said he believed Hale should be treated with a gentle hand because he had been ``a law-abiding, contributing member of the community.'' Tulsa Special Judge Pete Messler, who approved the plea, said the case will be dismissed May 1 if Hale stays out of trouble. Moss said the shooting shouldn't be excused. ``Before you shoot somebody, you or whoever you are defending has to be in imminent danger of death or bodily injury,'' Moss said. ``The rule of law must prevail.'' But he said he understood the community's growing frustration with juvenile crime. Attorney Jeff Fischer, who represents Jones' mother, said the family believed prosecuting Hale ``would not further the interests of the criminal justice system.''

DOC.HEAD: Question of European Unity Divides Prime Minister's Party
LaserPhoto LON1
DOC.TEXT: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's top aides rallied around their leader Friday after the divisive issue of European unity drove another man out of her Cabinet. Key Cabinet ministers declared that she, too, is a committed European, just like the departed Sir Geoffrey Howe. But her opponents wondered aloud: Is the governing Conservative Party still committed to her? ``The Cabinet must decide what they are going to do,'' ex-Prime Minister Edward Heath said. ``If it is ton Purina Co 6.46 vs 6.44

DOC.HEAD: Radical Students Clash with Police in Anti-Government Protests
DOC.TEXT: Radical students demanding the overthrow of President Roh Tae-woo clashed with police Friday, while factional strife that has threatened to split the governing party showed signs of easing. Clashes erupted at 15 colleges and universities in Seoul, where bands of 300 to 500 students fought police with rocks and firebombs to mark the 60th anniversary on Saturday of a 1930 student uprising against Japanese colonial rule. Police fired tear gas to block students from marching into the streets following the anti-government rallies. The total number of students involved in Friday's protests was estimated at 5,000. There were no immediate reports of arrests or injuries. The students oppose calls within Roh's party for a constitutional revision that would replace the country's presidential system of government with a parliamentary one headed by a prime minister. Urging one another to emulate the 1930 uprising, students at Yonsei University chanted: ``Let's inherit the fighting spirit of our seniors and punish Roh Tae-woo!'' Meanwhile, mainstream groups within the governing party indicated Friday they would withdraw their demands for a new form of government and seek to end the factional strife threatening Roh's leadership. ``It has become apparent that a constitutional revision for a parliamentary form of government is realistically impossible,'' said a senior governing party official close to Roh, speaking on condition of anonymity. His statement came after a minority faction of about 50 legislators threatened to break away from the governing Democratic Liberal Party. Rep. Kim Dong-young, a spokesman for the minority faction, expressed optimism Friday that the dispute could be resolved by the weekend. The infighting is basically a power struggle to determine which faction within the governing party will name the next presidential candidate in elections scheduled for 1992. Roh's group, which controls more seats in parliament and has no clear presidential candidate, prefers a parliamentary system because it would be better represented. A crisis within the party erupted last week when Seoul newspapers printed a memorandum showing a secret agreement between opposing factions to press for a parliamentary government. It was the worst political crisis since early this year when Roh joined two opposition leaders in forming a new governing coalition that controls more than two-thirds of seats in the 299-member National Assembly. The memo, signed by Roh and two former opposition leaders, Kim Young-sam and Kim Jong-pil, called for a parliamentary system by next year. Roh and Kim Jong-pil, a former prime minister, had been allied against Kim Young-sam, who as party chairman has the No. 2 post after Roh. The disclosure of the secret memo was especially damaging for Kim Young-sam, who has repeatedly vowed to fight attempts to change the system of government. Since the disclosure, Kim Young-sam has admitted to signing the memo but said he now realizes it is impossible to change the system of government without consent from the opposition camp. Kim controls 50 of the 218 governing party seats, enough votes to block any constitutional revision in parliament. A constitutional revision requires approval by two-thirds of lawmakers before being referred to a national referendum.

DOC.HEAD: US Trying To Get Blankets To Detained Hostages
With AM-Bush, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: With the onset of cooler weather in the Persian Gulf, U.S. officials have been trying unsuccessfully for Iraqi cooperation in supplying clothing and blankets to American hostages, the State Department said Friday. Spokeswoman Margaret Tutwiler said officials assume that most of the more than 100 detained Americans are ill-equipped to cope with dropping nighttime temperatures, now dipping to the 50s. ``We would be willing to provide the clothing and blankets if we knew that the supplies would go to the people that are being held,'' she said. So far, she added, the Iraqi government hasn't been willing to guarantee that any supplies the United States provides would actually get to the hostages. Officials believe the condition of the detained hostages has been deteriorating. Secretary of State James A. Baker III said Monday that some have been forced to sleep on ``vermin-ridden concrete floors.'' About 105 hostages are in detention, most at military and industrial sites to deter a potential U.S. military attack. Slightly fewer than 1,000 Americans are believed to be in Iraq and Kuwait.
