On a related subject, Ms. Tutwiler said the administration has learned that representatives of the Iraqi government are inviting members of hostage families and prominent American citizens to visit Iraq. ``Iraq is cruelly dangling as the lure for these visits the possibility of obtaining the release of or having the chance to visit hostages held against international law,'' she said. ``Saddam Hussein is using Americans and othe nationals as pawns in a cruel game. He is heartlessly toying with the anguish of family members and the sympathies of all civilized people for the plight of the hostages.'' She said the United States and other western governments discourage visits that the Iraqis can exploit for propaganda purposes. The government will not support ``political, economic or other concessions to Iraq in return for the release of hostages they hold in violation of international law, she said. On Thursday, Ms. Tutwiler dismissed as ``cruel'' an Iraqi offer to allow family members to make holiday visits to hostages in Iraq and Kuwait. Other officials said that despite the U.S. embargo against Iraq, family members can legally go there for purposes of family reunification.

DOC.HEAD: Outhouse Honored by Connecticut Trust for Historic Preservation
DOC.TEXT: A 19th-century outhouse with weathered shingles and a rusty latch may not have been the site of many memorable moments but officials are making a museum of it nonetheless. The free-standing, three-seat outhouse, no longer in use, got an honorable mention from the Connecticut Trust for Historic Preservation at the state Capitol during ceremonies Wednesday to recognize restored historical landmarks. It was chosen from among dozens of entries statewide, including restored municipal buildings, houses and barns. ``It's a rare and endangered building,'' said Christopher Wigren, project manager for the private, non-profit trust. ``It's part of the past that is rapidly disappearing.'' The venerable privy belongs to the former Ashford Academy, and apparently was built with the two-story schoolhouse in the 1830s. The academy graduated its last class in 1949, and until the Ashford Historical Society moved in, it and the outhouse fell into disrepair. The door of the dilapidated latrine was ripped off and was used to fill in for the missing roof, and the floor was long gone. Brush had nearly devoured the entire building before restoration began 18 months ago, said Lorraine S. McConnell, president of the society. After the society finishes restoring the academy, which will not be until at least 1993, it plans to turn the schoolhouse and outhouse into a museum, McConnell said.

DOC.HEAD: More Killed As Religious Dispute Spreads
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 13 grafs to UPDATE with higher death toll, CORRECTS overall deaths in angladesh to three sted two. Picks up 14th graf pvs, `At least ...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto planned
DOC.TEXT: Police killed at least 12 Hindus attempting to storm a disputed Moslem mosque Friday, and more than 40 others died in violence as the religious dispute spread across India to neighboring Moslem countries. Ten consecutive days of clashes between majority Hindus and minority Moslems have left nearly 280 dead in India and at least three dead in predominately Islamic Bangladesh. The unrest could also weaken Prime Minister V.P. Singh's chances of surviving a Nov. 7 confidence vote. Singh lost his majority in Parliament after Hindus withdrew from the 11-month-old coalition to protest government handling of the mosque dispute. Fundamentalist Hindus seek to destroy the hilltop Babri Mosque and build a a Hindu temple on the site in Ayodhya, 300 miles southeast of New Delhi. Hindus say the 460-year-old mosque was built on the foundation of an early temple marking the birthplace of Rama, the much-worshiped warrior god. Moslems dispute the history and say relinquishing the mosque would jeopardize hundreds of other Moslem sites. Police have fired twice this week on Hindus attempting to overrun the mosque. On Friday, a top district official said witnesses' estimate of 12 dead was ``nearer to the truth'' than reporters' tally of 10. The official spoke on condition of anonymity. Doctors at a hospital in the nearby town of Faizabad said they treated 64 injured people, including 48 wounded by gunfire. Several policemen were also treated, they said. Reporters saw three buses and several jeeps torched by the mob. Some homes were also burned. At least 25 deaths were reported in related riots across the Uttar Pradesh state, where the mosque is located, the Press Trust of India news agency reported. Thirteen more died Friday in the western state of Gujarat, the news agency said. Other deaths were reported from Karnataka, Bihar, Rajasthan and Andhra Pradesh states. At least 279 people have died in India in recent violence linked to the dispute, police and news agencies report. Last year, about 900 people were killed when a Hindu group first announced its intention to take over the site by force. Most of those killed near the mosque recently were Hindus, but authorities refuse to identify the faith of other victims out of fear of exacerbating tensions. In Bangladesh, which has a Hindu minority, two people died Friday of bullet wounds suffered during anti-Hindu protest earlier this week in the capital of Dhaka. At least three people have been killed and 350 wounded in three days of rioting in Dhaka and in 12 other cities. Two of those killed were Moslems, and the religion of the third victim was not immediately known. In Pakistan, India's predominately Islamic western neighbor, several demonstrations were held to protest the violence and some Islamic leaders called for larger pro-Moslem rallies. Pakistan's caretaker prime minister, Ghulam Mustafa Jatoi, said the Indian government was half-heartedly protecting Moslem shrines. ``It was the moral duty of the Indian government to protect the places of worship of Moslems,'' Jatoi said in a statemenet published in the Pakistan Times. ``India, which pleads herself the champion of secularism, has failed to give protection to holy places of Moslems.'' But one of those injured Friday near the mosque accused government forces of shooting needlessly. ``Two policemen dragged a man out of the house and shot him in the chest. Then they also shot two people who were crying over a dead body. They were shot in the back,''said Bhupendra Singh Rawat, speaking from a hospital bed. Rawat, a 24-year-old insurance agent from New Delhi, said he was knocked down by a police officer's bamboo club. Former Indian Deputy Prime Minister Devi Lal, a key figure in efforts to replace Singh, said a government comprising all parties should be set up to defuse the crisis. Singh, who lost his majority in Parliament after the pro-Hindu Bharatiya Janata Party withdrew, is expected to lose the no-confidence vote. The prime minister is also beset by moves within his National Front coalition for a new leader. Some newspapers and political commentators have called the Ayodhya dispute the greatest threat to the country's secularism since India gained independence in 1947. India's 880 million people are 82 percent Hindu and 12 percent Moslem. The others include Sikhs, Christians and Buddhists. India's constitution pledges tolerance of all religions and secularism.

DOC.HEAD: Britain, Albania to Discuss Restoring Diplomatic Ties
DOC.TEXT: Britain and Albania will hold further talks about restoring diplomatic ties severed more than 40 years ago, the Foreign Office said Friday. Representatives of the two governments will meet in Rome on Monday, a Foreign Office spokesman said on condition of anonymity. The two countries severed relations in 1946 after two Royal Navy vessels struck mines and sank in the Corfu Channel, near Albania's coast.Albania refused to pay compensation, and Britain impounded Albanian gold held in the Bank of England. ``I suppose you could say an accident of history is coming to an end,'' the Foreign Office spokesman said. ``The idea has gradually emerged that links should be restored.'' Michael Tait, an assistant under-secretary in the Foreign Office, will lead the British team in Rome, the spokesman said. Albania's vice minister for foreign affairs, Muhummed Kaplani, will head the Albanian delegation. The two countries first talked about restoring relations in Paris in 1985 and met for further exploratory discussions in 1988. Albania, a country of just over 3 million people, is considered the last bastion of Stalinism. Under its previous leader, Enver Hoxha, it pursued a policy of increasing diplomatic isolation. However, under Ramiz Alia, who became party leader and head of state in April 1985, Albania slowly has been moving out of its isolation and has restored diplomatic relations with dozens of countries.

DOC.HEAD: China Arrests Two Catholic Bishops, 13 Priests and Deacons
DOC.TEXT: China's Communist authorities have arrested two Roman Catholic bishops and 13 priests and deacons loyal to the pope, a church-run news agency reported Friday. The Chinese clerics were accused of violating government laws on religion and of being ``subjected to a foreign power,'' a reference to the Vatican, the agency, Asia News said. It said the government accused the men of criticizing the Chinese Patriotic Catholic Church, which is sponsored by the Communist state and consecrates its own bishops. They also were charged with illegally opening a seminary, ordaining priests and preaching to minors, the agency said. It was not known what sentences the clerics received. China broke diplomatic relations with the Vatican in 1957 and only allows worship under the guise of the Chinese Patriotic Catholic Church. Asia News, an agency of the Pontifical Institute for Foreign Missions, said the arrests took place in the coastal province of Fujian. The two arrested bishops were identified as Monsignor Xie Shiguang of Xiapu and Monsignor Hang Shoucheng of Fu'an.

DOC.HEAD: Central Park Jogger Cross-Examined
DOC.TEXT: The scarred woman known as the Central Park jogger was cross-examined Friday for the first time since she was gang-raped and nearly beaten to death. One defense lawyer refused to question her, but the other asked about her sex life, her job competence, her physical condition, her memory and whether she had been assaulted by the men in her life. Many of his questions were not answered because the prosecution's objections were sustained. The 30-year-old woman, who testified last summer at the trial of three attackers, approached the witness stand with an unsteady gait and nearly stumbled as she climbed to the box. With her blond hair cut in a short pageboy and combed back from her face, a scar twisting from her left eyebrow to her rebuilt left cheekbone was visible. During questioning by Assistant District Attorney Elizabeth Lederer, the woman described her hospitalization, her rehabilitation and the lingering effects of the April 19, 1989, battering. She was found naked and near death and covered with mud and blood in the northern end of the park after being gang-raped and beaten. She had lost three-fourths of her blood and her skull was broken in three places. ``I have difficulty with balance,'' she said. ``I have double vision. I still have no sense of smell.'' She said she has to hold reading materials askew to focus on them. Her testimony was similar to what she said at the first trial. Six teen-agers were indicted for the attack on the woman and two male joggers. Three were convicted of rape and assault in August but acquitted of attempted murder; two are on trial now on the same charges in state court. The sixth will be tried early next year. Colin Moore, lawyer for defendant Kharey Wise, suggested during cross-examination that the woman's injuries were less serious than the prosecution claimed, that a man she knew might have attacked her, and that the attack occurred earlier than police had said. Moore asked the witness to explain her job as a vice president in the corporate finance department at Salomon Bros., an investment banking firm. She did, and in mild tones, Moore asked, ``It's fairly complicated work, isn't it?'' ``Yes,'' she replied. ``And you're very competent?'' ``I like to think so,'' she said. Then Moore asked about her physical activities, apparently in an attempt to show she was not as badly injured as claimed. ``Do you still go jogging?'' he asked. ``Yes, as part of my rehabilitation.'' ``How often do you jog?'' ``Five or six days a week.'' She also said she spends a couple of hours a day in a gym several times a week. He asked her about driving, and she said she used to drive but no longer does. Moore attempted to question her about Michael Allen, a former male roommate and an alleged platonic friend with whom she canceled a dinner date because of work the evening she was attacked. ``He was a friend?'' the lawyer asked. ``Yes,'' the witness answered. ``A very good friend?'' Moore asked. ``What do you mean by a very good friend?'' the witness asked. ``Were you intimate with him?'' Moore asked. Acting Justice Thomas Galligan sustained Lederer's objection. Wise, 18, and his co-defendant, Kevin Richardson, 16, looked intently at the witness for much of her testimony. ``When you were at Metropolitan Hospital, do you remember calling the name of a boyfriend?'' Moore asked. The judge sustained Lederer's objection. ``Do you remember saying certain things, three or four days after admission to Metropolitan?'' Moore persisted. ``No, I was still in a coma.'' ``Prior to April 19, did you have any altercation with Kevin O'Reilly?'' the defense lawyer asked, referring to her steady boyfriend. The objection to Moore's question was sustained. ``Prior to April 19 were you ever assaulted by any male friend?'' The objection to that question also was sustained.

DOC.HEAD: Shamir Turns 75, Cites Need for `Consistency and Determination'
With AM-Israel
DOC.TEXT: Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir marked his 75th birthday Friday and said despite the controversy and unrest confronting Israel, he feels fulfilled in his life and work. Shamir, who heads the right-wing Likud bloc, hinted in newspaper interviews he was contemplating retirement. But aides were quoted as suggesting he may choose to run again for office in 1992, for lack of an obvious successor. Despite tensions with Washington, President Bush was among those sending good wishes, radio reports said. Family and friends joined Shamir in cutting a cake at his office. ``It is no big deal to get old and reach this age,'' he said. ``But looking back one can see something was done and achieved in the years that have passed.'' Asked by a reporter for the Maariv daily how he saw his name going down in history, Shamir said: ``Believe me, it doesn't matter. I do know I have succeeded in fulfilling myself. ... I haven't strayed either to the right or the left from my path.'' Born in Ruzinoy, Poland, on Oct. 15, 1915, Shamir celebrates his birthday according to the Jewish lunar calendar, or on the 14th day of the month of Heshvan. Shamir led the anti-British terror group known as the Stern gang before Israel's 1948 independence. After that, he was an agent for the Mossad intelligence service for more than a decade. He was elected to Parliament in 1973 and took over as prime minister 10 years later when Menachem Begin stepped down. Shamir's political longevity has defied expectations. The dimunitive, introverted Shamir says one reason for that is that he knows how to keep a lid on his emotions. ``I trained myself not to ever get too excited or angry. I learned that when a person gets angry, he doesn't function right,'' Shamir told the Yedioth Ahronoth daily. In the protracted conflict over the future of the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip, Shamir has held fast to his view that the territories are an integral part of biblical Israel. He has rejected U.S. calls for Israel to compromise with the Palestinians. ``From history I have learned that in times of crisis, the decisive factor in the end is the consistency and determination of a people standing by its views,'' he told Maariv. Shamir said he felt he had reached ``the peak of my activity'' and would have to face the prospect of retirement. ``I know that at some stage I will have to wind things up. I am preparing for this moment,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: U.N. Commissioner for Refugees Resigns
DOC.TEXT: The United Nations high commissioner for refugees announced Friday he is resigning after only 10 months of a five-year term and said he will become Norway's foreign minister. Thorvald Stoltenberg's resignation came as a shock to the agency, which is facing an unprecedented refugee crisis and has been recovering from low morale under its previous leadership. Stoltenberg, 59, who was foreign minister from 1987 to 1989, said in a statement he decided to resume the post because it was ``a critical moment for Norway.'' U.N. Secretary-General Javier Perez de Cuellar will nominate a successor, but there was no immediate indication of whom it might be. The U.N. High Commission for Refugees supervises some 15 million refugees worldwide, including 5 million Afghans in Iran and Pakistan, about 2 million in southern Africa and the Horn of Africa and many in southeast Asia. The agency, which won the Nobel Peace Prize in 1954 and 1981, has been in financial crisis and last month approved an 11 percent cut in next year's annual budget, to $345.5 million. In his statement, Stoltenberg said he was confident his resignation would not compromise the U.N. agency's ability to help refugees. He said the organization was ``on the right track'' in meeting challenges posed by ``a rapidly evolving international situation.'' But refugee organizations in Norway immediately criticized his move. ``It is letting down the refugees, and I must protest it strongly,'' Annette Thommessen, who heads the Norwegian Association of Asylum Seekers, told the national news agency NTB. ``Stoltenberg has accepted an extremely important job,'' she said, adding that leaving was ``on the verge of being immoral and a catastrophe for the U.N.'' The U.N. General Assembly approved Stoltenberg, then Norway's U.N. ambassador in New York, last November. He took up the post at the start of January. He was the only candidate nominated by Perez de Cuellar after Jean-Pierre Hocke of Switzerland left under a cloud of suspicion and criticism. Hocke resigned over charges he misused a special education fund for refugees to upgrade his air travel to first class. He was also criticized for alleged financial mismanagement and favoritism, but he denied wrongdoing and none was proven.

DOC.HEAD: Yale Grad Found Innocent by Reason of Insanity in Four Slayings
DOC.TEXT: A Yale graduate wo said God ordered him to kill his mother, brother and two other people was found innocent by reason of insanity Friday. Judge Miriam Span ordered Rolando Marcelo to undergo further psychiatric examination to determine whether he is still dangerous. Span scheduled a Dec. 20 hearing to decide whether to commit Marcelo, order further evaluations or release him. Marcelo confessed that he fatally stabbed his mother, Anita Marcelo, 51; his brother, Raymond, 20; his friend, Nelson Paiva, 21; and neighbor Mark Dennis, 36. He also stabbed Richard Hartmann, 38, and chased 38-year-old Robert Maul with a knife during the Memorial Day 1989 rampage. Evidence during the two-day, non-jury trial included Marcelo's statment that he was the ``second Messiah'' and had to kill his mother and brother so they could be resurrected to a better life. He told authorities he believed their dead bodies would be invisible like the ghostly ballplayers in the movie ``Field of Dreams,'' which Marcelo watched the night before the attack. He said he chased the visiting Paiva outside and stabbed him while neighbors watched because Paiva had questioned him about blood on his clothes, his eyeglasses and the kitchen floor. He said then went after Hartmann and Maul, who witnessed Paiva's killing. ``This is pretty serious stuff,'' testified Dr. Irwin N. Perr, a psychiatry professor at the University of Medicine and Dentistry of New Jersey. ``That's not the usual form of criminal behavior.'' Perr was one of several people who testified about Marcelo's mental state. While most agreed that Marcelo had symptoms of mental illness, they could not pinpoint which one he suffered from. Marcelo earned a bachelor's degree in economics from Yale in 1987 and was described as having an IQ between 111 and 133. His last job was at Chemical Bank in New York City, which he left in 1988 after contracting Epstein-Barr Syndrome, said Union County Assistant Prosecutor David Hancock. Perr is to evaluate Marcelo when he is moved to Trenton Psychiatric Hospital within the next few days, Hancock said. Marcelo has been held at the Union County Jail in Elizabeth in lieu of $4 million bail since his arrest.

DOC.HEAD: Thornburgh Orders Hearing on JOA Application by Manteca Newspapers
DOC.TEXT: Attorney General Dick Thornburgh on Friday ordered an administrative hearing to determine if two California newspapers should be given an antitrust exemption to form a joint operating agreement. Thornburgh rejected a recommendation from the Justice Department's antitrust division that he deny the application to form a joint operating agreement by the Manteca Bulletin and the Manteca News, both of Manteca, Calif. Without a hearing, ``it is not possible to determine whether the application should be approved or disapproved,'' Thornburgh said in an opinion. ``A hearing is necessary to resolve material issues of fact relating to whether the News is a `failing newspaper''' that would qualify it for the antitrust exemption under the Newspaper Preservation Act, Thornburgh wrote. The law allows two newspapers to form joint operating agreements with the approval of the attorney general if one of the publications is in ``probable danger of financial failure.'' Thornburgh said the hearing should determine whether the News, which is published Wednesdays and Fridays by Raymus Development & Sales Inc., could have avoided its continuing losses through different management practices. The hearing should also determine the accuracy of antitrust division's conclusion that the ``overriding objective (of the owner of the News) for the past four years has been to reach the safety net of this proposed JOA.'' The antitrust division concluded in its Aug. 13 report that ``the applicants have decidedly failed to prove that (the newspaper's losses) were incurred despite reasonable management practices ... or that these losses could not be avoided if the News were to operate on a more businesslike basis.'' In a reply to the report, the News said it is suffering irreversible losses and ``different management practices would not be the cure in the future.'' Thornburgh noted that a number of Manteca residents had requested a hearing, which the attorney general said should be held in that town. The joint operating application was filed July 13, 1988 by the News and the daily Manteca Bulletin, which is owned by Morris Newspapers. Under such arrangements, two competing newspapers merge their commercial and production facilities but maintain their own news staffs and produce separate editions.

DOC.HEAD: Audit Shows Some Farmers Double-Dip Into Subsidies
DOC.TEXT: An Interior Department audit shows that some western farmers regularly double-dip into federal irrigation and crop subsidies. The report by the department's Office of Inspector General said farmers in 1986 received Bureau of Reclamation water subsidies conservatively estimated at $66 million to irrigate lands that produced surplus crops. At the same time, the Agriculture Department paid the same farmers $379 million to limit surplus crop production. ``For example, we found that eight farms that produced surplus crops received over $2.1 million in irrigation subsidies while collecting about $4.5 million in various agriculture commodity program subsidies during the three-year period from 1986 through 1988.'' The farmers received dual subsidies because Interior and Agriculture ``did not make concerted efforts to coordinate their programs,'' said the report, released to the press Friday. The audit did not specify exactly how many farmers may have gotten double subsidies. Interior auditors concluded the dual subsidies ``should be discontinued expeditiously'' and that changes be made to coordinate the two programs. But the report said Interior has not expressed general support for eliminating the dual subsidies and has not supported bills in Congress that would do so. ``Department officials have expressed concern that eliminating the dual subsidy could create financial hardships for some farmers while not significantly reducing the cost of the nation's overall farm subsidy program,'' the report said. The subsidies are derived from the use of water from huge Bureau of Reclamation projects, which provide low-cost irrigation on about 10 million acres of farmland in 17 western states. Farmers are subsidized by the Bureau of Reclamation selling them water for less than the full amount needed to recover the government's investment in the irrigation facilities. In 1986, the report said, those lands produced crops with a gross value of $7.5 billion, including 121 million bushels of corn, 65 million bushels of wheat, 47 million bushels of barley, and 1.6 million bales of cotton. The question of using subsidized water to grow surplus crops has been examined a number of times over the years. Legislation to limit or eliminate the double subsidies has circulated in Congress. The House passed a bill that was weakened by the Senate and never received final congressional approval.

DOC.HEAD: Bomb Kills Part-Time Soldier
DOC.TEXT: A bomb hidden in a car killed a part-time soldier Friday, police said, and the Irish Republican Army reportedly claimed responsibility. Police said the slain man was 34-year-old Albert Cooper, a member of the Ulster Defense Regiment, a locally recruited army unit. Its members have been frequent targets of the IRA, which is fighting British rule in Northern Ireland. The domestic British agency, Press Association, said the IRA claimed responsibility for the killing in a call to a local radio station. Witnesses said a dark-haired young woman drove a car into a shop where Cooper worked in Cookstown, 30 miles west of Belfast. She said she needed a new muffler, and left, the witnesses said. They said the the bomb went off when Cooper opened the car door. Two other men working in the garage escaped injury. Police were looking for the woman. The bombing came one week after Protestant gunmen killed a member of the IRA's legal political wing, Sinn Fein, near Cookstown. The IRA had threatened retaliation. Friday's killing was the 64th this year attributed to political and sectarian violence in Northern Ireland. In Warrington, England, a soldier killed by an IRA bomb last week was buried with military honors on Friday. Stephen Beacham was one of five members of the King's Regiment killed by an explosion at a checkpoint near Londonderry on Oct. 24. Beacham died days before he had planned to come home to see his 3-week-old son for the first time. A Roman Catholic civilian, who had been forced to drive the explosives to the checkpoint, was also killed in the Londonderry bombing.

DOC.HEAD: Baker Going To Moscow to See Gorbachev About Persian Gulf
With AM-Bush, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Secretary of State James A. Baker III revised his travel plans Friday to add meetings in Moscow next week on the Persian Gulf crisis with Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev and Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze. Baker also scheduled a meeting in Cairo on Tuesday with Chinese Foreign Minister Qichen Qian. The sessions reflect an expanding U.S. campaign to pressure Iraq to end its three-month occupation of Kuwait. The Soviet Union and China are permanent members of the U.N. Security Council and their support would be essential for any tougher U.N.-backed economic sanctions or military action, Baker is also going to the Persian Gulf to see leaders of Bahrain, Saudi Arabia and the ousted Kuwaiti government, to Egypt and to Turkey, Britain and France - all within an eight-day span. He takes off Saturday morning. State Department spokeswoman Margaret D. Tutwiler described the purpose of Baker's trip as consultation with ``our coalition partners over a full range of diplomatic, economic and military matters.'' Baker on Friday called in the new Israeli ambassador, Zalman Shoval, for a 55-minute session. He is bypassing Israel again on his travels. Baker said this week he wanted to avoid linking the Arab-Israeli dispute to the campaign to reverse Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait. Shoval told reporters the U.S.-Israeli relationship ``does not have to be emphasized every day.'' The ambassador said he was confident Baker would make a trip to Israel soon and that his country shared with the United States an interest in promoting peace talks. Baker will fly to Moscow from Ankara, Turkey, on Wednesday and meet with Gorbachev and Shevardnadze on Thursday and Friday. Apart from the gulf situation, Baker will take up with the Soviet foreign minister lingering technical issues in the landmark arms control treaty to be signed at a 34-nation summit President Bush is scheduled to attend in Paris later this month. The White House said Friday that Bush would continue on to the gulf to spend Thanksgiving with U.S. troops. The Conventional Forces in Europe treaty, the most sweeping arms control accord in history, would set limits on tanks, anti-aircraft artillery and various other categories of non-nuclear weapons from the Atlantic Ocean to the Ural Mountains of the Soviet Union. Bush, speaking at a news conference in Orlando, Fla., Thursday, said the pending treaty was ``all but put to bed'' with the exception of one ``tiny technical matter. Hopefully, it's been resolved by now.'' Baker and Shevardnadze will discuss the way the Soviet Union and its allies will divide non-nuclear arms allowed to the Warsaw Pact under the treaty. Also, within the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, two U.S. allies, Norway and Turkey, want to lower the ceilings of arms permitted the Soviet Union in the zone that includes the two countries. The U.S. officials and private arms control specialists who discussed the issues did not say the summit might be set back. But they stressed the deadline is less than three weeks away. The Soviets have lost East Germany as an ally. Hungary is teetering, but remains in the Warsaw Pact with Bulgaria, Czechoslovakia, Poland and Romania. As these countries grow more independent, veering further away from Moscow, the likelihood of them using their weapons in a joint military action with the Soviet Union becomes remote. And yet, the United States has a tactical stake in how the Warsaw Pact resolves the issue as well as how the Soviets distribute their permissible weapons within the zones in their own country. Baker and Shevardnadze announced basic agreement on all outstanding issues in New York in early October but failed to conclude a U.S.-Soviet pact to curb long-range nuclear weapons.

DOC.HEAD: Minister Estimates Communists' Wealth At Up to $200 Billion
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 6th graf pvs, `Walter, head...,' with 4 grafs to UPDATE with details of Oslo arrest. Picks up 7th graf pvs, `I consider...' ADDS 4 grafs on Honecker probe, quotes
DOC.TEXT: A minister in Chancellor Helmut Kohl's new all-German Cabinet said East Germany's former Communist Party has assets of up to $200 billion, a newspaper reported Friday. The figure is a hundred times bigger than the sum named by officials of the former Communist Party. Hansjoachim Walther, a member of the former East German Parliament who was appointed as a minister-without-portfolio in Kohl's Cabinet after the Germanys united on Oct. 3, made the remarks in an interview in the daily Dresdner Morgenpost. The report follows the arrest of three former Communist Party officials who admitted to illegally funneling about $70 million in party funds to the Soviet Union. Two of the officials, Wolfgang Pohl and Wolfgang Langnitschke, were arrested last week, and Karl-Heinz Kaufmann, who was being sought on an international warrant, was arrested on Thursday in Oslo, Norway. Kaufmann, 42, was arrested when he went to a bank to discuss the transfer of $45 million from an account he controlled, newspapers reported. He is also suspected of transferring $21 million to a Netherlands bank, the Oslo newspaper Arbeiderbladet reported. Olso police spokesman Svein Olav Kristiansen said Kaufmann does not oppose extradition. The Party of Democratic Socialism, built from the remnants of the East German Communist Party, claimed the transfers were a debt repayment to the Soviet Communist Party, said Norwegian reports. Walther, head of the conservative German Social Union Party, was asked by the Dresdner Morgenpost to give his views on the wealth of the party. ``I consider it possible they have holdings of between 200 billion o 300 billion marks,'' the equivalent of $133 billion to $200 billion, the newspaper quoted Walther as saying. The Democratic Socialists, headed by Gregor Gysi, are fighting to minimize the repercussions of the money scandal as Germany approaches parliamentary elections on Dec. 2. Gysi has estimated the party's wealth at $1.3 billion, and has promised a full disclosure of its holdings to clear up the scandal. He has also denied prior knowledge about the money leaving the country. In former East Germany, most property and businesses were owned by the state and run by the Communists. Although the businesses were supposed to be turned over to a government trust, the Communists are widely suspected of spending their last days in power hiding and transferring the wealth. At a parliament session in Bonn on Tuesday, Ingrid Matthaeus-Maier, a prominent member of the leftist Social Democrats, charged the Democratic Socialists had taken over the ``material worth of the old Communist state without accepting responsibility for 40 years of injustice and a ruined economy.'' Also Friday, prosecutors probing former East German Communist leader Erich Honecker said they had stepped up their investigation, but Honecker said he is not afraid of a trial. Prosecutors are trying to decide whether there is enough evidence to charge the 78-year-old Honecker with corruption and murder for the shoot-to-kill orders aimed at would-be escapees. About 200 people were killed trying to flee from East Germany's hard-line regime. ``I am not afraid of a show trial. I consider all the charges so far brought by the prosecutor's office untenable,'' Honecker was quoted as saying in an interview published in The European newspaper. German Legislator Wolfgang Boetsch said Honecker was demonstrating his ``mockery of the people and cynicism.''

DOC.HEAD: U.N. Begins Angolan Famine Relief Operation
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 8th graf pvs, `Delegates from ...,' with 2 grafs to UPDATE with report of peace talks postponed. Picks up 9th graf pvs, `A leading ...'
DOC.TEXT: A convoy of trucks headed into the central Angolan bush Friday, carrying the first food supplies from a United Nations program to aid 2 million people facing starvation. Under the six-month U.N. plan, 130 million tons of food will be distributed to the hungry in half the 18 provinces of this southern African nation hit by drought and civil war. The first convoy was delayed 24 hours after United Nations officials said they had insufficient guarantees of the trucks' safety from U.S.-backed rebels fighting the leftist government. U.N. officials said the UNITA guerrillas provided assurances of the trucks' safe conduct through rebel-held territory after they were given details about the makeup of the convoy. Last month, UNITA and the Angola government agreed to set up ``peace corridors'' along which humanitarian aid could move safely. Friday's 25-vehicle convoy was carrying 400 tons of food from the western port of Lobito to central provinces hit the hardest by war and drought. Lobito lies on the Atlantic Ocean, about 250 miles south of Luanda. The convoy was expected to arrive Saturday at its destination, the city of Huambo, 150 miles east of Lobito. Portuguese news reports Friday indicated UNITA requested to delay peace talks with the government for at least seven days. The talks were scheduled to begin Tuesday in Portugal. The reports said UNITA sought more time to study Portuguese peace proposals. A leading official from the Portuguese government team which has mediated at four negotiating rounds this year between the Angolan foes said this week a truce was unlikely before next year. UNITA - the National Union for the Total Independence of Angola - has been fighting the Soviet-backed government since Angola gained independence from Portugal in 1975.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Trying To Bring Down Japanese Timber Tariffs
DOC.TEXT: U.S. negotiators at international trade talks in Geneva pushed Friday to increase exports of American finished wood products by eliminating $1 billion worth of Japanese tariffs, a congressman said. The direct talks with the Japanese are part of a larger attempt to reduce tariffs worldwide in negotiations with the European Community on the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade. Officials for the U.S. Trade Representative's Office told an aide to Rep. Ron Wyden, D-Ore., on Friday they are optimistic some kind of favorable agreement will be reached over the next month. Wyden said in a telephone interview from Portland, Ore., that the Japanese ``essentially committed'' to tariff reductions during the Super 301 talks this summer. ``I think ultimately what we are saying is that the Japanese have to live up to their end of the bargain. This market-opening agreement struck with the Japanese in effect said there are going to be substantial Japanese tariff reductions,'' he said. ``We are talking about more than a billion dollars worth of sales and 40,000 jobs. This is absolutely critical to our region right now at a time the timber cut has gone down as a result of the decisions on the northern spotted owl. I think that one of our big job-producers can be assuring access to Japanese markets.'' U.S. trade officials expect the Japanese initially to resist the push toward tariff elimination, but likely eventually will go along with some reductions as outlined in the Super 301 agreements this summer, Wyden aide Steve Jenning said. During those talks, the Japanese agreed to ease various fire, building and inspection standards that are expected to boost U.S. wood products exports by about $1.5 billion annually. However, the Japanese said during Super 301 talks they would not commit to specific tariff reductions until the GATT negotiations in Geneva.

DOC.HEAD: Prime Minister's Backers Unhappy With TV Coverage
DOC.TEXT: Aides to Prime Minister Tadeusz Mazowiecki on Friday accused state television of giving Lech Walesa favorable treatment in its campaign coverage. Walesa and Maziwiecki are facing off in Poland's first popular presidential election, to be held Nov. 25. In a letter to the State Election Commission, the press office of Mazowiecki's campaign listed examples of broadcasts it said supported Walesa, or included anti-Mazowiecki remarks. It asked election officials to demand that television management ``put an end to such practices.'' Jan Dworak, deputy chairman of the state Radio and Television Committee, responded that the state television was trying to report on the campaign in a balanced manner. He said he had received a similar protest from Walesa's camp only a few days ago. ``We cannot give up our basic informative function,'' Dworak said in a telephone interview. ``We cannot decide not to show the prime minister or the (Solidarity) chairman for the next month.'' The letter from Mazowiecki's office cited commentaries by journalists supporting the Solidarity chairman or criticizing government policies. It complained also about the sequence of news items on television newscasts. Dworak said television journalists had been told to be impartial and to put out a balanced news report. ``I understand the growing pre-election emotions of all sides,'' he said. ``I try to analyze all those cases but at the same time I cannot take off the screen all news programs and leave only sports and weather forecasts.'' Each of the six candidates has been allotted equal and free time on the state radio and television by election officials. Their campaign spots, which are carried on the two television channels and four radio stations, started Monday.

DOC.HEAD: Practice Doesn't Always Make Perfect in Desert War Drills
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 5 grafs to CLARIFY that Marines won mock battle despite mishaps. Picks up 4th graf pvs, `For the...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos DHA1,2,3,5
DOC.TEXT: Brig. Gen. Mike Myatt watched his game plan to counter an Iraqi attack go awry in the desert of eastern Saudi Arabia, but in the end the Marines won the day. And for the commander, it was a good test of conditions his forces would confront in a real war. ``You always say the plan is good until you have to execute it, and then you have to change it,'' the 49-year-old infantry officer said with a wry laugh. ``Whatever we plan, the enemy's going to plan some variations.'' The key, he said, is leaders at allng quickly to change. And that is why the Iraqis were defe levels respondiated in the simulated battle Friday - even if the Marines didn't choose the battlefield. For the past two months, about 30,000 Marines commanded by Myatt have been conducting war games in the desert, with Marines defending Saudi Arabia against a mock Iraqi invasion. During an exercise this week, the general was out in a mobile light armored command vehicle, racing across the undulating desert terrain at speeds up to 60 mph, deploying his forces in response to ahe main communications problem, Myatt said, is a blackout in parts of the desert between 9 a.m. and 2 p.m. One way to compensate is sending up planes. Once a C-130 was airborne over the exercise, the command vehicle's communications improved and its range expanded. Myatt, who spent two tours in Vietnam, commands all Marine ground and air forces in Saudi Arabia. More than 10,000 Marines are also deployed in the northern Arabian Sea where they have been practicing amphibious assault landings. The months of desert training, he said, have put the force in fighting shape. ``I think we owe it to the mamas and the papas of all these Marines out here to give them the best training that can be,'' Myatt said. ``They ought to know the leaders in charge of their sons and daughters aren't crazy and aren't hoping for hostilities to break out,'' he said. ``But if we have to do it, we're prepared.''

DOC.HEAD: Probe Makes Adjustments Aimed at Extending Sun Study Time
DOC.TEXT: Ulysses adjusted its course toward Jupiter on Friday using a maneuver designed to increase the amount of time the spacecraft will spend studying the sun's poles. The probe ignited its thrusters to slightly change the course, said Franklin O'Donnell, spokesman for the National Aeronautics and Space Administration's Jet Propulsion Laboratory. ``This is just to tweak the trajectory for the maximum amount of time over the sun's poles,'' he said. The latest mid-course correction and four days of thruster firings that began Oct. 15 will add a week to the time the $250 million Ulysses spends orbiting the sun's high latitudes during its five-year, $750 million joint mission by NASA and the European Space Agency. Ulysses was launched from space shuttle Discovery on Oct. 6. On Feb. 8, 1992, the spacecraft will use Jupiter as a ``gravity slingshot'' to leave the plane in which all the planets orbit the sun. That will allow Ulysses to fly almost over the sun's south pole in 1994 and north pole in 1995. O'Donnell said another trajectory maneuver may be needed in the weeks before Ulysses whizzes around Jupiter.

DOC.HEAD: Williams on Whistle-Stop Tour; Richards Charges Intimidation
With AM-Voters Revenge, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Republican Clayton Williams embarked on a whistle-stop tour Friday and Democrat Ann Richards campaigned with U.S. Rep. Richard Gephardt, while two polls showed the gubernatorial slugfest tightening. A Mason-Dixon opinion survey conducted for various media organiations put Williams at 45 percent and Richards at 43 percent. A Texas Poll showed the race 42-35 for Williams. The Mason-Dixon Poll was based on interviews with 824 likely voters between Monday and Wednesday. It had a margin of error of 3.5 points. Since Oct. 11, that survey said, Williams' support has fallen from 51 percent to 45 percent. The Texas Poll, conducted Oct. 19-29 by the Public Policy Resources Laboratory of Texas A&M University for Harte-Hanks Communications, involved interviews with 622 likely voters. It had a margin of error of 4 points. With the election just four days away, Williams made seven stops during his railroad tour from San Antonio to Houston. ``Thanks for comin' out today,'' he shouted to a cheering crowd in Luling. ``Luling, Texas, a little bit of the oil patch. I come from the oil patch. When oil was $40 a barrel and Texas was booming I was 6-feet-four,'' Williams said, gesturing well above his head. ``But now, I'm all that's left.'' Williams began each stop introducing several members of his family. Then he would give a speech, step off the train, shake hands, kiss babies and ask for votes. Between stops, the train would speed past miles and miles of rural ranchland. In Luling, bales of hay lined one part of the railroad tracks while a donkey stood nearby wearing a red blanket and visor that said ``We Love Claytie.'' In Longview, Richards raised the issue of intimidation of black voters and called again for Williams to release his income tax returns. ``You ought to be able to see whether or not someone who aspires to lead this state cares enough about government to pay his fair share in running the government,'' she said. Before the rally, Richards was asked about allegations by Democratic national leaders that Republicans have been intimidating voters in east Texas. The Democratic officials cited a newspaper ad warning of jail terms and fines for violating absentee voting regulations and said black voters who got mail ballots also received anonymous postcards threatening prosecution of those who gave a false reason for requesting a mail ballot. Gregg County Republican Chairman William Osborne has defended the newspaper ad and said Republicans had nothing to do with the postcards. ``This is a repeated pattern,'' Richards charged. ``I've been through a lot of elections where they attempted to do that. It is so cynical that you would distort and attempt to take advantage of someone's democratic right in this free society and keep them from voting.''

DOC.HEAD: Smooth Landing for Hobbled Jumbo Jet
DOC.TEXT: An American Airlines DC-10 en route to Dallas from London made an emergency landing Friday at Kennedy International Airport because of a blown tire and problems with a flap, officials said. None of the 225 passengers aboard Flight 51 required any medical attention. ``Not even an aspirin,'' said Port Authority Officer Dennis Engler. Passengers were taken off the plane and put on another American Airlines jet to complete the trip, said airline officials in Fort Worth, Texas. The plane had a wing flap that would not contract and reported blowing a tire during takeoff from London's Gatwick Airport, said airline spokesman Tim Smith. The pilot, Capt. Thomas Eanes, 59, told Engler, ``I thought I had everything under control.''

DOC.HEAD: New International Anti-Drug Agreement Coming Into Force
DOC.TEXT: A new global pact that provides for seizure of drug traffickers' bank accounts and property means ``there is no place for them to hide throughout the world,'' U.S. Attorney General Dick Thornburgh said Friday. The accord also commits nations to extradite accused drug traffickers to the countries where they face charges. ``It aims to hit the drug traffickers where it hurts the most; that is to say, in their freedom of movement and their liberty,'' said Margaret J. Anstee, coordinator of all U.N.-drug control activities. Both she and Thornburgh spoke about the new pact at a news conference at the United Nations. The new agreement, known as the U.N. Convention Against Illicit Traffic in Narcotic Drugs and Psychotropic Substances, takes effect Nov. 11. It binds the United States and 26 other nations that accepted it to cooperate in battling drug trafficking. Sixty-two more nations and the European Economic Community have indicated they will adopt it. ``Nov. 11 is a date that used to be observed worldwide as Armistice Day, marking the end of the first World War,'' Thornburgh said. ``Nov. 11 this year, however, is anything but an Armistice Day. It is a worldwide declaration of war upon those engaged in illegal drug trafficking around the world.'' The convention criminalizes each step of the drug-trafficking process, from cultivation or production of precursor chemicals to laundering of profits. Among its major provisions: -All signatory nations agree to share criminal evidence and to extradite accused traffickers, eliminating safe havens; -Nations agree to adopt banking laws that allow them to seize drug profits and banking records; -The manufacture and sale of chemicals needed to make drugs is to be monitored in each nation; -Shipments of illegal drugs are to be allowed to pass through countries so police agencies can trace them to their recipients, a technique common in the United States but new in international law. -Signatory nations will require commercial shipping, airline, and other transport companies to take steps to make sure their carriers are not used to carry drugs. ``The convention is a determined statement by the international community that it will not tolerate the misery, degradation and death being perpetrated by drug traffickers on a massive scale,'' said Anstee. The accord was initially called for by 106 nations at an international conference in Vienna, Austria, in December 1988.

DOC.HEAD: Poll Indicates Environmental Initiative Vote Will Be Close
DOC.TEXT: The California environmental initiative known as Big Green has lost some of its supporters, according to results of a poll released Friday that projected a close vote next week. The initiative, Proposition 128, was favored by 41 percent of the voters surveyed and opposed by 43 percent in the last pre-election poll, pollster Mervin Field reported. In early October, a poll by Field's organization showed Big Green's supporters led its opponents by 15 points. The initiative would curb auto emissions, ban oil development in state waters, bar pesticides suspected of causing cancer and create an elected post of environmental czar. The Field organization said the poll has a 5.8-point margin of error. The latest figures were based on a survey of 1,248 voters in late October.

DOC.HEAD: New Poll Shows Edgar, Hartigan in Dead Heat
DOC.TEXT: The governor's race between Democrat Neil Hartigan and Republican Jim Edgar is too close to call, according to a new poll. Edgar has 46 percent to Hartigan's 44 percent, with a 3.5 percent margin of error, making the race a virtual deadlock, according to the survey conducted for Copley News Service. The poll was conducted Sunday through Wednesday by Political-Media Research Inc. of Washington.
DOC.HEAD: Republicans Not Laughing at `Tongue-in-Cheek' Invitation
DOC.TEXT: The party invitations from former GOP candidate Vince Orza were supposed to be tongue in cheek, but some state Republicans aren't amused. Defeated in his bid for the Republican gubernatorial nomination in Oklahoma, Orza held ``The Orza for Governor Party ... 94!?'' The invitation read: ``Vince and Patti cordially invite you to celebrate our victory - our defeat and make fun of Bill Price.'' Republican Price, who defeated Orza in the primary runoff, already was irked because Orza refused to endorse him. Orza's party was held last weekend and among those attending was Price's Democratic opponent, David Walters. The Democrat won a straw poll of partygoers. Orza says his views are closer to those of Walters than Price on many issues. Orza has reminded reporters he pledged at the time of the runoffs only to support the Republican Party, and said he endorses neither Walters nor Price. That brought howls of outrage from some Republicans and the invitation caused consternation. ``If this is a real deal, he's got the political judgment of Saddam Hussein,'' Republican state Sen. Gary Gardenhire said after viewing a copy of the invitation. ``I thought it stunk,'' Price aide Mike McCarville said Thursday.
DOC.HEAD: Wellstone Criticizes Foreign Auto Dealer PAC For Running Pro-Boschwitz Ad
DOC.TEXT: Senate candidate Paul Wellstone asked TV stations to stop airing an advertisement supporting the re-election of Sen. Rudy Boschwitz. The stations refused. The ad by the Auto Dealers and Drivers for Free Trade Political Action Committee describes Boschwitz as a man who escaped Nazi Germany as young boy and started his own business. It says he is a leader in the federal child nutrition program and has been honored by groups that support cutting government waste. The Jamaica, N.Y.,-based PAC has no connection to Minnesota and its last-minute campaign doesn't allow voters to judge the independent group's credibility, says Wellstone. ``This kind of intrusion is exactly what is turning people off to politics. What are these outsiders buying with this'' money? said Wellstone. Twenty-five to 30 of its member dealerships are in Minnesota, said Frank Glacken, the PAC's executive director. The ad is costing the PAC $192,000 and started running Wednesday. Executives from Twin Cities television stations KARE, KMSP, KSTP and WCCO said they have no plans to stop airing the commercial.
DOC.HEAD: Hickel Continues to Move Ahead in Governor's Race
DOC.TEXT: Third-party candidate Wally Hickel is leading in the Alaska governor's race, according to a new poll. Hickel was the choice of 37 percent of the voters surveyed. Republican Arliss Sturgulewski was supported by 28 percent, followed by Democrat Tony Knowles at 26 percent. The copyright poll of 530 registered voters was commissioned by the Anchorage Daily News and Anchorage radio station KENI. It has an error margin of plus or minus five percentage points. It was conducted Monday through Wednesday. A week earlier, Hickel had 35 percent, Sturgulewski 30 percent and Knowles 24 percent, according to a poll by the same firm, Dittman Research Corp. of Alaska.
DOC.HEAD: Williams Targeted by Second Organization for His Arts Funding Stand
DOC.TEXT: A conservative group is criticizing Democratic Rep. Pat Williams for supporting legislation to fund the National Endowment for the Arts. Williams favors using taxes to finance pornography, the American Family Association Foundation of Tupelo, Miss., said in a letter to Montana residents. Evangelist Pat Robertson's Christian Coalition has launched a mailing and radi ad campaign against Williams for the same reason. Republican Brad Johnson of Bozeman, Williams' challenger, distanced himself from the Christian Coalition's ads, saying it's ``not the kind of tone I want to see in this campaign.''
DOC.HEAD: Hartigan Campaign Says Reporters Must Pay Own Way on Flyarounds
DOC.TEXT: Neil Hartigan's campaign says it will require news organizations to pay in advance for reporters accompanying the gubernatorial candidate. Hartigan's aides said it was not a sign of financial problems in the Democrat's bid to defeat Republican Jim Edgar in Tuesday's election. The estimated air fare for covering Hartigan over the weekend would cost $1,000 per reporter.

DOC.HEAD: President Bush to Visit Czechoslovakia Nov. 17
DOC.TEXT: President Bush will make the first-ever visit by a U.S. president to Czechoslovakia, a one-day stop on Nov. 17, the state news agency CTK reported Friday. The visit, at the invitation of Czechoslovak President Vaclav Havel, coincides with the anniversary of the start of last year's popular revolution that ended four decades of Communist rule. On Nov. 17, 1989, police repressed a student protest, setting off a wave of demonstrations that eventually led the Communist government to resign. Bush was to be in Europe for a 34-nation summit meeting Nov. 19 in Paris of the Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe. He is visiting Germany on Nov. 18 for talks with Chancellor Helmut Kohl.

DOC.HEAD: Romanians Protest Price Increases
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with details of demonstration, ends peacefully, new government measures. ADDS byline. No pickup
DOC.TEXT: Thousands of Romanians marched angrily through Bucharest for the second straight day Friday to protest government-announced price increases. About 2,000 workers of the Alfa trade union rallied in front of Parliament. An additional 3,000 protesters marched from central University Square to government headquarters, chanting demands that President Ion Iliescu resign. The crowds dispersed peacefully later in the evening. The protesters first assembled Thursday evening, after the government lifted price controls, doubling or tripling the cost of some foods and other consumer items. Rents, energy and certain basic food items were excluded from the price hikes. Demonstrators blocked traffic on Nicolae Balcescu boulevard, a main thoroughfare. They waved flags and banners protesting the price rises, and shouted ``Down with Iliescu!'' Officials of Alfa, an umbrella organization of unions from heavy industries, also demanded that the government privatize more than the 30 percent of state-owned companies it plans to sell as part of its reform package. The government said Friday it will compensate pensioners, handicapped people and some groups of workers to help ease the price increase shock. It also announced it would double the interest rates offered on savings by banks and approved plans to open up 100 state-owned firms to foreign capital. Gabriel Andreescu, a leading opposition figure, expressed concern that the government might respond with force if demonstrations continued. But special police units, brought downtown Thursday, kept out of sight behind the nearby Senate building on Friday. The last major protests at University Square were in August, when anti-government demonstrators blocked the square every evening for a week. About 100 people were arrested. The protesters accused Iliescu, a former Communist, of keeping many of the policies and attitudes of the former hard-line government led by Nicolae Ceausescu. Ceausescu and his wife, Elena, were executed in December's popular uprising. In the spring, University Square was occupied for 53 days by anti-Communist ralliers. In mid-June the government sent in police and miners, who clubbed and beat demonstrators, leading to six deaths.

DOC.HEAD: Thousands Gather in Stadium to Meditate for Persian Gulf Peace
DOC.TEXT: About 5,000 people gathered in a stadium Friday for a group meditation to send good vibrations to the Persian Gulf and help avoid war there. Twenty minutes of medititation is ``kind of short'' to result in world peace, but the event may result in ``some softening, some kind of statement that is more reconciliatory'' said David Orme-Johnson, a psychologist at the Maharishi International University in Fairfield, Iowa. Organizers from the Swedish branch of Transcendental Meditation had hoped to fill the 15,000-seat Globe stadium for the largest group meditation in history. But about 5,000 people bought $35 tickets for the event. About three-fourths of those attending were experienced meditators. A group in the Netherlands in recent years brought together 7,000 people for a mass meditation. Organizers of Friday's event said thousands of other people around the world also concentrated their energies during the 20-minute meditation. Transcendental Meditation founder Maharishi Mahesh Yogi delivered a message in a phone linkup from the Netherlands. ``I expect that we will very soon have irrevocable peace on earth,'' he said. Czechoslovakia's president-writer Vaclav Havel, a meditation practitioner, also sent a message, the organizers said. Swedish Lutherans and some other Protestant churches objected to the event. ``As we see it, it is a covert way of spreading Hinduism and we think people who practice it should be made aware of that,'' said the Rev. Dan Salomonson of the Philadelphia Pentecostal Church in Stockholm. Transcendental Meditation was introduced in Europe and the United States in the 1960s. Individuals repeat a mantra, or sacred word, to achieve a relaxed physical and mental state in which some goal can be envisioned. Orme-Johnson, 49, implied that organized group meditation had led to a softening of Saddam Hussein's martial stance since the Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait. A meditation by 3,000 people in Iowa last month may have created a lull in the gulf crisis, he said. ``That was the time of Saddam's dream and of talk of troop reductions'' in Kuwait, he said, referring to unconfirmed reports that Iraq's president was told in a dream to leave Kuwait.

DOC.HEAD: Government May Drop Civil Suits in U.S. Against Marcoses
DOC.TEXT: President Corazon Aquino said Friday her government may reach out-of-court settlements with the family of late President Ferdinand Marcos in a number of civil lawsuits pending in U.S. courts. Local newspapers reported the Marcoses and a presidential commission were nearing an agreement whereby the government would get 60 percent of the funds deposited in five Hong Kong bank accounts by representatives of Marcos. ``The projected settlement does not entail dropping civil cases in the Philippines, but possibly civil suits in the U.S. only, if the amounts recovered are significant,'' Mrs. Aquino said in a statement. ``Criminal cases are not part of the settlement.'' The Marcoses face 33 civil suits in the Philippines but have never been charged with a criminal offense because the government feared they would demand their right to return from exile in the United States to defend themselves. Marcos died in September 1989 in Hawaii, where he fled after his ouster in the 1986 popular uprising that propelled Mrs. Aquino into the presidency. Imelda Marcos was acquitted in July of criminal charges in New York City that she and her husband embezzled money from the Philippines treasury and used it to buy four buildings in New York. On Thursday, several leading Manila newspapers reported that the Marcos accounts were in the Wing Lung Bank Ltd., Standard Chartered Bank, Hang Lung Bank, Banque de L'Indochine and the Hong Kong and Shanghai Banking Corp. David Castro, chairman of the Presidential Commission on Good Government, was quoted as saying that both the Marcoses and the government do not know the exact amount held in the accounts. ``We both realized that if we continue to litigate on (Marcos') money held in trust by other people outside the country...we could not expect immediate recovery within the time frame of the needs of our people,'' Castro said. The government claims Marcos looted billions of dollars from the national treasury during his 20-year administration and deposited it in Swiss banks or used it to buy real estate outside the country. The money recovered from the Marcoses would be used to fund the administration's agrarian reform program. The government has filed civil suits against Marcos in the Southern District Court of California. The court has frozen all suspected Marcos assets worldwide, including the Hong Kong accounts, but government lawyers reportedly will seek to exclude them.

DOC.HEAD: Mozambique Fighting Spurs New Flight of Refugees to Malawi
DOC.TEXT: Fighting between rebels and government forces in Mozambique has driven 13,000 refugees across the border to Malawi in the last three weeks, a relief agency said Friday. In a statement, the French aid group Medicins Sans Frontieres, or Doctors Without Borders, estimated up to 15,000 more people will flee Mozambique by the end of November. Over the past decade, an estimated 850,000 refugees from Mozambique have crossed into southern Malawi, located north of Mozambique in East Africa. They are fleeing a war between the Marxist government in Maputo and guerrillas of the Mozambique National Resistance organization, known as RENAMO. The latest round of fighting is said to be taking place in the central Mozambican province of Zambesia. Aid officials in Malawi estimate as many as 19,000 people are without shelter and say food supplies and sanitary conditions at refugee camps are being strained by the new influx.

DOC.HEAD: Court Blocks Some Louisiana Judicial Elections
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court on Friday blocked some judicial elections scheduled for Tuesday in Louisiana. The court, by a 7-2 vote, granted an emergency request by blacks in the state who said the elections would violate the federal Voting Rights Act. The court order barred elections for trial judges in 10 districts and appeals court judges in two districts. The blacks said the districts - as well as the election date - are invalid because they have not been approved by the Justice Department as required by the voting rights law. Some judges in the districts already were elected in an Oct. 6 primary. The blacks said they should be barred from taking office. A three-judge federal court on Oct. 24 permitted the elections but warned candidates that winners would be removed from office if their districts did not receive federal approval within 90 days. The three-judge court also approved holding any run-off elections, if necessary, on Dec. 8. Friday's high court order also suspends any run-off elections for the affected districts. The Bush administration sided with the blacks who challenged the judicial elections. The Justice Department said permitting the elections would violate the voting rights act, even though the judges only would be elected on a provisional basis. The law requires Louisiana and other Southern states to submit any election changes for Justice Department approval. The department said incumbent judges could remain in office until it has the chance to study the districts and decide whether the voting power of blacks has been reduced illegally. Justices Byron R. White and Harry A. Blackmun dissented, voting to permit the elections. The case is Clark vs. Roemer, A-327.

DOC.HEAD: N.Y. Attorney General Asks FCC to Reconsider Nynex Consent Decree
DOC.NOTE: EDS: SUBS last graf with 2 grafs to give Nynex comment
DOC.TEXT: New York state officials say that based on new and ``extensive'' evidence of wrongdoing by New York Telephone, the Federal Communications Commission should reconsider a consent decree that ended its investigation of the New York and New England Telephone companies. In a filing scheduled for delivery Monday to the FCC, Robert Abrams, the state attorney general, and Richard Kessel, executive director of the New York Consumer Protection Board, said New York Telephone's violations of commission rules on affiliate transactions ``was far more extensive and had a far greater effect on NYT's rates than the commission believed when it adopted the consent decree.'' A copy of the filing made available to The Associated Press on Friday also said the FCC had not given an explanation for agreeing to the consent decree and that it had foreclosed participation by New York authorities into the investigation of the two Nynex Corp. subsidiaries. On Oct. 4, the FCC announced that the two telephone companies had agreed to make voluntary contributions totaling $1.4 million to the U.S. Treasury. They also agreed to cut their long-distance rates $35.5 million to resolve allegations that they overcharged customers through a Nynex subsidiary, Materiel Enterprises Co. In exchange, the FCC ended its investigation without finding any wrongdoing. The FCC in February had said it intended to fine the two telephone companies $1.4 million - a record amount - over apparent violations of FCC rules governing transactions between regulated telephone companies and unregulated affiliates. The FCC had ordered the companies to return $35.5 million to long-distance customers because of alleged $118.5 million in overcharges to NYT and NET by Nynex Materiel Enterprises Co. (MECO), an unregulated Nynex purchasing subsidiary. The companies agreed to the $35.5 million rebate, to be made within 30 days, and also said they would reduce their capital accounts by $32.6 million to ``remove the alleged excess profits on plant and equipment purchased from MECO.'' Local phone rates were not be affected by the rebates. A few days before the FCC consent decree, New York state utility regulators authorized a study into whether Nynex should be forced to divest New York Telephone. The new filing said evidence submitted during a rate increase proceeding show that FCC methodology ``vastly understates the unjust and unreasonable charges ultimately passed on to New York consumers in their interstate rates.'' As a result, New York long-distance ratepayers ``have paid rates inflated by NYT's imprudent overpayments to MECO and other Nynex unregulated affiliates.'' An FCC spokeswoman, Audrey Spivack, said the commission had not seen the filing and could not comment. Nynex spokesman Peter Goodale said by telephone from New York that he had not seen the filing and could not respond to specifics. But he noted that the telephone companies already had taken steps to comply with th consent decree, including making the $1.4 million payment to the Treasury. ``We've upheld our end of the bargain and we hope the FCC does as well,'' Goodale said.

DOC.HEAD: Western Hostages Deny Reports of Mistreatment
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERT 3 grafs after 11th graf `The visits' to UPDATE with comments from second American. Hometown unavbl. Picks up 12th graf, `All 10...'
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Iraq on Friday permitted interviews with several American, British and Japanese hostages, who said they eagerly want to go home and denied reports they were being mistreated. The Iraqi Ministry of Information took a group of Baghdad-based reporters to different strategic sites to discount recent reports that foreign hostages are maltreated. ``I love freedom. When I get out of this and go home, I'll go to the beaches and have a nice swim,'' said a man who identified himself as Clem J. Hall, an educator from Takoma Park, Md. Hall said he was in Kuwait until Sept. 19 and was moved to a Baghdad hotel before he and others were taken to vital economic and military installations in Iraq. He and nine other foreigners at a site about 60 miles north of Baghdad said they received adequate food and denied any mistreatment by their unarmed guards. Officials insisted the exact location or the name of the site should not be mentioned. Iraq invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2, prompting a U.S.-dominated military buildup in Saudi Arabia. Iraqi officials responded to the buildup by refusing to allow Westerners to leave the country. They later allowed women and children to leave, but took some 600 Western and Japanese men to strategic sites as ``guests'' to try to prevent an attack on Iraq. In recent days, there has been an escalation of claims in the West that the foreigners were being mistreated. Iraqi officials have denied the claims and said that all the foreigners were given adequate food and medical treatment. Information Minister Latif Jassim said President Bush was using claims of mistreatment as a pretext for an attack on Iraq. The visits on Friday were meant to demonstrate that the hostages are well treated. ``The food is decent. I eat well and I'm treated well,'' said a second American, Charles Keegan, 56, an investment strategist who worked three years for the Kuwaiti Investment Co. But Keegan said he had been rounded up on Sept. 19 and had since been kept against his will. Keegan's hometown was not available. All 10 foreigners seen said they had been given good treatment. But they disputed the wisdom of Iraq holding them to deter war, saying that neither Bush nor British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher would be deterred. Briton Frank Graham said Mrs. Thatcher would fight a war despite the fact that hundreds of British citizens were taken hostage into a number of strategic sites in Iraq. ``If she wants to bomb, she will bomb, whether we are here or not,'' said Graham, 49, who was working as an engineer more than four years for the Kuwaiti Minsitry of Electricity and Water. The foreign hostages said they received messages from their families over the BBC and the Voice of America radio. ``The BBC messages keep us sane. Without them, we could not have heard anything from them,'' said Leon Corral, 45, another British hostage. Iraqi officials at the site said that they arranged for the hostages to send and receive letters from their families, and accused authorities in Britain and the United States of blocking the mail. The Japanese hostages said they receive food and medical supplies from their embassy in Baghdad and expressed hope that former Japanese Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone might be able to release some of them when he visits Baghdad over the weekend. Sercho Saisso, regional manager of Japanese Airways, said he was arrested in Kuwait and moved to Baghdad with about 200 other Japanese who have been relocated at different strategic sites. Saisso said his embassy sends Japanese food for fellow nationals being held.

DOC.HEAD: Slovak Leader Cancels Departure Amid Fears of Secession
DOC.TEXT: The Slovak premier, who has warned that his republic may secede from Czechoslovakia, has postponed a visit to Hungary because of ethnic tension at home, a news agency reported Friday. Later, the Slovak governing coalition's interior minister, Anton Andras, resigned. He left under pressure from Slovak Premier Vladimir Meciar, who had accused his political rival of incompetene. The state CTK news agency quoted Frantisek Miklosko, president of the Slovak parliament, as announcing postponement of the trip to Hungary. ``Due to the newest political development in the Slovak republic, we have officially apologized to the Hungarian representatives yesterday and asked them to postpone the visit to an unspecified date.'' Miklosko was to accompany the premier on a three-day visit to Hungary beginning Friday. Meciar, the premier, warned recently that nationalists might declare Slovak independence from Czechoslovakia on Nov. 17, the first anniversary of street unrest that culminated in the toppling of Communist rulers in this Eastern European country. The postponement of Meciar's visit to Hungary came a week after nationalist protesters in Bratislava, the Slovak capital, demanded the republican government's resignation and Parliament's dissolution. The nationalists oppose recent legislation permitting Slovakia's estimated 500,000 ethnic Hungarians to use their language in areas where they comprise at least 20 percent of the population. Some analysts suggested, however, that the trip has been canceled because of the political rivalry between Meciar and his interior minister. Meciar belongs to Public Against the Violence, which played a key role in orchestrating the overthrow of the Communists. Andras is a member of the conservative Christian Democratic Movement, the junior Slovak government coalition partner of Public Against Violence. Milosko announced on state television that Slovak Vice Premier Jan Carnogursky will act as interim leader of the interior ministry.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Admits Secretly Dating Key Witness in Drug Case
DOC.TEXT: A judge is under investigation after admitting she secretly dated a police officer, whom she later married, while he was a key prosecution witness in a drug case she handled. Municipal Judge Irene Takahashi said Thursday she didn't reveal her affair with El Cerrito officer Michael Ramirez but said she should have before presiding over an October 1989 preliminary hearing. Takahashi said she realized failure to disclose the relationship deprived Alberto Torrez and Luis Lozano of their constitutional right to a fair and impartial hearing. The revelations came in an agreement Takahashi reached with attorneys for the two men, who are charged with selling cocaine. Takahashi's attorney, Ephraim Margolin, said his client entered the agreement to avoid a lengthy inquiry into impropriety charges. He said it was premature to discuss the impact her conduct would have on her career. The Commission on Judicial Performance is investigating Takahashi, said visiting Judge Julie Conger of the Berkeley-Albany Municipal Court, who is now handling the drug case. The original charges against the men were dismissed in April after defense attorney Linda Fullerton challenged the propriety of Takahashi presiding over the preliminary hearing. The case has been refiled and the defense is trying to have it thrown out a second time. The defense maintains the district attorney's office should be disqualified for its handling of the first attempt to dismiss the case. Fullerton and Deputy Public Defender Oscar Bobrow are charging government misconduct in the prosecutors' failure to investigate whether Takahashi and Ramirez were dating at the time of the hearing. Deputy District Attorney Nancy Georgiou said Ramirez also is being investigated for misconduct for allegedly lying about when he and Takahashi became involved. The two were engaged in December 1989 and married in September. Ramirez initially told the district attorney's office and his supervisor that the affair began after the preliminary hearing. He later admitted he was dating the judge at the time.

DOC.HEAD: Cattle Disease Detected in Switzerland
DOC.TEXT: Switzerland on Friday eported its first case of mad cow disease, which has already killed thousands of Britain's cattle and prompted some countries to ban British beef. The Swiss Economics Ministry said it would ban exports of infected or suspicious beef only if more cases are found. The first case was diagnosed Friday in the brain of a cow from northwestern Switzerland that was slaughtered in July, officials said. There is no evidence humans can catch the disease, which is transmitted among animals through feed and excrement, the statement said. Bovine spongiform encephalopathy, as the disease is formally known, attacks a cow's brain and central nervous system, leaving tissue spongy. Afflicted cattle foam at the mouth and cannot stand or walk normally. Infections in Britain last summer led European Community countries and other governments to ban imports of British cattle and beef. Some of the bans have since been lifted. The disease is believed to have spread to the British cows when bones of sheep, which are susceptible to a similar disease, were ground as a supplement in cattle feed. To curb the spread, the British government in September banned the use of brain, spinal cord and other cattle offal in animal feed and pet food. The British government has said more than 18,000 cattle died from the disease in the last four years.

DOC.HEAD: Anti-Nuclear Groups Win Court Fight Against Streamlined NRC Rules
DOC.NOTE: EDs: Subs 7-9: ``The court,'' to clarify that court would allow some consolidation of proceedings, but still held that second round of hearings is needed; also clarifies decision involves one rule some parts of which were upheld sted several rules
DOC.TEXT: A federal appeals court said Friday that the Nuclear Regulatory Commission went too far in attempting to streamline the licensing of future atomic power plants.
