The unanimous decision by the three-judge panel of the U.S. Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit was a victory for anti-nuclear groups that had argued the NRC's streamlining amounted to the public not having adequate say in the licensing of such plants. The court specifically said a ``one-step'' licensing scheme under the NRC regulations, which would allow a power plant operator to get both a construction and operating permit as part of a single proceeding, violated the Atomic Energy Act. The NRC issued its new licensing regulations last year as part of an attempt to simplify the licensing process and reduce uncertainties and delays for atomic plant operators. The action immediately was challenged in court by the Nuclear Information and Resource Service and the Union of Concerned Scientists. ``It's disappointing,'' said NRC spokesman Joe Fouchard. ``We've attempted to craft a rule which provides for early decision making.'' Fouchard said the commission would have to examine the court ruling more closely before deciding on a next step. The court upheld some parts of the NRC regulation including early site approval and standardization of reactor design. But it said that while some combining of the construction and operational permits may be allowed, the commission must hold a second round of hearings after construction is complete, before an operating permit can be issued. Under previous licensing procedures, the commission held formal hearings on construction and then began the procedures again before issuing a permit for actual operation. The streamlined regulations would not have required a second round of hearings. The three-judge panel said the Atomic Energy Act clearly requires the second round of formal hearings so the NRC may ``consider significant new information that comes to light'' during and after the construction phase. The nuclear and electric power industries for years have campaigned for ways to speed up the licensing process for nuclear plants. The process can easily take a dozen years or more under current procedures. ``The court's decision makes clear that the NRC does not have the right to remove the public from the reactor licensing process (by not having a second hearing after construction),'' said Michael Mariotte, executive director of the Nuclear Information and Resource Service. Robert Pollard of the Union of Concerned Scientists said the decision supports the argument that some issues cannot be resolved in a single hearing before construction of a reactor even begins. The opinion was written by Chief Judge Patricia Wald. The other two panel members were Circuit Judge David B. Sentelle and Circuit Judge Clarence Thomas.

DOC.HEAD: Voters Turn Tables On Candidates with Ad Parodies
DOC.TEXT: The revenge wasn't slick but it was sweet when Texas voters broadcast their version of ``America's Funniest Home Videos'' - homemade parodies of the bitter gubernatorial race between Clayton Williams and Ann Richards. For the last year, Texans have been bombarded with poll results, slip-ups and million-dollar mudslinging during what some say is the nastiest race for the governor's office in recent memory. Dallas' public television station, KERA, decided it wasn't going to take it anymore and turned its airwaves over to viewers for 30 minutes this week in what they called ``Voters' Revenge.'' The program featured 12 of the best submitted homemade video parodies and skits of the gubernatorial race between Richards, the Democrat, and Williams, the Republican. In Irwin Arnstein's video, the 31-year-old computer programmer imitated Williams during a campaign ad. ``Yes folks, I plan to service Texas,'' Arnstein said, referring to William's admission to being ``serviced by prostitutes'' as a young boy. `If you elect me, there's nothing for you to do but sit back and enjoy it,'' the video continued, referring to a comment Williams made in March comparing bad weather and rape. ``If it's inevitable, just relax and enjoy it, '' Williams told reporters. In another video, voters were asked to compare Williams to an animal. Examples included rooster, weasel, jackass, piranha and ostrich. The recording quality resembled homemade 8mm movies - nothing like that of ads run by Richards and Williams, who have spent a record-breaking $32 million on the campaign. Some ads were corny, like a spoof sent in by Alicia Plaski featuring a rewritten Clement C. Moore's ``'Twas The Night Before Christmas'': ``Twas the week before the election and all through the state, the voters were waiting for just one debate. `` ... The voters were all snuggled al warm in their beds, while visions of gas hikes danced in their heads. '' Most videos poked more fun at Williams, whose west Texas bravado has resulted in several statements he later retracted. But video directors say that's because there's more material. ``Well, Ann Richards has done nothing to offend anybody whereas Clayton William ... they had plenty of ammunition,'' Arnstein said. ``It was like hitting the broad side of a barn with a two by four.'' One segment titled ``Hot Talk'' featured controversial Dallas disc jockey John Ford, of radio station KDGE, playing a sleazy talk show host. In the video, created by KDGE intern Jeff Ballew, Ford interviewed the two ``candidates from hell.'' The ``Satan Williams'' character, played by Ballew, sported a cowboy hat and devil's horns. If elected, he promised viewers a ``Satan Williams' Deluxe Detention Center and Family Theme Park.'' Meanwhile, a much younger looking ``Sat-Ann Richards,'' capped in a large curly white wig, told voters she once dated Elvis. Ballew, 28 and a sophomore at North Lake Community College, says he last voted in a governor's race, but was unsure of the date. Another Williams imitator joked that women's rights was a contradiction in terms. His campaign promises included sending all teen-agers caught smoking marijuana ``to hell.'' Since the program aired Wednesday, viewer response has been ``mostly positive,'' said Jonnie England, KERA spokeswoman. About 15 viewers complained at the satirical portraits of Williams. But others said they enjoyed the break from the usual election coverage. It was not known whether the candidates were offended by the parodies. ``I have no time to watch it,'' said Gordon Hensley, a Williams spokesman. Margaret Justus, a spokeswoman for Richards said: ``We haven't seen it because we don't have time to look at these things.'' In one video, a three-piece band called The Tenner Shoe River Boys presented their version of the theme from the ``The Beverly Hillbillies'' show. ``Well the next thing you know, ol' Clay's a millionaire. His kinfolks said: `Hey Clay, Austin's over there.' ... Now he's in the runnin' with a lady Democrat. Says, `I'll be a gentleman and always tip my hat.' Tries to pass hisself off as a sensitive dude, But out from his mouth comes a bubblin' crude. Words that is, prostitute. Getting serviced. Lie back and enjoy it.''

DOC.HEAD: Attorney Pushes for Compensation over Abuse Registry
DOC.TEXT: A federal judge's ruling that a state child abuse list fails to provide due process could result in compensation for more than 200,000 people on the computerized registry, a lawyer said Friday. ``This could turn into a fairly expensive proposition,'' said Ronald Meyer, an attorney for the Florida Teaching Profession-National Education Association. He filed a class-action lawsuit challenging parts of the Florida Abuse Registry in April. Although the suit is still pending, an order by U.S. District Judge Maurice Paul ``takes probably 90 percent of the plaintiffs' claims and decides it in their favor,'' Meyer said. But Steve Konicki, spokesman for the state Department of Health and Rehabilitative Services, said the agency was seriously considering appealing the six-page order filed Tuesday. In the order, Paul said Florida law ``does not provide any procedural safeguards or due process'' for people who are named in the 211,000 ``indicated'' reports of abuse on the statewide registry. The computer list was used for screening job applicants for day care centers, camps, nursing homes or other state-run centers that offered care for the young, elderly or handicapped. The list was compiled by reports, often anonymous, through hotlines and from others such as teachers who suspected child abuse. After the Health and Rehabilitative Services conducted an investigation, it would deem the alleged abuse to be ``unfounded,'' ``indicated,'' which means there's a possibiltiy of abuse but no proof, or ``confirmed.'' Some school administrators were listed for spanking students. Teachers, parents and others who are named in an ``indicated'' report of abuse of either a child, an elderly person or a disabled person have no way of appealing, the judge noted. Their names are retained for seven years. ``Nobody should be on this,'' Meyer said. ``This is America - you're not guilty by suspicion. You should either be proven guilty of wrongdoing - in which case let HRS keep your name on a computer - or your name should be cleared and not retained on any computer or anywhere else.'' Paul upheld the way the state handles ``confirmed'' cases of abuse, a process that was changed by the Legislature this year. Paul has yet to certify the lawsuit as a class action, and the amount of damages that would be sought on behalf of the thousands of people named has not yet been calculated, Meyer said. ``The hundreds of thousands of class members ought to be able to receive (something) as a sort of blanket compensation for what they're going through,'' Meyer said. He said the bulk of the 200,000 people named in the indicated reports are probably parents but also lists teachers, nursing home employee and day care workers.

DOC.HEAD: Langer of Morning News Takes Over as APME President
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 2nd graf, `Other new ...' to CORRECT Ritter's affiliation to Gannett News Service, sted Denver newspaper.
DOC.TEXT: Ralph Langer, executive editor of The Dallas Morning News, was elected president of the Associated Press Managing Editors association on Friday at the organization's annual meeting. Other new officers elected are: Vice President Sue Reisinger, managing editor of The Miami Herald's Broward County edition; Secretary Robert Ritter, editor of Gannett News Service; and Treasurer Jan Brandt, assistant managing editor of The Morning News in Tacoma, Wash. The executive committee named Drake Mabry, executive editor of the Ames (Iowa) Daily Tribune, as chairman of the Continuing Studies Committee, and W. Curtis Riddle, publisher of The Lansing (Mich.) State Journal, as vice chairman. Elected to the APME board of directors for three-year terms were Barbara Henry, editor of the Democrat and Chronicle and Times-Union in Rochester, N.Y.; Bill Evans, executive managing editor of The Dallas Morning News; David Hawpe, editor of The Courier-Journal in Louisville, Ky.; Earl Maucker, managing editor of the Sun-Sentinel and Fort Lauderdale News in Fort Lauderdale, Fla.; Bennie Ivory, managing editor of The Clarion-Ledger in Jackson, Miss.; Tonnie Katz, managing editor of The Orange County Register in Santa Ana, Calif.; and Pam Johnson, managing editor of The Phoenix Gazette. Two directors elected representing papers with a circulation of less than 35,000 were Jack Willis, editor of the Muskogee (Okla.) Daily Phoenix & Times Democrat, and Joan Behrmann, executive editor of The Desert Sun in Palm Desert-Palm Springs, Calif. The APME comprises news executives of the member papers of the AP newsgathering cooperative.

DOC.HEAD: Snow Blankets Wyoming, Utah, Colorado
DOC.NOTE: Eds:SUBS 4th graf, `Record high ...' to DELETE reference to Winnemucca, Nev. Picks up 5th graf, `Snow blanketed ...'
DOC.TEXT: A foot of snow fell Friday in parts of Wyoming, Utah and Colorado. The Great Lakes region basked in summer-like conditions. A cold front advanced across the northern Plains and upper Mississippi Valley overnight. Afternoon temperatures dipped 25 to 35 degrees in parts of Minnesota, South Dakota and Nebraska, dropping into the teens and 20s. In contrast, temperatures were in the 60s and 70s from the Great Lakes through southern New England south through the Ohio, Mississippi and Tennessee valleys, the mid-Atlantic states and the southern Plains. Some areas in the Gulf Coast region were in the 80s. Record high temperatures for the date included 72 in Alpena, Mich., 71 in Green Bay, Wis., and 67 in Sault Ste. Marie, Mich. Snow blanketed the central Rockies northeast to western parts of the northern Plains. Up to 12 inches of snow fell in Wyoming, including 9 inches at Lander. In South Dakota, between 1 and 2 inches of snow fell over wide areas. Four inches fell at Hill City and 5 inches of snow fell near Custer. In northern Utah, Alta had at least 13 inches of new snow. In southern Utah, 6 inches fell at Cedar City. Colorado's first major snowstorm of the season hit the San Juan mountains Friday with up to 10 inches of snow, prompting imposition of the chain law for motorists. Thunderstorms rumbled through southeast Arizona and western New Mexico. Snow dusted the higher elevations of central Arizona. Up to 5 inches fell in the mountains of western and northern New Mexico. High pressure over the Carolinas continued to bring warm and windy weather to the southern Plains, the middle Mississippi Valley and the central and eastern Great Lakes. Heavier snowfall during the six hours ending at 1 p.m. EST included 9 inches at Lander, Wyo., 6 inches at Casper, Wyo., and 5 inches at Gallup, N.M. The low in the Lower 48 states was 10 degrees at Winnemucca, Nev. Temperatures around the nation at 3 p.m. EST ranged from 25 degrees at Laramie, Wyo., to 90 degrees at McAllen, Texas.

DOC.HEAD: Rooney Says He's Pulled Back Since `60 Minutes' Suspension
DOC.TEXT: Humorist Andy Rooney said Friday he has tempered his commentary since being suspended from ``60 Minutes,'' in one case shelving plans to criticize a gift to the United Negro College Fund because he didn't want to be branded a racist. ``I have pulled back some. (The suspension) was a chilling experience,'' Rooney said at a meeting of the Associated Press Managing Editors. Rooney, whose humorous essays have closed CBS-TV's ``60 Minutes'' programs for 12 years, was suspended for three weeks without pay in February because of statements attributed to him in a magazine for gays. Rooney denied he made the comments. The experience, however, caused Rooney to decide against criticizing a $50 million gift to the college fund. The March donation by publishing tycoon Walter Annenberg is the largest ever for black colleges. Rooney said he had planned to criticize the gift in his newspaper column as well as his television commentary, but, ``I pulled back because I was chilled. I did not want to be known as a racist.'' Rooney said he still believes it is inconsistent to support all-black or all-female institutions, while criticizing their all-white, or all-male counterparts. Rooney said he had decided not to air the critique on the advice of ``60 Minutes'' correspondent Ed Bradley, who is black, and others, including executives of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People. He also decided against the critique because he was afraid of losing his audience. ``Like all of us, I hold the hope that I would influence the world, and you have to decide on the best way to do that,'' he said. ``You would lose every good affect you would have had.'' Rooney also criticized network television news operations. ``The network news organizations are not what they were,'' he said. ``I feel badly about the people who left newspapers for television.'' As an example, Rooney said news producers sent reporters off ``to stand in front of camels, or minarets, or temples'' to read words written in New York. ``If anybody's looking for a reporter, I think I'm ready to get out of TV,'' he said. ``I'm not comfortable being a famous person,'' he said. ``I'm rude and I don't want to be grabbed on the street'' by strangers seeking autographs.

DOC.HEAD: Iraqi Jailed for Trying to Frame Two Kuwaiti Women
DOC.TEXT: A judge on Friday jailed a former employee of the Kuwaiti embassy for falsely accusing two Kuwaiti women of drugging him and stealing $15,600. Witnesses told the court that Mohammed Ajeel, 38, an Iraqi citizen and employee at the Kuwaiti embassy in London, became infatuated with one of the women early this year. He had been assigned to interpret for the woman when she visited London, where her daughter was being treated at London's St. Thomas's Hospital. On March 28, Ajeel declared to detectives that the 28-year-old woman and her friend, a 25-year-old student, had drugged him and stolen the money. ``Eventually he broke down and admitted the allegations were completely false,'' said prosecutor Robert Hardy. Police said Ajeel told them: ``This woman has been driving me mad, and I cannot sleep. I was completely obsessed by her. I was blind to everything, except my desire to keep her here. I just had to make up this story.'' The women returned to Kuwait after being questioned by British police in the case. Their names were not made public court because they are in hiding in Kuwait and fear retribution by Iraqis who have since invaded their homeland. Ajeel was jailed for six month by the Old Bailey, London's central criminal court. He pleaded guilty to trying to obstruct justice.

DOC.HEAD: Reagan Eulogizes Former U.S. Attorney General William French Smith
LaserPhoto LA3
DOC.TEXT: William French Smith, who was U.S. attorney general from 1981 to 1985 and a member of Ronald Reagan's ``kitchen cabinet,'' was eulogized Friday by his old boss as a man worth listening to. ``For more than two decades, Nancy's and my life was enriched, yes, blessed, by William French Smith,'' Reagan said. ``When he spoke he made sense, and when he spoke, I listened.'' Reagan and others eulogized Smith during a one-hour service attended by 250 people at San Marino Community Church. Smith was 73 when he died of cancer Monday at the University of Southern California's Kenneth Norris Jr. Cancer Hospital. The memorial service came a day after Smith was interred during a private service at Forest Lawn Glendale, said his son-in-law, Lee Lorenzen. Born Aug. 26, 1917, in Wilton, N.H., Smith served as a Navy officer during World War II. As a managing partner of the Los Angeles law firm of Gibson, Dunn & Crutcher, he specialized in corporate relations with labor. As attorney general, Smith oversaw the breakup of AT&T and the deregulation of airlines. ``Bill ... believed firmly in limited government and keeping government as close to the people as possible,'' said U.S. Solicitor General Kenneth W. Starr in his eulogy. Starr, who served under Smith in Washington, described Smith's interests in the ``far reaches of the Department of Justice,'' including his visits to Cambodian refugee camps in eastern Thailand and anti-drug efforts in Pakistan, Peru and Bolivia. Reagan's personal attorney and investment advisor, Smith was also informal chairman of the ``kitchen cabinet'' that helped usher Reagan into the California governor's mansion and the White House. ``It was the source of the greatest comfort to have a friend from home at the Cabinet table,'' Reagan said. ``We really lost a good pal, he was the best,'' said entertainment industry producer Merv Griffin. A eulogy also was delivered by Charles Z. Wick, former director of the U.S. Information Agency. Also in attendance were former Attorney General Edwin Meese III, Sen. Pete Wilson, R-Calif., Eva Gabor and filmmaker Jerry Weintraub. U.S. Attorney General Richard Thornburgh was addressing the United Nations General Assembly in New York and could not attend the service, said Starr. Smith is survived by his wife, Jean; sons William French Smith III, Scott Cameron Smith, Gregory Hale Smith; daughter, Stephanie Smith Lorenzen; stepson G. William Vaughan Jr.; stepdaughter Merry Vaughan Dunn; and seven grandchildren.

DOC.HEAD: Mexican Activists Release German Diplomat Held Hostage
DOC.TEXT: Political activists on Friday freed a German consular agent they held hostage for five days. In exchange, the government promised to review the case of a jailed colleague of the kidnappers, the diplomat said. In Mexico City, members of the same activist group also ended a hunger strike begun Sept. 17 to push for their comrade's release, the Excelsior news service said. They were reportedly told they could discuss the case with authorities. ``I'm just happy I got out,'' the German official, Wolfgang Wilczek, said by telephone a few minutes after his release. Wilczek was at the consular office in Oaxaca, 250 miles southeast of Mexico City, on Monday when five unarmed members of the National Independent Committee moved in and took over the facility. The 11-year-old group is also known as the Independent Committee for the Defense of Prisoners, Persecuted, Disappeared and Political Exiles. The five took Wilczek hostage to pressure the Mexican government to release a member of their organization jailed in connection with the fatal shootings in April of two newspaper security guards in Mexico City. They claim Felipe Martinez Soriano, a former rector of Oaxaca's Benito Juarez Autonomous University, was illegally arrested. Oaxaca state Interior Secretary Ildefonso Zorilla assured in negotiations with the hostage-takers' group that the government would review the legal procedures used in the case, Wilczek said. He sat in on the talks that led to his release. Zorilla also promised the hostage-takers they would not be prosecuted for the kidnapping, Wilczek said. He said the group left his office with Zorilla and reporters. Wilczek said the kidnappers treated him well at first, but at midweek cut off his food and propped him in a chair behind the office door as a shield against any police intervention.

DOC.HEAD: Iraqi Patrol Captures Three French Soldiers, Frees Them
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 11 grafs to ADD military sources saying three were captured in all-terrain vehicle, were under orders not to get close to border. Picks up graf 10 pvs, `Saudi mililtary...'
DOC.TEXT: Iraqi troops captured three French soldiers on a reconnaissance patrol this week near the Saudi Arabian border with Iraq, the Defense Ministry reported Friday. They were later freed. The soldiers, who were taken captive Monday, were turned over to the French Embassy in Baghdad, Iraq's capital, the Defense Ministry said in a communique. It was unclear whether the incident occurred inside Iraqi territory or in Saudi Arabia. A ministry spokesman said later Friday that the soldiers face disciplinary measures for an ``act of carelessness,'' which suggests the incident was on the Iraqi side of the border. The ministry initially reported the capture occurred northwest of Hafar el Batin, a desert city in northeastern Saudi Arabia. Hafar el Batin is about 5 miles inside Saudi Arabia. Attempts to reconcile the different locales were not immediately availing. A French Defense Ministry source, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said the captured soldiers ``committed an error of exceeding their mission. There's a lot of movement around the border right now, and we don't know exactly what happened. The commander who has opened the investigation believes they are responsible.'' About 13,000 French forces, including Foreign Legionnaires, are among the more than 200,000 multinational troops assembled in the Persian Gulf region to face off against Iraq, which invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2. Iraq has about 430,000 troops in Kuwait and near the Saudi border. The Iraqi patrol surprised the French soldiers, who committed no ``hostile act,'' the ministry said. The three were taken to Baghdad and turned over to the French charge d'affaires, the communique said. Other military sources, speaking on condition of anonymity, said the trio was composed of one officer and two non-commissioned officers in an all-terrain vehicle. French forces are scattered around strategic crossroads near the Saudi-Iraqi border, the sources said, but are under strict orders not to get too close to the frontier. Saudi military commanders, who have overall authority over the multinational forces in their country, are aware of the incident, the ministry said. The French army has opened an investigation of the incident and ``will draw all the consequences,'' the communique said. The name of the regiment that the soldiers came from was not disclosed. The incident occurred the same day that an Iraqi Airways jetliner flew 262 French and 17 other Western hostages to freedom in Paris after nearly three months' captivity in Iraq and occupied Kuwait.

DOC.HEAD: Couple in Australia's Dingo Baby Case to Divorce
DOC.TEXT: Michael and Lindy Chamberlain, the couple who claimed their infant daughter was spirited off by a dingo in the Australian outback, are planning to divorce, a newspaper said Saturday. The marriage fell victim to the strains of fighting for more than nine years to clear their names, the Sydney Morning Herald said. The couple claimed in August 1980 that their daughter Azaria was carried away by a dingo, an Australian wild dog, from the tent where they were camping in central Australia near Ayer's Rock. The child's body was never recovered. In 1981, Lindy Chamberlain was charged and later convicted of her daughter's murder. She spent 3{ years in prison but was released after new evidence was discovered - a piece of clothing that indicated a dingo might indeed have taken the child. The infant's disappearance, one of the most hotly disputed criminal cases in Australia's history, was the subject of a Hollywood movie ``A Cry in the Dark,'' starring Meryl Streep as Lindy Chamberlain. The newspaper said the couple is still living together at their home north of Sydney and that it has not been decided who will have custody of their three remaining children. Lindy Chamberlain is in New Zealand on a nine-day trip to promote her book, ``Through My Eyes.''

DOC.HEAD: Miami Blacks Call for School Boycott Over Cuban Appointee
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS two grafs after 5th graf, `Miami is ...' to UPDATE with black leaders urging black voters to go the polls. Pick up 6th graf, `The city ...'
DOC.TEXT: Blacks and Cuban-Americans are at it again in this city where bad ethnic relations seldom get a rest. This time, blacks are outraged at the appointment of a Cuban school superintendent in the nation's fourth largest school district. A 53-year-old veteran black administrator who twice served as interim chief was passed over to promote 39-year-old Octavio Visiedo. Dade County Superintendent Paul Bell died of a heart attack Oct. 16 after eight months on the job. Some blacks reacted to the appointment by calling for a county-wide boycott by black students and workers on election day, hoping to draw attention to charges of inbred racism in the city's power structure. ``Miami is the Selma (Ala.) of the 1990s,'' said Ray Fauntroy, head of the Miami-Dade Chapter of the Southern Christian Leadership Conference. ``It deserves the negative publicity that it gets.'' Black leaders called Friday for the black community to vote on election day. Some were afraid a black boycott might be misinterpreted as a call to stay away from the polls. ``We know that Tuesday, Nov. 6 is D-Day for us,'' said state Sen. Carrie Meek, D-Miami. ``We want people to turn out in numbers like they've never turned out.'' The city had hoped to recover from the negative image of four race riots in the 1980s, spurred by anger over police shootings. The indignant blacks are looking to recall the five school board members who voted Visiedo into the superintendent's seat last week. They say they will attempt to recall Miami Mayor Xavier Suarez and all four city commissioners for this summer's official snub of Nelson Mandela after Mandela made kind comments about Fidel Castro. The Mandela incident sparked a 4-month-old boycott of Miami hotels by some national black organizations. Visiedo, a deputy administrator who has been with the school system for 17 years, was selected over the black community's first choice, Tee S. Greer. He's a black educator with a doctorate who has been with the district for three decades, twice as interim school chief. Although Visiedo has less experience than Greer, school board members said he had impressed them in recent months. He was overseeing the district's finance and business management operations, including a $1.56 billion construction program, considered a top priority in the district. School Board members praise Greer as a competent, well-credentialed administrator, but they cite the decisive style and ``dynamism'' Visiedo displays, despite his relative inexperience. Greer repeatedly has called for calm and is opposed to the boycott. ``I know they hurt,'' he said of the angry black community. ``I would prefer they do something other than keep children out of school.'' The decision was important for the school board in Dade County, where innovative schools have become a hallmark since the administration of Joseph Fernandez, who is now school superintendent in New York City. Black leaders say Greer was passed over on Oct. 24 because of his race and that Visiedo's appointment further tips the imbalance between Cubans and blacks in positions of power. Dade County public school officials say 46 percent of their 295,000 students are Hispanic, 33 percent are black and 19.8 percent are white. ``His selection was purely political and racial,'' said the Rev. Richard Dunn, who headed up the black ministers call for the boycott. Dunn and the Rev. Victor Curry used their call-in talk show on a black-oriented radio station to announce the boycott. At least seven other prominent black ministers have joined, said Dunn. ``We want to expose the blatant racism that persists here in Dade County,'' said Dunn. Although Greer and some black leaders say the boycott would only hurt the students, others believe it it will serve as a badly needed civil rights lesson for black kids. ``It's more than symbolic - we're going to give them a lesson in life,'' said Dunn. ``They did more damage to the children last week than we're going to do to them in one day.'' Visiedo prefers to see the boycott movement as a display of affection for Greer rather than an anti-Cuban statement. ``We inside the system perceive it as a display of concern and affection for a person who has served his community for many, many years,'' Visiedo said. ``I share the concerns of all educators in this county, black, white and Hispanic - that is that we want our kids in school.''

DOC.HEAD: Bones Found That Were Believed Those of Prospective Saint
DOC.TEXT: Skeletal remains were found Friday that were believed to be those of a former Haitian slave under consideration for sainthood, a medical examiner said. ``I'm sure we have his body,'' said Dr. Millard J. Hyland, chief medical examiner for Westchester County. Roman Catholic Church officials hesitated to say whether two days of digging at a small cemetery in the Little Italy section of Manhattan succeeded until the remains of two adults found in the grave of Pierre Toussaint can be studied. ``They didn't come out of the ground in one piece,'' Hyland said. No caskets were found in the grave, which is believed to contain the bodies of Toussaint, his wife and his niece. It is believed they were buried in wooden caskets, which would have disintegrated. Toussaint was buried at Old St. Patrick's Church Cemetery after his death in 1853 at age 87. As a preliminary part of the church's inquiry into his life so that he can be considered for sainthood, his skeletal remains were sought and will be moved to St. Patrick's Cathedral. They eventually would be distributed in Haiti and prominent churches if the church makes him a saint. Church leaders and doctors standing by the grave were disappointed Thursday when only fragments of a few bones were found. They were believed to be mostly animal bones. On Friday, workers, sometimes digging with their hands, found two slightly overlapping skeletons 8 to 9 feet beneath the ground. ``I was expecting nothing,'' Hyland said. ``Bones are sturdy but they don't last forever. I'm surprised to find two intact skeletons.'' He said the remains of one of the bodies was apparently that of a black person, but the other could not immediately be determined. He said he would wait for anthropologists and pathologists to determine the gender of each. The remains were taken into Old St. Patrick's Church, where they will be assembled and studied in a process that will last weeks. Digging at the grave was essentially concluded, church officials said. Monsignor Robert O'Connell said the skull of one of the bodies obviously belonged to an older person because the jaw bones and teeth were worn down and there were cavities in the teeth. ``These are definitely not children,'' he said. Toussaint was born a slave in Haiti in 1766 and moved to New York with his owner's family in 1787. After becoming a hairdresser, he was allowed to keep some of his income and used it to support his owner's wife and child for 20 years after his owner died. The widow freed Toussaint from slavery shortly before she died in 1807. Church officials have said they hope Toussaint could be approved for sainthood by the time Pope John Paul II visits Haiti in 1992 to celebrate the 500th anniversary of the arrival of Christopher Columbus.

Hyosuke Niwa, a former Japanese labor minister, died Friday of heart failure caused by excessive bleeding at age 72, nearly two weeks after he was stabbed by a mental patient at a military ceremony. Niwa, a 12-term member of the governing Liberal Democratic Party in Parliament, was labor minister from December 1988 to June 1989 in the Cabinet of former Prime Minister Noboru Takeshita. Niwa was attacked Oct. 21 while walking to a military ceremony at the Moriyama military base in Nagoya, 170 miles west of Tokyo. He was stabbed with a knife by a 47-year-old mental patient.

Jack Sterling, a morning radio host on WCBS in New York for 18 years, died Wednesday of lung cancer in Stuart, Fla., at age 75. ``The Jack Sterling Show'' was one of the last radio programs to offer live music - by a quintet occasionally joined by the host's drumming. Sterling was also the ringmaster of a children's television show, ``Big Top,'' broadcast live from Philadelphia for seven years. He wrote two books, ``So Early in the Morning'' and ``The Sterling Cookbook.'' He retired from broadcasting in 1979 after spending 25 years with CBS and its affiliates. Sterling is survived his wife, Trish, eight daughters, two stepsons and two stepdaughters.

Lionel B. Richie Sr., father of the popular singer, died Wednesday in Los Angeles at age 75. The cause of death was not disclosed. Richie served in the Army during World War II and worked for many years at the Veterans Hospital and Alexander Insurance Co. in Tuskegee. Lionel Richie Jr. is a founding member of the Commodores singing group.

C.R. Roseberry, whose books documented the histories of Albany, aviation and steamboats, died Thursday after a brief illness at age 88. Roseberry's work as a reporter, critic and columnist at newspapers in Albany, Ithaca, Buffalo and Rochester spanned five decades. His column ``The Melting Pot'' appeared on the editorial pages of the now defunct Knickerbocker News in the late 1930s. Among his books were ``Capitol Story,'' published in the 1960s. Commissioned by the state Office of General Services, it told the story of the more than three decades it took to construct the state Capitol under numerous architects, governors, legislatures and pressures. Roseberry also wrote ``The Challenging Skies,'' a history of aviation from 1919 through 1939. His other works include ``Steamboats and Steamboat Men,'' ``Glen Curtiss, Pioneer of Flight,'' and ``Albany: Three Centuries of a County.'' Roseberry is survived by two sons, several grandchildren and great-grandchildren.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. to Raise Nuclear Issue with New Government
DOC.TEXT: The Bush administration said Friday it will raise the question of nuclear weapons with Pakistan's new government, a question that forced suspension of American aid last month. ``We expect to engage the new Pakistani government early on in discussion of these issues,'' said Assistant Secretary of State John Kelly. ``Meanwhile, we have complied with the law and suspended all military assistance and new economic aid to Pakistan,'' he told a Congressional panel. Before aid can be granted each year, the law requires the president to certify to Congress each year that Pakistan does not possess nuclear weapons. In the fiscal year that began Oct. 1, the United States had planned $564 million for Pakistan. Chairman Stephen Solarz, D-NY, opened the hearing of the Asia-Pacific subcommittee he chairs for the House Foreign Affairs Committee with a blunt warning that ``neither the administration nor Congress is prepared to turn a blind eye toward mounting evidence that Pakistan persists in its pursuit of nuclear weaponry.'' Unless the new government takes steps to prove that it does not have those arms, ``American law is quite clear, no further U.S. assistance can flow to Pakistan,'' Solarz added. For U.S.-Pakistani relations to improve, he said, Pakistan must undertake ``a genuine commitment to democracy, non-interference in the affairs of Pakistan's neighbors and a new willingness to address U.S. nuclear concerns. ``Within this framework, everything is possible, but without it, we will have reached a parting of the ways.'' Kelly said tension between India and Pakistan has eased in recent months and the United States is ready to help the two neighbors develop confidence-building measures, he said. ``It would indeed be ironic if our success in reducing the arms race between the superpowers'' were offset by arms proliferation on the Indian subcontinent. The continuing review of Pakistan's nuclear program is part of such concern, Kelly said, citing a U.S. law, the Pressler amendment, requiring the president to certify annually that Pakistan does not possess a nuclear weapon. He confirmed that lack of the certification when the new fiscal year started in October prompted suspension of aid for Pakistan, planned by the administration at $564 million for 1991. Kelly also said the United States intends to ``review all available information'' in meeting another condition attached by Congress to Pakistan's aid, that last month's parliamentary election be certified as free and fair. Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto's Peoples Party suffered a landslide defeat in the balloting, and Ms. Bhutto charged wholesale fraud. The newly elected assembly and the next government, to be formed by the victorious right-wing Islamic Democratic Alliance under Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif, may be installed Saturday. Kelly said the administration accepts the preliminary finding of a U.S.-organized international observer team that the election was generally fair, but was marked by flaws and controversy that probably did not affect the outcome. ``Hard and fast evidence regarding massive fraud has yet to be documented and presented, but the process of collecting data that would form the basis for such claims is now underway,'' said Kenneth Wollack, executive vice president of the international arm of the U.S. Democratic Party, which organized the 18-nation observer team. Wollack testified that the team's preliminary report ``was not intended as a certification of the elections, and the delegation was quite careful in avoiding statements that could be seen as suggesting such a conclusion.''

DOC.HEAD: City Officials Settle $28 Million Civil Rights Suit for $50,000
DOC.TEXT: A $28 million civil rights lawsuit filed against the city by Lenell Geter, an engineer who was wrongly convicted of armed robbery eight years ago, was to be settled for $50,000 under an agreement reached Friday. The Greenville City Council voted unanimously to settle the case, which has haunted the east Texas town for eight years. ``The city contends that its actions never violated the rights of Geter and the other plaintiffs,'' said Dianne Callander, city attorney. ``But this situation ... has created, to my understanding, a schism in the community.'' Geter, who is black, was sentenced to life in prison in 1982 for the armed robbery of a Kentucky Fried Chicken restaurant, even though his co-workers at E-Systems, a defense contractor, testified he was at work that day. An all-white Dallas County jury convicted Geter and he served 18 months before he was exonerated. U.S. District Judge Barefoot Sanders dismissed most of Geter's claims against the city and its police department Aug. 14. The claims against Greenville police Lt. Jim Fortenberry, who originally implicated Geter in the robbery, were left intact. Geter's attorney, George Hairston, was unavailable for comment Friday when contacted at his New York office. According to the settlement, which brings to an end the nearly 7-year-old lawsuit, the council does not admit liability of its own or fault on the part of Fortenberry. Before the settlement, Geter's attorneys offered out-of-court settlements of up to $1 million, which the city council rejected. Geter's case received national attention and was the subject of a CBS ``60 Minutes'' story and a television movie. The settlement will come out of the city's general fund.

DOC.HEAD: Convicted Arkansas Attorney General Says He'll Resign
DOC.TEXT: Arkansas' top legal officer announced Friday he will step down, effective Monday, because of his felony theft conviction. ``Although my future at this point is not certain, that uncertainty must not affect the office of the Attorney General,'' Steve Clark told reporters. ``Therefore I have decided it's in the state's best interest that I resign as attorney general,'' he said. A jury convicted Clark on Thursday of felony theft by deception and fined him $10,000. Clark maintained his innocence Friday. He said he was discussing a possible appeal with his attorney. ``I want the people of Arkansas to know that I've made mistakes, and I apologize for those mistakes, but I'm not guilty of theft by deception,'' he said. The prosecutor in Clark's trial charged that the attorney general used his state Visa card to prop up his gubernatorial campaign and failing personal financial condition. Clark's attorney, Bill Bristow, argued Clark could use his state Visa card in any way Clark saw fit.

DOC.HEAD: Man Shot by Judge Had Been in Trouble Before
DOC.TEXT: A man who was shot and injured by a judge Halloween night when he allegedly tried to break into his house was once convicted of double murder, but the conviction was overturned, police said. Jeffrey Dale Parnell was convicted of murdering two drug dealers and burying them in a sugarcane field, records showed. The victims were robbed of money and drugs before they were shot in 1981. An appeals court reversed Parnell's conviction in October 1986, saying statements made to key witnesses were improperly used as evidence. The state dropped the charges because key witnesses refused to cooperate in a new trial. Richard Barlow, the prosecutor in the murder case, said Thursday Parnell had about 30 arrests and no convictions. His 21-page record includes charges of kidnapping, involuntary sexual assault and robbery with force. Parnell, 30, was shot in the stomach Wednesday with a .22 caliber pistol by Judge Harvey Baxter when he and another man allegedly tried to break into the judge's home. The intruders wore gorilla masks. The 60-year-old judge and his wife were not injured. Baxter returned to the bench Thursday. Parnell was hospitalized in good condition Friday. He was arrested at the hospital and charged with attempted murder, armed burglary, aggravated battery and use of a firearm during the commission of a felony. The second man remained at large.

DOC.HEAD: RETRANSMITS to ADD Writethru designation, editor's note.
Millionaire Candidate Says He Paid No Income Tax In 1986
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout with Williams saying he paid no income tax in 1986, details; PRECEDES Luling. No pick up.
DOC.TEXT: Millionaire Republican gubernatorial candidate Clayton Williams said Friday he didn't pay any income taxes in 1986 because of the poor economy. Williams, who has refused repeated calls by his rival, Democrat Ann Richards, to release his income tax returns, made the remark in response to a reporter's question. ``Yes, I've paid lots of income tax, lots, lots,'' he said. ``I'll tell you when I didn't pay any income tax was 1986, when our whole economy collapsed.'' Bill Cryer, Richards' press secretary, said Williams' admission shows why Williams has refused for months to make public his income tax returns. ``Absolutely, it's no wonder he didn't want to release his income tax (returns),'' Cryer said, adding that the Richards campaign thinks Williams now needs to make all his recent returns public as the Democrat did months ago. ``It is an absolute necessity now that we know whether or not this man - who is one of the richest men in the United States - paid any income taxes like the rest of us,'' Cryer said. ``In 1986, I can understand he was going through some hard times. But everybody in Texas was. And we all paid our taxes then,'' Cryer said. He said Richards' 1986 return showed she paid $47,343 in income taxes on earnings of $154,000. That included her $68,000 state salary, capital gains, $14,000 in interest income and a divorce settlement. Williams' admission came during a whistlestop train trip from San Antonio to Houston. He pledged to boost the state's economy, veto any income tax and fight a war on drugs. Richards, campaigning with Missouri Congressman Richard Gephardt in east Texas, accused Republicans of trying to intimidate black voters and denounced the GOP as cynical. Two new opinion polls, meanwhile, showed the race continuing to tighten as Tuesday's election. A Mason-Dixon poll conducted for various media outlets showed Williams at 45 percent support and Richards at 43 percent. Another poll showed the race at 42 percent for Williams to 35 percent for Richards. Earlier in Longview, Richards called again for Williams to release his income tax returns. ``I want to know if he paid income tax,'' she told about 200 people gathered at the Gregg County courthouse. ``You ought to be able to see whether or not someone who aspires to lead this state cares enough about government to pay his fair share in running the government,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: John Kennedy Jr. Passes Connecticut Bar
DOC.TEXT: John F. Kennedy Jr., who twice flunked the New York bar examination, passed the Connecticut bar exam Friday, allowing him to practice law in the state. Kennedy, 29, took the Connecticut and New York exams last summer. The New York results were expected next week. Kennedy, a graduate of New York University Law School, was among 1,081 people who passed the Connecticut test out of 1,489 people who took it. If Kennedy fails the New York bar, he will lose his job as a prosecutor in the office of Manhattan District Attorney Robert Morgenthau, who allows assistants three shots at the test. Kennedy, son of the late President Kennedy, could not be reached for comment Friday at the his office. An office spokeswoman said the district attorney does not allow his assistants to speak to the press.

DOC.HEAD: Former House Speaker Says Voters Turned Off by Negative Campaiging
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS two grafs for 11th graf, `Wright estimated ...' to CLARIFY that Williams and Richards have spent at least $32 million and to fix garble. Pick up 12th graf, `APME is ...'
DOC.TEXT: American voters have been turned off by negative campaigns this election year, former House Speaker Jim Wright said Friday. Wright said he was disturbed fewer Americans vote in local, state and national elections than people living in countries with less of a democratic history. While about 90 percent of the potential voters in a country such as Nicaragua will cast ballots, only 50 percent of qualified American voters turn out here. ``The negative campaigns have gotten out of hand,'' Wright said in a speech at the 56th annual convention of the Associated Press Managing Editors. ``Some people have been turned off and have tuned out. And that's just a damn shame.'' The gubernatorial race has been marked by negative television ads by Republican candidate Clayton Williams and his Democratic opponent Ann Richards. Wright said he recently asked Richards why she didn't spend more time talking about positive issues. He said Richards told him she has talked about positive issues, discussing prison reform, education and more jobs for Texans. ``Of course you don't know i because all you see or read in the paper is some negative thing that I said about Clayton Williams,'' Wright said Richards told him. Wright also discussed what he said was another ``dangerous trend'' - the rising cost of running for office. ``The cost of campaigns has become obscene.'' Wright said that he started his first congressional campaign in 1954 with $31,000 of his own money. With another $31,000 in contributions he won the election. ``If a young man came to me today with $31,000 and asked my advice, I would tell him that that wouldn't even be a start,'' Wright said. ``I would tell him he'd need about ten times that much and that he should expect to spend 20 times that much.'' Wright estimated the average cost to run for U.S. Senate in 1968 was $600,000. In 1988, the average rose to $1.7 million. Richards and Williams have spent at least $32 million in the gubernatorial race, he said. Many potentially good political candidates do not seek public office because they don't have enough money, said Wright. He suggested establishing an enforceable campaign spending limit of $500,000 per candidate. APME is comprised of managing editors and other news executives of the 1,500 member newspapers of the AP, the world's largest news gathering organization. The four-day convention, which ended Friday, drew 263 editors from across the nation.

DOC.HEAD: Top Trade Official Gives Gloomy Assessment on Vital Talks
DOC.TEXT: A top official, opening faltering talks on overhauling global trade, warned Friday that the negotiations could collapse entirely. ``While we still have everything to gain, the risk of losing everything has never been so present,'' declared Arthur Dunkel, director-general of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade. The Uruguay Round of talks, held under GATT's auspices, are scheduled to conclude in a month with a ministerial meeting in Brussels, Belgium. The 100-nation talks were launched in Uruguay four years ago in an ambitious attempt to restructure world trade. They are aimed at accords in 15 sectors, with the goal of reducing protectionism and expanding trade by more than a trillion dollars. However, in his comments, Dunkel said progress has been alarmingly slow. He said substantive talks on agriculture, the most contentious issue of the discussions, have not even begun. Dunkel also said negotiators are far apart on textiles, banking, and intellectual property rights like patents. The negotiations are being slowed particularly by a deadlock in the 12-nation European Community over a plan to reduce agricultural subsidies by 30 percent. The United States and the Cairns group of farm exporting nations, led by Australia, say 30 percent is not enough. Argentina has warned it will walk out of the talks if there is no satisfactory agreement on slashing farm subsidies. Some European nations, including Germany and France, fear that cutting subsidies would hurt their domestic farmers.

DOC.HEAD: RETRANSMITS to CORRECT overline.
Karpov and Kasparov Agree to Draw in Game 10
With AM-Chess Algebraic
DOC.TEXT: Defending champion Garry Kasparov and challenger Anatoly Karpov agreed to a draw Friday in the 10th game of the world chess championship. The players agreed to the draw after Kasparov's 18th move. The game lasted three hours and 12 minutes, by far the shortest so far in the match. Each player had 4{ points after they agreed to a draw Wednesday in the ninth game. Friday's draw gave them each another half-point, bringing the match score to 5-5. Karpov had the advantage in Wednesday's game but blundered on the 32nd move and lost a pawn. A few moves later, he offered a draw and Kasparov immediately accepted. Grandmaster Maxim Dlugy called the Wednesday mistake ``the most horrible blunder of this match.'' It was the third game in a row in which one player or the other made a significant mistake. Kasparov and Karpov each have a victory and played to a draw eight times, including Friday's game. A victory is worth a point, a draw a half-point. The first player to gain 12{ points wins the championship and $1.7 million of a $3 million purse. The first 12 games are being played in New York and the remainder will be played in Lyons, France.

DOC.HEAD: McDonald's Move May Signal Plastic-Shunning Trend
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 1 graf after 4th graf, `Disposable food-service ...' to UPDATE with background on effects of polystyrene foam. Pick up 5th graf, `MacDonald's said ...' A longer version moved on financial wires.
DOC.TEXT: Fast-food giant McDonald Corp.'s decision to abandon foam packages won't put much of a dent in the plastics industry, but it symbolizes America's growing discomfort with a throw-away society, analysts said Friday. The clamshell-style containers for Big Macs, Quarter Pounders and other sandwiches served at McDonald's 8,000 restaurants nationwide account for less than 1 percent of the $5 billion-plus market for polystyrene, says the Society of the Plastics Industry, a Washington trade group. ``In itself this is not a major event,'' George Krug, an industry analyst at Oppenheimer & Co., said. ``But there's more to be seen from it. People are going to be more conscious about their packaging materials and that is an important market for the plastics industry.'' Disposable food-service packages represent roughly 20 percent of the total polystyrene market, Krug said. Besides foam sandwich boxes, food-related polystyrene products include plastic cutlery as well as clear plastic goods like glasses. Polystyrene foam has been banned by several U.S. cities that say it contributes to landfill problems by lingering for years before disintegrating. The polystyrene production process also is suspected of harming the Earth's protective ozone level. McDonald's said Thursday it will begin replacing foam sandwich containers with paper products within 60 days. The company's main competitor, Burger King, already uses lightweight paper boxes. McDonald's President Edward Rensi said the sandwich containers account for nearly 75 percent of the company's total foam use. McDonald's is still seeking suitable replacements for plastic cutlery and plastic coffee cups. The immediate impact will be felt by the handful of McDonald's suppliers, which include Amoco Foam Products Co., Mobil Corp., Jen-Pak and Huntsman Chemical. Container-maker Dolco Packaging Corp. of Wenatchee, Wash., expects business to drop more than 50 percent in the coming months with the loss of McDonald as a customer. Brad Gothberg, a spokesman for Irwin Research and Development Inc., a Yakima, Wash.-maker of the machines that make the clamshell containers, said he expects some impact. He would not say how severe. Karl Kamena, a spokesman for Dow Chemical Co., a major plastics producer, said he didn't think the McDonald's move would have a ripple effect. And he disputed the environmental threat posed by the product, as have McDonald's executives themselves. ``People tend to forget that foam polystyrene is 95 percent air,'' Kamena said. ``We've found a clever way of using air as a package.'' Kamena said the average American uses between three and four pounds of polystyrene each year - the equivalent of up to 888 foam cups. Besides fast-food containers, polystyrene is a main building block for egg cartons; yogurt containers, which are a combination of polystrene and rubber; hard, clear plastics like those that contain compact discs; insulation; toilet seats and stereo and television cabinets. Dart Container Corp., a Mason, Mich.-based company that operates four polystyrene reprocessing centers, denounced McDonald's for discouraging foam recycling, calling the decision an ``environmental fumble.'' Dart Chairman W.A. Dart asserted that foam ``requires 30 percent less energy than the energy needed simply to process paper products.'' He said foam production ``generates 46 percent less atmospheric emissions and contributes 42 percent fewer pollutants to America's waterways than paper production.'' McDonald's decision comes at a time when the plastics industry is about to boost capacity to produce the raw materials essential for making polystyrene, Krug said. Within the next two years, global capacity is expected to expand by about 20 percent. ``There's going to be a bloodbath in terms of overcapacity,'' Krug said. ``That's not good from a supply-and-demand point of view for the plastics companies.'' McDonald's move, he said, ``whetted the appetite of consumer advocates who say they can make a difference by bringing public pressure on these people.''

DOC.HEAD: Police, Town Officials Apologize to Boston Celtics Player
DOC.TEXT: Police and town selectmen formally apologized to Boston Celtic Dee Brown, who was mistaken for a bank robber and held at gunpoint, Brown's lawyer said Friday. Town officials agreed to pay Brown's attorneys fees and hire a consultant to examine law enforcement procedures, including under what circumstances police should draw their guns, attorney Alan Margolies said. The amount Brown is to receive was not disclosed. Town selectmen promised to consult U.S. Justice Department and Wellesley College experts on racial diversity. ``These obviously are issues which need attention and the selectmen are committed not to lose sight of them,'' Selectmen Barbara Shanahan said. Margolies, in a statement, called the agreement adequate to settle any claims against the town. Brown, who is black, was sitting in a parked car Sept. 21 with his fiancee, who is white, when at least five police officers forced him from his car at gunpoint and told him to lie face down on the pavement. Police said they believed him to be a suspect in the robbery of a nearby bank. Within a few minutes, police realized they had the wrong man, police said. The issued brought allegations of racism bubbling to the surface of this mostly white, affluent Boston suburb. Brown, the Celtics' top draft choice this year, decided to go ahead with plans to live in Wellesley.

DOC.HEAD: Silber Calls Opponent `orange-headed WASP,' Nader Blasts Silber Candidacy
DOC.TEXT: Democratic candidate for governor John Silber described his opponent Friday as an ``orange-headed WASP.'' GOP candidate William Weld brushed off the Silber comment about his white Anglo-Saxon Protestant background. ``That doesn't bother me at all, that name,'' Weld said. ``He's called me far worse.'' Silber made the remark about Weld while urging reporters to examine the Republican's public statements as closely as they examine his. The media ``has a set of blinders on'' because they ``can't see the shockers when they come from an orange-headed WASP,'' he said. Later, Silber characterized the remark as simply a description of Weld. ``I think just as surely you can say, `the short, wiry candidate,' or `the one-armed candidate, the candidate with the withered arm running for governor,''' Silber said. ``I think that would be an adequate substitute for `John Silber.' '' Meanwhile, consumer advocate Ralph Nader came to Boston to urge voters to vote against Silber, calling him an ``authoritarian personality.'' Nader said he was not recommending votes for Weld, but believed Silber's personality made him unsuited to be governor. ``Do the voters of Massachusetts, whose forebearers threw out King George over 200 years ago, now want to elect a King John?'' Nader asked. Michal Regunberg, a Silber campaign spokeswoman, called Nader's comment ``part of a deliberate smear tactic.'' Nader, who is traveling around the country to discuss campaign issues, also appeared in Los Angeles on Friday to urge voters to reject Republican California attorney general candidate Dan Lungren.

DOC.HEAD: RETRANSMITS to CHANGE byline.
Daily News Union Leader Asks Jesse Jackson to Mediate
DOC.TEXT: The leader of the Daily News' striking unions asked the Rev. Jesse Jackson on Friday to act as a mediator and he said he would help in any way he could. Labor lawyer Theodore Kheel later amended the request by Allied Printing Trades Council President George McDonald by saying Jackson could potentially mediate on one issue common to all nine striking unions - the right of strikers to return to their jobs. ``We're very bullish on his becoming involved in this one issue,'' said Kheel, an adviser to the unions. Jackson said he would be willing ``to offer my services in whatever way would be effective.'' News spokeswoman Lisa Robinson had no immediate comment on Jackson's offer to mediate or on the content of his meeting earlier Friday with News publisher James Hoge. Jackson said Hoge had indicated a willingness to negotiate. Eight of the News' 10 unions went on strike Oct. 25, joined a day later by the Newspaper Guild, over what they term unfair labor practices. They have negotiated fruitlessly since January over contracts that expired in March. The front of a store sellinge newspaper's 350 editorial employees have crossed picket lines and another 40 reporters have been hired from other newspapers in the region. Jackson spoke at a rally in front of the Daily News Building that police said was attended by an estimated 3,500 people. ``We must stand for the right of the American people to have a job, and to get paid, and to have health care,'' he said. ``We choose negotiation over confrontation, but dignity and job security above all.'' Jackson warned non-union replacement workers: ``Beware, if you take someone's $10 job today, there's an $8 crowd waiting for you tomorrow.'' The News claimed in a letter that striking craft unions have excluded women and minorities and questioned why Jackson ``would choose to endorse or align himself with six lily-white craft unions whose membership rolls are strictly closed to blacks and females.'' The News said it printed and distributed 1.06 million copies of Friday's newspaper. A source at a rival newspaper, who spoke on the condition of anonymity, said its tracking of the News' circulation showed that the News may have sold 285,000 to 295,000 papers Friday. Another industry source, who also spoke on condition of anonymity, estimated that just 400,000 to 500,000 copies were sold.

DOC.HEAD: Paper Ballots Will Make for Long Election Night
DOC.TEXT: For the first time in decades, votes in the Minnesota governor's race will be cast on paper ballots. That means results probably won't be known until Wednesday morning. On Friday, the secretary of state's office directed the printing of supplementary paper ballots for the governor's race. The ballot was determined Thursday, when the Minnesota Supreme Court ruled that Joanell Dyrstad and not Sharon Clark will be Republican Arne Carlson's runningmate. Election judges aren't thrilled about the prospect of counting the separate gubernatorial ballots into the wee hours on Wednesday. ``It will take an extra three or four hours,'' predicted Joan Pelzer, the Ramsey County election supervisor. ``We probably won't know the results'' in the governor's race ``until 7 a.m. the next morning.'' The hand-counting will delay results in other races - including votes in the U.S. Senate contest and even minor city races - because precincts are required to tally all votes before releasing any figures, said Elaine Voss, deputy secretary of state. To further complicate matters, supporters of former gubernatorial nominee Jon Grunseth who cast absentee votes for the ex-candidate will be scrambling on election day to pick another candidate. Grunseth dropped out of the race Sunday amid allegations of sexual impropriety. Clark, Grunseth's running mate, had claimed she was entitled to remain the candidate for lieutenant governor, but the Supreme Court ruled otherwise. If voters have mailed absentee ballots and want to make another choice in the governor's race, they must go to their polling place before the election judges count absentee ballots. Voters who haven't mailed their absentee ballots can return the ballots to their city clerk or county auditor and receive fresh ballots and - when ready - a supplementary gubernatorial ballot.

DOC.HEAD: Greek Bank Pleads Guilty to $700 Million Fraud Scheme
DOC.TEXT: The National Mortgage Bank of Greece pleaded guilty Friday to running a $700 million money laundering operation in the United States and agreed to pay $8 million in fines. The bank and 12 of its top U.S. executives were named in a 28-count federal indictment alleging violations of currency reporting laws, operating a bank without a license and conspiring to defraud the Internal Revenue Service since September 1985. ``I believe, with what the bank did, we are guilty,'' Apostolos Georgiakis, a governor of the Athens-based bank, told U.S. District Judge Raymond J. Dearie. The bank agreed to pay $8 million, he said, speaking through an interpreter. Federal law enforcement officials say the defendants controlled the largest money-laundering operation in U.S. history which did not involve drug money. U.S. Attorney Andrew J. Maloney said the penalty was ``the largest money-laundering fine ever collected in a non-drug related case.'' Most of the people named in the indictment have pleaded guilty or agreed to plead guilty to a single count in the indictment. The individuals, all Greek citizens who worked in American branches of the bank, face up to five years in prison and $250,000 in fines when they are sentenced next year. Two defendants, Vasilis Kretsas and Kostas Giziakis, have fled the United States and remain fugitives, Maloney said. The bank, the second largest in Greece, had branches in New York, the Chicago area and the suburbs of Boston and Philadelphia. The bank's branches were not authorized to perform usual banking functions in the United States and were only to serve as a liaison between the bank's customers in the United States and the parent bank in Athens. However, the bank flagrantly violated those limitations and opened accounts, accepted deposits and processed withdrawals for thousands of its customers. Depositors, under the scheme, brought cash - frequently suitcases full - to bank branches. Bank employees would then help change the cash into smaller checks or money orders at nearby American banks, thus circumventing federal reporting laws on deposits of more than $10,000. The checks were then transferred to Athens or deposited into bank accounts controlled by the National Mortgage Bank of Greece. The bank catered almost entirely to Greek-Americans and promoted secret deposits in the nited States, assuring depositors the bank could get them money back from Greece in three days without the IRS learning of the unreported income.

DOC.HEAD: Mother Who Locked Daughter in Car Reunited With Girl
DOC.TEXT:
A woman was reunited with her 5-year-old daughter Friday, nearly two weeks after police found the child locked in a car while her mother was at work. ``We embraced, we hugged, we didn't cry. We were just happy,'' Chante Fernandez, accompanied by her daughter, Anjuli, told reporters after the reunion at an undisclosed location in New Jersey. The case attracted national attention and an outpouring of support after Ms. Fernandez, a single mother, told authorities she left her daughter in the car while she worked because she couldn't find adequate or affordable child care.
Wednesday, a Family Court judge ruled Anjuli should be returned to her mother no later than Friday. Ms. Fernandez, 24, was jailed after police found her pajama-clad daughter locked in a car in a shopping mall parking lot Oct. 20. The mother had a weekend sales clerk job at a department store. Ms. Fernandez pleaded guilty Oct. 26 to a disorderly persons offense and was given a $100 suspended fine. State officials will retain legal custody of the child until a progress report is submitted to the court within a month.

DOC.HEAD: Reservist Arrested on Charge of Desertion
DOC.TEXT: An Army reservist who decided to join the peace movement rather than report for active duty in Saudi Arabia was arrested Friday on a charge of military desertion, authorities said. Spec. Stephanie R. Atkinson was arrested at her home in Murphysboro, the Jackson County sheriff's office said in a statement. She was held without bond in the county jail on a warrant charging her with military desertion. Atkinson has been absent without leave since she failed to report Oct. 15 for duty with the 300th Adjutant General Postal Company for training at Fort Sheridan before leaving for the Persian Gulf. Her name was entered in the Crime Information Computer to advise police the Army considered her a deserter. In recent interviews with newspapers, Atkinson said she had became a conscientious objector and opposed war, violence and President Bush's policy in Saudi Arabia.

DOC.HEAD: Woman Testifies She Had No Choice When She Used Men's Restroom
DOC.NOTE: Eds: DELETES redundent graf 18, `Ms. Wells ...' and SUBS 13th graf, `Ms. Wells ...' to DELETE redundent first-name reference to Valorie Wells Davenport.
DOC.TEXT: A woman who said she was desperate when she went to the men's room at a country-western concert was found innocent Friday of illegally using the restroom. Jurors deliberated for 23 minutes before acquitting Denise Wells of violating a city ordinance that prohibits people from using restrooms intended for members of the opposite sex in a manner calculated to cause a disturbance. She faced a maximum $200 fine if convicted of the misdemeanor. Ms. Wells, 33, and her lawyer and sister, Valorie Wells Davenport, laughed and hugged each other when the verdict was read. ``I'm relieved. I'm elated,'' Ms. Wells said. ``The jurors told me, `You had us all the way.''' Testimony in the trial, which began Thursday, ended earlier in the day. Ms. Wells testified that she saw the line outside the women's room at the July 7 concert by George Strait was so long, ``I felt I was in a situation where I had to be in a restroom. I took the only option I felt was available.'' The legal secretary said she covered her eyes and apologized to men already in the restroom at The Summit. A loud remark she made about leaving the toilet seat up was ``more of a nervous reaction than a cocky remark,'' she said. Ms. Wells was arrested and removed from the concert, for which she paid $125 to attend. ``I was devastated. I felt I was being harassed for doing something I felt I had no choice but to do. I entered the men's room to go to the bathroom and that's all,'' she testified. Earlier Friday, police officer Steven Andrews said he was not offended by Ms. Wells' presence in the men's room. ``It didn't bother me one way or the other,'' said Andrews, a vice officer for nearly two decades who was involved in Ms. Wells' arrest. Ms. Davenport said the state failed to prove she had no permission to enter the men's room and that she entered with the intent to ``raise a ruckus.'' Assistant City Attorney Karl Rosette said he didn't think he needed the Summit management to testify whether Ms. Wells had permission. Ms. Davenport asked Municipal Court Judge Francelia Totty to declare Ms. Wells innocent, but said she wanted her sister to rebut some of the testimony offered by police. Two police officers have testified Ms. Wells left the stall in the men's room and announced: ``There - I left the lid up just like y'all like it.'' The defense's case focused on the lack of adequate facilities for women at such public places as the Summit. The case has made Ms. Wells a celebrity of sorts. Her bathroom trip has been the subject of national news coverage and she has made appearances on the talk shows of Johnny Carson, Geraldo Rivera and Joan Rivers. On Thursday, Officer Daniel B. Ramsey said he was working as a security guard at the Summit when he answered two men's complaints that women were in the men's room. Ramsey testified he removed three women from the men's room. When he returned, he saw Ms. Wells coming out of a stall. But unlike Andrews, Ramsey, a vice officer for 18 years, said he was offended by the women's presence in the men's restroom. Under cross-examination, Ramsey said 20 women were in a line stretching into the hallway waiting to enter the women's room, while the line of people waiting to use the men's room did not reach past the door. Ms. Davenport said her sister waited until intermission was over and again tried to use the women's room, but the line was even longer. Then, in desperation, she followed a couple into the men's room, while the other woman's date cleared the way.

DOC.HEAD: Jury Refuses to Hold Church Responsible For Priest's Affair
DOC.TEXT: A jury Friday ruled against a former church secretary who sought $7 million from the Roman Catholic Church, claiming a priest seduced her and made her pregnant. After several hours of deliberations, jurors declined to issue any damages or hold the Catholic Diocese of Galveston-Houston responsible for the actions of the Rev. Fernando Noe Guzman. Debbie McCorvey, 34, claimed church officials knew Guzman had a history of sexual misconduct and failed to intervene. She has claimed that Guzman, 39, forced her into a sexual relationship with him from July 1985 to June 1987. Miss McCorvey's lawsuit originally asked for $11 million in damages, but her attorneys reduced that amount to $7 million Thursday. Attorneys for the church maintained that Miss McCorvey consented to the relationship with Guzman. Church officials also have denied knowing the extent of Guzman's history of sexual misconduct. Guzman has admitted having sex with a teen-age parishioner in 1984 in Navasota, 45 miles northwest of Houston. Six months later, the diocese assigned him to the Houston suburb of Galena Park. Miss McCorvey claimed Guzman exploited her dependence on him as a spiritual counselor and forced her into a violent sexual relationship. By 1986, Miss McCorvey was divorced from her husband and pregnant by Guzman. Church attorney Margaret Wilson said that after Miss McCorvey became pregnant, she begged church officials to let her keep her job teaching religion to children and to allow Guzman to remain a priest. But once Guzman was fired, Miss McCorvey lost interest in him, the attorney said.

President Bush, waging a war of words with Iraq from the campaign trail, is advising American hostage families to ignore Saddam Hussein's invitation to visit loved ones in captivity, calling it a brutal ``ploy.'' ``I think those people should come home to visit with their families. I think they should be released from captivity,'' Bush said Thursday. He suggested the Iraqi leader had surpassed even Adolf Hitler in some forms of brutality. And, while the president said he wasn't trying to sound a call to war, he told a news conference in Orlando, Fla., ``I don't think the status quo can go on forever and ever.'' Bush, in a nonstop campaign swing for Republican candidates that will end on Election Day, was to speak for GOP candidates today here and in Rochester, Minn., and Sioux City, Iowa, before flying on to California to spend the night. ---= WASHINGTON (AP) - More than 1.5 million people have been displaced by the Persian Gulf crisis, World Bank officials and other sources say. And hundreds of thousands of workers from the Third World remain in Iraq and Kuwait. The numbers dwarf the approximately 1,000 hostages from the United States, 1,400 from Britain and 3,000 from the Soviet Union. Hundreds of thousands of others are returning to their distant homelands, some as far away as the Philippines and South Korea, said officials at the World Bank, which coordinates aid at its Washington headquarters for the hardest-hit countries. The foreigners were lured to the Middle East by the better wages that Iraq and Kuwait could pay because of income from oil. ---= MINNEAPOLIS (AP) - The upheaval in the Minnesota governor's race has battered Rudy Boschwitz as well, forcing the Republican senator to scramble in a re-election bid once thought to be a sure thing. ``He better bring out the heavy artillery. I think he needs it,'' said Selden Hanson, Minnesota 8th District GOP chairman. ``Three weeks ago I didn't even worry. Now I hope we win. I've got my fingers crossed.'' Boschwitz, seeking a third term, had been considered to have one of the safest senatorial re-election bids this year against Democrat Paul Wellstone, a political science professor at Carleton College. But his fortunes have turned in the 2{ weeks since allegations of skinny-dipping with teen-age girls and adultery rang out against Minnesota's one-time Republican gubernatorial nominee, Jon Grunseth. ---= LONDON (AP) - Debate over Britain's integration into the European Community has thrown Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher into a political crisis after her deputy, Sir Geoffrey Howe, quit in protest of her resistance to the process. Howe's resignation late Thursday prompted speculation that he or another senior lawmaker may try to oust her as leader of the Conservative Party - and thus the premiership - in a challenge this winter. But many observers believe a leadership challenge would be too risky for the party, now less than two years from the June 1992 deadline for the next general election. Howe, 63, a soft-spoken man who had come to irritate Mrs. Thatcher profoundly, according to political insiders, handed his resignation to her without notice in a 30-minute interview on Thursday evening. ---= BEIRUT, Lebanon (AP) - For the first time in 15 years of devastating civil war, the bomb-shattered St. Georges Hotel served as a backdrop for a fashion show with Moslem and Christian models. ``This is the message we hope to carry to the people of our country: the phoenix rising from the ashes,'' said fashion designer Loulwa Abdel-Baki, the creator of Thursday's 30-minute program. Ms. Abdel-Baki, a member of the Druse Moslem sect, and 20 models worked 20 days to clear the debris from the lobby of the once-majestic beachside hotel for the exhibit, ``but left just enough to remind people of what happened,'' she said. The show, called Kalabsha, Arabic for handcuffs, was intended to boost the latest government efforts to dismantle Beirut's dividing Green Line and reunite the capital, Abdel-Baki said.

DOC.SECOND: PM-AP Arts: Pet Shop Boys, Adv 16,0716
DOC.NOTE: $Adv 16
For Release Fri PMs, Nov. 16 and Thereafter
DOC.HEAD: Thinking People's Dance Music From British Duo
DOC.TEXT: Their name may be silly, but their music isn't. The Pet Shop Boys pride themselves on crafting witty, often sardonic lyrics to go with the smooth, synthesized electro-pop on such hits as ``West End Girls'' and ``What Have I Done to Deserve This?'' ``We always used to think of dance music as rhythm - just something you dance to,'' says Neil Tennant, one half of the British duo. ``But there's no reason why you can't have lyrical content. We try to have dance music that's kind of thought-provoking.'' Tennant and his partner, Chris Lowe, continue their musical and literary pursuits on their first full album in three years, ``Behavior.''
