The first single, ``So Hard,'' is clubland ready-made and already a hit in Britain. But the rest of the album is something of a departure: ``softer,'' ``loose'' and ``warm-sounding.'' The Boys are still trying to lose the calculated, contrived image they got after their 1986 hit, ``Opportunities,'' which included the chorus: ``I've got the brains, you've got the looks. Let's make lots of money.'' ``Even though we've only ever written two or three satirical songs about fame, it kind of casts a shadow over everything else you do,'' says Tennant, the lyricist and generally the more loquacious of the two. So the new album explores new territory, like the Russian Revolution in ``My October Symphony.'' Another song is based on a bon mot from Zelda Fitzgerald - ``We were never bored, because we were never boring,'' she once said. ``So Hard'' is a ``true story'' about two of their London friends and the trouble they have staying together, Tennant says. ``I'm always hoping you'll be faithful. But you're not, I suppose,'' he croons in his distinctive, subdued style. ``We've both given up smoking, 'cause it's fatal. So whose matches are those?'' In New York recently to shoot a video, Tennant, 36, and Lowe, 31, said they try to write songs that people their age can relate to. ``We're growing older,'' says Tennant, tall and slight, whose dark complexion and hair is accentuated by an all-black outfit. ``I've always written lyrics from the point of view of someone who's ...'' ``Old,'' Lowe interjects. ``Incredibly old,'' Tennant agrees as they both break out laughing. Lyrics are intentionally gender-neutral to appeal to all sexes and sexual orientations. ``We always liked a kind of mystery, a fascination with sexual ambivalence,'' Tennant says. Making compromises is a recurring theme in Pet Shop Boys music - ``finding a compromise between what you really want and what you're really going to get,'' Tennant says. Lowe, dressed like a teen-ager in a T-shirt, jeans and high-top sneakers, adds, ``It's a pretty big compromise.'' Tennant and Lowe met in 1981 in a London Hi-Fi shop, began talking and realized they both were interested in synthesizers. At the time, Tennant was working in book publishing and Lowe was an architecture student. They began writing their own songs because they hated playing other people's music. They took their name from two friends who actually worked in a pet shop, and in 1985 had their first hit, ``West End Girls.'' Since then, they've sold more than 10 million albums and achieved what Tennant called ``a medium-level of popularity.'' They're hoping their first U.S. tour early next year will give them another boost. They also snared photographer Bruce Weber, famed for his erotically charged Calvin Klein ads, to direct the video for ``Being Boring.'' Weber, making his video debut, is shooting on Long Island in keeping with the song's Fitzgerald-``Great Gatsby'' connection. But whether they move up to superstar status or not, the Pet Shop Boys don't expect their music to ever change. ``We always hope to produce a record that moves people in some way, whether it moves them to dance, or moves them to reflect on something in their own life, or moves them to cry,'' Tennant says. ``That's what it does to us when we made the record.''
DOC.NOTE: End Adv
$Adv 15
For Release Thurs PMs, Nov 15 and Thereafter
DOC.HEAD: Veteran Musician Rocks Back in `Ragged Glory'
LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: Neil Young had just seen the movie ``Spinal Tap'' for the first time. And his life took on new meaning. ``That's my life. My life is `Spinal Tap,''' said Young, reaching for the morning's first cup of coffee. The 1984 mock documentary follows hapless rockers on tour, their future imperiled by a rift with the band's co-founder. Young, who turned 45 on Nov. 12, doesn't struggle like those low-rent musicians. He was, though, estranged, saying a few years ago he never would play again with longtime companions Crazy Horse. But now Young has recorded an album with the legendary bar band. Awestruck critics say ``Ragged Glory'' resurrects Young's spontaneous, hard-driving rock 'n' roll. That freewheeling sound was shelved at times in favor of Young's acoustic ballads and country rock on solo albums and collaborations with Mynah Birds, Buffalo Springfield and Crosby, Stills and Nash. Young said the time was right to reunite with Crazy Horse. Any bad blood between him and the band is forgotten. ``Crazy Horse is a band that I'm a part of,'' said Young, wearing his standard uniform: jeans, T-shirt, tennis shoes, Ray Bans and stubble. ``I lead the band, yeah. But I'm just a member. It's like returning to your roots. It brings me back to where I started.'' Two of Young's most popular and acclaimed albums - 1975's ``Tonight's the Night'' and 1979's ``Rust Never Sleeps'' - were recorded with Crazy Horse. Their first effort together was 1969's ``Everybody Knows This Is Nowhere.'' Their last was 1986's ``Life.'' Crazy Horse's own new album is titled ``Left for Dead'' in part, the band members say, because Young and others in the business abandoned them. In ``Ragged Glory,'' Young is joined by Crazy Horse's guitarist Frank Sampedro, bassist Billy Talbot and drummer Ralph Molina. ``It may be the best one I've ever done with them,'' Young said. ``It's even. And that's a little peculiar. There's not one song that really stands out.'' Last year, Young released what some considered the best album of 1989 and perhaps of his career: ``Freedom.'' Young, who's hardly given to flowery self-promotion, believes ``Ragged Glory'' is superior. ``I was amazed at the success of `Freedom,' not because I didn't think it was good, but I was surprised that its shortcomings were not mentioned more often,'' Young said. And what were these shortcomings? ``Well, `Ragged Glory' has what `Freedom' doesn't have,'' he said. ```Freedom' was OK to listen to; it's got all the soft songs. But in this album, we'll lose all the people who like the soft songs.'' Indeed, only one track on ``Ragged Glory'' - ``Days That Used to Be'' - could be considered contemplative both lyrically and musically. Filled with longing reminiscences of the '60s - ``Psychedelic music fills the air, Peace and love live there still'' - the melancholy song says that personal dreams are threatened by ``possessions and concessions.'' ``I usually shy away from this kind of song,'' Young said a few days before setting off on another trip on his sailboat. ``I was in the middle of the ocean on my boat, halfway between here and there, and had been there for about 10 days. No airplanes. No other boats. No noise. But I did see a couple of humpback whales. The song came to me.'' The album was recorded at Young's 2,000-acre ranch. The band doesn't rehearse, arranges on the spot and avoids re-recording takes to cover glitches or raw edges. The album stands like a piece of unfinished furniture. ``It doesn't matter how you get it as long as it sounds good in the end,'' said bassist Talbot. ``People make music, not the instruments. It's just us hanging out together.'' On a whim, the band recorded the R&B classic ``Farmer John'' for the album, even though Young was the only one who knew how to play it. That carefree approach carries over to Young's songwriting, too. ``I don't sit down and say I'll play a G or something. It's mindless. It's the other way around from what most people think. It comes to you and you grab it and then find out what it is.'' Young was born in Toronto and received a ukulele as a Christmas gift at age 13. He joined the Squires in 1963, and met Stephen Stills soon thereafter; he teamed with Stills in Buffalo Springfield and Crosby, Stills Nash & Young. Throughout his career, he has been irreverent. His 1988 song, ``This Note's for You,'' a critique of commercialism in the music business, yielded a controversial and award-winning video. ``I'm the lost character in this place because I don't know where I fit,'' Young said. ``The record company is building an image, grooming you. I have no idea what that's all about. Where do I fit with this?''
DOC.NOTE: End Adv
$Adv05
For release Mon PMs, Nov 5, and thereafter
DOC.HEAD: Denver Experiment May Be Wave of Election-Night Future
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Everette in 16th graf is cq
DOC.TEXT: On Tuesday, as network polls troop to the voters, NBC-owned station KCNC-TV in Denver will attempt an election-night experiment that will allow viewers to vote a split ticket. They can watch NBC's prime-time schedule of ``Matlock,'' ``In the Heat of the Night'' and a one-hour NBC News election night special on KCNC. Or they can tune to Channel 20, independent station KTVD, a UHF station, and see three full hours of Colorado election coverage, gathered and reported by the news staff of ... KCNC. The NBC station bought the time from the other station, and both have been promoting the three-hour election-night show on KTVD. ``I guess it's as simple as trying to have it both ways,'' says KCNC news director Marv Rockford. He means pleasing those who consider election-night coverage a crashing bore and those who can't get enough of it. This split-ticket approach, which Rockford says also is being tried by several other stations elsewhere in the nation, has a basic goal. It aims to avoid losing audiences to competitors who counter-program against traditional local prime-time election coverage with beefed-up entertainment fare - blockbuster movies and the like. Some may wail - quite wrongly, says Rockford - that KCNC is ducking its news responsibilities. But not David Bartlett, president of the Radio-Television News Directors Association. ``We think it's a pretty good idea,'' says Bartlett, whose organization claims 3,600 members in broadcasting and cable. ``You obviously have to treat it delicately. It's really a business consideration. ... ``But from a journalistic standpoint, the idea of offering the viewer an alternative - a long-form, short-form pair of alternatives - seems to be the highest execution of our craft, and that's what we should be doing.'' Although KCNC is offering two hours of entertainment on election night, ``we're not going to ignore the elections'' on that station, Rockford emphasizes. In addition to its election show on KTVD, he says, KCNC will air five-minute election updates until 10 p.m. Denver time, when its full-tilt election coverage on the other station ends. At that point, the coverage will shift to KCNC, pre-empting the ``Tonight'' show and probably ``Late Night With David Letterman.'' The new two-outlet method of election night coverage, tried on a cable-only basis during primary races in September by NBC's Boston affiliate, could prove an electronic wave of the future, Bartlett says. He calls it ``a very elegant solution to this heretofore insoluble problem of how to make everybody happy,'' the news junkies and those who don't want their entertainment bumped for a night of voting results and analyses thereof. His opinion is seconded by Everette C. Dennis, executive director of the Gannett Center for Media Studies: ``In a sense, it's probably a better compromise than trying to play the ratings game, mixing entertainment with election coverage, or losing a big proportion of the audience with only election coverage.'' Many in the industry will be watching the results of the experiment at KCNC, a station that emphasizes news and plans to add a one-hour morning news and information show in January that will air after ``Today.'' Among them: news director Nancy Valenta of NBC-owned KNBC-TV, which serves Los Angeles, the nation's second-largest television market. That station also is strong on news. Valenta says its prime-time election coverage will start with live updates during ``Matlock,'' then pre-empt both ``In the Heat of the Night'' and the NBC News special for KNBC's own local, state and national election-night telecast. But its coverage will be the traditional kind - seen only on KNBC. Still, ``I think what Denver is doing is new and revolutionary, and certainly we'll be watching their results to see what comes of it,'' she says. ``And who knows? If it proves to be successful, it might happen somewhere else.'' If it succeeds in Denver, says KCNC's Rockford, ``we'll do it in the presidential election'' in 1992 and possibly in next year's mayoral elections. ``We don't know if it'll work...whether the three hours of election returns on channel 20 will attract much of an audience,'' he says. ``But the point is, the broadcasting industry is changing so much, you have to try some of these experiments, some different ways of doing things ... and unless you find some ways to change along with it, you're going to be left in the dust.'' --- Elsewhere in television: NETWORKS GIRD FOR ELECTIONS, TOO: CBS, NBC and ABC will have prime-time election specials Tuesday, anchored by Dan Rather, Tom Brokaw and John Chancellor, and Peter Jennings and David Brinkley, respectively. The NBC and ABC efforts will last an hour, that of CBS two hours, with all continuing their coverage at 11:30 p.m. Eastern time. With Bernard Shaw anchoring, Cable News Network will start its coverage of the off-year election returns at 6 p.m. After he signs off at 1 a.m., CNN will offer a 90-minute wrap-up that includes final results from the West Coast.

DOC.NOTE: $Adv12
For Release Mon AMs, Nov 12 and Thereafter
DOC.HEAD: Sex Symbol of `Dismal Science' Celebrates 20 Years on PBS
DOC.TEXT: Combining anemic puns with relevant statistics, Louis Rukeyser, the host of ``Wall Street Week,'' grins and winks his way into the homes of 10 million viewers every Friday. Since 1970, Rukeyser has demystified the jargon and gyrations of the economy. His irreverant attitude toward the often stuffy subject has made his show one of the most popular half-hours on public television. A 20th anniversary show with some of the program's best guests will air Nov. 16 from Tavern on the Green restaurant in New York. A one-hour retrospective will follow on Monday, Nov. 19. The rakish Rukeyser is one of the most durable TV personalities on the air, rivaling veteran luminaries such as Mr. Rogers, Johnny Carson and Julia Child. Rukeyser is known for painful fits of prose. Once while answering a viewer's letter on investing in a hairpiece manufacturer, he said, ``If all your money seems to be `hair' today and gone tomorrow, we'll try to make it grow by giving you the bald facts on how to get your investments toupee.'' After a market slump, he considered changing the name of the show to ``Wall Street Wake.'' He often consoles viewers by telling them to remember that it's only their money, not their life. ``We have in America a bad tendency that things have to be either serious or fun,'' he said in an interview before taping the show at Maryland Public Television in suburban Baltimore. ``Whereas in real life, this isn't true. The teachers we all remember in high school and college were not the ones who put us to sleep. I don't think any of us should apologize for not being dull. ``Nobody wants to come home on a Friday to be `educated.' First you have to pull them into the tent.'' Along the way, Rukeyser was dubbed by People magazine as the only sex symbol of the ``dismal science'' of economics. The New York Daily News identified him as the ``economic guru of the industry.'' ``Outside of the Wall Street Journal, Rukeyser has been a pioneer in demonstrating the popular appeal of quality business journalism,'' said media critic Thomas Rosenstiel of the Los Angeles Times. ``He is especially good at proving that this stuff can be interesting and useful without being deadly dull.'' Rukeyser, 57, appears each week with three panelists, chosen from a pool of money managers and financial analysts, who question the guest of the week, such as the chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission or noted economist John Kenneth Galbraith. In addition, technical analysts, whom he calls elves, vote on a weekly ``elves Index'' that assesses the strength or weakness of the economy. Rukeyser doesn't make any predictions other than to say he is a long-term bull. He constantly issues disclaimers on stock tips offered by guests of the show. Their recommendations often cause share prices to rise sharply the week after the show airs. Ralph Acampora, head of Prudential Bache's technical analysis division and one of Rukeyser's elves, credits him with starting business coverage on television. ``When I started with Prudential, I told them I wanted a big chart room and a television,'' Acampora said. ``They asked me why I wanted a TV and I told them Mrs. O'Brien sitting at home has the greatest information in the world.'' That mythical viewer is watching business news on CNN and FNN, and it's all because of Rukeyser, Acampora said. A former foreign correspondent for ABC and The (Baltimore) Sun, Rukeyser became the first economic commentator for a network in 1968 with ABC. He moonlighted on the PBS show for three years before leaving ABC, complaining about television coverage of economics. He still maintains economics is the most poorly covered area of American journalism. ``The prevailing view is that the subject of economics is too dull and or too complicated to hold an audience larger than the capacity of your average telephone booth,'' he said. ``I think that's nonsense. I think there is a hunger in the American public for clear, believable, understandable, usable pocketbook information.'' Despite his bullish outlook, he concedes the economy is currently looking bleak, but is quick to remind anyone that he does not invest for short-term profit. ``Punk, anemic, weak, getting weaker. The outlook for the next few months is soggy at best,'' Rukeyser said. ``But even with minimal policy changes we can be on our way again by 1992.'' Rukeyser, who writes a syndicated newspaper column, gives lectures and has written two books, is known for being tough on his panelists and guests. He continually pleads with them to speak in English. ``Jargon is a very convenient shield for people not entirely sure of what they are saying,'' he said. Rukeyser says he will continue doing the show as long as it is fun, which it still is, and as long as his audience still wants him. Or as he might put it: His ratings stock remains bullish and the dividends rewarding. So rally round the tube in confidence the guru will keep your interest primed.
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Monday AMs, Nov. 12
$Adv08
For Release Thurs AMs, Nov 8 and Thereafter
DOC.HEAD: CHUCK D: The Public Enemy Goes Public
With AM-AP Arts: Geto Boys and AM-AP Arts: The Afros
DOC.TEXT: --- EDITOR'S NOTE - Rap has emerged as the most controversial form of youthful expression since rock 'n' roll in the 1950s. There was a time when Elvis was considered obscene, and had gone ``too far.'' Now groups such as the Geto Boys and 2 Live Crew have gone much further. ---

Rap music without controversy would be like Run without DMC - like Chuck D without something to say. ``I think the government has a lot better things to take care of than the lyrics in rap music,'' said Chuck D, referring to the recent obscenity trial of the rap group 2 Live Crew, who were acquitted by a Florida court. ``Joblessness, homelessness, better health care and education is what they need to worry about.'' Chuck D, who was born Carlton Ridenhour in Queens, N.Y., is not your ordinary rap star. The music of his group, Public Enemy, concerns contemporary issues, their videos don't have choreographed dance routines and Chuck D doesn't wear gold chains. He went to Adelphi University and lives in a Long Island suburb. He is in his cluttered office at the group's recording studio in Hempstead, N.Y., wearing a Detroit Pistons T-shirt, paint-splotched sweat pants and a Los Angeles Kings baseball cap - backwards. ``Materialism isn't good for the black community,'' Chuck D says. ``It just has everybody questing for that money. And if that money is in very few areas and you don't have the know-how or the opportunity to get it, then you're gonna start feeding off each other.'' Not that Chuck D can't afford gold chains. The band that has attempted a leveraged buyout of controversy began its second world tour of the year on Oct. 27, making stops in the rap havens of Hong Kong and Australia, among others. The group's third album, ``Fear of a Black Planet,'' was released earlier this year and has gone platinum (more than 1 million copies sold). Public Enemy completed a 55-city American tour in early September, which preceded a seven-city Canadian tour. The self-styled ``Prophets of Rage'' have thrived without softening their sound. The band has not candy-coated its lyrics to accommodate the pop charts. ``I don't duck no issues,'' Chuck D said. ``I come down on brothers maybe five, six times an album. I got to come down on sisters sometimes, too, for their faults. Nobody's not guilty. Just like I come down on white supremacy. I got to come down on everybody.'' On ``Brothers Gonna Work It Out,'' Chuck D implores historians to tell the truth of the black American's plight. On ``911 Is a Joke,'' Chuck's partner in rhyme, the jester-like Flavor Flav (born Charles Drayton), berates the response time of emergency medical service crews, declaring, ``I'll call a cab 'cause a cab'll come quicker.'' And on ``Welcome to the Terrordome,'' Chuck D enraged the Jewish community with ``Crucifixion ain't no fiction - So-called chosen frozen - Apologies made to whoever pleases - Still they got me like Jesus.'' The Anti-Defamation League of B'nai B'rith denounced the lyrics of ``Welcome to the Terrordome'' as anti-Semitic, which was nothing new to Public Enemy. In 1989, former band member Professor Griff blamed Jews ``for the majority of wickedness that goes on across the globe.'' The album also attacked the ``black hands'' responsible for the murders of Muslim leader Malcolm X and Black Panther Huey Newton; the white teen-agers in Brooklyn who killed a black teen-ager; and the 1989 Virginia Beach riots. ``These people are just stuck on those lines and didn't know what the rest of the song said,'' said Chuck D, who says he is not anti-Semitic, just pro-black. ``That song dealt with a lot of different issues, different things.'' If you want BMWs, sexy ladies and self-aggrandizement, listen to Eric B and Rakim. If you want popular pap-rap, turn on MTV and check out MC Hammer. Rap cognoscenti have come to expect the unexpected from Public Enemy. Public Enemy's first album, ``Yo! Bum Rush the Show,'' was released in 1987 but the group's breakthrough album was the widely acclaimed ``It Takes a Nation of Millions to Hold Us Back,'' issued the following year. The hit single ``Don't Believe the Hype'' asked listeners to form their own opinions about the group without the influence of the media. Ah yes, the media. Public Enemy is not into public relations. Chuck D described a New York Times reporter as being ``on his own trip.'' He called the New York Post ``the worst piece of ... on the planet.'' Harry Allen, the group's public relations director, goes by the title of ``Media Assassin.'' ``Most of my criticism has come through white male critics,'' Chuck D said. ``Who ... are they to give me criticism when I'm talking about a serious situation going on in my community that they don't hardly know about? ``My suggestion to white critics is that they should know what they're talking about.'' The group also has a DJ, named Terminator X, whose real name is Norman Rogers, and a security force that accompanies them onstage. They don't do much except stand around in army fatigues and red berets, carrying fake Uzis and looking mean. Despite his importance in the music industry, Chuck D does not covet the title of ``rappo de tutti rappi.'' He is unassuming and has no misconceptions of his own grandiosity. ``I don't really look at myself as being the man because it's usually interchangeable with other people,'' he said. ``It feels very good just to share a seat with the other rappers.'' The phone rings and it's the Flav. He has to go to Connecticut and can't come in to finish up the group's latest project, titled, ``Get the ... Outta Dodge.'' The title is a reference to Dodge City, which is quickly becoming a euphemism for New York and its Wild-West atmosphere. ``New York is a bad territory because of the limited opportunites for the black communities and the growing amount of limited opportunities in the white community,'' Chuck D said. His solution is a blueprint for Marxism. ``I'd like to make it even all the way around where 100 percent of the people share 100 percent of the product,'' he said. ``There should be a salary cap. There shouldn't be ones at the bottom with nothing. No one should go without. There's enough in this world for everybody to have.''
DOC.NOTE: End Adv
$Adv08
For Release Thursday AMs, Nov. 8, and Thereafter
DOC.HEAD: GETO BOYS: Nastier Than 2 Live Crew, Beyond NWA
With AM-AP Arts: Chuck D and AM-AP Arts: The Afros
DOC.TEXT: --- EDITOR'S NOTE - Rap has emerged as the most controversial form of youthful expression since rock 'n' roll in the 1950s. There was a time when Elvis was considered obscene, and had gone ``too far.'' Now groups such as the Geto Boys and 2 Live Crew have gone much further. ---

Houston rappers The Geto Boys are scatological, misogynist, violent and homophobic, their critics say. Maybe, they respond, but they're not apologetic. ``The Geto Boys would rather be hated for what we are than loved for what we are not,'' says Bushwick Bill, one-fourth of the controversial crew whose new album made headlines before a single copy was available. Hated? You've got it. An Indiana plant refused to press copies of ``The Geto Boys'' because of its offensive lyrics. Geffen Records backed out of a national record distribution deal for the same reason. Two record store chains will not sell the group's national debut. The National Organization for Women charges their lyrics promote violence against women. The flap over their songs such as ``Mind of a Lunatic'' and a pair of unprintable titles caused some people, including ex-New York mayor Edward Koch to add their voices to the anti-Geto Boys chorus. ``The Geto Boys sing rap songs so foul that their own record company refuses to distribute their album,'' wrote Koch, who decried their ``sickening lyrics'' and suggested the group encouraged ``rape and mayhem.'' Does all this bother Bushwick Bill? He responds with an obscenity, a ``no'' and a fast-paced defense of his record. ``I always knew they can't stop the truth. The truth is going to be heard. We're holding a mirror up to America, and letting them see their naked selves. Who knows what evil lurks in the hearts of men? That's the mirror we're holding up,'' says Bushwick. It's also a mirror of Houston's Fifth Ward, the desolate neighborhood the group once called home. Although none of the four lives there anymore, it remains their base of operations. The band celebrated the release of its new album last month with a party at Club Obsession in the old 'hood. The loyalty lies in part with their support there; the band sold 500,000 copies of its last album on the local Rap-A-Lot label before signing a national deal. ``The Fifth Ward is shotgun shacks, houses ined up beside each other. There's a lot of wild dogs, prostitution, needles on the floor,'' says Bushwick. ``If you're walking down the street and you look wrong, somebody'll beat your ... .'' How it was growing up in the Fifth Ward is reflected in their lyrics, in such songs as ``Assassins'' and ``City Under Siege.'' ``Some kids never even make the milk cartons. That's why we can hit hard like that, because that's how we grew up,'' says Bushwick. ``You step out the front door, it's survival. ... You only get a minute to pray and a second to die.'' The Geto Boys are not alone in the controversy over rap lyrics. But unlike 2 Live Crew, who were recently acquitted of obscenity charges in Florida, the Geto Boys choose not to use the First Amendment as a explanation for their lyrics. ``According to the same Constitution, we're considered three-fourths of a human being,'' Bushwick said. ``The First Amendment doesn't apply to us. ... We've never been protected by any American law.'' The one song that has drawn the most criticism is ``Mind of a Lunatic,'' in which the band details the rape and murder of a random victim chosen only because her curtains are open. Bushwick defends the song, comparing it to the work of Alfred Hitchcock. ``I don't get it. When Alfred Hitchcock directed `Psycho,' he filmed from a maniac's point of view: his fears, his feelings, his thoughts,'' says Bushwick. ``That's how we wrote `Mind of a Lunatic.' Alfred did the same thing. ... I think it has a lot to do with race.'' The group, including the diminutive Bushwick, is all black. The flap over the album hasn't persuaded anyone in the band to change his approach. In fact, says Bushwick, it has strengthened their resolve to get it done their own way. ``We'll keep on calling it the way we see it,'' concludes Bushwick. ``Just because it's not going on in your neighborhood doesn't mean it isn't going on.''
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Thursday AMs, Nov. 8
$Adv08
For Release Thursday AMs, Nov. 8, and Thereafter
DOC.HEAD: As Nasty As They Wanna Be (Almost): Here Come the Afros
With AM-AP Arts: Chuck D and AM-AP Arts: Geto Boys
DOC.TEXT: --- EDITOR'S NOTE - Rap has emerged as the most controversial form of youthful expression since rock 'n' roll in the 1950s. There was a time when Elvis was considered obscene, and had gone ``too far.'' Now groups such as the Geto Boys and 2 Live Crew have gone much further. ---

Hurricane, the aptly named emcee of the Afros, paused during a recent interview and noted the parental advisory label on the rap group's debut album. He then picked up a reporter's tape recorder and pressed the microphone against his mouth and intoned: ``THEY DON'T WANT TO SEE A BLACK MAN MAKE IT. THOSE PEOPLE WHO DISAGREE, THEY DON'T WANT TO SEE US MAKE IT. WE DON'T WANT TO SELL DRUGS. WE'RE TRYING TO STAY CLEAR OF DRUGS. WE DON'T WANT TO ROB NOBODY. WE WANT TO MAKE RECORDS AND EXPRESS OURSELVES WITH RECORDS. GROWING UP IN THE GHETTO, WE GOT ATTITUDES.'' And this is supposed to be a mellow day for Hurricane and fellow Afros, who picked at a lunch of baconburgers and orange juice as they spoke at the Manhattan offices of Columbia Records. They're not as nasty as 2 Live Crew, but that's not because they don't wanna be. ``Kickin' Afrolistics'' has plenty of strong words, most of them suitable for airplay, and a point of view that Hurricane advises will only get more explicit. ``We didn't want to come out and be just any rappers,'' he said. ``It would be kind of hard to get attention. We decided to be Afros, as in Afro-Americans. Afros symbolize black power. We knew the reaction would be `Oh, wow.''' The Afros are veterans in this business, or to put it another way, they're the oldest established permanent floating rap game in New York. Emcees Hurricane and Kool Tee grew up a few houses from each other in Queens - the same neighborhood as Run-DMC's Jam Master Jay - and started rapping in 1976, before anyone had even heard of rap and when everyone had heard of Afros. It was all for fun at first, hanging out in the park and chanting dirty nursery rhymes you'd otherwise find scratched on bathroom walls. But the better they became the more they thought about it as a way of life. The Afros started rapping at house parties, then clubs, and when Run-DMC and others hit it big in the 1980s they figured their turn was coming. ``We're not rockers and we're not r&b, and we can't sing,'' Hurricane said. ``The young black generation has the gift of being able to rap and we are part of that young black generation. We can rap off anything, jazz, r&b, rock. Rap brings back people you forgot about. We bring back Parliamant, James Brown, Rick James.. .'' How many Afros there are depends on who happens to show up on a particular day. Hurricane (born Wendel Fyte), Kool Tee (born Tadone Hill) and deejay Kippy-O (whose real name is Kip Morgan) were around for the interview. Auxiliary Afros - actually Afros Auxiliary - Smith, Doc, Cool E (a.k.a. The Dictionary), Jah Easy, Randy, Marvin, Davy D and Jam Master Jay are out there spreading the word. The Afros are also friendly with Public Enemy, and toured with them this summer. Most of the memories are happy ones, at least when they were the only people on stage. ``We almost got arrested in Augusta, Ga.,'' Kool Tee said. ``We were doing a song called `Hoe Cakes' and nobody told us when we got on stage we can't curse. We came to the show late. We came on stage and they wanted to arrest and our manager talked them out of it. They put the handcuffs out and they said, `We run a clean city here. We don't have stuff like that here.''' Most of the 16 songs on ``Kickin' Afrolistics,'' such as ``Afro Like a Mutha,'' ``Coolin' With the Fros'' and the single ``Feel It,'' are good-time raps, but the record becomes more serious on ``Straight From the Penial'' and ``Federal Offense.'' ``I was looking in the paper and I was reading about six bodies found in the water,'' Hurricane said. ``I just started singing `Six bodies found in the water, the people said it was manslaughter.' We came up with `Federal Offense.''' The Afros get inspiration from television, magazines, the streets and probably orange juice and baconburgers if they put their minds to it. Because of all the time spent performing on stage and trying to hook up with a label, the record took three years to make. Finding the right bass sound for ``Jump'' also caused delays. They see themselves coming from the same direction as Public Enemy, talking about black power and ways of encouraging young fans to express themselves. The Afro hairdos may be the first thing you notice, but Hurricane promises the songs will be just as memorable. ``I held back a little on this album,'' he said. ``First you get their attention, and when you got their support, you just slam 'em with everything. The next album we're gonna slam 'em.''
DOC.NOTE: End Adv
$Adv15
For Release Thursday AMs, Nov. 15, and Thereafter
DOC.HEAD: Business Licks and Incurable Adolescence
DOC.TEXT: Sing as if you stuck your finger in a hot frying pan, or write songs about drugs deals and desperation and people might get the idea you're a little unhappy. But the members of Soul Asylum insist they're not bitter or cynical, just realistic. Dragging people down is not what this band stands for even if they do present life in three-minute bursts of agony. Singer-guitarist Dave Pirner, for instance, is a veteran of flipping burgers and mowing lawns who cites the group's very existence as proof that none of them are giving up. ``You know, you got to work hard for your good times,'' says Pirner, speaking in a groan that recalls a 45 rpm record being played at 33. ``You got something to get off your chest and you're actually celebrating the fact you're spitting it all out and putting the cards on the table. ``It's like blues music, it's pretty bleak stuff. People are trying to get stuff out in the open and share it with people who identify with things that aren't always sex, driving and dancing.'' ``Soul Asylum and the Horse They Rode On,'' the band's first record since 1988, was produced by Steve Jordan, who worked on Keith Richards' ``Talk Is Cheap'' LP. The music is fast and tight, ranging from guitar rave-ups such as ``Bitter Pill'' and ``Be on Your Way,'' to the bluesy ``Nice Guys,'' to the rockabilly-influenced ``Brand New Shine.'' With all that noise and no lyric sheet, it's not easy to catch the words, but occasionally they slow down to make sure a key phrase - ``If I lost my mind would you help me find it,'' or ``It's not supposed to make you feel so helpless'' - is not missed. ``We kind of sat down and talked about the idea of this being a band and bringing it back to what it's all about in the first place,'' Pirner said. ``Steve said, `You guys are about playing live. You guys are a band and we want to emphasize that as much as possible.''' ``These songs are in a story format,'' said guitarist Dan Murphy. ``You're trying to put something down that people are going to listen to outside the context of a rock concert. I prefer something that's thought-provoking or having some imagery.'' Murphy, drummer Grant Young and bassist Karl Mueller attended the same high school in Minneapolis, and they hooked up with Pirner a couple of years later. They were originally called Loud Fast Rules and were ``a terrible band, the band that wouldn't go away,'' Murphy recalled. ``The scariest show I remember playing was in Philadelphia,'' he said. ``There was a capacity of 600 and they put in a thousand people. These people seemed like they wanted to kill each other and then kill us. Bottles were flying. ``In London, the same thing happened. There was a pub and people were just killing each other.'' ``You'd stop the song,'' Pirner added, ``and people would slow down a bit. Then you'd start the next one and they'd start punching each other again.'' Somehow, band and listeners stuck it out, and Soul Asylum went on to share bills with the Replacements, Husker Du and even Billy Idol. By 1984, they had signed with Twin-Tone Records and released their debut album, ``Say What You Will ...'' Other records include ``Hang Time'' and ``Clam Dip and Other Delights,'' and they have covered such songs as James Brown's ``Hot Pants,'' the Bangles' ``Walk Like an Egyptian'' and Dr. John's ``Right Place, Wrong Time.'' In 1987, the group signed with a major label, A&M Records. Soul Asylum now faces the same challenge as any rock 'n' roll band that's been around a few years: Keep the spirit that drove your early records, but don't try to make them sound the same. So if Pirner's flicking ashes into the cuffs of his rolled-up jeans suggests incurable adolescence, Murphy's talk of ``getting our business licks down'' and raising a family indicates the band is looking for ways to become more adult but not less contemporary. ``Being 28 is pretty staggering in a lot of ways,'' said Murphy, who became a father late last year. ``It's not fun anymore and it's time to get on with your life. You got to keep asking quesitons. If things were easy for us, we could start singing about sports cars. ``It's my occupation, but it's not my life. We've been at it long enough that we all have a pretty good sense of who we are. When the well runs dry, we'll be fine.''
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Thursday AMs, Nov. 15
$Adv12
For Release Monday AMs, Nov. 12, and Thereafter
DOC.HEAD: Ancient Jericho and the Uprising: Lazy Days, Social Nights
DOC.NOTE: With LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: The stillness of this ancient oasis is shattered now and then by army gunfire or Israeli soldiers shouting through loudspeakers: ``This is a curfew! Anyone leaving his house will be punished!'' For Jericho, the Israelis are the latest of many invaders, like the warrior Joshua, who felled its famous walls with a blast of trumpets and put a curse on any man who would rebuild the town. On scorching summer days, when the sun beats down and mosquitoes and flies buzz through mud-brick huts and white stone houses, it seems as if Joshua's curse still afflicts the town, which is as old as civilization. Yet, Jericho is a place of rare beauty. The sweet smells of jasmine and orange blossoms waft through the air, bursts of red and orange bougainvillea dot the lush green of the oasis against a backdrop of the dusty Judean hills. It also has come to resemble a ghost town during the 34-month Palestinian uprising. Stores and restaurants close at noon on orders from pro-PLO leaders who want a united front against Israeli occupation. Few of the 12,000 Palestinian townspeople come out. ``It's boring now. The only thing I do in the evenings is visit my friends,'' said Wajihah Godah, 28, who works as a secretary in Jerusalem, about 20 miles away. After sundown, the streets belong to the soldiers and the ``shebab,'' teen-age activists who mask their faces with black-and-white checked Arab headdresses called keffiyehs. In the darkness, the shebab move silently through gardens and alleys, spraying walls with slogans like ``PLO, Israel No'' or a favorite, mocking symbol: a Nazi swastika paired with a Jewish Star of David. They stone Israeli cars racing along the main road from Jerusalem to Tiberias. A prize target is the black limousine of Foreign Minister David Levy, who commutes through part of the West Bank between Jerusalem and his home in Beit Shean, an Israeli town. The uprising has taken 10 lives in Jericho and the neighboring refugee camps of Aqabat Jaber and Ein Sultan. Four Israelis were killed in the firebombing of a bus, Israelis shot three Palestinians to death and three others were slain by fellow Arabs who suspected them of being informers. More people have been killed in other places, and sometimes outsiders say Jericho sleeps while the rest of the West Bank and Gaza Strip is burning. Winters are mild in Jericho, and it was a favorite resort of Arabs before Israel seized the West Bank from Jordan in the 1967 Middle East war. Christian pilgrims, curious Israelis and West Bank residents kept it going afterward. Until the uprising, bands played Arabic music in garden restaurants along the main road. Stately matrons with scarves tied around their hips sometimes performed sensuous belly dances to shouts and applause. Young men, chain-smoking American cigarettes, played cards in the coffeeshops. Israelis stopped on the way home from outings at the Dead Sea to buy pottery or pomelas, a football-sized citrus fruit grown in the area. Busloads of foreign tourists came to see Jericho, which is the lowest town on Earth, at 850 feet below sea level, in addition to being one of the oldest and best-known. They climbed to the Byzantine Monastery of the Temptation, carved into a steep hillside north of town to mark where the Bible says the Devil tempted Jesus for 40 days, or toured nearby Tel Sultan, where remains of city walls date from 7000 B.C. The garden restaurants are closed now. Israelis and most foreign tourists stay away for fear of being stoned. Jericho's people have adapted to the rebellion, and the boredom. When leaders of the uprising called a one-week strike to protest the killings of 20 Palestinians on Temple Mount in Jerusalem, the three video shop owners dutifully closed but still did booming business, renting movies from their homes or car trunks. Frequent general strikes leave plenty of time for visiting. In the evenings, families sit on garden chairs in their front yards, scrutinizing whoever passes. Sometimes it's only a herd of goats or an army foot patrol. But if someone familiar comes along, and in Jericho that's nearly everyone, they call out ``T'fadalu!'' - Arabic for ``Please come in.'' Each arrival is offered tea with fresh mint, and in return contributes a little gossip. A recent tidbit concerned a man who charged into a neighbor's house, after her goats ate his flowers, and now fears revenge from her angry clan. Saeb Erakat, a journalist from Jericho who supports the Palestine Liberation Organization, says the uprising has brought people closer. ``Divorce rates are down, there has been a big decline in family feuds and people share more because of the economic hardships,'' he said. Amid the upheavals of occupation and uprising, Jericho's people take some comfort from its turbulent history. They live among cultural relics of Romans, Crusaders, Ottoman Turks and other invaders. All the foreign armies left, eventually.
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Monday AMs, Nov. 12
$adv05
For Release Monday, Nov. 5, and Thereafter
DOC.HEAD: Analysts See Faster Fed Action
DOC.TEXT: If many Wall Street crystal balls are functioning properly, the Federal Reserve may soon get more aggressive in its efforts to lower interest rates and stimulate the sagging economy. Signs of an incipient recession are building up, analysts note, increasing pressure on the Fed to do something to brake the economy's slide. Furthermore, they argue, the forces that have militated against an easing of the central bank's credit policy - most notably fears of inflation - are showing signs of ebbing. But these same observers caution that a new approach by the Fed would come with no guarantee of fast, effective relief for the problems afflicting the economy and the stock market. They say there is a real danger that Chairman Alan Greenspan and his colleagues will find themselves ``pushing on a string'' - trying to prod the economy without getting much immediate response on the other end. ``The economy started to dive in early October,'' says Edward Yardeni, economist at Prudential-Bache Securities. Yardeni says a full-scale recession might still be staved off if some sudden resolution of the showdown in the Persian Gulf drove oil prices below $20 a barrel. But that, he acknowledges, looks like a long-shot proposition at best. ``A better bet is that the Federal Reserve is likely to lower short-term interest rates very sharply very soon,'' he asserts. ``The economy desperately needs easier monetary policy.'' The rise of the civilian unemployment rate from 5.4 percent at the start of the summer to 5.7 percent last month provides one rationale for Fed easing. The Bush administration and Congress also helped clear the way by reaching agreement at last in late October on a federal budget plan, even though the measure is expected to put only a slight dent in the government deficit. The Fed gave a nod of acknowledgment to that development last Monday with moves that pushed down the interest rate on federal funds, or overnight loans between banks, from the neighborhood of 8 percent to about 7.5 percent. With a bit more oomph behind it soon, Yardeni says, the federal funds rate is likely to hit 7.25 percent by yearend and 6.75 percent by March 1991. For the past several months, the Fed's maneuvering room has been widely viewed as limited because of inflation worries in general and soaring oil prices in particular. If the Fed sought to ease, it was widely believed, long-term interest rates might actually rise rather than fall, because bond traders feared that the authorities were abandoning their anti-inflation stand. Now, however, economists say recent declines in a wide range of commodity prices other than oil have cooled inflationary fears. What may prompt Fed action faster than anything else, many analysts agree, is the shaky state of the banking system. ``As we see it over the next several months, investors, like the central bank, will switch anxieties,'' says Robert Barbera, economist at Shearson Lehman Brothers. ``Deflation worries, reflecting falling asset prices and banking system fissures, will soon overwhelm inflation concerns.'' In the world of banking, Barbera says, ``strains normally associated with recession are already acute. Recently, U.S. financial markets have been confronted with the first signs of bank funding difficulties. ``When the banking system's safety and soundness are called into question, dramatic ease is the necessary response, and we are confident that the Fed will deliver.''
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Monday, Nov. 5
$Adv07
For Release Wednesday AMs, Nov. 7, and Thereafter
DOC.HEAD: Cole Porter's Music Comes Alive Again in AIDS Tribute
DOC.TEXT: The songs of Cole Porter have come alive again for a cause the composer couldn't have imagined before his death in 1964. ``Red, Hot and Blue,'' a benefit album for AIDS research and relief, matches such artists as U2, Sinead O'Connor, Fine Young Cannibals, Neneh Cherry and the Neville Brothers to songs made popular in the 1930s and '40s. The 20-song CD is a daydream come true for New York City art critic John Carlin and his friends at the New York city law firm that manages the late songwriter's trust fund. ``It struck me that the Cole Porter songs were a wonderful way to make a contemporary record that would appeal to all sorts of people and deliver a message,'' said Carlin, who wanted to do something for friends dying of AIDS. ``Everyone loves Cole Porter,'' he said. ``No one's covered his songs for 20 or 30 years. In the back of my mind I always wondered what it would be like for David Byrne to sing a Cole Porter song, or Tom Waits.'' In those cases, it sounds a lot like how Byrne and Waits sing their own songs. But other results will surprise fans of both Porter and contemporary music - like the Jungle Brothers' rap on ``I Get a Kick Out of You'' and the torch song stylings of country star k.d. lang and dance-pop singer Jody Watley. ``The songs worked better than we dreamed,'' Carlin said. ``What was a simple love ballad, when played in this context, took on a different meaning.'' Porter's career stretched from the '20s through the '50s. His songs were a staple on Broadway and in movies, and he was known for his humorous, often boundary-breaking, treatments of love and sex. AIDS, of course, wasn't a worry when Porter was around. On a few of the new versions of Porter's songs, particularly Cherry's blunt rap to ``I've Got You Under My Skin,'' the disease is addressed. It was the initial participation of Cherry and Byrne that really got the project going because it helped convince other artists to join in, Carlin said. Carlin and two entertainment lawyers who work at the law firm that manages the Porter trust fund, F. Richard Pappas and Leigh Blake, put it together. The album veers recklessly from style to style. There's the campy rock duet of Deborah Harry and Iggy Pop on ``Well, Did You Evah,'' the cool soul of Fine Young Cannibals' ``Love for Sale,'' the African language version of ``Begin the Beguine'' by Salif Keita and the rollicking Irish duet by Kirsty MacColl and the Pogues on ``Miss Otis Regrets.'' Despite the album's variety, Carlin concedes there's something missing. The album has no Latin ifluences and not enough black voices, an important omission considering the impact of AIDS in those communities. And there are no heavy metal artists. Carlin said the lack of hard rock artists was largely by design - he didn't feel the genre was appropriate to Porter's songs. It's also because, he said, that community is without a doubt the most homophobic in the music business. Last year, the Gay Men's Health Crisis in New York City dropped the band Guns 'N Roses from an AIDS benefit concert after organization volunteers noted the lyrics to one of their songs, ``One in a Million,'' contained the lyrics: ``Immigrants and faggots, they make no sense to me.'' Several artists asked to participate refused because of the stigma attached to AIDS and homosexuality, Carlin said. ``There were a few big artists,'' he said. ``I don't want to give the names of people who didn't do it for the wrong reasons. I'm surprised at how many artists we did get.'' The only artist Carlin will reveal who turned down a request to participate was Prince, but it had nothing to do with homophobia. Carlin said he wanted him to record a version of ``Let's Misbehave,'' but Prince was too busy on his ``Graffiti Bridge'' movie and soundtrack. When organizers approached an artist to ask for involvement, they suggested a tune from the Porter songbook. Most took the advice. Some artists, including MacColl and Watley, had their own ideas for songs. ``We wanted the album to be very modern and very youth-oriented,'' Carlin said. ``We wanted a club sound, not an Ella Fitzgerald sound.'' Watley, known for her dance music, remembered a Fitzgerald recording she listened to as a child to use as a model for her version of ``After You, Who.'' She said she relished the chance to sing a jazz tune, something she can't do on her own records. ``After recording this song I've been asked by virtually everyone who heard it, `Are you going to do an album like this?''' Watley said. ``Even my mom asked me that.'' An expert on Porter's work said he's excited about the project and predicted that Porter would have been, too. ``The man was insatiable in his curiosity and he traveled all over the world to listen to all kinds of performances of his music,'' said Robert Kimball, who's written and edited several books on Porter's music. ``He was genuinely open to all different interpretations. My feeling is he would have reacted very enthusiastically to it.'' A 90-minute TV special featuring videos of artists performing their Porter songs is scheduled to air on ABC-TV at 11:30 p.m. on Dec. 1. A videocassette is expected to be released next year. The lawyers have formed a non-profit corporation called King Cole, Inc. that will funnel profits from ``Red, Hot and Blue'' to AIDS organizations all over the world. A committee of representatives from the project, including musicians and filmmakers, will recommend which charities receive the money.
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Wednesday AMs, Nov. 7
$Adv04
For release Sunday, Nov. 4, and thereafter
DOC.HEAD: Campaign '90: The Issues Changed Faster Than the Weather
DOC.NOTE: Eds: To UPDATE with Bush focus on gulf crisis, SUBS 3 grafs for 6th graf pvs, When candidates; SUBS 2 grafs for grafs 14-15 pvs, Politicians of
DOC.TEXT: The 1990 campaign has been a little like the capricious New England weather. If you don't like it, just wait a minute. Less than six months ago, politicians were at fever pitch over a constitutional amendment to ban flag-burning. Reluctant Democrats feared for their patriotic reputations; crusading Republicans smelled blood. It's hard now to recall the passion and acrimony generated by that once blazing concern, and harder still to find traces of it on the campaign trail. Ephemeral, fickle, call the season what you will, but issues came and went almost as quickly as movies of the week - until the campaign came home to roost in voter pocketbooks. ``The only national issue is the economy - taxes, economic leadership and fairness. It's driving the entire electorate,'' said analyst Stuart Rothenberg, publisher of The Political Report. President Bush attempted to shift voter attention to the Persian Gulf in the final days of the campaign, heating up his rhetoric and declaring he had ``lost patience'' with Iraq's Saddam Hussein. The president succeeded in dominating the news with an issue that traditionally favors his party. But most analysts predicted that the economic themes working to the Democrats' advantage would remain an influential factor in the election. When candidates first hit the campaign trail months ago, Kuwait had not yet been invaded. Recession worries were hypothetical and budget talks were a speck on the distant horizon. Emotional ``values'' issues were the political currency of the moment. Some candidates pledged their allegiance to the flag-burning ban. Others stoked the controversy over federally funded obscene art. Big-state gubernatorial candidates waged a spirited competition over who would order the most executions, deny the most paroles, propose the harshest penalties for drug-users. Congress was put on the defensive for voting itself a pay raise and then became enmeshed in the savings and loan scandal. The issues proved potent in a smattering of races, and planted the first seeds of anti-incumbent, rich-vs.-poor sentiment among voters. Abortion also took a brief turn on center stage. But the waters got muddied and the issue lost its fire. Both parties ran candidates with a full range of positions. States, meanwhile, failed to impose the serious restrictions anticipated in the wake of a 1989 Supreme Court decision, and abortion moved to the wings in most races. The spotted owl flew by and prompted intense debate in the Northwest. But the conflict over whether to protect forest habitat for the tiny owl at the expense of logging jobs never broadened into a compelling national issue, and environmental concerns colored only scattered races across the country. Communism fell and the peace dividend arose. Early in the campaign, candidates proposed 50-percent cuts in military spending and argued over whether to use the money saved from the Cold War thaw to expand domestic programs or reduce the deficit. Then came the late-summer Iraqi invasion of Kuwait and the deployment of U.S. troops to Saudi Arabia. The peace dividend vanished like a mirage in the blinding desert sun; the nation worried about war, incumbents looked like statesmen and other issues temporarily were swept aside. But politicians of both parties rallied behind Bush's policies, the standoff dragged on without shooting and the issue waned until Bush sought to revive it at the end. The declining economy and turbulent federal budget negotiations combined in September to produce the potent pocketbook themes that dominated the campaign's final weeks. The battle cry of no new taxes turned into a debate over whose new taxes and voters witnesed a confusing, chaotic struggle over their economic futures. Democrats railed at ``high-flyers'' and the rich who got richer in the 1980s at everyone else's expense. ``Let's go and get it from those who got it,'' Sen. Barbara Mikulski, D-Md., declared during floor debate over whether to raise taxes on the wealthy. The ``fairness'' pitch hadn't been particularly successful in the past and Democratic leaders were not making much headway this year from the launchpad of the bipartisan S&L scandal. Then they received a series of assists from Bush - his reversal on the need for new taxes, his insistence on a capital gains tax cut, his painful public wavering on whether to raise taxes on the rich, his failure to adequately explain his positions. ``Bush can truly take responsibility for whatever happens on Tuesday,'' said University of Virginia political scientist Larry Sabato. ``He created the Democrats' best issue, one that they could never have created for themselves.'' ``The Republicans gave the Democrats the ammunition,'' agreed Rothenberg. Analysts were not surprised that pocketbook issues ended up being pivotal. Democratic pollster Geoff Garin said the earlier ``boomlets'' were brief because ``it's hard to sustain a political debate when there is no debate. Everybody's against drugs. Everybody's against S&L crooks.'' The budget, by contrast, is ``a real live issue that really does raise differences,'' Garin said. Others suggested that some Republicans drew the wrong conclusions from Bush's successful use of patriotism and crime issues two years ago. ``Politicians thought they had learned a lesson from 1988 - the importance of certain symbols, the Republicans pushing identification with them and the Democrats trying not to look weak on them,'' said Rothenberg. But those were better days. ``Symbolic issues only work in times of peace and prosperity,'' said Sabato. ``Whenever the economy weakens, it always takes first place on the campaign agenda.''
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Sunday, Nov. 4
$adv03
$adv04
For Release Weekend Editions Nov. 3-4
DOC.HEAD: Putting the Bad News Behind Them
DOC.TEXT: A remedy for hard times has emerged: Take your lumps now and put the bad news behind you. That was the strategy employed this past week by two big corporate names, who chose to pay the piper now rather than later. General Motors Corp., the nation's largest industrial company, and Eastman Kodak Co., the 18th biggest, took hefty charges in the third quarter to put some big problems to rest. The charges turned profits into losses for both. GM, slugging through a slump in auto sales, said it took a $2.1 billion charge to cover the costs of plant closings and other production cutbacks. The stunning accounting move esulted in a $2 billion loss for the quarter, the largest in automotive history. It was a dismal quarter all around for the Big Three automakers. Ford Motor Co. reported lower than expected earnings, and Chrysler registered a $214 million loss. Without its charge, GM would have managed a gain of just $109 million. The motivation for Kodak's move was a $909.5 million patent infringement judgment the company has been ordered to pay rival Polaroid. Kodak officials said that although no money has changed hands and the case was still under appeal, it was appropriate to book the charge right away. That left the photographic company with a $206 million third-quarter loss. Earnings would have risen 19 percent to $358 million without the judgment. Was the bloodletting good medicine? Wall Street thought so and registered its approval by bidding up shares of GM and Kodak after their announcements. Experts said the moves went a long way toward wiping the slate clean for both companies, although they still face stern competition in a tough economy.
DOC.HEAD: ECONOMY: Preparing for the Worst
DOC.TEXT: Economic worries were prompting companies across the country to retrench. Citicorp, General Dynamics and Aetna were among several announcing cutbacks. Many economists said it could be the start of something ugly. ``We haven't had a recession for so long that people forget what happens,'' said Bruce Steinberg, an economist at Merrill Lynch & Co. The news on the economy continued to darken, with the exception of a surprising government report that pegged economic growth at a strong 1.8 percent in the third quarter. That hopeful report was later overshadowed by a litany of woe from several sources. The government's economic forecasting gauge dropped 0.8 percent in September, its second straight monthly drop. By conventional wisdom, three consecutive declines in the Index of Leading Economic Indicators signal a recession. The government said unemployment held steady in October at 5.7 percent, but job erosion continued among manufacturing and construction payrolls. A separate report showed construction spending in September took its deepest plunge since the 1982 recession. A report from the National Association of Purchasing Management said October was the worst month for manufacturers in eight years. Business failures rose by 14.5 percent in the first nine months of the year, according to Dun & Bradstreet Corp. The Economic Policy Institute, a liberal think tank, said heavy debts accumulated in the heady 1980s would make a recession longer and deeper than usual. Amid the gloom, the Federal Reserve, the nation's central bank, followed through on a promise to ease credit in response to the federal budget agreement. The Fed lowered a short-term rate that banks charge each other for overnight loans, but other interest rates weren't expected to drop much, unless the Fed relaxes the credit reins even further.
DOC.HEAD: WALL STREET: More Cuts, Restructurings
DOC.TEXT: On Wall Street, where cutbacks have been a way of life since the 1987 market crash, Morgan Stanley & Co. announced it would lay off about 6 percent of its investment banking division, a small but noteworthy cut for one of the Street's most profitable firms. In addition, the New York Stock Exchange said it was freezing executive salaries for 1991 and enacting an early retirement plan that aims to trim about 8 percent of its staff next year. Also during the week, Merrill Lynch & Co., the nation's biggest securities firm, announced a restructuring that could put hundreds out of work over the next several months.
DOC.HEAD: AUTOS: A Pattern Agreement for Chryser
DOC.TEXT: Countering news of Chrysler's loss for the quarter was the announcement of its contract agreement with the United Auto Workers union. The company and union reached the pact after 27 straight hours of bargaining, averting a strike. It was a settlement modeled after earlier agreements with GM and Ford, which pleased the union but left some observers wondering whether Chrysler could digest it. The pact's provisions for job security and protecting the income of laid-off workers apparently followed the GM-Ford pattern. To help offset those costs, Chrysler officials said they gained some flexibility to shift workers' schedules and boost production of the profitable minivan line.
DOC.HEAD: MAC ATTACK: No More Foam for McDonald's
DOC.TEXT: McDonald's Corp. tried to remove itself as an environmental target by announcing a sudden end to use of foam boxes for Big Macs and other sandwiches. erstand everything.'' Clark confirmed other statements from Miss Brando's deposition, including her account of the moments after the shooting. Shapiro said Miss Brando ``clearly is suffering from serious mental and emotional problems.'' Marlon Brando wept last month when he discussed his daughter's emotional problems, which he said dated to a serious car crash last year. ``Cheyenne has suffered enormously,'' Brando said then. ``She's been beaten physically. ... She's suffered a head injury where her face was smashed and she had to have her face remade. She's suffered a nervous breakdown. She's had to be in a sanitarium under a doctor's care.'' In recent weeks, Miss Brando was reported to be out of the hospital and living with her mother, Tarita.

The tortured $1.36 billion buyout of MGM-UA Communications Co. by Giancarlo Parretti's Pathe Communications Corp. has been completed, a spokeswoman for Parretti said. The Italian financier took possession of the historic studio and its roaring Leo the Lion trademark at 11:07 a.m. Thursday, spokeswoman Arlene Cattani said. The deal had been delayed for months. --- NEW YORK (AP) - Morgan Stanley & Co. said it was laying off about 6 percent of the investment banking division as rumors swirled on Wall Street of major cuts at another big firm. Morgan Stanley, the second most profitable on Wall Street last year, said it planned to cut 50 professionals from its worldwide investment banking staff of 800 by the end of the year. Also Thursday on Wall Street, the New York Stock Exchange board froze officers' salaries for 1991 and said it expects to reduce staffing by about 8 percent next year. Both reductions come during a prolonged downturn in the financial industry that has seen thousands of layoffs, management overhauls and reductions in major business sectors. --- CHICAGO (AP) - The plastic foam boxes that cradle millions of Big Macs and other sandwiches - boxes an environmentalist called ``a huge symbol of the throwaway society'' - are being eliminated, McDonald's said. Under pressure from environmental groups, which say the clamshell boxes add to the nation's overflowing garbage crisis, McDonald Corp. President Edward Rensi said Thursday the company had decided ``to do what's right.'' --- NEW YORK (AP) - IBM agreed to pay a Scottish manufacturer of computer memory devices an undisclosed amount to settle a patent infringement suit, the two companies said. The settlement, announced Thursday, could result in other payments by computer makers to the company, Rodime PLC, since its patents cover the most widely used type of internal memory device for personal computers, the 3{-inch magnetic hard disc drive. --- NEW YORK (AP) - A former Merrill Lynch & Co. vice president was charged with soliciting and demanding payoffs from vendors hired to construct the world headquarters of the nation's biggest brokerage firm. A four-count information, filed Thursday in U.S. District Court in Manhattan, alleged Merrill Lynch vendors supplied the executive, Albert Young, with a stretch limousine and chauffeur and helped pay for his country home in Hawley, Pa. --- ST. LOUIS (AP) - Ralston Purina Co. reported its profit for its fourth quarter soared 81.4 percent compared to the same period last year mainly because of lower advertising and administrative costs. The consumer products company Thursday said it earned $82 million, or $1.37 a share, in the three months ended Sept. 30 compared with $45.2 million, or 65 cents a share, a year earlier. Sales edged up 1.7 percent to $1.79 billion in the quarter from $1.76 billion in 1989. --- FLAT ROCK, Mich. (AP) - Osamu Nobuto resigned as chairman of Mazda Motor Manufacturing (USA) Corp., Mazda Motor Corp. said. Nobuto, 58, a Mazda senior managing director, was placed in charge of the Japanese auto company's worldwide purchasing activities in June. Nobuto was named MMUC's first president in May 1985. He returned to Japan in March 1990 and was named chairman at that time. --- SPOKANE, Wash. (AP) - Kaiser Aluminum & Chemical Co. and the United Steelworkers of America reached a tentative contract agreement, averting a strike by 3,500 employees in three states. Agreement on the four-year contract was reached shortly after 4 a.m. Thursday, said Kaiser spokeswoman Susan Ashe. A ratification vote as expected to be completed by next week.Ashe said the new agreement would increase base pay by 50 cents an hour in the first and fourth years, increase pension benefits, provide a signing bonus of $1,000, continue a bonus plan tied to the price of metal and introduce a managed health care program. --- NEW YORK (AP) - Business failures rose by 14.5 percent nationwide in the first nine months of 1990, accelerated by economic turmoil in New England and the Middle Atlantic states, Dun & Bradstreet Corp. said. The study by the business information company found that combined business bankruptcies in the two regions soared by more than 90 percent in the period. Also Thursday, a closely followed survey said that the nation's industrial sector weakened in October, pushing the overall economy into a decline for the first time in nearly eight years. ---

Stock prices chalked up a moderate gain as traders studied accumulating evidence of weakness in the economy. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials Thursday climbed 12.62 points to 2,454.95. Bond prices strengthened, lifted by gloomy unemployment figures and other signs of economic duress. The dollar fell against all major currencies but the Japanese yen on further signs of a weakening U.S. economy and rising interest rates overseas. Gold prices advanced.

DOC.HEAD: More Layoffs Expected as Economy Stalls
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Friday AMs report.
DOC.HEAD: With BC-Layoffs-List, PM-Wall Street Cuts, Bjt
Graphic
DOC.TEXT: Citicorp, General Dynamics, Aetna and General Motors are only a few of the major employers that announced layoffs in recent days. Many economists say it could be just the start of a widespread job scaleback as the economy stalls. ``There will be more layoffs, the unemployment rate will rise, job market conditions will deteriorate for the next six months or longer,'' said Bruce Steinberg, an economist at Merrill Lynch & Co. ``We haven't had a recession for so long that people forget what happens,'' he said. Some economists said service jobs may be hit hardest. That's due partly to the boom in the banking, finance, advertising and other service industries in the 1980s, which allowed these companies to grow fat. Finance and banking companies ``were basically taking anyone who could walk through the door,'' said economist Robert Dye of the Wefa Group, an economic forecasting firm in Bala Cynwyd, Pa. But in the face of increasingly grim economic forecasts and figures - compounded by the economic shock from the Persian Gulf standoff - these companies have been letting go of workers in droves. Citicorp, for one, said it will eliminate 2,000 jobs by the end of next year. ``They grew too fast and this is the consequence of growing too fast, a shakeout if you will,'' said Kenneth Goldstein, an economist with the Conference Board, a New York-based business research group. The slowdown among financial companies began with the Wall Street crash of October 1987, but it since has intensified as small investors have grown more cautious and avoided the stock and bond markets. The crash, along with the end of the real estate boom and the spread of the savings and loan crisis, also hurt banks and insurers. Aetna Life & Casualty Co., for example, plans to eliminate 2,600 jobs through layoffs and attrition. Manufacturing companies have fared somewhat better because they learned from the last recession eight years ago to keep operations lean, economists said. But the recent economic sluggishness has prompted many of them to lay off workers as well. In perhaps the largest such cutback, General Motors Corp. said it would close four plants and idle others temporarily, affecting thousands of workers. Experts say GM was responding to excess carmaking capacity as well as to the economy. State and local government jobs also are facing cuts due to withering tax revenues. Reductions are planned by Massachusetts, Virginia and the city of Pittsburgh, among others. Defense cutbacks also are hitting employment. General Dynamics Corp. said it will lay off 700 to 1,000 workers in January because of budget cuts and declining demand for the F-16 jet fighters. In all industries, middle-management jobs have been particularly hard hit. Economists say companies are cutting jobs not deemed crucial or revenue-producing. Regardless of the cause, employers should view layoffs as a last resort, said Martha White, a Chicago-based consultant who helps troubled companies reorganize. ``Because the victims go away during a downsizing or layoffs, people tend to think the problems go away. But that's not true, there's always residual fallout in the organization'' in the form of morale and loyalty problems that can hurt productivity, she said. Some economists said they believe employers announcing layoffs recently were prompted by actual signs of economic decline, not by a desire to take pre-emptive action before the downturn worsens. That means more layoffs are almost certain if the sluggishness intensifies. The Labor Department said last month that 1,127,000 people were out of work in September due to temporary layoffs, up from 918,000 in June. The unemployment rate in September actually was higher for manufacturing and low-skilled jobs than for white-collar jobs, the department said. For example, the jobless rate for managerial workers was 2.7 percent in September, virtually unchanged from a year earlier. For low-skill manufacturing jobs it was 7.3 percent, also almost unchanged from a year ago. ``The impression has been created that there are just zillions of professionals who are suddenly out on the street, but that is just not the case,'' said Jay Meisenheimer, a Labor Department economist. Private economists are looking to the release Friday of October unemployment figures for further insight into the economy's direction. September's overall rate was 5.7 percent, up from 5.6 percent in August. Several reports Thursday indicated the economy continues to slow. In one, a widely watched monthly survey of purchasing executives indicated that manufacturing fell to its lowest level in eight years in October. In another, the Labor Department said the seasonally adjusted number of new unemployment claims filed in the week ended Oct. 20 rose to its highest level in seven years. But many economists are not forecasting a downturn as severe as the 1981-82 recession, when unemployment hit 11 percent. Several say they don't expect unemployment to rise above 7 percent while others, including the Conference Board's Goldstein, aren't even predicting a full-blown recession.

DOC.HEAD: Morgan Stanley, NYSE Plan Cuts; Rumors Fly at First Boston
With PM-Layoffs
DOC.TEXT: In the throes of a prolonged downturn, another round of cutbacks is taking shape on Wall Street. Morgan Stanley & Co. on Thursday announced 50 layoffs in its investment banking unit. The New York Stock Exchange froze executive salaries and targeted an 8 percent staff reduction. Merrill Lynch & Co. expects to cut hundreds of jobs. A First Boston Corp. spokesman said cuts were expected by year's end. The securities industry has been locked in decline since the 1987 stock market crash. Activity in the once-lucrative mergers and acquisitions area has plummeted. Big-time fees for managing deals are a thing of the past. Individual investor activity also is down. ``If people aren't bringing in business, you're running a loss,'' said Perrin Long, an analyst with Lipper Analytical Securities Corp. ``You can't sit back and say, `Times will be get better, we'll just keep the people.''' ``With the slowdown we've had, in order to maintain some semblance of income before taxes you have to let people go,'' Long said. According to Securities Data Co., U.S. merger activity plummeted 52 percent in the first nine months of 1990. Total fees for securities underwriting, another critical measure of profitability, plunged to $1.5 billion in the period, the lowest level since 1984. ``The roaring profits of the 1980s are a distant memory as Wall Street undergoes another wave of cutbacks,'' Securities Data said. Morgan Stanley spokeswoman Jean Andrews said the firm - Wall Street's second most profitable last year with $443 million in earnings - planned to cut 50 professionals from its worldwide investment banking staff of 800 by the end of 1990. She said the cuts would be across the board, including some senior executives. The investment banking division includes mergers and acquisitions, corporate finance, real estate and capital markets. ``It's in response to the current and expected business environment for the industry,'' Andrews said. ``Managing in this environment, you always look at what resources you commit to these businesses.'' Morgan last week reported a 29 percent drop in third-quarter earnings, to $71.9 million from $101 million in the same 1989 period. The firm attributed the decline to a sharp drop in merchant banking and investment banking activity. In the first nine months of the year, Morgan dropped to sixth place from first place in 1989 in the total value of merger deals completed - to $30.9 billion in 89 deals from $83.3 billion in 119 deals. At First Boston, rumors circulated widely that the firm was planning a major restructuring to include hundreds of layoffs in coming days. Also Thursday, the NYSE said it was freezing executive salaries for 1991 and enacting an early retirement plan in an effort to trim about 8 percent of its staff next year. Earlier this week, Merrill Lynch, the nation's biggest securities firm, announced a major restructuring that it expects will lead to hundreds of layoffs. And Oppenheimer & Co. this week had the credit rating of some of its debt downgraded - an especially tough blow because Wall Street firms rely on short-term loans to sustain daily operations. Standard & Poor's Corp. attributed its action to ``a weak operating performance due largely to a poor retail market and trading conditions'' First Boston workers said talk has focused on staff cuts of up to 10 percent involving investment banking and back-office personnel to be announced early next week. A First Boston spokesman said the company was reviewing all its businesses and some cuts were expected by the end of the year. But the spokesman said reports of a ``D-Day'' for layoffs constituted ``unfounded rumor and speculation.'' ``It looks like there is a consistent overcapacity vis a vis customer and client demand. We'll shrink,'' said the spokesman, who asked not to be identified by name. First Boston, a division of CS First Boston Inc., has struggled because of the slump affecting all of Wall Street as well as large junk-bond ``bridge loans'' to corporate clients that could not be refinanced.

DOC.HEAD: Crude Environmentalists: Oil Companies Adopt Greener Posture
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Friday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: Some of the nation's giant oil companies suddenly are proclaiming steps to conserve energy and protect the Earth, in what almost seems a battle over which one can be the biggest environmentalist. Within a 24-hour span this week, four of the majors announced media efforts with an environmental spin. The greener stance comes as the industry is disputing charges of price-gouging and profiteering from the Persian Gulf crisis, but it remained unclear if the timing was coincidental or intentional.
