As the conservation campaigns got under way, Chevron Corp. issued a ``Report on the Environment'' that said it's trying to protect elephants and rhinos in Sumatra. Texaco Inc. kicked off a conservation drive called ``Let's Put Our Energy into Saving It,'' which will include a barrage of print and broadcast advertising that urges consumers to use less fuel in cars and homes. Exxon Corp. announced it was distributing two types of cleaner fuel ``to help improve air quality.'' Amoco Corp., saying ``it's time to think green,'' unveiled a $2 billion package of energy initatives that range from cleaner fuel to low-fume gasoline pumps. Some environmentalists found themselves at a loss for comment when asked Thursday about the oil companies' new stance. Some expressed cautious optimism and others questioned the timing of the media blitz. ``I applaud the litle things they do, but they're still a long way from being green,'' said Michael Francis of The Wilderness Society. ``They want to keep this nation addicted to oil for one reason: Their profits.'' The oil companies disputed contentions they were trying to polish their image amid the current oil shock, although Texaco acknowledged that would be a welcome side effect. As the companies put forth their environmental messages, they even acted like they were trying to outdo each other in a competition over who could be the greenest. Chevron's claimed ``a reputation as one of the petroleum industry's most environmentally responsible companies.'' Exxon, which became an environmentalist hate-object after the Valdez oil spill in Alaska, called itself ``the leading producer of gasolines reformulated to reduce pollution'' with cleaner fuels available in more than 50 markets. Amoco spokesman Neil Geary responded: ``Exxon's talking about making changes in two grades. Our product in all three grades, in the Washington, Baltimore and Richmond markets, meets the Clean Air Act standards for 1992.'' Amoco's environmental battle plan was unveiled Thursday in a Washington news confernce at a model full-service gas station equipped with ``new and more effective Amoco-designed gasoline pump recovery nozzles, a used motor oil recycling collection facility for any motorists who change their own oil, and a compressed natural gas fueling facility for select fleet vehicle use.'' ``I think we were the only guys with a thoroughly prepared press conference today,'' Geary said. ``We had vehicles that are actually dual-fuel. They are able to run on both gasoline and compressed natural gas. We've already got the pump installed. We had all these other elements in place. I kind of get the sense other people are rushing to get stuff out on the wire.'' Not so, said Texaco, which had its fuel-saving package out in New York a day earlier. ``Our conservation initiative has been in the works for a couple of months,'' Texaco spokeswoman Anita M. Larsen said. ``We act independently from other companies. This is not in reaction to what anyone else is doing.'' Chevron's media package was in earth tones, on recycled, recyclable paper. Amoco prominently pointed out that its media package also was made of recycled paper. It went a step further, by including a deck of cards for playing an Amoco trivia game, ``Environmental Pursuits.'' Texaco, however, was not immediately sure whether the paper in its media package was recycled. ``That was pulled from existing stock, whatever we had,'' Ms. Larsen said.

DOC.HEAD: MGM-Pathe Deal Closes, Finally
DOC.TEXT: Pathe Communications Corp.'s $1.36 billion buyout of MGM-UA is finally a done deal, but whether the historic studio and its trademark lion will roar again remains uncertain. The new enterprise, like the pending purchase of MCA Inc. by Matsushita Electric Industrial Co., seeks to exploit an international hunger for Hollywood entertainment. Pathe's holdings are mainly European. But unlike robust Sony Corp., which last year bought Columbia Pictures Entertainment, Giancarlo Parretti's cash-poor Pathe labored for months to close the MGM-UA deal. Bringing success to the new studio will be a struggle, analysts say. Wall Street experts have said it will take at least $500 million and several years to revive MGM-UA, whose recent releases range from hits such as ``Rain Man,'' to box office bombs such as ``Desperate Hours.'' Pathe has mortgaged its future, said Jessica Reif, an analyst for First Boston Corp. The new studio's budget and its profits, Reif said, will be tied up in the sale of foreign, domestic and home video rights to nearly every movie in the combined Pathe-MGM-UA libraries for the next 10 years. Speaking on condition of anonymity, an executive for a rival studio said the newly formed MGM-Pathe Communications Co. will need hit movies fast. He estimated the price paid may have been double the studio's worth. Pathe officials say they paid a fair price and intend to recapture the once-legendary status of MGM. Parretti spokeswoman Arlene Cattani said the Italian financier took possession of the studio and its Leo the Lion trademark at 11:07 a.m. PST. A beaming Parretti later was greeted in his offices with a surprise from his staff - a real lion named Sudan - to personify the deal's closing. He gingerly sidled up to the 450-pound brute for a few quick photographs. ``Our goal is to make the MGM lion roar again,'' Parretti said in a statement. ``We will continue to develop the kind of product that has made the MGM and UA names legendary for generations, while building on Pathe's global presence.'' The buyout pays stockholders of MGM-UA a total of $21.50 per share. Earlier payments of $4 a share were made this summer. Craig Parsons, a spokesman for Pathe, said Parretti would become chief executive officer. He and his longtime associate, Florio Fiorini, will be named co-chairmen. Pathe Entertainment's Alan Ladd Jr., part of a host of film executives who headed MGM-UA, will run the new studio, Parsons said. Beverly Hills-based Pathe produces television and feature films. It also has a variety of European movie-related holdings. As part of the complicated transaction, MGM-UA will buy Pathe's assets for $700 million, raised in part through the sale of rights to a variety of Pathe, MGM and United Artists film and television properties. That $700 million will then be used to help buy MGM-UA. Independently, Pathe raised $600 million through stock sales to unidentified European investors. Those entities are believed to include Parretti's principal holding company, Com Finance S.A. of Luxembourg; his Melia International, one of the world's largest travel agencies; and the Spanish real estate business Renta Inmobiliaria S.A. An earlier MGM-UA sale to Pathe fell apart last spring when Time Warner Inc. backed out of its agreement to finance $650 million of the deal. Pathe spokesman Parsons said company officials are ``very comfortable'' with production financing, which will be partially underwritten by ``one new film a month,'' he said. No new debt is involved in the deal, Parsons said. MGM-UA currently has about $400 million in debt and Pathe owes $300 million. For MGM-UA's current management, the future is unclear. Chief executive Jeffrey Barbakow and studio chief Richard Berger did not return phone calls seeking comment Thursday. MGM-UA majority stockholder Kirk Kerkorian offered the Culver City-based studio for sale in April 1988. A spectrum of suitors - including Japan's Sony and C. Itoh, Rupert Murdoch's News Corp., the Walt Disney Co. and the Dutch conglomerate PolyGram - expressed interest in a deal, lured largely by the United Artists library, which included the ``Rocky'' and James Bond movies.

DOC.HEAD: McDonald's Eliminating Plastic Foam Containers
DOC.TEXT: McDonald's Corp.'s decision to eliminate plastic foam containers for its food is being hailed by environmental groups, but it's no source of joy for a company that recycles that plastic foam. McDonald's president Edward Rensi announced Thursday the goal of eliminating within 60 days the polystrene boxes that now cradle millions of the fast-food giant's Big Macs and other sandwiches. Under pressure from environmental groups, which say the clamshell-shaped boxes add to the nation's overflowing garbage crisis, Rensi said the company had decided ``to do what's right.'' ``Although some scientific studies indicate that foam packaging is environmentally sound, our customers just don't feel good about it,'' Rensi said by telephone from the company's suburban Oak Brook headquarters. ``So we're changing.'' The change was sudden. As recently as last week, McDonald's had been defending the use of plastic foam and was planning to extend an experimental plastic recycling program to all of its 8,500 restaurants nationwide. ``When we learned they were planning to go to comprehensive recycling, we reacted strongly,'' said Frederic D. Krupp, executive director of the Environmental Defense Fund, which opposes polystrene foam use. The announced shift to paper containers did not please the National Polystyrene Recycling Co., which is trying to establish a nationwide network of plastic foam recycling centers from its headquarters in suburban Lincolnshire. ``NPRC is disappointed to learn that McDonald's has decided to phase out its use of polystyrene foam packaging,'' said NPRC president E. James Schneiders. But he said the company can count on many other sources for its recycling centers. Schneiders also said McDonald's has proved to be an important educational tool in making the public conscious of recycling in general and plastic recycling in particular. A number of U.S. towns and cities have banned the use of polystyrene foam, saying it not only contributes to landfill problems, but also contains chemicals that harm the Earth's ozone level. Environmentalists praised Thursday's decision, but a spokesman for the packaging industry said McDonald's was folding to pressure that isn't based on fact. ``You don't want to get rid of them (polystyrene products) all together,'' said Joseph Bow, president of the Foodservice & Packaging Institute in Washington. ``They provide consumers with a sanitary and timesaving method of food delivery.'' McDonald's ``is bowing to public pressure that is based on misperceptions and misinformation,'' said Bow. A spokeswoman for the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency in Washington said her agency had no studies that indicated foam packaging is environmentally sound. On the other hand, said spokeswoman Robin Woods: ``It may not be an environmental hazard because it's inert. It's not something that breaks down easily and leaches into landfills, for example.'' Krupp, though, predicted that McDonald's has begun writing the industry-wide obituary on polystyrene. ``McDonald's understands that the future is green,'' Krupp said. ``I think other companies will follow suit.'' Jerry Johnson, executive director of the Polystyrene Packaging Council in Washington, disagreed. ``McDonald's is a major user, but they're not that big that they influence the total market here,'' Johnson said. ``There are still many places where polystyrene is used - and used because it is one of the most environmentally responsible materials used in the packaging industry today.'' McDonald's vice president Shelby Yastrow said the polystyrene containers are made for McDonald's by from five to seven companies - including Amoco Foam Products Co., Mobil Corp., Jen-Pak and Huntsman Chemical. Amoco Foam president John Giroux said 10 percent of his company's polystyrene sales were to McDonald's. First to go will be the plastic foam sandwich boxes, which will be replaced by paper products manufactured in a new process that will preserve the food's temperature and freshness, Rensi said. The company is still trying to determine suitable replacements for plastic cutlery and the plastic cups in which coffee is served, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Iraqi Turmoil Taking Toll on American Jobless Rate, Analysts Say
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also on general news wires. To be led with 8:30 a.m. EST release of report.
DOC.TEXT: The turmoil in the Persian Gulf, which has taken its toll on the U.S. economy by sending oil prices skyward, now threatens to worsen the nation's unemployment problems, analysts say. The fallout from Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait has left American businesses skittish about adding employees, according to private economists. ``There's a buttoning up of the overcoats going on,'' said Robert Dederick, chief economist at the Northern Trust Co. of Chicago. Iraq's continued occupation of Kuwait and the threat of war ``does not make one anxiously go out and hire people,'' Dederick said. Analysts will get their first comprehensive look at the nation's economic activity for October with today's release of the Labor Department's unemployment figures for last month. In advance of the report, many analysts predicted the jobless rate inched up from 5.7 percent to 5.8 percent in October, or possibly even up to 5.9 percent. If the unemployment rate did climb last month, it would mark the fourth straight monthly increase. The nation has not suffered four consecutive jumps in the jobless rate since 1982. Although government data indicates the U.S. economy grew at a slow annual rate of 1.8 percent in the third quarter of 1990, many analysts contend the nation slipped into a recession at the tail end of the July-September period or the start of the current fourth quarter. The recent rise in unemployment - before the jobless rate began going up in July it had been holding steady for months at 5.3 percent - just offers more evidence of a downturn, analysts said. ``What's happening is the economy is rolling into a mild recession,'' Dederick said. A jobless rate of 5.8 percent would mark a three-year high, the largest level since it reached that level in November 1987. Many analysts expected the Labor Department's report to probably show that the nation's industries lost about 75,000 jobs in October, a far cry from the 200,000 new jobs the economy was adding each month last year. The nation's manufacturing sector, which has been in a slump for months, was expected to continue its slide in October. Economic weakness probably continued to spread to the service sector as well, analysts said. They noted that the only area in the U.S. economy that has been booming recently is the health care industry, which has been adding about 50,000 jobs a month. David Jones, chief economist at Aubrey G. Lanston & Co., a government securities dealer, said business leaders' concerns ``intensified after the Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait by Iraq.'' But Jones noted that the nation's economy had been staggering for months, well before the Middle East erupted. ``We were clearly slipping gradually into recession even before the oil price shock,'' he said. Just in the last week, Citicorp, General Dynamics, Aetna and General Motors announced layoffs, and many economists said it could be the start of widespread job cuts as the economy continues to sputter. Many analysts say the only reason the unemployment rate had stayed at the relatively low and stable rate of 5.3 percent before July was because the American labor force is growing slowly.

DOC.HEAD: Honda, Range Rover Release 1991 Prices
DOC.TEXT: American Honda Motor Co. Inc. is boosting prices by about 1.3 percent on ts 1991 model cars over comparably equipped 1990 models. Honda blamed the price increase of $173 per vehicle on fluctuations in the exchange rate between the U.S. dollar and the Japanese yen. Prices range from $6,995 for a 1991 Honda Civic hatchback to $19,795 for an Accord Special Edition 4-door Sedan. Honda said Thursday its Accura division also was affected by the price increases, with 1991 models Integra and NSX costing 1.2 percent more, up $199 per vehicle. Prices range from $12,100 for the 1991 Integra RS with a manual transmission to $17,870 for the 1991 Integra GS with leather-trimmed interior and automatic transmission. The new NSX starts at $61,000 for a manual-equipped model, ranging up to $65,000 for the automatic version. Range Rover of North America Inc. also announced price increases on Thursday. The 1991 version of the British-built sport utility vehicle will cost 1 percent more than a comparably equipped 1990 model, with prices starting at $42,400.

DOC.HEAD: United, Pan Am Seek Quick Decision On Route Transfer
DOC.TEXT: United Airlines and Pan American World Airways have asked federal regulators to approve quickly United's proposed purchase of most of Pan Am's trans-Atlantic routes. American Airlines Inc., which has objected to the deal, declined comment on its competitors' request Thursday that the Department of Transportation approve the transfer of route authorities by Dec. 31. Under a $400 million deal announced Oct. 23, United would acquire all of Pan Am's U.S.-London routes except those landing in Miami and Detroit; a Washington-to-Paris route; all Pan Am facilities at San Francisco International, Washington's Dulles International and London's Heathrow airports; and two Boeing 747-200 passenger jets. American Airlines has asked Pan Am's board of directors for an opportunity to bid on the U.S.-London operations. American Chairman Robert Crandall suggested in letters to Pan Am's chairman and directors that the deal could run into regulatory and legal trouble if Pan Am did not seek higher bids. ``At this point, we're going to let those letters stand,'' said Tom Stack, an American spokesman in the Chicago area. He said American's leaders had not yet seen the United-Pan Am filing and so could not comment on it. The Teamsters Airline Division has said it plans to sue Pan Am for selling the London operations cheap. United Chairman Stephen Wolf and Pan Am Chairman Thomas G. Plaskett said in a joint statement that the proposed deal would enhance U.S. airline competition in international markets. Meanwhile, the Wall Street Journal reported today that the pilots union at Pan Am is considering making an offer for the Pan Am Shuttle, which serves the Boston-New York-Washington, D.C., corridor. Financially-ailing Pan Am Corp. put the shuttle up for sale earlier this year. Without identifying its sources by name, the Journal said the pilots union might be willing to pay as much as $150 million to $200 million for the shuttle. The report said the pilots would contribute as much as $60 million in cash toward the purchase while borrowing the rest. It also said the group would be willing to negotiate with third-party investors interested in buying the shuttle. The report said Pan Am declined commewnt on a possible shuttle bid from the pilots.

DOC.HEAD: Leading Indicators Dropped 0.8 Percent in September
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Combines pvs, inserting grafs 4-5, In another report ... with unemployment. Also moving on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: The government's chief economic forecasting gauge dropped 0.8 percent in September, the government said today, for its second straight monthly drop. The September drop followed a 1.2 percent plunge in August, the steepest since a 1.4 percent fall a month after the October 1987 stock market crash. The index was unchanged in July. Three consecutive declines in the Commerce Department's Index of Leading Economic Indicators are viewed as a fairly reliable - although not infallible - sign that a recession is imminent. In another report, the government said the unemployment rate held at 5.7 percent in October even though the nation's manufacturing and construction industries continued to slump. The index of leading indicators lags a month behind the unemployment report. Although last month's civilian jobless rate was unchanged from September's 5.7 percent, the Labor Department said the nation's job market continued to show weakness and widespread job losses. There has not been a recession since World War II without the index of leading indicators turning down for at least three consecutive months. However, the index was negative for six months in 1984 and for five months in 1987-88 and, both times, the economy escaped a recession. Many economists who believe the nation's economy is in a recession are now debating how long it will last and how severe it will be. Even those analysts who say the economy still can skirt a recession generally agree the current quarter is in a contraction. A recession generally is defined as two straight quarters of negative growth. The GNP is the nation's total output of goods and services and its broadest measure of economic activity. Nine of the forward-looking indicators pulled the index down in September. They were lower stock prices, a decrease in orders for consumer goods, an increase in weekly unemployment claims, a decline in building permits, a drop in an index measuring consumer confidence, a decrease in unfilled orders, a lower money supply, faster business delivery times and a decline in the price of raw materials. The only positive contributor was an increase in orders for new plants and equipment. One indicator, the average workweek, was unchanged. The various changes left the index at 143.3 percent of its 1982 base of 100 and down 1.1 percent from its level a year ago. Many analysts who contend a recession will be avoided still express concern the economy may have weakened during the current quarter. Michael Boskin, chairman of President Bush's Council of Economic Advisers, said earlier this week that ``we are concerned about a sluggish fourth quarter and the early part of 1991.'' Stephen S. Roach, senior economist at Morgan Stanley & Co. of New York, believes the economy will avoid a recession although he projects a decline in growth during the current quarter. However, he added, ``We are not projecting two consecutive quarters of declining GNP'' - the generally accepted definition of a recession. Roger Brinner, chief economist with DRI-McGraw-Hill in Lexington, Mass., said he expects a recession starting in the current quarter, with an economic recovery in the second half of 1991. Michael K. Evans of Evans Economics Inc. in Washington said a ``recession will be shallow but extended, with growth remaining near zero throughout 1991.'' On the other hand, a survey of 52 economists by the publication Blue Chip Economic Indicators showed a consensus believed the economy will decline 0.6 percent this quarter and 0.1 percent in the first quarter of 1991. The consensus then projected the economy to edge up 1.2 percent in the second quarter and 2.3 percent and 2.6 percent in the next two. Economists with Regional Financial Associates in West Chester, Pa., said they expect ``the current recession to be mild in comparison to other post-war recessions. The contraction is estimated to have begun in August and to end in March 1991, a total of eight months.'' ``This is significantly shorter than the 11-month average length of the six previous post-war recessions,'' they wrote in their Regional Financial Review. But a study for the Economic Policy Institute, a liberal think tank financed partly by labor unions, contends the next recession will be longer and deeper than normally would be expected due in large part to consumers' heavy debt. This will cause consumers to cut back spending even more sharply than they otherwise would and thus deepen the contraction, said the study by Robert Pollin, an economist at the University of California-Riverside.

DOC.HEAD: Slow Sales Idle Auto Workers
DOC.TEXT: General Motors Corp. says it is making a new round of production cutbacks at 11 U.S. and Canadian assembly plants, moves that will idle more than 27,000 workers. Ford Motor Co., meanwhile, will temporarily lay off about 10,600 workers as it shuts down five car and truck assembly plants because of slow sales. Chrysler Corp. is holding production relatively even and has announced no layoffs or temporary shutdowns for the current quarter. The cuts in fourth-quarter auto production come in the wake of pessimistic economic forecasts. Early October sales were stronger than predicted, but automakers are wary. ``It doesn't look like sales are falling off the cliff, but dealers are afraid of carrying big inventories,'' said David Healy, an auto analyst with Barclays de Zoete Wedd investment banking group in New York. The GM cuts are the most extensive by the nation's largest automaker since last winter. All three of the company's vehicle groups announced temporary shutdowns. Nineteen of the 29 GM plants in the United States and Canada will be affected by the cuts between now and Christmas. Layoffs began Monday at plants belonging to GM's Truck & Bus Group with the shutdown of two assembly lines in Flint. Second shift production at the Flint 2 line will end in early January, idling more than 1,700 workers indefinitely. The Pontiac East truck assembly plant as well as plants in Moraine, Ohio, and Fort Wayne, Ind., will shut down temporarily next Monday. GM's Chevrolet-Pontiac-Canada Group also is shutting the Corvette assembly plant in Bowling Green, Ky., for two weeks starting Monday and will reduce production at the plant when the workers return Nov. 19. Plants in Tarrytown, N.Y., Oklahoma City, Okla., Arlington, Texas, and Van Nuys, Calif., also will close for two weeks beginning Monday. The cutbacks in Tarrytown include the indefinite layoff of approximately 450 workers by reducing the speed of the assembly line, following the temporary shutdown. GM of Canada Ltd. will drop one shift at its van plant next month and will cut production at a truck plant in Oshawa, Ontario, by 13 percent in early December. Cuts at the Buick-Oldsmobile-Cadillac Group are less extensive but will involve shutdowns of plants in Wentzville, Mo., Wilmington, Del., and the Allante assembly plant in Detroit. The Wilmington plant also will close for at least one week in December. The Lordstown van plant, meanwhile, will shut for approximately one month Monday, prior to the dropping of a second shift at the plant now scheduled for Dec. 3.

DOC.HEAD: Eurotunnel Sets Price on New Share Offer
DOC.TEXT: Eurotunnel, the Anglo-French consortium which is digging a rail tunnel beneath the English Channel, announced Friday it hopes to raise 532 million pounds, or about $1.04 billion, after expenses through the sale of new shares to existing shareholders. The company set the price of each share at 285 pence, or $5.56. It plans to offer nearly 200 million new shares; there are 332.4 million shares already outstanding. The proposed sale price is 34 percent below Eurotunnel's current price per share of 430 pence, or $8.36, on London's stock market. The new shares will begin trading on London's Stock Exchange, the Paris Bourse and the Brussels Stock Exchange on Nov. 12, the company said. Existing shareholders will be eligible to buy three new shares for every five they already own, Eurotunnel said. It is also offering a range of travel perquisites, including limited free travel, to encourage share purchases. The tunnel is scheduled to open in 1993, but the company projected no dividends until 1999. Details of the share offer were released three days after drillers in one of the project's three tunnels broke through from the British side to the French side. The success of the share sale with investors is a condition for the release of an additional $4.1 billion in loans agreed to by banks, which already have put up $9.8 billion. The sale has been fully underwritten by a group of British, American and French financial institutions, Eurotunnel said. The consortium previously raised 1.02 billion pounds, or $2 billion, through the sale of stock. The 31-mile rail tunnel between Folkestone, England and Calais, France needs the extra funds because of a 60 percent jump in its costs, mostly because the rolling stock turned out to be much more expensive than expected. The tunnel now is expected to cost 7.61 billion pounds, or $14.8 billion, up sharply from the initial estimate of 4.87 billion pounds in 1986. This week's breakthrough occurred in the project's service tunnel, and the first meeting on the two major tunnels should occur next year. When Eurotunnel opens in June 1993 it will carry passengers, cars and freight between London and Paris in three hours, half the car-ferry journey time. It expects to transport 28 million people in the first year.

The stock market gained ground today, supported by hopes for lower interest rates. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials climbed 10.40 to 2,465.35 in the first half hour of trading. Gainers outnumbered losers by about 5 to 4 in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed issues, with 499 up, 401 down and 476 unchanged. Volume on the Big Board came to 205.30 million shares as of 10 a.m. on Wall Street. Analysts found no big surprises in two government reports this morning that showed new signs of weakness in the economy. The Labor Department reported that nonfarm payroll employment dropped 68,000 last month, although the civilian unemployment rate held steady at 5.7 percent. Separately, the Commerce Department said its index of leading economic indicators fell 0.8 percent in September, on top of a 1.2 percent drop the month before. Such evidence of a recession continues to drag down corporate earnings estimates in the financial world. But it has also stirred talk that the Federal Reserve might soon step up its efforts to ease credit conditions. Among actively traded blue chips, Philip Morris rose ] to 48\; General Electric gained ] to 52}; American Express rose ] to 19[, and Bristol-Myers Squibb was up { at 59}. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks rose .45 to 168.04. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index was up .32 at 289.22. On Thursday the Dow Jones industrial average climbed 12.62 points to 2,454.95. Advancing issues outnumbered declines by nearly 3 to 2 on the NYSE, with 889 up, 612 down and 481 unchanged. Big Board volume totaled 159.27 million shares, against 156.06 million in the previous session.

DOC.HEAD: Steelmaker Hopes to Emerge Soon from Bankruptcy Protection
DOC.TEXT: Wheeling-Pittsburgh Steel Corp. hopes to conclude a reorganization of its debts and emerge from bankruptcy court protection on Dec. 20. Parties to the reorganization, now in its sixth year, will soon receive ballots and documents related to the proposed settlement, Wheeling-Pittsburgh spokesman Ray Johnson said Thursday. The materials were to be mailed today. Under a tentative timetable, voting on the reorganization plan will conclude Nov. 27. A court hearing to confirm will take place Dec. 6 and Judge Warren Bentz will likely approve it by Dec. 10, he said. ``All of the major creditor constituencies are on board'' and ready to approve the revised plan of reorganization, said Robert Sable, an attorney who represented Wheeling-Pittsburgh's unsecured creditors. An original plan of reorganization had to be revised to account for added costs related to a labor contract the company agreed to earlier this year. When the case concludes, more than $700 million in claims against Wheeling-Pittsburgh will have been settled. The company was helped significantly by changes that occurred during the years it was under court protection. ``It was helped by circumstances - a revival of the economy, a revival of the steel business and primarily a reduction in industry-wide capacity,'' Sable said. ``The creditors were patient and worked it out.'' Sable said unsecured claims were being sold in 1985 for 12 cents on the dollar. Under the revised plan of reorganization, holders of the claims will get more than 60 cents on the dollar in cash.

The stock market pushed ahead today, supported by hopes for lower interest rates. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials climbed 11.39 to 2,466.34 by 11 a.m. on Wall Street. Gainers outnumbered losers by about 8 to 5 in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed issues, with 739 up, 446 down and 491 unchanged. Volume on the Big Board came to 52.21 million shares at midmorning. Analysts found no big surprises in two government reports this morning that showed new signs of weakness in the economy. The Labor Department reported that nonfarm payroll employment dropped 68,000 last month, although the civilian unemployment rate held steady at 5.7 percent. Separately, the Commerce Department said its index of leading economic indicators fell 0.8 percent in September, on top of a 1.2 percent drop the month before. Such evidence of a recession continues to drag down corporate earnings estimates in the financial world. But it has also stirred talk that the Federal Reserve might soon step up its efforts to ease credit conditions. Among actively traded blue chips, Philip Morris rose ] to 48\; Exxon gained [ to 49~; McDonald's rose \ to 25}, and American Telephone & Telegraph was unchanged at 34}. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks rose .84 to 168.43. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index was unchanged at 288.90.
The NASDAQ Composite Index at 11am was 332.56 up 1.96 from the previous day's close.

DOC.HEAD: Crop Futures Rise Slightly In Early Trading
DOC.TEXT: Grain and soybean futures prices rose slightly in early trading today on the Chicago Board of Trade amid signs that export sales of soybeans may be picking up as the soybean harvest winds down. Last week's export sales of 437,100 metric tons of soybeans, as reported by the Agriculture Department, as an improvement over recent weeks. Analysts said rumors of buying interest from Spain also prompted buying of futures contracts. Speculation continued in the futures markets that President Bush will soon announce export credits to the Soviet Union that would allow Moscow to buy U.S. grains and soybean meal. Wheat futures were narrowly mixed this morning. Corn futures were fractionally higher on indications that South Korea bought 100,000 metric tons of U.S. corn. In early trading, wheat futures were } cent lower to { cent higher with the contract for delivery in December at $2.62} a bushel; corn futures were \ cent to } cent higher with December at $2.30\ a bushel; oats were { cent higher across the board with December at $1.21{ a bushel; soybeans were \ cent lower to 1\ cents higher with November at $5.96 a bushel. Cattle futures were mostly lower while pork futures were higher in early trading on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange. Live cattle were .20 cent lower to .05 cent higher with the contract for delivery in December at 76.80 cents a pound; feeder cattle were .17 cent to .30 cent lower with November at 87.15 cents a pound; live hogs were .05 cent lower to .30 cent higher with December at 52.27 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were .47 cent to .75 cent higher with February at 62.92 cents a pound. Cattle futures fell modestly Thursday, hogs were mixed and pork bellies advanced.

DOC.HEAD: U995
DOC.TEXT: The spot month contract for light sweet crude was $34.60 per barrel at 12 p.m. Friday on the New York Mercantile Exchange.

DOC.NOTE: $adv05
For Release Monday, Nov 5
DOC.HEAD: Japan Concentrating More on Quality of Life
DOC.TEXT: Japan is shifting the focus of its technological prowess from economic growth to a higher quality of life, the government says in an annual assessment that provides some insight into the nation's self-image. The Science and Technology Agency's report, released in October, emphasizes that Japan has matured into a leading economic giant, producing 14 percent of the world's goods and services, largely due to scientific and technological achievements. The report also emphasizes that much of the progress Japan engendered is enjoyed abroad instead of home, where millions of Japanese historically have scrimped and saved. But now, the report says, ``the people's consciousness has been transformed in the midst of this economic prosperity, and they now wish to live their lives in comfort and fulfillment.'' It says Japan still lags far behind Europe and the United States in areas of technology related to housing, as well as facilities for elderly and handicapped people. Robert Broadfoot, managing director of Political and Economic Risk Consultancy in Hong Kong, said Japanese are strongly aware of the gap in quality of life between their nation and countries like the United States, despite Japan's wealth. ``Money doesn't mean that much now, with the possibility of rapid market fluctuations. But quality of life is something real,'' he said in a telephone interview. Nobuaki Teraoka, an aide at the Science and Technology Agency's policy bureau, said: ``Until now, the use of science and technology in Japan has emphasized pursuit of economic development. But now we are at the point where we need to shift our focus to the pursuit of fuller lives.'' The annual report said Japan spent about 2.85 percent of its gross national product on research and development last year, slightly below West Germany's 2.87 percent. United States' spending dropped to an estimated 2.53 percent of GNP, it said. The report said Japan spent 9.8 trillion yen, or $77 billion, on research and development in 1989, an increase of 46 percent in real terms over the previous five years. Including research on humanities and social sciences, the total was 10.6 trillion yen, or $83 billion. Despite the image overseas of large Japanese government subsidies for technological research, public funding once again provided a far smaller portion of Japan's total research and development expenses in 1989 than in other major nations. Of total research spending, the report said, only 19.9 percent was government-funded, vs. 47.4 percent in the United States and 33.2 percent in West Germany. Instead, ``the very extensive research effort by private companies'' has resulted in technological progress that accounted for two-fifths of Japan's economic growth during the past 10 years, said Yoshiki Kurihara, director of the policy bureau's research division. The report called for more government spending, particularly for basic research that private industry can rarely undertake because it is either extremely risky or requires a big investment in time. In 1989, Japan had 462,000 researchers - 535,000 including humanities and social sciences - a 25 percent increase from five years earlier. In the sciences, 294,000 worked for private industry, 132,000 for universities and 36,000 for government research institutes. It said the United States had about 806,000 researchers and West Germany 166,000, including those in humanities and social sciences.

DOC.HEAD: Profit Doubles in First Half Despite Recall
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 3rd-4th graf pvs, First-half sales ... with 3 new grafs to CLARIFY sales volume fell 14 percent while revenue dropped 3 percent. Picks up 5th graf pvs, The latest ...
DOC.TEXT: The bottlers of bubbly Perrier water reported Friday that net profits more than doubled in the first half of 1990 despite a worldwide recall after dangerous chemicals turned up in some samples. The profit increase came mostly from the sale of the group's soft-drink operations, Source Perrier SA said. First-half volume sales of the popular mineral water were down 14 percent from 1989 and revenue slipped 3 percent due to the recall and delays in restocking the beverage, Source Perrier said. Consolidated net profits amounted to 856 million francs, or $167 million, up from 397 million francs a year earlier. Revenue for the first half fell to 8.302 billion francs, or $1.62 billion, compared with 8.541 billion francs in 1989. The latest results included a gain on the sale of its soft-drink operations as the company shifted its focus back to the green-bottled mineral water. The U.S. Food and Drug Administration discovered traces of the cancer-causing chemical benzene in bottles of Perrier in January, leading to a recall of millions of bottles worldwide. Perrier said the contamination occurred from a dirty filter on a gas line at the spring in Vergeze, southern France. The discovery that Perrier added gas to boost the water's natural fizz forced the company to drop claims on its labels that the water sparkled naturally. Benzene-free Perrier went back on the shelves in the United States and Europe by mid-April. The sale of the soft-drinks unit and other non-strategic assets for 1 billion francs, or $195 million, more than offset the cost of the recall, the statement said. Perrier did not list the recall costs, but specified that a provision of 435 million francs, or $85 million, was set aside for it in the 1989 accounts.

DOC.NOTE: For Release Monday, Nov. 5
DOC.HEAD: Tax-Exempts Getting More Popular With Higher Taxes
DOC.TEXT: Higher taxes are making tax-exempt mutual funds more popular as investors move past big credit-troubled municipal issuers like Massachussetts, New York City and Philadelphia. Bolstered by the new tax law that gives few income tax breaks and higher rates, more investors seeking high-quality municipal debt issuers are putting money in tax-free mutual funds. With higher taxes, their reasons are obvious. A tax free bond fund that yields 7 percent has a tax-equivalent yield of 9.7 percent for an investor in the 28 percent tax bracket. But if that investor lands into the new 31 percent bracket, the tax equivalent yield on the same 7 percent fund rises to 10.1 percent. That kind of math may be popular among investors who have become wary of the high-risk double-digit yeilds of the junk bond funds. ``It is clear that demand for municipal bonds will be strong enough to make tax-exempts the most stable - as well as the most attractive - investments in today's market,'' said Siesel E. Canaday, Jr, vice president of municipal underwriting at John Nuveen & Co. Inc., an investment banking firm. Some bond funds are reporting brisker sales of the tax-exempts. At Vanguard Group, in Valley Forge, Pa., municipal mutual funds' net cash inflow increased sevenfold in October over September, said Brian Mattes, a spokesman. Some of that, he said, may be a result of investors anticipating tax increases. Fidelity Investments says net inflows are running at the highest levels this year, comparable to the peak season following the tax return deadline. ``They're reacting to threats of increasing taxes on federal level and on state level as well,'' said Heidi Baxter, marketing manager of Fidelity's state tax-free funds. Despite the horror stories about credit problems in the Northeast and fears that a recession would strike cities and states particularly hard, investors have been willing to invest in the municipal market when they can find quality. ``If people are looking for quality they have the opportunity to still earn very attractive yeilds. Quality is a consideration, you just have to be more selective,'' Ms. Baxter said. But as a result of their popularity, the tax-free funds' main attraction may be diminished. Increased demand, coming at a time of relatively short supply, will likely bid up the price of municipal bonds, causing yields to fall. Helped by the higher tax bracket, the municipals have quite a way to go before their tax-equivalent yields fall into the range of most low-risk taxable investments. For now, though, the yields are there and the bond funds are ready. The increased business could be a good sign for an industry that has been sagging since the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait. The Investment Company Institute reported last week that total sales of long-term municipal funds, including reinvested dividends, fell $275.3 million from August to $968.2 million in September. At Oppenheimer, where officials are discussing advertising their tax-free funds more, Sam Friedman, president of Oppenheimer shareholder services, said nobody wants to get too excited until the federal budget agreement is signed. ``A lot of people are jumping on the bandwagon, although I think its a good bandwagon to get on,'' he said.
DOC.NOTE: End advance for Monday, Nov. 5

DOC.HEAD: Data General Reports Quarterly Loss Of $89.3 Million
DOC.TEXT: Data General Corp. said Friday it lost $89.3 million, or $2.93 per share, in its fourth fiscal quarter because of a charge related to the computer maker's consolidation efforts in August. The loss for the quarter ended Sept. 29 included a $71.7 million restructuring charge for the corporatewide consolidation, Data General announced. During the same quarter last year, Data General reported an $84.1 million loss, or $2.86 per share. That loss included an $80 million restructuring charge. Data General posted a fourth-quarter operating loss of $88.2 million, incuding the restructuring charge, compared with an operating loss of $82.2 million for the same quarter last year. Revenue for the fourth quarter totalled $308.5 million, down from $357.1 million a year earlier. For fiscal 1990, the company reported a loss of $139.8 million, or $4.65 a share, including the restructuring charge. In fiscal 1989, the company reported a loss of $119.7 million, or $4.10 a share, including that year's restructuring charge. The operating loss for its fiscal 1990 was $132.6 million, compared with $127.4 million in fiscal 1989. Revenue for 1990 totaled $1.22 billion, compared with $1.31 billion in fiscal 1989. Data General also announced that sales of its Aviion open-system computers grew significantly, in part because of a $45 million contract with a division of U.S. Sprint and a $15 million contract with Computer Sciences Corp. ``During 1990, the first full year of shipments, Aviion systems produced revenues of more than $100 million, showing sequential increases each quarter,'' said Ronald L. Skates, Data General's president. ``We are confident that Aviion revenues will continue to increase significantly in fiscal 1991.''

DOC.HEAD: London Shares End Mixed
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES with closing prices.
DOC.TEXT: Share prices finished mixed in dull trading on London's Stock Exchange Friday, as investors stuck to the sidelines. With the weekend approaching, investors held steady positions in the uncertain, nervous market, dealers said. They said investors and investment bankers postponed any portfolio adjustments until after they have a chance to digest the sudden resignation of British Deputy Prime Minister Sir Geoffrey Howe late Thursday. The Financial Times-Stock Exchange 100-share index was up 2.7 points, or 0.1 percent, at 2,030.7. But the Financial Times 30-share index was down 1.4 points at 1,570.7, and the Financial Times 500-share index fell 0.98 to close at 1,086.69. Volume was 403.4 million shares compared with 373.7 million shares Thursday.

DOC.HEAD: Shearson Lehman Files Claim Against Polly Peck's Nadir
DOC.TEXT: Lehman Brothers Securities, the British arm of Shearson Lehman Brothers Inc., on Friday filed a claim of 18.5 million pounds, or $36 million, against Polly Peck PLC Chairman Asil Nadir for failure to pay for share purchases. Lehman Brothers said in a brief statement it hadf submitted the claim to the High Court in London, joining an earlier petition filed last week by Barclays de Zoete Wedd Ltd. seeking 3.6 million pounds, or $7 million in unpaid fees. Lehman Brothers claims Nadir hadn't paid for 6.25 million Polly Peck shares purchased Sept. 4-6. The petition seeks to force payment from the embattled Polly Peck executive through liquidation of personal assets. The two filings are personal claims against the Polly Peck executive. The company last week obtained court protection from its creditors while it works out its 1.3 billion pounds ($2.5 billion) in debt.

DOC.HEAD: Japanese Company Buys Heavenly Valley Ski Resort
DOC.TEXT: A Japanese business group that bought Steamboat Ski Area in Colorado plans to buy Heavenly Valley Ski Resort in South Lake Tahoe, Calif., the resort's owner said Friday. Heavenly would become the third ski resort under control of Kamori Kanko Co. Ltd. of Sapporo City, Japan. It also owns Rusutsu Kogen ski resort near Sapporo City, site of the 1972 Winter Olympics, as well as a koala park in Australia and restaurants, golf courses, zoos and amusement parks in Japan. The company bought Steamboat for a reported $110 million in 1989. No purchase price was announced for Heavenly Valley. The announcement was made by resort owner Bill Killebrew, who will stay on as general manager. Martin Hart, former owner and current president of the Steamboat ski resort, will be Heavenly's chairman, while all 120 year-round employees also will be retained. Heavenly Valley has 24 lifts over 20 square miles of private and leased land.

DOC.HEAD: Soybeans Close Mixed
DOC.TEXT: Grain and soybean futures prices closed mixed Friday on the Chicago Board of Trade. Soybeans sold off late in the session amid disappointment that President Bush did not announce export credits to the Soviet Union. Wheat futures ended moderately higher while corn futures rose slightly. The soybean market rallied early, extending Thursday's gains, on speculation that President Bush would announce export credits to the Soviets during a campaign swing through the Midwest on Friday. Some analysts reasoned that Bush might announce the credits, which would allow Moscow to buy U.S. grain and soybeans, to help boost the chances of Republican candidates from the Midwestern farm states. But the president made no mention of export credits on his swing through the region, prompting disappointed selling of soybean futures, analysts said. At the close, wheat futures were 2\ cents to 4} cents higher with the contract for delivery in December at $2.66 a bushel; corn was \ cent to 2 cents higher with December at $2.30 a bushel; oats were unchanged to { cent higher with December at $1.21{ a bushel; soybeans were 3{ cents lower to 1 cent higher with November at $5.92{ a bushel.

The stock market advanced broadly today, supported by hopes for lower interest rates. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials climbed 25.50 to 2,480.45 by 3 p.m. on Wall Street. Gainers outnumbered losers by about 2 to 1 in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed issues, with 1,014 up, 488 down and 455 unchanged. Analysts found no big surprises in two government reports this morning that showed new signs of weakness in the economy. The Labor Department reported that nonfarm payroll employment dropped 68,000 last month, although the civilian unemployment rate held steady at 5.7 percent. Separately, the Commerce Department said its index of leading economic indicators fell 0.8 percent in September, on top of a 1.2 percent drop the month before. Such evidence of a recession continues to drag down corporate earnings estimates in the financial world. But it has also stirred talk that the Federal Reserve might soon step up its efforts to ease credit conditions. Among actively traded blue chips, Philip Morris rose { to 48]; Texaco ] to 60{; International Business Machines ] to 107|, and American Express | to 19]. In the depressed banking group, J.P. Morgan gained ~ to 38~; BankAmerica 1[ to 20{, and Citicorp \ to 12[. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks rose 1.76 to 169.35.
