DOC.HEAD: Continental President Says Airline May Have to Sell International Routes
DOC.TEXT: Soaring fuel costs could force financially strapped Continental Airlines to sell some international routes and prompt layoffs if the carrier wants to avoid another round of bankruptcy reorganization, its president said. One plan under consideration is the sale of Continental's Air Micronesia, the carrier's Pacific service operated from its hub in Guam. Air Micronesia holds the authority to fly from Honolulu to Tokyo. ``That is worth doing if it allows us to continue with a viable airline,'' Continental president Hollis Harris said Thursday in an appearance before a group of Houston businessmen. Such a sale could mean the end of Continental's Houston-Honolulu-Tokyo route. Continental still would have the ability to fly to Honolulu, but the most lucrative leg of the trip is from Honolulu to Japan. Continental began Tokyo service just four months ago after a 24-year effort to get direct air access between Houston and Japan. Officials at Delta Airlines, Harris' former employer, have confirmed they are looking at some assets Continental has for sale, but won't say what kind of deal the Atlanta-based carrier is interested in pursuing. Harris, who recently took over at Continental, said layoffs were possible but he hoped such moves, as well as cuts in wages and benefits, could be avoided. A 20 percent cut in salaries would save about $16 million a month. Harris, however, said the savings would not be worth the toll on employees. ``Their morale would just go down the drain,'' he said. ``They would be so depressed, we'd run off more revenue than we would save.'' Analysts note Continental, which employs 37,000 nationwide, already has low labor costs. ``According to my cash flow work, they need to sell assets to provide a cushion large enough to not have liquidity problems,'' said Paul Karos, an analyst with First Boston Corp. Continental already is negotiating the sale of its Houston airline food service operation, Chelsea Catering, which employs 800 at its Houston kitchen. On Friday, Continental and Dallas-based Electronic Data Systems broke off talks on a multibillion-dollar deal through which the airline would have relinquished control of its computerized reservation system. One reason cited was the increase in fuel prices caused by uncertainty in the Middle East. Last week, Continental's board of directors, faced with monthly fuel bills that have risen $70 million since July, considered filing for bankruptcy protection. Continental previously filed for reorganization under federal bankruptcy laws in 1983. Instead, directors opted to sell off assets and undertake whatever measures necessary to remain afloat. Harris said airlines need an additional 10 percent increase in ticket prices to offset the jump in fuel costs, but he doesn't think the flying public would tolerate such increases.

DOC.HEAD: Government, Eurotunnel Trying to Sell Billions in Stock in Jittery Market
DOC.TEXT: Bargain prices and generous inducements will be the keys to success for $10 billion worth of securities the government and Eurotunnel are trying to sell in a jittery market. Eurotunnel is asking shareholders who already have bought $2 billion worth of stock to take up another $1 billion to ensure completion of a rail tunnel beneath the English Channel. Meanwhile, the government is about to sell Britain's 12 regional electricity distribution companies for an expected 4 billion to 5 billion pounds, or $7.8 billion to $9.8 billion. It's the biggest and most complex privatization yet, and has been in the works for months. Incentives have been offered for both. Eurotunnel announced Friday it would sell the extra stock at 285 pence ($5.56) each, an unusually large 34 percent discount to the market price. It also offered perks such as free travel through the tunnel for 49 years for those who buy at least 1,500 shares. Analysts said the discount demonstrates the Anglo-French consortium's fear that shareholders might reject the stock when it starts trading Nov. 12. The government, meantime, is including a two-year installment plan among its inducements for the privatization, whose price will be announced Nov. 21. The government has also begun an aggressive marketing drive that includes television advertisements. Such perks are necessary, given the uncertainty surrounding the London market, said Anthony Winnington, director of equity sales at the London investment firm Hoare Govett Ltd. The Persian Gulf crisis, low corporate earnings, a faltering British economy and political turmoil in Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's government have been blamed for the market's jitters. The Financial Times-Stock Exchange 100-share index has fallen 384 points since mid-July. ``The appetite with cash-rich institutions for new equity even at a discount at the market is not terribly strong because of the uncertainty in the Middle East and the threat we could see a 200-point drop in prices overnight,'' Winnington said. ``I think the government has to make sure that the electricity issue is priced low enough'' to assure success on the London market, said Richard Jeffrey, an economist with Hoare Govett. The government's $64 billion worth of privatizations over the years have been largely successful, with the exception of the government's remaining one-third stake in British Petroleum Co. PLC. The BP sale coincided with the October 1987 stock market crash and flopped. At a news conference Friday, Energy Secretary John Wakeham denied that the government was ``giving away'' the electricity companies. But Ernie McKnight, a British equity manager for Glasgow-based Scottish Amicable Investment Managers, said that since the government wants to sell off the electricity generating companies next year, ``they can't afford to fail.'' ``If the Gulf situation escalates I think the market reaction will be negative and it's obviously more difficult to place large quantities of stock in a falling market,'' he said. The stakes are high for Eurotunnel, too. The sale's success with shareholders is a condition for the release of an additional $4.1 billion in loans by banks. The 50-mile tunnel, which is to open in 1993, needs the extra funds because of a nearly 60 percent jump in its overall cost to 7.61 billion pounds, or $14.8 billion. Eurotunnel Deputy Chairman Alastair Morton said earlier this week that the sale had been timed to coincide with Tuesday night's confidence-inspiring breakthrough by diggers on the first of the project's three tunnels. Optimistic about the sale, he noted that Eurotunnel's offer comes before the government's. The governments says 6 million people have registered to buy electricity shares, and the Eurotunnel sale is fully underwritten by investment firms. But many recent issues have been left in the hands of underwriters, and not many companies have been trying to sell new stock for months, Winnington said. Institutional investors held some 29 billion pounds ($57 billion) in cash in the third quarter compared with 22 billion pounds ($43 billion) a year ago, Jeffrey said. Sales of new stock have fallen to 660 million pounds ($1.3 billion) from 1.6 billion pounds ($3.1 billion), he said.

DOC.HEAD: Act III Suspends Publication of The Marketer
DOC.TEXT: Act III Communications Inc. has suspended publication of The Marketer and is seeking a buyer for the monthly magazine for senior marketing executives that was launched only this past April. Robert C. Gardner, president of Act III Publishing, said Friday the move reflects te parent company's decision to deemphasize magazine publishing and focus resources on its other businesses - TV stations, production of TV shows and theater operations. Act III Communications, based in Los Angeles, is privately held and headed by television producer Norman Lear, best known for the classic TV series ``All in the Family.'' It owns eight TV stations and about 550 movie screens. Last month, Act III sold the trade monthly Marketing & Media Decisions to a subsidiary of BPI Communications Inc. that owns Adweek magazine. BPI, an affiliate of the owner of the Boston Globe, said it planned to make the magazine a weekly starting next year. Remaining magazine titles owned by Act III Publishing are Channels, which appears every other week and covers the television industry; the music industry monthlies Mix and Electronic Musician; and the international television magazines Television Business International and World Broadcast News. Asked whether its other magazines are for sale, Gardner said he was ``not commenting on it'' but added that the company was making ``selective decisions as we go along here.'' The Marketer will be suspended after the November issue, which appears Nov. 7. The company said ``negotiations are ongoing with several potential buyers of the publication and that an announcement is expected shortly.'' Gardner declined to identify any potential buyers or say how many there were, but said chances for a sale of the magazine are ``extremely good.'' The Marketer was sent free to 45,000 senior marketing executives, and Gardner said it was ``doing very well'' for a startup magazine. It had employed about a dozen editorial and advertising staffers. The suspension of the magazine comes amid what many analysts are calling an advertising recession in the publishing business. Ad volume has slumped at many magazines and several magazines have halted publication. This week alone, Knight-Ridder Inc. said it was ceasing publication of Runways, a news magazine devoted to the commercial aviation industry, and Goldhirsh Group suspended publication of Business Month magazine, a business news and feature magazine whose roots extended to 1893. Both publications cited a lack of advertising support.

DOC.HEAD: Visa Cards Issued for Eastern Europeans
DOC.TEXT: Visa International said Friday that a Prague bank has issued the first internationally accepted Visa cards to Czechoslovakian citizens. The company also said three Polish banks will issue internationally accepted Visa cards by next June. ``The benefits of carrying a Visa card are significant for Eastern European citizens. Procedures which in the West we take for granted, such as checking into hotels, booking airlines, ... are cumbersome and time-consuming for them,'' said Visa chairman Charles T. Russell. Zivnostenska Banka of Prague has issued credit cards to customers with convertible foreign currency deposits. Next year, cardholders will be able to use the cards to make payments in koruna inside the country.

DOC.NOTE: $adv05
For release Monday Nov. 5
DOC.HEAD: Nasty Fight Over Farm Subsidies Threatens Important World Trade Talks
DOC.TEXT: British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher was furious. She demanded to know how the European Community could map out grandiose schemes to become a United States of Europe when it couldn't even end an impasse over reducing government farm payments in world trade talks. ``It is very urgent indeed because if we do not get agreement on agriculture it will give a signal to the world that the community is protectionist,'' she said at a recent summit of the 12 trading bloc nations. The nearly month-old dispute, pitting Britain against France and Germany, has threatened the collapse of the Uruguay Round negotiations, an ambitious four-year effort to lower trade barriers in about 100 nations and give a hefty boost to the world's economy in the next century. ``It's jeopardizing the success of the trade talks,'' said Anna Murphy, research fellow at the Brussels-based Center for European Policy Studies. Agriculture is only one of 15 areas under discussion in the trade negotiations, which began in 1986 in the Uruguayan resort of Punta del Este. But the United States, Australia, Argentina and others insist it holds the key to expanding trade in other areas, including textiles, manufactured goods and services, such as telecommunications and banking. Some nations threaten to quit if nothing is done on agriculture. Jeffrey Schott, research fellow at the Institute of International Economics in Washington, said the EC is isolated in its seeming unwillingness to reduce subsidies. The final round of negotiations begins in just four weeks. Yet, the community has not submitted its farm offer for bargaining in the talks, held under the auspices of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, a forum and an accord for freer world trade. Its member nations have been unable to endorse a proposal to trim subsidies on major farm crops by 30 percent over 10 years, starting in 1986. Some reductions already have been made so analysts estimate cuts in the coming years would amount to 10 percent to 15 percent. Agriculture and trade ministers of the community nations will meet Monday in a seventh attempt to back the plan. But, Schott said, ``even if it were to be approved by the ministers, it would be dead on arrival.'' Other nations, including the United States, have dismissed the proposed reductions as insufficient. ``What worries the United States and (other nations is) that the community won't go any further than that, and that isn't enough as far as they're concerned,'' said Ms. Murphy. The Bush administration asked trading partners to slash farm income supports by 75 percent and export subsidies by 90 percent over a 10-year period, starting in 1991. Andre Herlitska, secretary-general of the European farm lobby COPA, thinks that ``there is a big part of bluff'' in the American proposal. The United States contends it wants to put agriculture trade on a more free-market footing. ``We must let farmers compete with farmers, instead of farmers competing with the deep pockets of government treasuries,'' President Bush said recently. European farmers are skeptical. ``We don't believe blind market forces are the best instruments to (ensure) market stability,'' said Herlitska. Farm assistance is costly. Industrialized nations spent $251 billion on agricultural subsidies last year, the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development has estimated. Of that, the European Community spend $97.5 billion and the United States spent $67.2 billion. The community has pared its support programs in recent years, making the prospect of further trims unpalatable to its 10 million farmers, more than three times as many as in the United states. German Chancellor Helmut Kohl, who faces his nation's 1 million farmers in elections on Dec. 2, has said the community's proposal goes too far. He wants compensatory measures to offset any income losses to farmers. France, where 2.2 million farmers produce much of the community's agriculture exports, has balked at any move to snip export aids, which enable the Europeans to sell high-priced goods on the world markets. It also wants to maintain a system of taxes and other measures that encourage trading bloc nations to shun imports and buy home-grown crops. Farmers complain they have been hit hard in recent years by poor prices, government limits on production, bad weather, food safety scares and a flood of cheap products from Eastern Europe. ``There is a trend toward declining income ... The situation is very bad,'' said Herlitska. Farmers have sometimes turned to violence to underscore their complaints. In France, demonstrators this fall hijacked livestock trucks, mostly from Britain, and slaughtered the animals inside. French President Francois Mitterrand was forced to cancel an inaugural ride on a new stretch of high-speed rail track when farmers barricaded the line. Kohl was booed by several thousand farmers at a recent campaign rally. He professed to have ``much understanding for your worries'' and promised budget measures to do something about shrinking pocketbooks. Despite these pressures, the community disputes its image as the bad guy in the Uruguay Round and insists it wants the n,0153
DOC.HEAD: Son of Nobel Laureate Appeals Sentence on Fake Bomb Charge
DOC.TEXT: The son of Archbishop Desmond Tutu went before a magistrate Friday to appeal an 18-month sentence for making a false bomb threat at Johannesburg's international airport. Defense attorney P. Wilson argued that Trevor Tutu made the bomb threat to test security at Jan Smuts Airport and said the sentence was ``shocking'' for a first-time offender. Wilson also said police did not take the threat seriously because they did not search the terminal for an hour. The magistrate reserved judgment. During the Dec. 31, 1988, incident, Tutu told police he had a bomb in his luggage. Tutu later told reporters his action was part of a publicity stunt for his advertising agency. He has been free pending appeal. Desmond Tutu won the Nobel Peace Prize in 1984 for his fight against apartheid.

DOC.NOTE: $adv03
$adv04
For Release Weekend Editions Nov. 3-4
DOC.HEAD: Moscow Commodities Exchange Turns To Chicago
DOC.TEXT: Chicago's futures exchanges have agreed to help guide the development of the Moscow Commodities Exchange, making the leaders of the Chicago markets not unlike surgeons performing an organ transplant. Their mission: to transfer to the Soviet Union the market concepts and trading techniques that make visitors to the floors of the Chicago Board of Trade and Chicago Mercantile Exchange feel that they are walking through the beating heart of capitalism. The operation won't be easy. The Moscow exchange, started in May, reportedly runs in fits and starts, opening the trading floor only when enough commodities have been brought to market to justify a session. The Chicago Tribune reported that during this past week's visit to the Moscow market by Chicago exchange officials, the goods on the block included 2,000 tons of Russian cement, a shipment of Japanese videotapes and radio-telephones, and a few million Winston cigarettes. The products were auctioned off by an exchange officer to traders who stood around him in a circle and shyly raised their hands to signal their acceptance of an offer, the Tribune reported. That scene is a far cry from the Chicago trading floors, where traders crowd into specially constructed ``pits'' and deal directly with each other by shouting out bids and offers and gesturing furiously in a deafening and seemingly chaotic maelstrom. But the object of the Chicago and Moscow commodity markets is the same: to provide a place for buyers and sellers to come together and set the prices of goods. Like the Moscow exchange, the Chicago exchanges began as markets for physical commodities - farmers actually brought their grain to the Chicago Board of Trade to sell. But after 140 years, Chicago's exchanges have evolved into futures markets where traders exchange contracts that represent the commodities. The system also allows the exchanges to offer an ever-widening array financial products such as government bond and stock-index futures. The Moscow exchange is close to where the Chicago Board of Trade was in 1948, which is why the Moscow market officials looked to Chicago for assistance in creating an exchange that will help push the Soviet Union toward a market economy and away from one in which prices are set by the government. The creation of a Moscow futures market also could help open the Soviet Union up further as a market for U.S. products. In documents signed Thursday and Friday, the Board of Trade and Chicago Merc agreed to provide educational and research support to the Moscow Commodities Exchange. ``We are honored to be playing so significant a role in this historic undertaking,'' said Leo Melamed, chairman of the Merc's executive committee, in a statement. ``While the process of moving from a controlled economy and fixed exchange rates to a free economy based on supply and demand is difficult and will take a protracted period of time, the contributions of commodity markets toward this process will be significant.'' Board of Trade President Thomas Donovan said the Moscow exchange, like the Chicago markets, arose out of a need for more efficient allocation of basic commodities. ``Over a span of some 20 years in the mid-19th century the Chicago Board of Trade developed the most efficient system ever, the futures market. We will see it happen again in the Soviet Union,'' Donovan said. ``With the help of the Chicago Board of Trade and the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, it won't take 20 years,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: NEW YORK: credit conditions.
DOC.TEXT: The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials climbed 35.89 to 2,490.84, finishing the week with a gain of 54.70 points. Advancing issues outnumbered declines by about 2 to 1 on the New York Stock Exchange, with 1,086 up, 453 down and 443 unchanged. Big Board volume totaled 168.70 million shares, against 159.27 million in the previous session. The NYSE's composite index rose 2.48 to 170.07.

Hopes for lower interest rates provided the spark for a broad advance in stock prices today. Analysts found no big surprises in two government reports this morning that showed new signs of weakness in the economy. The Labor Department reported that nonfarm payroll employment dropped 68,000 last month, although the civilian unemployment rate held steady at 5.7 percent. Separately, the Commerce Department said its index of leading economic indicators fell 0.8 percent in September, on top of a 1.2 percent drop the month before. Such evidence of a recession continues to drag down corporate earnings estimates in the financial world. But it has also stirred talk that the Federal Reserve might soon step up its efforts to ease credit conditions.
DOC.NOTE: MORE

DOC.TEXT: The Russell 3000 index of companies with the largest market value closed at 169.35 Friday, up 3.48, or 2.10 percent, from a week ago and down 27.93, or 14.16 percent, this year to date. The Russell 1000 index of the largest companies, closed at 160.57 Friday, up 3.50, or 2.23 percent, from a week ago and down 24.54, or 13.26 percent, this year to date. The Russell 2000 index of smaller companies, closed at 120.34 Friday, down 0.53, or 0.44 percent, from a week ago and down 47.97 or 28.50 percent, this year to date.

DOC.HEAD: Oil Winds Up Slow Week By Falling $1
DOC.TEXT: As the Persian Gulf crisis turned three months old Friday, oil prices fell a little more than $1 a barrel in a weary futures market that traders said has lost its enthusiasm for going wild on news and rumors. ``They're not looking at every headline now and saying, `Buy, because Saddam said this,''' said Thomas P. Blakeslee, an energy analyst with Pegasus Econometric Group Inc., in Hoboken, N.J. ``They're waiting for something real.'' Light sweet crude oil for December delivery closed at $34 per barrel, down $1.17, on the New York Mercantile Exchange. Contracts for delivery in later months also settled lower. For the week, crude for near-term delivery rose 99 cents. Oil traders said it has been by far the slowest week they have seen since Iraq invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2. ``You're in a very narrow range on very light volume,'' said trader Ed Kevelson of Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. Analysts attributed Friday's drop to perceptions that President Bush's latest comments about Iraqi President Saddam Hussein were softer than a day earlier. Bush has been attacking Saddam sharply most of the week, but traders have paid little attention because the comments have come on the campaign trail, where the president is stumping for Republicans running in Tuesday's elections. ``If he's out there campaigning and he's down in Florida, can he really start a war from there?'' Blakeslee said. Petroleum products also fell Friday. Unleaded gasoline dropped 3.09 cents to 89.21 cents per gallon for December delivery, with later months also down. The near-term contract finished the week down 2.26 cents. Home heating oil fell 2.95 cents to 87.42 cents a gallon for December delivery. Later contract months were all lower. For the week, heating oil dropped .83 cent. Natural gas for December delivery settled at $2.358 per 1,000 cubic feet Friday, up .8 cent from Thursday.

DOC.HEAD: Chrysler, Fiat Call Off Joint Venture Talks
DOC.TEXT: The shaky economy caused Chrysler Corp. and Fiat SpA to call off months of talks about possible joint ventures or other business arrangements, the No. 3 U.S. automaker and the Italian company said Friday. ``Uncertainties in the global economy, rising oil prices brought on by the crisis in the Gulf, the slowdown in sales in both the U.S. and European automotive markets and the overall deterioration in worldwide business conditions created overwhelming obstacles,'' Chrysler Chairman Lee Iacocca said. ``Today, we have to realize that the world economic scenario is plagued with uncertainty, and that synergies and mutual advantages cannot be pursued,'' said Giovanni Agnelli, chairman of Fiat Group. Rumors of talks between the two automakers had been swirling since June, although Chrysler and Fiat declined to comment until Iacocca confirmed in August that the two companies were negotiating. ``We discovered some strong potential opportunities for working together and some outstanding operational synergies that could have benefited both companies,'' Iacocca recalled on Friday. Speculation had run the gamut from Fiat buying a large share of Chrysler, to an agreement to cooperate on a small sport-utility vehicle. Fiat spokesman Gualberto Ranieri confirmed on Friday that discussions included potential production agreements, commercial and distribution arrangements and equity investments. But the companies concluded that the time wasn't right, he said. Chrysler reported dismal third-quarter results on Monday - a $214 million loss on revenues of $6.5 billion. The loss, however, was expected, and Mary Ann Sudol, an analyst with Fitch Investors Service Inc. of New York, instead blamed world economic uncertainty for scuttling the talks. ``With the war in the Mideast that could affect oil and gasoline prices, and the murky geopolitical and economic situation, they might end up regretting any capital commitment, particularly if it were going to be very product specific,'' Sudol said. She said the companies earlier had ruled out a possible equity investment in Chrysler by Fiat but had refused to elaborate further on the talks. ``They really kept the lid on,'' she said. Ranieri did not rule out a resumption of talks if world economic conditions stabilize. ``Everything is possible,'' he said. The companies said they would continue their existing business arrangements, including some component deals and Chrysler's marketing of Alfa Romeo cars in North America. Chrysler stock closed up 37{ cents Friday on the New York Stock Exchange, at $11.37{ per share.

DOC.HEAD: Forget GNP and Jobless Stats: These Economists Look To The Stars
LaserPhoto CX3
DOC.TEXT: For these economists, the picture always is bright - out of this world, you might say. That's because when it comes to business, astro-economists turn to the stars. They look at the rise of the moon, gravitational forces of Venus and Jupiter, and Earth's tidal flows and weather patterns to forecast the future of economic trends ranging from unemployment to gold prices. Spacey? Not to these high rollers, er, astro-economists. This weekend about 150 of them are in Chicago for the Third Annual World Conference on Astro-Economics. Say what? ``When most people hear about astro-economics, they go, `What?''' Robert Hand, creator of a computer program overlaying star charts with stock market fluctuations, said Friday. ``I think that there is a great deal of incredulity,'' he said, ``but the proof is in the pudding in that people who use it make money.'' Among the lecture topics at the conference, for which each attendee paid $170: ``Geocosmic and Rhythmic Cycles in Today's Precious Metals Markets,'' ``Astrological Technical Analysis,'' and ``Hot Stocks for the Coming Year.'' Over the coming months, Hand said, he foresees a bottoming out in the stock market and recession-like trends. Critics might argue it doesn't take a rocket scientist to predict such events. Take, for example, Robert Eisner, a William R. Kenan professor of economics at Northwestern University in Evanston. He calls astro-economics ``garbage, unequivocally.'' ``Unless you have some theory about how stars relate to economic activity - and I'm not aware of any good one - it's inconceivable,'' Eisner said. ``Of course, the stars will do no worse, on average will do about the same, and sometimes will do better on Wall Street than any speculating would.'' Still, Hand insists that to predict the economic future within 80 percent to 90 percent certainty proves the practice works. Grace Morris, an astrologer and psychoanalyst who co-sponsored the weekend conference in Chicago, defended the pseudoscience. She said skeptics should note astrology predicted Iraq's invasion of Kuwait - precipitated by a lunar eclipse, a stress-causing event on any planet. Morris said she uses astrology to advise businesses on the proper timing for startups, new product introductions and corporate takeovers. ``Virgo companies like Texaco and Coca-Cola will do very well in late 1991,'' she said. ``Jupiter will move into Virgo after September of 1991, and Jupiter symbolizes the expansion of business.'' Astrology has been a subject of fascination for years, studied by U.S. presidents beginning with George Washington and Thomas Jefferson and more recently by Nancy Reagan for setting her husband's schedule. So, it's only natural that it take on financial applications, said Elizabeth Gauerke, who analyzes weather cycles to predict events. ``In the history of the world, money and the planets have always been tied up,'' she said. ``The market is not predictable, but what planets do is. It's a simple formula that works for a lot of people.''

DOC.NOTE: Eds: Updates with closing prices throughout.
DOC.TEXT: The stock market rolled up a broad gain Friday, bolstered by expectations of help from the Federal Reserve toward lower interest rates. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials climbed 35.89 to 2,490.84, finishing the week with a gain of 54.70 points. Advancing issues outnumbered declines by about 2 to 1 in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed stocks, with 1,091 up, 466 down and 439 unchanged. Volume on the floor of the Big Board came to 168.70 million shares, up from 159.27 million in the previous session. Nationwide, consolidated volume in NYSE-listed issues, including trades in those stocks on regional exchanges and in the over-the-counter market, totaled 204.47 million shares. Analysts found no big surprises in two government reports Friday morning that showed new signs of weakness in the economy. The Labor Department reported that nonfarm payroll employment dropped 68,000 last month, although the civilian unemployment rate held steady at 5.7 percent. Separately, the Commerce Department said its index of leading economic indicators fell 0.8 percent in September, on top of a 1.2 percent drop the month before. Such evidence of a recession continues to drag down corporate earnings estimates in the financial world. But it has also stirred talk that the Federal Reserve might soon step up its efforts to ease credit conditions. In addition, the market had a drop in oil prices working in its favor. Among actively traded blue chips, Philip Morris rose | to 48{; Texaco } to 60~; International Business Machines 1[ to 108]; General Electric | to 53, and American Express 1 to 19}. In the depressed banking group, J.P. Morgan gained 1 to 39; BankAmerica 1 to 20]; Bank of New York 2{ to 17\; Chase Manhattan | to 10|, and Citicorp } to 12| as the most active NYSE issue. Elsewhere among insurance and financial issues, Continental Corp. rose 1} to 19[; Travelers 1] to 13~; Federal National Mortgage ~ to 29\, and Federal Home Loan Mortgage 1| to 36\. A sustained decline in interest rates would stand to relieve pressure on many financial issues, brokers said, and also shore up the real estate markets where most of these companies have a major stake. Orion Pictures picked up 1{ to 11[ on takeover speculation. As measured by Wilshire Associates' index of more than 5,000 actively traded stocks, the market increased $42.43 billion, or 1.49 percent, in value. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks gained 2.48 to 170.07. Standard & Poor's industrial index rose 5.05 to 364.85, and S&P's 500-stock composite index was up 4.83 at 311.85. The NASDAQ composite index for the over-the-counter market gained 5.85 to 336.45. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index closed at 289.98, up 1.08.

DOC.NOTE: $adv03
$adv04
For Release Weekend Editions Nov 3-4
DOC.HEAD: Uncle Sam Stands Out in the Borrowing Crowd
DOC.TEXT: In the midst of hard times for many borrowers, the biggest credit junkie of all comes to Wall Street this week to ask for a record-sized loan. And there is little doubt he will get his money with a minimum of fuss. Lenders, in fact, may be so eager to oblige him that they will offer him a break on the interest rate. The party with the oustretched hand is the U.S. Treasury, which plans to solicit $34.25 billion through the sale, over a three-day span from Tuesday through Thursday, of notes and bonds. More often than not in recent years, these quarterly ``refundings'' by the government have been greeted with trepidation by traders in the stock and bond markets. The nagging fear keeps recurring that one day they will hold a Treasury auction and many of the usual bidders simply won't show up. This time, however, such talk has been all but stilled. Instead, some observers say, a developing credit crunch in many sectors of the economy may actually have enhanced the market for paper floated by Uncle Sam. As Jack Lavery, director of global research at Merrill Lynch put it recently: ``Increased concern about credit quality has sparked greater domestic demand for Treasury issues, even though foreign demand appears to be drying up.'' The Treasury has long ranked as one of the world's best credit risks, supported by a vast store of national resources and assets, and by its powers to tax and to print money. So what if its checkbook has been chronically out of balance for the last 20 years? Demand at the refunding is also expected to be bolstered by spreading weakness in the economy and expectations that the Federal Reserve might soon take further steps to relax its credit policy. Both those forces traditionally work in the direction of lower interest rates. So as the Treasury outlined its borrowing plans in the past week, stock prices managed to gain ground. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials rose 54.70 points to 2,490.84. The New York Stock Exchange composite index climbed 3.36 to 170.07; the NASDAQ composite index for the over-the-counter market added 2.09 to 336.45, and the American Stock Exchange market value index was down 1.41 at 289.98. Volume on the Big Board averaged 154.29 million shares a day, against 143.98 million the week before. Even if interest rates decline in the markets for Treasury debt, analysts caution that it won't necessarily become easier and cheapier for everybody to borrow money. Holding companies of some of the nation's biggest banks now have to pay astronomical returns to attract and keep capital from investors. The banks, in turn, have grown increasingly stringent in the standards they apply to customers who seek loans. Elsewhere the story is much the same. In the market for short-term, interest-bearing securities, for instance, money market mutual funds, which sit on a $400 billion-plus pile of lendable cash, are still reported to be narrowing the scope of the risks they will take. ``As more and more of the investment world is driven into the little corral of Treasury bills, quality spreads must inevitably widen,'' says James Grant in his biweekly Grant's Interest Rate Observer. In a summarizing comment, he adds: ``In the contraction phase of the credit cycle, trouble begins at the fringe and worms its way into the core. ``It begins with the thrifts and ends with the banks, some of which were thought to be above it. It tests all financial structures the way salt water finds every unpainted crevice aboard a ship.''
DOC.NOTE: End Adv Weekend Editions Nov. 3-4

DOC.HEAD: Ford Increases Number of Possible Defective Air Bags
DOC.TEXT: Ford Motor Co. said Friday up to 3,000 1990 and 1991 model cars may have defective air bags, up from its original estimate of 133. Earlier this week, Ford announced a recall of 55,000 cars to locate and replace the defective bags. That number stands, Ford spokesman Jim Trainor said. The No. 2 automaker's module supplier, TRW Vehicle Safety Systems Inc., further reviewed production records and informed Ford of the increase in the possible number of cars with defective bags, Trainor said. Ford is recalling 1990 models Taurus, Sable, Continental, Tempo and Topaz and 1990-1991 Crown Victoria and Grand Marquis models.

BUSINESS EDITORS COMPOSING ROOMS
The Associated Press will conduct another test transmission from its new market computer system on Sunday beginning at noon Eastern time. The test will be conducted on both Digital and Dataspeed circuits. This is only a test. We ask those receiving the transmission to respond Monday by calling the AP in New York at 212-621-1568.
DOC.HEAD: The AP
Precious Metals Slump, Led by Sharp Drop in Platinum
DOC.TEXT: Precious metal futures prices fell sharply Friday, led by a drop of more than $15 an ounce in the price of platinum amid heavy Japanese selling. On other commodity markets, oil prices tumbled; livestock and meat futures were mixed; and grains and soybeans were mixed. Platinum futures settled $15.10 to $15.90 lower on the New York Mercantile Exchange with the spot price at $416.60 and the actively traded contract for January delivery at $420.60 a troy ounce. Gold finished $5.10 to $5.50 lower on New York's Commodity Exchange with December at $377.80 a troy ounce; silver was 7.1 cents to 7.8 cents lower with December at $4.185 a troy ounce. The sell-off wiped out most of the gains registered in the precious metals complex earlier in the week. Analysts said lower Japanese stock prices and weak U.S. economic data prompted heavy selling of platinum on perceptions that industrial demand for the metal will decline as economic conditions worsen. ``A good part of the selling was coming from the Japanese,'' said Don Tierney, metals analyst with Fortune Commodities Inc. ``Whenever their stock market falls off, they've got to sell some of their platinum to lighten up on their holdings.'' Some observers also cited Friday's sharp drop in oil prices, which eased inflationary pressures. And several analysts said gold futures weakened due to Middle Eastern sales of gold bullion and perceptions that more Middle Eastern selling could occur over the weekend. ``This seems to be a pattern we've developed on Fridays: traders get quite nervous and sell out because of fears of weekend sales from the Middle East,'' said Peter Cardillo, commodity trading adviser with the futures brokerage Jesup, Josephthal & Co. Tierney said buying by Swiss and U.S. investors lifted gold off its lows. The November gold contract traded as low as $376.10 an ounce during the session. Petroleum futures tumbled on the New York Mercantile Exchange, reflecting a lack of bullish developments in the Persian Gulf standoff. Instead of an escalation in the warlike rhetoric of recent days, news reports from the Middle East mainly highlighted the possibility that Iraq will free more foreign hostages. Light sweet crude oil settled 55 cens to $1.17 lower with December at $34 a barrel; heating oil was 2.26 cents to 2.96 cents lower with December at 87.42 cents a gallon; unleaded gasoline was 2.65 cents to 3.09 cents lower with December at 89.21 cents a gallon. Pork belly futures soared their permitted daily limit of 2 cents a pound on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, boosted by higher prices for fresh bellies. Analysts said belly demand by bacon makers remained strong. Cattle futures ended mixed in dull trading. Live cattle were .08 cent lower to .10 cent higher with December at 77.10 cents a pound; feeder cattle were .05 cent to .18 cent lower with November at 87.22 cents a pound; live hogs were .18 cent lower to .53 cent higher with December at 52.75 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were 2 cents higher across the board with February at 64.45 cents a pound. Grain and soybean futures ended mixed on the Chicago Board of Trade. Soybeans sold off late in the session amid disappointment that President Bush did not announce export credits to the Soviet Union Friday as some analysts had expected. Wheat futures settled 2{ cents to 3} cents higher with December at $2.65\ a bushel; corn was { cent to 1{ cents higher with December at $2.30\ a bushel; oats were unchanged to { cent higher with December at $1.21{ a bushel; soybeans were 3{ cents lower to 1 cent higher with November at $5.92{ a bushel.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar, Gold Down
DOC.TEXT: A series of negative economic reports Friday sent the dollar falling on speculation the Federal Reserve will push interest rates lower. Gold dropped in active trading. Analysts said the dollar fell after two government reports on the economy provided further evidence that the economy is weakening. The Labor Department said the unemployment rate was unchanged last month from September's 5.7 percent, but non-farm payrolls fell by 70,000, indicating businesses have less demand for workers. The government also reported that its chief economic forecasting gauge, the Index of Leading Economic Indicators, dropped 0.8 percent in September for its second straight monthly drop. Foreign exchange markets sold the dollar down following the release of both reports, believing the data would put more pressure on the Fed to nudge interest rates lower as a means of stimulating the economy. Lower U.S. interest rates are bad news for the dollar, which like all currencies is supported by higher rates. Jack Barbanel, a market analyst with First Global Asset Management Inc., said the dollar was further hurt by Germany's decision Thursday to raise a key interest rate, the Lombard rate. The increase gave more support to the German mark. The dollar fell to 1.4945 marks in New York Friday from 1.5035 late Thursday. In earlier European trading, the dollar fell to 1.5020 German marks, from 1.5070. In Tokyo, the dollar fell to a closing 129.10 Japanese yen from 130.70 yen at Thursday's close. Later, in London, it fell to 128.50 yen, and the dollar closed at 127.78 yen in New York, down from 130.555. In London, the British pound fell to $1.9515 from $1.9525 late Thursday. But in New York, the pound rose $1.9590 from $1.9450. Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with Thursday's late prices, included: 1.2605 Swiss francs, down from 1.2735; 5.0180 French francs, down from 5.0410; 1,123.75 Italian lire, down from 1,127.25; ad 1.16475 Canadian dollars, up from 1.16425. Other late dollar rates in Europe, compared with late rates Thursday, included: 1.2705 Swiss francs, down from 1.2745; 5.0420 French francs, down from 5.0525; 1.6938 Dutch guilders, down from 1.6980; 1,129.00 Italian lire, down from 1,129.75; and 1.1653 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1650. Gold fell in New York, closing at $376.40 a troy ounce, down $5.10, on the Commodity Exchange. Republic National Bank later quoted a bid of $376.25 a troy ounce, down $5.15. Gold prices fell in London to a late bid of $376.25 a troy ounce, down from $379.75 late Thursday. In Zurich, gold fell to $375.50 an ounce from $380.75 late Thursday. Earlier, in Hong Kong, gold rose 81 cents an ounce to $380.06. Silver dropped 7 cents on the Commodity Exchange, closed at $4.160 a troy ounce. Silver fell earlier in London to a late bid of $4.18 a troy ounce, down from $4.19 late Thursday.

DOC.HEAD: Fuel Prices Widen Pan Am's Loss
DOC.TEXT: Pan Am Corp. said Friday its third quarter losses increased by 62 percent, reflecting sharply higher fuel costs brought on by the Persian Gulf crisis. The ailing airline reported Friday that it lost $29.1 million, or 19 cents per share, for the quarter, compared with a loss a year earlier of $18 million, or 12 cents a share. Observers were not surprised to see the loss at Pan Am, which recently announced the sale of prized London routes to UAL Corp. in what is viewed as a bid to raise cash to buy time through the sluggish winter travel season. ``It's not too hopeful, and that's supposed to be their best quarter. I mean, that's when people travel overseas,'' said analyst Raymond E. Neidl, with Dillon Read & Co Inc. The skyrocketing costs of jet fuel ``killed any chance they had of making any profit in the quarter,'' Neidl said. Pan Am's earnings statement said jet fuel costs averaged 77.2 cents a gallon in the quarter, compared with 60.3 cents a year earlier. Iraq's invasion of Kuwait on Aug. 2 sent all fuel prices soaring, and airlines complain that jet fuel rose even higher than other fuels. Pan Am said that for the first nine months of the year, it lost $268.8 million, compared with a $273.9 million loss for the same period in 1989. The company's main subsidiary, Pan American World Airways, reported a loss of $29.2 million for the third quarter, compared with a loss of $29.1 million a year earlier. Pan Am said revenues increased by 13.1 percent, to $1.154 billion from $1.020 billion, for the highest total in company history, Pan Am also pointed out that its scheduled passenger traffic was up 6.7 percent, its load factor was up from 71.7 percent to 73.4 percent and revenue passenger yield rose 8 percent. ``Our improvement in these key areas is very encouraging, and gives us renewed confidence that our marketing, scheduling and service strategies are working,'' chairman and chief executive Thomas G. Plaskett said. ``But the dramatically escalating price of fuel, as well as expense increases in virtually all other areas, offset the positive effect these improvements might have had on our financial performances in the quarter.'' The corporation's bottom line also was eroded by $40.5 million in interest costs and a $9 million loss through foreign exchange transactions.

DOC.HEAD: Unemployment Rate Holds At 5.7 Percent Despite Big Job Losses
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 12th graf, Many expect, to CORRECT reference to Friday and show layoffs announced over past week. Also moving on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: America's unemployment rate held at 5.7 percent in October after rising for three straight months, but big new job losses still cut across the U.S. economy, the government said Friday. For the third month in a row, more industries lost jobs than gained them, the Labor Department said in a report analysts took as new evidence a recession is taking hold. Dramatic falloffs in construction and manufacturing jobs pushed non-farm payrolls down by 70,000, the agency said. The jobless rate held steady rather than rising again only because the labor force, which had been growing slowly, shrank by 183,000 workers in October. Students' return to school probably explained much of that drop, economists said. ``This is strong evidence that the economy really has lost its footing now and slipped into recession,'' said Robert Dederick, chief economist at the Northern Trust Co. of Chicago. The numbers ``point to a worsening employment picture ... the employment situation continued to deteriorate in October,'' said Janet Norwood, commissioner of the Bureau of Labor Statistics. ``It clearly shows a downturn ... I think you'd have to be pretty starry eyed to think otherwise,'' said Peter Radford of National Westminster Bancorp in New York. In other discouraging news Friday, the Commerce Department said its Index of Leading Economic Indicators dropped 0.8 percent in September for its second straight decline. Three consecutive drops in that index are generally considered a sign that a recession is imminent. Before October, the nation's unemployment rate had risen three months in a row, increasing half a percentage point from June's 5.2 percent rate. Analysts have expected the nation's jobs outlook to continue to darken, partly because of the turmoil in the Persian Gulf. The oil price shock and the threat of war have left American businessmen skittish about adding employees, analysts said. ``They buttoned up the overcoat, put on the scarf and the galoshes, too. Businessmen really are preparing for the worst,'' Dederick said. In addition, analysts add that the economy had shown little sign of life even before Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait. Many expect the jobless rate to continue climbing in coming months, possibly up to as much as 6.5 percent by next summer. Just in the past week, several major corporations announced large-scale job layoffs, including General Motors' plan to idle 27,000 workers. The nation's 70,000-job loss in October followed a September payroll decline of 52,000 jobs, the government said. A year ago, the economy was producing nearly 200,000 new jobs a month. Construction lost 80,000 jobs last month to reflect a continued deterioration in the housing market. Over the past five months, that industry has seen jobs tumble by 185,000 and its unemployment rate surge from 9.7 percent to 13.2 percent, the government said. In manufacturing, payrolls fell by 60,000 in October as that sector continued on an 18-month downward spiral. Since reaching a post recession peak in January 1989, the manufacturing sector has lost 580,000 jobs, the government said. In another sign of weakness, the average work week for private businesses fell to 34.2 hours from 34.7 in September. That half-hour drop was the largest decline since the 1981-82 recession, when the work week dropped six-tenths of an hour in January 1982, from 35.0 hours to 34.4 hours. The average manufacturing work week was down, too, registering at 40.8 hours in October, compared to the 41.1 hours in September. ``We got a double hit - we lost workers and in addition we lost average hours worked. This is consistent with the forecast that output is falling,'' said Laurence H. Meyer, who heads a St. Louis economic forecasting firm. The service-producing sector added 74,000 jobs. But within the sector, retail trade lost 48,000 jobs and wholesale trade lost 11,000 jobs. Job cutbacks in department stores have totaled about 80,000 since May 1989, the government said. Most of the service sector growth came from health services, which continued to show robust job growth, adding 60,000 new jobs last month. Labor costs were unchanged, as the average hourly worker made $10.13 an hour in October, just as in September. Overall, total civilian employment was about 117.7 million in October while the jobless numbered just over 7 million. In a separate calculation of unemployment that counts members of the armed services stationed in the United States, the October jobless rate was 5.6 percent, unchanged from September.

DOC.HEAD: Mortgage Rates Down This Week
DOC.TEXT: Fixed-rate mortgages averaged 10.13 percent this week, down from 10.17 percent last week, according to a national survey released Friday by the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corp. On one-year adjustable rate mortgages, lenders were asking an average initial rate of 8.15 percent, down from 8.17 percent last week. The rates do not include add-on fees known as points.

$adv04
For release weekend editions Nov. 3-4
DOC.HEAD: UNDATED: years,'' he said.
DOC.TEXT: Here are some weekly commodity price trends: Grain futures prices rose on the Chicago Board of Trade but soybeans retreated. Wheat for delivery in December settled Friday at $2.65\ a bushel, up from $2.62\ a week earlier; December corn rose to $2.30\ a bushel from $2.27}; December oats rose to $1.21{ a bushel from $1.20; November soybeans dropped to $5.92{ a bushel from $5.94}. Livestock and meat futures had a mixed week on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange. December live retreated to 77.10 cents a pound from 77.87 cents; November feeder cattle rose to 87.22 cents a pound from 87.17 cents; December hogs dropped to 52.75 cents a pound from 52.95 cents; February frozen pork bellies rose to 64.45 cents a pound from 62.95 cents. Gold and silver futures rose on New York's Commodity Exchange, ending a five-week decline in silver and a four-week drop in gold. December gold climbed to $377.80 a troy ounce from $373.20; December silver rallied to $4.185 a troy ounce from $4.07. Crude oil and gasoline futures advanced on the New York Mercantile Exchange but heating oil retreated for the third straight week. Light sweet crude oil for December delivery rose to $34 a barrel from $33.01; wholesale December heating oil fell to 87.42 cents a gallon from 89.25 cents; wholesale December unleaded gasoline rose to 89.21 cents a gallon from 85.98 cents.

DOC.HEAD: Bond Prices Ease
DOC.TEXT: Bond prices fell slightly in volatile trading Friday as conflicting economic forces turned the market into a buy-sell rollercoaster. The Treasury's bellwether 30-year bond fell 5-32 point, or about $1.56 per $1,000 in face amount. Its yield, which rises when prices fall, advanced to 8.70 percent from 8.68 percent late Thursday. The small price change ``camouflages some fairly active trading and large volatility today,''said Scott Winningham, market analyst at Stone & McCarthy Research Associates. Bond traders said things got off to a turbulent start with a flurry of speculative buying just before the Labor Department released its monthly employment report early in the day. The department said the unemployment rate held steady at 5.7 percent in October, but it also reported that dramatic declines in construction and manufacturing jobs pushed non-farm payrolls down by 70,000. Analysts said the report - which signaled a further weakening of the economy - met the market's expectations, and traders began to sell off their holdings to cash in on the earlier gains. The government also said Friday that its gauge of future economic health dropped 0.8 percent in September, the second straight big decline and the third month without improvement. Bond prices usually rise on negative economic news. When the economy is on a downturn, the Federal Reserve is considered more likely to nudge interest rates lower. But prices were held down by investors worried about next week's scheduled Treasury refunding auction. Traders were concerned that the sale of $34.25 billion in bonds could create an oversupply of government securities. Bonds did get some support from a decline in oil prices. Light, sweet crude, the benchmark grade of U.S. oil fell $1.17 a barrel to $34.00 on the New York Mercantile Exchange, alleviating some concerns about inflation. Inflation is an anathema to the bond market because it erodes the value of fixed-income securities and puts pressure on the Fed to keep interest rates high. In the secondary market for Treasury bonds, short-term maturities were unchanged to 3-32 point lower, intermediate maturities fell 5-32 point to 3-16 point and long-term issues ranged from 5-32 point lower to [ point higher, the Telerate Inc. financial information service reported. The movement of a point is equivalent to a change of $10 in the price of a bond with a $1,000 face value. The Shearson Lehman Brothers Daily Treasury Bond Index, which measures price movements on all outstanding Treasury issues with maturities of a year or longer, fell 0.44 to 1,160.86. Yields on three-month Treasury bills rose to 7.30 percent as the discount rose 3 basis points to 7.08 percent. Yields on six-month bills rose to 7.39 percent as the discount rose 2 basis points to 7.04 percent. Yields on one-year bills rose to 7.33 percent as the discount rose 3 basis points to 6.87 percent. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point. The yield is the annualized return on an investment in a Treasury bill. The discount is the percentage that bills are selling below the face value, which is paid at maturity. The federal funds rate, the interest on overnight loans between banks, traded at 7~ percent, down from 7 15-16 late Thursday. In the tax-exempt market, the Bond Buyer index of 40 actively traded municipal bonds rose 3-32 point to 89 19-32. The average yield to maturity fell to 7.66 percent from 7.67 percent late Thursday.

The government's gauge of future economic health dropped 0.8 percent in September, the second straight big decline and the third month without improvement, the Commerce Department said. Many analysts responded to the Friday report by saying a national recession not only had arrived but was intensifying. The Bush administration contends the economy is growing and will continue to do so at least into the new year, but the question for many private analysts instead is how long and severe the contraction will be. --- WASHINGTON (AP) - America's unemployment rate held at 5.7 percent in October after rising for three straight months, but big new job losses still cut across the U.S. economy, the government said. For the third month in a row, more industries lost jobs than gained them, the Labor Department said Friday in a report analysts took as new evidence a recession is taking hold. --- WASHINGTON (AP) - The Resolution Trust Corp. announced it is putting up for sale 18 failed savings institutions, including Lincoln Savings and Loan Association, considered to be the costliest collapsed thrift ever. The failure of Lincoln, formerly owned by Charles Keating Jr., is costing taxpayers an estimated $2 billion. Keating faces numerous civil and criminal charges. The RTC, the federal agency responsible for disposing of hundreds of failed S&Ls, said Friday it is accepting bids from potential buyers for the 18 institutions. --- NEW YORK (AP) - Pan Am Corp. said its third-quarter losses increased by 62 percent, reflecting sharply higher fuel costs brought on by the Persian Gulf crisis. The ailing airline reported Friday it lost $29.1 million, or 19 cents per share, for the quarter, compared with a loss a year earlier of $18 million, or 12 cents a share. --- DETROIT (AP) - The shaky economy caused Chrysler Corp. and Fiat SpA to call off months of talks about possible joint ventures or other business arrangements, the No. 3 U.S. automaker and the Italian company said. ``Uncertainties in the global economy, rising oil prices brought on by the crisis in the Gulf, the slowdown in sales in both the U.S. and European automotive markets and the overall deterioration in worldwide business conditions created overwhelming obstacles,'' Chrysler Chairman Lee Iacocca said Friday. --- NEW YORK (AP) - Fast-food giant McDonald Corp.'s decision to abandon foam packages won't put much of a dent in the plastics industry, but it symbolizes America's growing discomfort with the throw-away image and could prompt other businesses to shun the material. The containers for Big Macs, Quarter Pounders and other sandwiches served at McDonald's 8,000 restaurants nationwide account for less than 1 percent of the $5 billion-plus market for polystyrene, says the Society of the Plastics Industry, a Washington trade group. The immediate impact will be felt by McDonald's suppliers. --- PARIS (AP) - The bottlers of bubbly Perrier water reported that net profits more than doubled in the first half of 1990 despite a worldwide recall after dangerous chemicals turned up in some samples. The profit increase came mostly from the sale of the group's soft-drink operations, Source Perrier SA said Friday. First-half volume sales of the popular mineral water were down 14 percent from 1989 and revenue slipped 3 percent due to the recall and delays in restocking the beverage, Source Perrier said. ---

The stock market rolled up a broad gain Friday, bolstered by expectations of help from the Federal Reserve toward lower interest rates. The Dow Jones industrial average climbed 35.89 to 2,490.84, finishing the week with a gain of 54.70 points. Oil prices dropped, precious metals fell sharply, livestock and meat futures were mixed, and grains and soybeans were mixed. The dollar fell, as did gold. Bonds also declined.

DOC.HEAD: EDS and Continental Cancel Reservations System Deal
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 2nd graf to CORRECT that no assets have been sold; INSERTS one graf after the 3rd graf with Continental saying the collapse of the deal will have no effect on current situation; SUBS 13th graf to remove now-redundant first reference to Kent; picks up 14th graf, Neither Still ...
DOC.TEXT: Electronic Data Systems on Friday canceled a multibillion-dollar deal with Continental Airlines for half the airline's reservations system. The action is a blow to beleaguered Continental, which has been trying to raise cash. The Houston-based carrier last week mulled a bankruptcy declaration but instead decided to try to sell some assets. The reservation system, called System One, is one of Continental's most prized assets and would have yielded an estimated $4 billion from the EDS deal over 10 years. Continental spokesman Art Kent said the collapse of the deal would have no effect on the company's immediate situation. Money from the transaction was to have been placed in escrow for disbursement when the bankruptcy of Continental's sister carrier, Eastern Airlines, was resolved, he said. EDS and Continental attributed the cancellation to the upheaval in the airline industry caused by higher jet fuel prices. The increase has cut into airline profits and forced carriers to raise ticket prices. ``It's not a positive impact and was one of a number of factors that, over time, led us to believe we should not go forward with this transaction,'' said Roger Still, a spokesman for Dallas-based EDS, the computer services subsidiary of General Motors Corp. ``If you're going to enter into a fairly complicated deal, anything that has a financial impact on one of the partners has an impact on the entire deal,'' Still said. Continental president Hollis Harris said this week that the company paid $70 million more in October for jet fuel than it did in July, just before Iraq invaded Kuwait and triggered a sharp increase in oil prices. The carrier uses 3.5 million gallons of jet fuel a day. Continental, the most actively traded issue on the American Stock Exchange, lost 50 cents on Friday to close at $2.62{ per share. General Motors Class E stock, which represents its share in EDS, slipped 12{ cents to close at $33.37{ per share on the New York Stock Exchange. Both companies said discussions would continue on other marketing and management ventures involving System One. The agreement, first made in February and signed in September, would have made EDS the first non-airline company to participate in an airline reservations system. The deal created two partnerships. The first involved the reservations system itself and the second involved technological services System One provides to other airlines and travel-related customers. Kent said Friday's action was a postponement ``of the full breadth of the working relationship'' between the two companies. ``EDS has great knowledge and technology to bring to what System One does,'' Kent said. Neither Still nor Kent had specific details on how the canceled deal may be reformed. Airline analyst Bob Bernstein, of the Edward D. Jones & Co. investment firm in St. Louis, said the cancellation was a disappointment for Continental. ``This was a way of gathering some cash to possibly tide them over a weak airline traffic situation that appears to be coming with the higher ticket prices,'' Bernstein said. Continental's financial problems may force the company to lay off some workers, Harris said during a speech to Houston leaders Wednesday. The carrier is already negotiating the sale of its Houston airline food service operation, Chelsea Catering. It also may sell a lucrative Honolulu-Tokyo route to Air Micronesia. The carrier has only had the route for six months. It begins in Houston and is the only one from Texas' largest city to Japan.

DOC.HEAD: State Street Agrees To Sell Its Credit Card Portfolio
DOC.TEXT: State Street Bank and Trust Co. has agreed to sell its $425 million credit card loans portfolio to an unnamed buyer, the company announced Friday. ``We believe the time is right to exit the highly competitive credit card business and consider the premium we were offered attractive,'' said Peter Madden, president of State Street, a wholly-owned subsidiary of State Street Boston Corp. The sale was expected to be completed in January 1991, said David Spina, a spokesman for State Street. He said the anticipated pre-tax gain from the sale was $60 million. ``We have agreed with the buyer that we are not going to reveal its identity until after its board approves the sale,'' said Spina. Madden, in a written statement, said State Street was only receiving a small profit from the portfolio and decided to unload it to one of the large players. State Street has more than $800 billion in assets. It provides securities processing and record-keeping services for mutual funds and pension funds.
